column2: The performance of Gluck's "Orfeo ed Euridice" at the Metropolitan Opera on Sept. 25 will raise money for the company's production fund. The benefit was arranged by the Metropolitan Opera Guild, which still has tickets from $10 to $50 available at its office at 1865 Broadway.

BUFFALO, Sept. 10 Arthur J. Goldberg, the Democratic gubernatorial candidate, told state employes here today that if he was elected, "the Taylor Law will be replaced by a law that mandates genuine collective bargaining for government employes."

In a suit filed yesterday on behalf of all prisoners of the Manhattan House of Detention, the Legal Aid Society asked for a Federal Court order to shut down the overcrowded facility, known as the Tombs, "until such time as it can be made safe, sanitary, and decent for its inmates."

TORONTO, Sept. 10 Eight American states and three Canadian provinces called on Washington and Ottawa today to give the International Joint Commission new powers to help combat air and water pollution in the Great Lakes region.

Seagrams Distillers, eager to move its five-year-old 100 Pipers Scotch brand line into the best-seller list, is about to start a new advertising campaign through its new agency and adopt a new marketing stance as well.
DETROIT, Sept. 10 The further dissolution of the group of banks led by Donald H. Parsons, who resigned a month ago as chairman of the Bank of the Commonwealth here, was disclosed today.

MANSFIELD, Pa., Sept. 10 (UPI) Tom McMillen, 6-feet-11inches tall, considered the top prize in the country's college basketball recruiting scramble, decided today to attend the University of Maryland instead of the University of North Carolina.
Benjamin Altman, the city's Commissioner of Rent and Housing Maintenance, said yesterday that he had asked the Corporation Counsel to investigate rumors that fuel oil companies were rigging prices.
BETHESDA, Md., Sept.10 The streetcar was named Desire in honor of the trolley that still goes by Representative Hale Boggs's home in New Orleans.
A contingent of Federal armed guards wilt begin flying on international flights of United States airlines starting tomorrow, according to highly placed sources here and in Washington.

Dr. Samuel Shenkman, former chief of neurosurgery at Harlem and Sydenham Hospitals, died Wednesday night in Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 870 United Nations Plaza and in Weston, Conn. His office was at 135 East 83d Street.

MONTPELIER, Vt., Sept. 10 (AP) An economist warned today that unless the Vermont Yankee Nuclear Power Corporation, state regulatory agencies and environmentalists settled their differences over Vermont Yankee's $130-million atomic power plant in Vernon, the outlook for the plant was grim.
NEWARK, Sept. 10 (AP) The New Jersey National Guard has been called in to help remove more than 800 abandoned cars from the streets here.

TRENTON, Sept. 10 John V. Kenny, the powerful democratic leader of Hudson County, and nine other leading Democratic party officials testified for nearly six hours today before the statewide grand jury that is investigating corruption and organized crime in New Jersey.
Semantics complicated the return of Muhammad Ali to boxing yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 10 Secretary General Thant criticized Israel today for having ignored two appeals he had made for the release of two Algerian officials arrested during a stopover at Lydda Airport Aug. 14.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 10 The Rev. Dr. Joseph H. Jackson, spiritual leader of more than 6 million black churchgoers and the chief spokesman for Negro conservatism, said today that he favored polarization but only on the basis of character, not color.

There is nothing primitive about the 250 photographs in "French Primitive Photography," a new exhibition at the Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street, except from a strictly technical point of view having to do with the types of lenses, sensitized emulsions, and the like, that were in use between 1820 and 1865, the limiting dates of the show.

Three treaties involving the future of the Panama Canal, which required three years of painstaking negotiations to produce and represented major concessions by the United States, have been formally rejected by Panama. Whatever lame explanations the Panamanians put forward, it is clear that the rejection is due much more to the domestic political needs and desires of Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera's Government than to the content of the treaties.

Sixteen states have formally designated mercury pollution a hazard to public health by actions ranging from banning of fishing in certain waters to cautioning the public about eating questionable fish or game birds too frequently. In some cases initial stringent restrictions have been reduced.

MOSCOW, Sept. 10 Novosti, the Soviet Union's press and information agency, announced today the retirement of Boris S. Burkov, who guided the agency since its formation in 1961 into one of the world's largest operations of its kind.

Red flags have been known to enrage bulls. They also have been known to produce wrathful indignation among top-ranking tennis players. But when a red flag suddenly sprouts atop an umpire's stilted chair during the United States Open tennis championships at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, the fans come running in joyous anticipation.
In a highly unusual move, Texaco, Inc., recalled from retirement its former chairman, Augustus C. Long, to take over the company's management.

The airline industry faced the strong possibility yesterday that the cost of insurance coverage against damage caused by politically-motivated hijackers might go up by as much as 100 per cent or become completly unavailable.

AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 10 Jordanian troops and Arab commandos battled for hours in Amman today while negotiators of the International Committee of the Red Cross met with commando leaders to seek freedom for 300 hijacked hostages.

DEERFIELD, Mass., Sept. 10 Mr. and Mrs. Arthur S. Williams Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Fox Williams, to Richard Henry Saunders 3d. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Saunders Jr. of Grafton.
Bronx Borough President Robert Abrams yesterday assailed the idea of having a 2,500-foot mountain of compacted garbage in Pelham Bay Park swampland as an unthinkable "Matterhorn of muck."

BOSTON, Sept. 10 The F.W. Woolworth Company, the originator of the 5-and10-cent store, will come, full circle here tomorrow. It will open its largest and potentially most profitable store in downtown Boston, where the retail giants are already jostling one another on major traffic arteries. Woolworth's nationwide chain has about 5,000 stores.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 Senator Edward M. Kennedy told a three-judge Federal District Court today that Congress responded to an "invitation" from the Supreme Court when it passed the statute that lowered the voting age to 18 years.
ALBANY, Sept. 10 Governor Rockefeller today announced the awarding of grants of more than $7-million to 134 cultural organizations throughout the state.
The Pittsburgh pitching staff is a much maligned group of players, very often deservedly so.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UPI) The Federal Home Loan Bank Board today announced a new mortgage purchase procedure intended to stabilize interest rates and increase the available funds for home loans.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) Support by the Nixon Administration for repeal of the Emergency Detention Act was criticized today by two members of the house Internal Security Committee.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 10 Premier Golda Meir strongly indicated today that Israel had no intention of releasing any of the Arab guerrilla prisoners now held captive.
FONTANA, Wis., Sept. 10 (AP) A Latin-American scientist attacked "scientific fashion" today and said it often resulted in the wdong kind of research in underdeveloped countries.
The London stock market finished mixed yesterday in light trading.
Heavy profit taking sent prices of wheat futures down yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. The loss was offset somewhat, however, by good commercial support, generated by large export sales.
KITCHENER, Ont., Sept. 10 Still wearing their summer tans, the New York Rangers opened training camp today for their longest National Hockey League season.

ALBANY, Sept. 10 Governor Rockefeller announced today plans for the demolition of the vacant Ten Eyck Hotel and buildings on three adjacent blocks in downtown Albany to make way for a new hoteloffice building-garage complex and for a new bus terminal.

Miss Ingrid Digby Matsner, an editor at Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, Inc., was married here yesterday afternoon to Arthur William Einstein Jr., a partner in the New York advertising firm of Lord, Geller, Federico Partners.
Alabama Diamond Shamrock Corporation, Muscle Shoals; discharge reduced; trial date pending.

The Iron Ore Company of Canada, Ltd., a joint venture of United States and Canadian mining and steel concerns, said yesterday it would spend about $270-million in United States funds to enlarge and improve an iron-ore complex that straddles the Quebec-Labrador boundary.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 10 In his 13 seasons as head football coach at Harvard, John Yovicsin brought the Crimson back to respectability, even moments of glory. Under Yovicsin, Harvard shared three Ivy League championships and completed an undefeated campaign in 1968 by tieing Yale in that memorable 29-29 finale.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UPI) The Senate approved a pay rise today for 850,000 blue collar Government workers.
MOBILE, Ala., Sept. 10 (AP) A pushing, shirt-pulling brawl erupted today between groups of white and Negro youths in the Murphy High School campus.
FRANKFURT, West Germany Sept. 10 (Reuters) West Germany's monetary reserves rose by 630-million marks to 37,719-billion marks in the week ended Sept. 7, the central bank said today.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 10 Mercury pollution, which suddenly emerged as a new environmental problem six months ago to worry officials, industry and the public, has proved a far more widespread hazard than was expected.

Old demagogues like old prizefighters keep coming back for more. When Orval Faubus retired in 1966 after six terms as Governor of Arkansas, most Americans were more than content to see and hear the last of him, but there was no way of telling for certain whether his fellow Arkansans shared that view. On Tuesday evening he found out that they do.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10 (UPI) A judge today ordered the city's 275 public schools reopened tomorrow but then agreed to postpone the effective date of his injunction pending a hearing Monday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) Senator Mark O. Hatfield, Republican of Oregon, said today that, for family and economic reasons, he might not seek re-election in 1972.

Everything about this advertisement could be true, but there is a catch. The townhouse's address is 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, which happens to be the site of the Whitney Museum of American Art.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 10 United States District Judge William T. Sweigert issued today a memorandum decision urging the Supreme Court to rule on the legality of the Vietnam war.

The Lorillard Corporation is moving True cigarettes from Foote, Cone Belding to Lennen Newell because F.C. has Kent and the new management doesn't want brands in the same competitive category in the same agency.

ORADELL, N.J., Sept. 10 John T. Duffy, a circulation sales representative for The New York Times, who had worked for The Times 50 years, died today at his home after a long illness. He was 64 years old and lived at 479 Bergen Boulevard.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 10 Two leading Thai officials have declared that their Government will not send troops to Cambodia. This decision also covers the 3,000 ethnic Cambodians who have been in combat training since July 2, they said:

CLEVELAND, Sept. 10 Mrs. Grace Chapman Rose, who with her late husband, Henry Nelson Rose, had been active in the oil, coal and molding sand business, died Aug. 28. She was 93 years old, and formerly lived in Columbus, Ohio.

LONDON, Sept. 10 This is the time of the year when Broadway and West End producers are flying backward and forward like swallows or even larger birds. The one thought in their nobly avian minds is whether this Broadway hit might prove too American for London audiences, or that West End hit too English for the Americans.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 10 Loretta Luckes, the 23-year-old Black Panther apprentice who has testified for the state in the Alex Rackley torture-murder case, was given a suspended 25-year prison sentence today.
The Eighth New York Film Festival opened yesterday at Lincoln Center in a 13-hour whirl of sometimes overlapping events in which 17 films were shown.
GENEVA, Sept. 10 (Reuters) A DC-6 airliner loaded with supplies for use by the nearly 300 airline hostages held in the Jordanian desert by Palestinian commandos left Amman early today.

Myron Arms Wick, retired vice president in charge of finance and a former director of the Republic Steel Corporation, died Monday in Baden-Baden, Germany, while on a visit. He was 87 years old and lived at 655 Park Avenue.
A $10.5-million engineering building that looks like a well-fortified honeycomb was dedicated yesterday on New York University's Bronx campus.
Randy Newman is a young song writer from Los Angeles, and rather special.

DENVER, Sept. 10 (UPI) Representative Byron Rogers, a 20-year member of Congress, and Craig Barnes, a Denver lawyer who ran as a peace candidate, may have to wait 10 days before getting final word as to who won the Democratic primary Tuesday in Colorado's First Congresstional District.

SIEGEN, West Germany, Sept. 10 The United States team scored a second victory in the 19th Chess Olympiad at Siegerand Hall here last night when it defeated the Virgin Islands, 3-0, with one game adjourned in the fifth preliminary round. Thus, the Americans have posted 17 points out of a possible 20, with one game adjourned.
TOKYO, Sept. 10 (Reuters) Japan today offered a package of trade and economic concessions designed to offset criticism from its main trading partners and its economic aid clients.
Phil Jackson bent over and touched his toes with ease, straightened up and smiled.

DETROIT, Sept. 10 Leonard Woodcock, the president of the United Automobile Workers, said today that one automobile company had decided to take a strike rather than make a contract offer that could lead to a settlement.

A 27-year-old woman, who was taken from her parents when she was a year old and placed in a foster home because she was a neglected child, pleaded guilty with her husband yesterday in the Bronx to criminally negligent homicide in the starvation death of one of their four children.

Following, as issued by Trans World Airlines, is a revised list of passengers aboard its jetliner hijacked to Amman, Jordan, on Sunday. Asterisk indicates that a passenger has previously been identified as one of the hostages moved from the plane to a hotel in Amman.

ROWAYTON, Conn., Sept. 10 Miss Virginia Wilmer Scott and John Charles Devlin Jr. of New Canaan were married this afternoon in the garden of the bride's parents' home by the Rev. Donald Emig, pastor of the United Church of Rowayton.
"Sudden death" trapped Arthur Ashe yesterday in the United States Open tennis championship, but Cliff Richey rolled on as the tournament were being played on a clay court.

Southern University and North Carolina A. and T. will be quite serious when they meet in the third annual Invitation Football Classic at Yankee Stadium tonight, but there will be plenty of fun and frolic before and after the game.
EDINBURGH, Scotland, Sept. 8 In cellars and small shops the young men and women write pamphlets through the night to send to towns in the highlands and villages along the barren northern coast.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission suspended today the broker-dealer registration of Richard L. Kamen, a Chicago stockbroker, for 30 days beginning next Monday.

ATHENS, Sept. 10 G. Warren Nutter, the United States Defense Department's assistant secretary for international security affairs, arrived here today from Turkey with a large party of military and civilian aides for talks with Premier George Papadopoulos and other leaders.
CASPER, Wyo., Sept. 10 Vice President Agnew, appealing to "the workingmen of the country" to give President Nixon a Republican Congress, lashed out today at the Democrats as "radical liberals."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 The Jackson, Miss., public school system has withdrawn 800 textbooks it had transferred to a new "segregation academy," apparently averting the loss of a $1.3-million Federal grant for easing desegregation.

ATLANTA, Sept. 10 V.O. Key, the eminent, political scientist, concluded 25 years ago that Southern politics was essentially a politics of personality, conducted within narrow ideological boundaries. That ...

Welcome home, Pat." These were the words with which Mayor Lindsay opened yesterday's press conference at City Hall to announce his selection of Detroit's Commissioner of Police, Patrick V. Murphy, to succeed Howard R. Leary as New York City's Police Commissioner. The words go beyond the formality of a greeting.
The Interstate Commerce Commission decided yesterday to delay further action on the merger request of the Norfolk Western and Chesapeake Ohio Railways by at least six months.

During the week of the SixDay War in 1967, a high Soviet official had a conversation with a Western diplomat in Moscow. "What a disaster," he said. "We thought Israel would be in trouble, and the United States would be drawn into a war against the whole Moslem world. We thought it would be worse for America than Vietnam.
Leo Lefkowitz, brother of State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, died yesterday in Albert Einstein Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 1430 Parkchaster Road, the Bronx.
SAN DIEGO, Sept, 11 Vice President Agnew broadened his attack on liberal politicians today to include members of his own party.

TEL AVIV, Sept. 11 Reliable sources said today that Israel had informed the International Committee of the Red Cross that she was ready "in principle" to release some Arab guerrilla prisoners in return for all the hostages held by Arab hijackers in Jordan and for certain other Israeli prisoners of war.

OLNEY, Ill. George E. Shipley is a 43-year-old, ex-marine who traded his restaurant in this dusty oil town a dozen years ago for a seat as a Democrat in the House of Representatives on the strength of a public career of four years as the sheriff of Richland County.

Residents of Mill Basin in Brooklyn manned homemade barricades against street traffic yesterday as the nearby Kings Plaza shopping center opened officially, drawing tens of thousands of shoppers and curiosity seekers.

The reported decline of foreign language studies in the nation's high schools raises the specter of a dismal chapter in American education history repeating itself. In the late 1920's, many educators dismissed foreign languages, along with mathematics and science, as irrelevant frills. The illusory politics of isolationism made it easy to deride the skills needed to communicate with foreign people and cultures.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 11 "Hey, honey, what is your name?" the 22-yearold lieutenant asked his Vietnamese fiancee at the United States Consulate here, where they were applying for a marriage affidavit. The girl giggled. In wiggly letters she carefully wrote her name: Nguyen Thi Le. The lieutenant, looking surprised, tried to pronounce it but gave up.
Patrick V. Murphy, who once pounded a police beat in the tough Red Hook section of Brooklyn, was named by Mayor Lindsay yesterday to head the city's 32,000-man police force.

Two New York City patrolmen were arrested in Brooklyn yesterday after they allegedly demanded and received a $10 bribe at an East Flatbush construction site, Robert K. Ruskin, the city's Commissioner of Investigation, said last night.

The New York Mets had a chance to take sole possession of first place in the National League's East last night before Mayor Lindsay and 50,555 other persons in Shea Stadium. But they were blocked at the threshold chiefly by one man Bob Gibson of the St. Louis Cardinals.

AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 11 Jack Nicklaus, Billy Casper, Tony Jacklin and Dave Stockton played in a rehearsal of how to win $50,000 in two rounds of golf. Because each is a winner of one of the world's four major championships, the four professionals are here for the World Series of golf, a special two-day event tomorrow and Sunday at the Firestone Country Club.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 11 (UPI) Charles D. Watson, a central figure in the Sharon Tate murder case, arrived tonight in Los Angeles under heavy police guard and was immediately booked on seven counts of murder and one of conspiracy.

PARIS, Sept. 11 France and the Soviet Union today signed an agreement for French participation in construction of a truck plant to rank among the world's largest, on the Kama River, a tributary of the Volga, in central Russia.

The city Corporation Counsel's office was asked yesterday to start a court test of the constitutionality of the war in Southeast Asia on behalf of two soldiers from New York City, one stationed near Saigon, South Vietnam, and the other under orders to go to Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 Foreign diplomats and some American officials said today that the chances of a peace settlement in the Middle East were gravely compromised by the stalemate over reported violations of the Suez Canal ceasefire.

GLEN HEAD, L. I., Sept. 11 Miss Elise Burns Bradley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Bradley Jr., was mairied today to William M. Duryea Jr. of Locust Valley, a member of the New York Stock Exchange and a partner in H. Hentz Co., stockbrokers in New York.

TOKYO, Sept. 11 The Toyota Motor Company has announced that it was negotiating a technical tie-up with Texas Instruments, Inc., a leading American electronics company as part of its program to produce a pollution-free car. The program requires miniaturization of many parts, so there is a need for sophisticated electronic equipment.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 11 (UPI) Joe Moore ran for 171 yards, scored on a 16-yard touchdown sprint and connected with Mel Gray on a 72-yard touchdown pass in three quarters of action to lead Missouri to a 38-0 victory over Baylor tonight.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Sept. 11 (UPI) Frank Tedesco of Jersey City, N. J., a bus line principal, and two of his company's employes were held today for grand jury action in connection with the deaths of seven Long Island school children in a bus crash last July 15.
Kennedy International Airport set a new four-day record for inbound international travelers over the four-day Labor Day weekend.
The eagerly awaited Agriculture Department crop estimate came out yesterday but after the close of trading on the Chicago Board of Trade with the result that it had little effect on futures prices.
Dr. James C. Whitaker, visiting surgeon and member of the medical board at Harlem Hospital Center, died at the hospital Thursday. He was 72 years old and lived at 173 Underhill Street, Yonkers.
Eighty-eight hijacked passengers were flown out of Amman yesterday and early today, but the status of negotiations to free 300 other passengers held by Arab commandos remained unclear.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 A virulent plant disease and a mild drought have combined to reduce the nation's corn crop by more than 400 million bushels, or almost 9 per cent less than early summer predictions, the Agriculture. Department estimated today.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Sept. 10 (Reuters) Bolivia will pay the United States-owned Gulf Oil Corporation $78,622,171 as compensation for the nationalization last October of its Bolivian subsidiary, President Alfredo Ovando Candia announced today.

The National Biscuit Company announced yesterday that all of its cracker, cookie and snack products made with wheat flour are now being enriched with vitamins B-1, B-2, niacin and iron. Some 230 of the company's 300 products are affected by the enrichment program.

His hair is gray and thinning. His build is slight, almost frail. His voice is soft, his language scholarly. He does not fit the stereotype of the tough, burly Irish-Catholic cop from the streets of New York, but he is the son of a policeman and the brother of two more.
How many Wall Street firms are slated for the scrap heap?

Bowing to an order from authorities at the Board of Education, a reluctant community school board in northern Queens agreed yesterday to accept at least 45 black and Puerto Rican students from Brooklyn.

EASTON, Md., Sept. 11 Rollin Browne, a widely known New York tax lawyer, died today after a brief illness at his summer home here, where he had been vacationing. He was 74 years old and lived at 755 Park Avenue in New York City.
LONDON, Sept. 11 Pilots on European airlines began canceling flights to Israel today because of new fears about possible hijackings.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 11 The arrival of 25 United States Phantom jets at an American air base in Turkey and rumors in Beirut of movements in the eastern Mediterranean by the United States Sixth Fleet fueled today Palestinian guer-... rilla charges that Western powers were planning military intervention in Jordan.

SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 11 (UPI) Bobby Howfield of Denver, a soccer-style kicker, booted a 52-yard field goal with 48 seconds left tonight as the Broncos edged the Boston Patriots, 16-14, in a national football league preseason game at the University of Utah.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said yesterday that it had eliminated extra charges on certain galvanized steel products, effective Sept. 1. The change amounted to a reduction in price of about $5 a ton and was "directly responsive to a competitive situation in the market place," the company added.

GENEVA, Sept. 11 Representatives of four of the five countries most vitally concerned in the crisis over plane hijacking Switzerland, Britain, the United States and West Germany are meeting in Berne to direct the negotiations for the release of hostages.

This week's crisis in international civil aviation has finally overcome the inertia which for so long prevented nations other than Israel from mounting energetic, organized efforts to prevent aerial hijacking. The program President Nixon announced yesterday will by its very existence create strong pressure on other major nations to take similar steps.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 11 Stuart B. Rowe Jr., of the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club became the new world champion in the International One-Design Class today. In a way he led a parade of champions. All four of those who placed directly behind him in the standing had preceded him as a titleholder.
William Olden, a prominent camera dealer, died yesterday at his home, 737 Park Avenue, after a long illness. He was 61 years old.

ONEIDA, N.Y., Sept. 11 By the time David Goff, who is director of the Madison County Historical Society here, had made the last of his calls for the day, he was laden with boxes of blueberries and bags of homemade chocolate fudge and johnnycake. He'd already eaten the poppyseed cake and enjoyed the elderberry wine. All were gifts from the craftsmen he had been visiting.
BURBANK, Calif., Sept. 11 The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation said today that it had made tentative arrangements to increase its credit line by up to $250-million.

King Hussein's recent observation that Jordan is "like a minefield" vividly portrays conditions in his country today as fragmented Palestinian guerrilla groups quarrel over the fate of hijacked international air passengers and crews and over the future of Hussein's tottering government.
Only two companies felt this week that the time was right to try to sell their shares to the public for the first time, according to a weekly survey of new-issue underwriters.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) President Nixon formally approved today plans for bringing the entire nation into the celebration of its 200th anniversary in 1976 with Philadelphia as "an exciting focal point for international participation."
LONDON, Sept. 11 (Reuters) Mia Farrow, the actress, and Andre Previn, the conductor, were married yesterday in a church here.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 11 The electronic surveillance program that President Nixon ordered expanded today has been in use at New Orleans International Airport since July.

NEW ROCHELLE, Sept. 11 United States Senator Charles E. Goodell, the Republican-Liberal candidate for election to a full term, quietly toured Westchester County today the home of his Democratic opponent, Richard L. Ottinger and charged that Mr. Ottinger's "legislative record is paper thin."

Beck Industries, Inc., which has been retrenching from an acquisition spree last year, announced yesterday that it had reached agreement in principle with a group of four banks for "substantial additional credit facilities as well as the extension of maturities on the company's present bank obligations" of more than $20-million.
Almost 100 Federal agents arrived at Kennedy International Airport yesterday to begin a cram course that might be called "How to Fire a Gun Inside a Jetliner Without Shooting It Down."
Antipoverty elections scheduled for next Tuesday in the racially tense Crown Heights section of Brooklyn have been postponed for three weeks by the Council Against Poverty.

The two main dishes below, which can be prepared ahead, offer a pleasant change of pace from the usual warm-weather fare of cold and barbecued meals. The cucumber and carrot melange would go equally well with either entree. Add pilaf and a fresh fruit dessert for an impressive dinner menu.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 11 United Nations legal experts said today that Israel might have been within her legal rights when she arrested two Algerians on a British plane in transit at the Lydda airport last month.

Earnings of the Utah Construction and Mining Company rose 40.8 per cent in the third quarter, lifting profits for the nine months ended July 31 by 25.6 per cent, the company reported yesterday. The gains were attributed to expanded mining operations.
Recent discoveries on the ocean floors are leading to a comprehensive theory on how the far-flung mountain ranges of the world were formed.
Following are quotations on the police and on law enforcement from interviews at various times with Patrick V. Murphy, New York's newly designated Police Commissioner:
The London Stock Exchange closed slightly lower yesterday in quiet trading.
HARTFORD, Sept. 11 United States Senator Strom Thurmond told a national meeting of conservative youths today that the country was entering a period of guerrilla warfare.
SCRANTON, Pa. Along Scranton's south side is an escarpment the Apollo astronauts might well use for rehearsals before landing on the moon.

Robert W. Haack, president of the New York Stock Exchange, expressed confidence yesterday that the proposed new commission-rate plan under study by the Securities and Exchange Commission would be approved.

FALMOUTH, Mass., Sept. 11 (AP) A key cancer research project directed by Dr. Albert Szent-Gyorgyi, a Nobel laureate biochemist who says his experiments were at a decisive stage, has been brought to a halt by vandals.

"Thomas Hudson does not die because I asked Ernest not to kill him, to give 'the guy a chance. He did that once before he was going to have Santiago die in 'The Old Man and the Sea' and I said "no, he is too nice a man, please let him live,' " Mary Hemingway said the other day.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Sept. 11 A gathering of 54 Federal judges here was told today that they and their colleagues did too much "meddling" in state criminal cases and that public confidence in all courts was "sorely lacking."
The introduction of roundthe-clock child-care centers to serve working mothers at two Brooklyn industrial parks was announced yesterday by the Economic Development Administration.

Southern University of Baton Rouge, La., scored two touchdowns in the fourth quarter last night to defeat North Carolina A. and I., 21-6, in the third annual Invitation Football Classic at Yankee Stadium before a crowd of 25,000.

Rebuilding Panther Eleven Is Aim of Coach DePasqua PITTSBURGH, Sept. 11 Each of the four University of Pittsburgh football victories last season was a plus in the opinion of Coach Carl DePasqua, who said today, "I didn't see a year ago how we could win one game." That was when DePasqua was about to start his first season as Pitt coach.

DE KALB, Ill., Sept. 11 Ash alarm over the corn blight began to diminish today in the Middle West, the possibility emerged that farmers who were not too badly hurt might offset their reduced yields by selling their remaining corn at higher prices.

SIEGEN, WEST GERMANY, Sept. 11 The United States team continued its winning ways in the 19th Chess Olympiad when it defeated Turkey in the sixth preliminary round, 3 to , at Siegerland Hall last night. In the seventh round, tonight, it drew one game with Finland, and adjourned three, two in a favorable position and the other in a probable draw.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Sept. 11 Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Jackson of Lloyd Harbor have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susanne Jackson, to Jeffrey Clark Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Otterson Miller Jr. of Laurel Hollow. The wedding is planned for Oct.17.
ALBANY, Sept. 11 Secretary of State John P. Lomenzo ruled the Courage party and its gubernatorial candidate off the November ballot today.

AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 11 The balance of forces in Jordan has been thoroughly shaken up this week by the airliner hijackings and by bloody clashes between Palestinian guerrillas and the army. But opinions are sharply divided as to who has gained and who has lost.
Charles S. Shaughnessy Sr. has been appointed president of Drexel Enterprises, a division of U.S. Plywood-Champion Papers, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 President Nixon announced today that a corps of specially trained guards would begin tomorrow to police both domestic and overseas flights of United States-flag airlines to deal with "the menace of air piracy."

MANHASSET, L.I., Sept. 11 Gerald Deakin, who retired as a vice president and general technical director of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation in 1951, died last night in St. Francis Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived at Harbor Road. Harbor Acres, Sands Point.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 11 A motorcycle, gang member who said he joined Charles Manson's hippie "family" in the summer of 1969 because of the family's free sex atmosphere, testified in the Tate murder trial today that Manson frequently talked of starting a race war.
The First National Bancorporation of Denver in yet another setback for banks seeking to extend their activities into insurance has quietly withdrawn an application to the...

Miss Mary Clement Myerson, director of public relations for the United Planned Parenthood Campaign of New York City, was married yesterday to Burton H. Brody, a member of the law firm of Jezer, Slade Weiss here. Rabbi Martin J. Zion performed the ceremony at the Carlyle Hotel.
Chancellor Albert H. Bowker said yesterday that the City University would not tolerate any acts of violence or threats of violence and that the university would not provide sanctuary for lawbreakers.
BONN, Sept. 11 Cabinet ministers of 17 European countries adopted a resolution here today laying down general principles of future cooperation in regional planning.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 11 Mr. and Mrs. Carlyle M. Baker have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carole Ellen Baker, to R. Woodward Millen, assistant vice president of Bache Co., stockbrokers. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert S. Millen of Brookville, L. I. A November wedding is planned.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) The Japanese Government was reported today to be planning to lift import restrictions on all but 40 items within the next year.

DRY, hot summer weather causes most turf grasses in the North east to go into a dormant state. They turn brown unless there has been adequate rainfall or proper irrigation. As summer evenings become cooler toward autumn and there is more uniform rainfall, the bluegrasses and fescues "wake up" and lawns become green. September provides optimum growing climate for lawns and is a good month for major turf renovation and for planting a new lawn.

About half way through the Alexander's men's wear fashion show last night at the Baronet Theater, three women bounded onto the stage and snatched the hair off the heads of three male models.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) The White House asked Congress today for $28-million for the recruiting and training of 2,500 security guards to ride commercial planes.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 14 An ominous weather forecast calling for 20-knot northeast breezes, rain, fog and visibility of a mile or less added to the uncertainty here today on the eve of the 21st America's Cup defense.

Mozart's "The Marriage of Figaro" is an iridescent opera with endless facets. Every time it's given, something surprising or new shines out from it, even in a relatively glib performance such as the New York City Opera's on Sunday night at, the New York State Theater.
Mayor Lindsay's office said yesterday that the city's cultural festival on the New York piers will be put back at least a week because of picketing by longshoremen.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 In the judgment of some of the best-informed officials here, the Palestinian guerrillas have now shown themselves able to wreck any Middle Eastern settlement that might be negotiated without them.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 New Government figures gave further indication today that the business downturn may be at or near its bottom.
The 62-year-old Opera House of the Brooklyn Academy of Music is getting a $60,000 face-lifting in preparation for the opening of its dance season on Oct. 2.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Sept. 14 (AP) Dr. Rocco Impeglia of Auburn, treasurer of the New York State Golf Association, was tied with Charles Tesari today for the first-round lead in the 54-hole New York State Senior men's championship.
TEL AVIV, Sept. 14 Foreign Minister Abba Eban said today that he thought the Jordanian Government no longer had the capacity to negotiate a peace treaty with Israel.

LONDON, Sept. 14 (AP) Lloyd's, the London underwriters, said today that the British Overseas Airways Corporation would receive $8.4-million as an insurance settlement for the VC-10 airliner destroyed by Arab guerrillas in Jordan.

BRUSSELS, Sept. 14 Participants in an international Roman Catholic theological congress here waged an apparently successful palace revolution today after accusing their leaders of using Vaticanstyle methods in behalf of their own brand of liberalism.
Governor Rockefeller announced yesterday that he had protested Federal cuts of $3million in antipoverty funds for community action agencies throughout New York State.
LONDON, Sept. 14 Five nations agreed today on an "allor-nothing" settlement over the release of the 50 or more hostages held by the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine.
BOGALUSA, La., Sept. 14 A two-hour fight today between white and black students at an integrated high school was broken up by policemen using tear gas.

FORT WORTH, Tex., Sept. 14 (UPI) C.A. Sellers, editor of The Fort Worth Press and a former president of the Texas United Press International Editors Association, died today of a heart attack. He was 47 years old.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 14 As a rule, Congressional politics in Baltimore are about as volatile as three-day-old ginger ale.

The New York State Athletic Commission cannot deny a boxing license to Muhammad Ali because he was convicted of refusing to submit to the draft, according to a Federal Court order issued here yesterday.
SEATTLE, Sept. 14--In the primary election campaign in the State of Washington, attention has focused on the challenge to Senator Henry M. Jackson, a moderate Democrat who is seeking a fourth term.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 14 Doctors at Jewish Hospital have implanted an inert plastic material molded in the shape of a heart valve under the skin of dogs and are experimenting with the resulting fibrous membrane as a substitute heart valve.

PARIS, Sept. 14 The Premier of France and the political leader trying to unite the nonCommunist Opposition accused each other of lying today in an explosive exchange over timing of a Ford Motor Company decision to build a plant in Bordeaux.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 Theodore E. Desch, 38 years old, was named a vice chairman of the board and chief executive officer here today of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad. William J. Dixon, 51, was named president and Peter Kiewit, 70, was named acting chairman.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UPI) The Securities and Exchange Commission today ordered hearings on staff charges that Sentinel Securities, Inc., a Wichita broker-dealer, manipulated the stock of its parent company, Investment Centers, Inc.

It was a bull market for long-shot players at Belmont Park yesterday as an Uncle Sam daily double of $1,315.40 the largest of the New York season had the big-ods fraternity in the crowd of 25,202 beating a trail to the payoff windows for much of the afternoon.
PARIS, Sept. 14 (Reuters) Former Premier Maurice Couve de Murville will make a threeweek private visit to China next month, informed sources said today.

The 86th season of the Metropolitan Opera opened last night before a not-quitesold-out house of 3,863 lovers of opera and lovers of public occasions. They had paid out a total of $122,000, with a $700 top for a parterre box, to see Verdi's four-act opera "Ernani."
The president of the National Organization of Women, Inc., accused President Nixon yesterday of being "totally insensitive" to the problems of women.
The New York State Lottery's special $1-million lottery ends at midnight to night, with $7-million worth of the coupon's already purchased by the hopeful who are willing to take a $3 chance.

Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 A 50-cent bus service to link the city's hotel and business district with Metroliner trains at Union Terminal was begun on a six-month experimental basis today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) The Food and Drug Admin istration moved today to ban as ineffective a major class of prescription cold and respiratory disease remedies. Barring objections, the ban would take effect in 40 days.

Dr. James M. Hester, president of New York University, told students yesterday that they should feel free to express themselves and bring forward new ideas, but that they should never infringe on the rights of others.

ITHACA, Sept. 14 If anyone wants to find out who checked out a book about bombs, or revolutions, or how to ski, the Tompkins County Public Library has been directed by the county government to open up the records.

Service for 196,000 daily commuters into New York City will be normal this morning, railroad officials said, although late last night Westchester-bound trains of the Penn Central were halted briefly in anticipation of a strike.
Life in the Jordanian desert aboard the hijacked Trans World Airlines plane was described last night by a succession of returning hostages as calm, organized, and orderly.
The stock market wobbled to a decline yesterday as news events in the economic sphere seemed to establish the trading pattern.

The first thing Mrs. Joan Grant, one of the city's 6,000 new public school teachers, told her sixth-graders yesterday was her name. The last thing one of her pupils asked her as he raced away from school at 3 P.M. was her name.

CHAPPAQUA, N. Y., Sept. 14 Otto J. Myers, vice president and a director of the executive committee of Reichhold Chemicals, Inc., White Plains, and board chairman and a director of Reichhold Chamicals of Canada, Ltd., of Toronto, a subsidiary, died at his home here on Saturday. He was 55 years old and lived at 115 Marcourt Drive.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) The Federal Communications Commission announced today the appointment of Francis R. Walsh, dean of the University of San Francisco Law School, as chief of the F.C.C. Broadcast Bureau.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 The A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the Chamber of Commerce told Congress today that they disapproved of the Administration's tax proposals.

A subway train that stalled on the Manhattan Bridge at the height of the evening rush hour, a train behind it that broke into two parts, and a series of rider revolts on both trains tied up the IND line into Brooklyn for three and a half hours yesterday. The delay affected 60,000 passengers.
LAFAYETTE, Calif., Sept. 14 (UPI) A real estate man who vanished last Wednesday night returned to his home yesterday, saying that be had been kidnapped but did not know why.

LUSAKA, Zambia, Sept. 14 President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia, who presided over a conference of leaders of nonaligned countries here last week said today that he was bound by the decisions of that conference to do his utmost to get Communist China into the United Nations.
CHICAGO, Sept. 14 The gypsy moth, which plagued thousands of New Yorkers all summer, can now be detected and trapped through the use of a new synthetic sex lure, a scientist reported today.

AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 14 Ignoring the photos of napalm wounds, the rifle niches in the walls and the goings and comings of armed youths, a young man transfixed his visitors with his steely eyes and barked "We've won the first-round!"

The new academic year, the first under decentralization, got off to a smooth start yesterday for most of the city's 900 public schools, but parents' boycotts kept all 2,400 pupils out of classes at two school and cut attendance sharply at a third.

The heavyweight boxing championship has always been the most important in sports. When a colorful champion reigned, the busted-beak business boomed. Or at least it did up to these more recent years, which have gone veering off into less predictable patterns. But live-wire fighters helped stimulate the gate throughout fisticuffing history by helping pump hot air into the ballyhoo machines.

The signs of success were everywhere: record crowds, sizable prize money, national television, the introduction of a sudden death scoring system, a grand slam, a public protest by women players, complaints against the press, renewed talk of synthetics replacing grass, manufacturers peddlling their wares, and, of course, politics.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 The White House told the Palestinian guerrillas today that the holding of United States citizens as hostages was "totally unacceptably to the United States Government."
SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 14 Nathan Berlin, an advertising executive, died in Veterans Hospital here yesterday following a two-year illness. He. was 62 years old.

Public schools in West Haven, Conn., were shut down yesterday for the first time since a week-long teachers' strike started in eight Connecticut communities. Nonstriking teachers, aided by volunteers, had kept the West Haven schools open until yesterday.

AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 14--A spokesman of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine said tonight that it was treating the American hostages "on the same basis as Israelis" and that they would be released when the Israelis were released.

Should you trust the stock market, now that it's showing a little warmth, or do you believe the noted financial observer who has said that the market will drop to 500 on the Dow-Jones industrials or even lower?

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 The Administration reacted strongly today to news accounts quoting leaders of nine Negro colleges who accused the White House of intensifying racial problems by failing to support black education.
BRUSSELS, Sept. 14 The Belgian Minister for Scientific Planning, Theo Lefevre, flew today to Washington to discuss the possibility of European countries taking part in the post-Apollo space program.

In his new novel, Harvey Swados takes a handful of American radicals from the Molotov-Ribbentrop pact to the assassination of John F. Kennedy. In the beginning, they are all associated with a Trotskyite faction calling itself the New Party, opposed equally to Hitler and Stalin, organizing factory workers for the socialist millenium.

GARDEN CITY, L.I. Sept. 14 Lou Carnesecca, in his famous coaching crouch, watched Rick Barry go to the basket today during the New York Nets' workout and said, "I helped make this boy an allAmerica at Miami University."
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 14 More than 12,000 public school teachers involved in a labor dispute with the board of education returned to work today under a 30-day truce.

Lum's, Inc., which operates quick-service restaurants, announced yesterday that an agreement has been executed that changes the terms under which it will pay the rest of the purchase price for the Caesar's Palace hotel and casino in Las Vegas, Nev.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 14 Direct two-way radio communication between an animal's brain and a computer has been established for the first time by a team of scientists at Yale University. It was used to enable the brain to control artificially one of its own functions.

MINEOLA, L.I. Sept. 14 Correction officers employed at the Nassau County Jail picketed the Board of Supervisors meeting here today in a demand for more jailers at the overcrowded facility and an end to enforced overtime work.

The Northrop Corporation, a diversified aerospace, ordnance, electronic and communications equipment concern, increased its earnings for the quarter and fiscal year ended July 31 despite reductions and postponements in defense programs, Thomas V. Jones, president, reported yesterday.
A new type of auto seat belt designed to force the six out of 10 American motorists who do not use this safety aid now to "buckle up" was demonstrated here yesterday.

Robert W. Anderson, a television actor and model known as Andy Anderson, died at Roosevelt Hospital yesterday as a result of a gun accident at his home, 56 East 58th Street, on Friday morning. He was 31 years old.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 The House of Representatives passed today, by the relatively narrow margin of 177 to 140, a bill to add $1.3-billion more to United States contributions to international lending institutions, the bulk of it for the benefit of Latin America. The bill now goes to the Senate, where its fate is uncertain.
"As far as profits go, last year was our best year ever and this year we're going to be up 50 per cent."

Six small businesses in the New York area, all owned by members of minority ethnic groups, have joined some 600 well-known national suppliers for this year's National Merchandise Show, which runs through Wednesday at the New York Coliseum.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 14 A Government minister jumped from his car and walked into a restaurant in downtown Saigon to check the price of beef noodle soup.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 14 Gov. Ronald Reagan signed legislation today aimed at preventing busing of students to achieve racial integration in classrooms. SEATTLE, Sept. 14 (AP) The Boeing Company has rolled out an upgraded version of its 747 jumbo jet. Flight testing of the new model, called the 747B, is expected to start Oct. 1.
WASHINGTON, Tuesday, Sept. 15 Four railroad unions ordered a strike against three major railroads at 12:01 this morning after contract negotiations with the carriers collapsed late last night.

Maine potato futures prices rose sharply yesterday In heavy trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange. All contracts closed at their highs for the day and within a few pennies of the highs for the year.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UPI) The National Petroleum Council said today that more oil output from Canada was the only practical way to meet a fuel-oil shortage outside the United States.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 Treasury bill rates declined at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.
ROME, Sept. 14 The Vatican announced today that Pope Paul VI would deliver "a message to Asia" while in Manila during his trip to the Philippines and Australia from Nov. 27 to Dec. 3.

GENEVA, Sept. 14 World trade should expand in value by 8 to 10 per cent this year after increasing by almost 14 per cent in 1969 to $272-billion, according to a staff study published by a leading international trade agency. The 1969 rise was the fastest since the Korean War price boom.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 The Government has acted to bar one manufacturer from bidding on a new contract to produce a minimum of six million doses of German measles vaccine.

MANILA, Sept. 14 Search and rescue teams at Casiguran Sound in the eastern Philippines, recovered 144 bodies by yesterday and were still looking for some 150 persons missing since a typhoon struck Friday.

An Alitalia DC-8 jetliner, landing at Kennedy International Airport yesterday, split in two about midway along its fuselage and skidded off the runway. In what one official called "quite a miracle," no one was seriously hurt.
The American Stock Exchange took its worst beating in more than a month yesterday as stocks declined in slower trading.

They stripped Clay of his heavyweight championship recognition and of his boxing license.
