The Madison Square Garden Corporation scored a clean-cut decision yesterday by finally getting the Transnation Development Corporation and Roosevelt Raceway, Inc., to agree in principle to merge with it.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 15 Ewald B. Nyquist, the State Commissioner of Education, announced today that he would soon establish an "external degree" program to enable qualified persons not enrolled in college to earn degrees through independent study and examinations.

A new electronic cash register and information system for stores that uses an optical "wand" to read credit cards, price tags and other coded tickets was introduced here yesterday by the National Cash Register Company.
PLATTSBURGH, N.Y., Sept. 15 Arthur J. Goldberg declared today that Governor Rockefeller "is not entitled to re-election solely on the basis that he has not handled the drug problem properly."

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 15 Former Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey began his attempt for a political comeback tonight with a convincing triumph over Earl D. Craig Jr., a Negro peace candidate, in Minnesota's Democratic senatorial primary election.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 13 When Communist forces attacked Saang in early April and the Cambodian war began in earnest, the Cambodian Army numbered about 30,000 men who had few modern weapons and who had been trained in nothing more rigorous than building dikes, draining paddies, and repairing roads.

Archie E. Albright, president of the investment banking subsidiary of F. I. duPont, Glore Forgan Co., the largest partnership in the securities industry, and chairman of the executive committee of the partnership, has resigned to become a special limited partner of the firm.
Ten days before President Nixon took office 20 months ago, Dr. Paul W. McCracken, who was about to become Chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, ...

Nearly upstaged by the bodily ejection of the originally selected referee during the mainevent introductions, Floyd Patterson returned to boxing after a two-year absence last night and knocked out Charlie (Devil) Green in the 10th and last round at Madison Square Garden.

BOSTON, Wednesday, Sept. 16 The Rev. Robert J. Drinan, a Roman Catholic priest on leave as dean of the Boston College Law School, turned antiwar sentiment into a lever to defeat Representative Philip J. Philbin in a Democratic primary.

The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, the nation's fifth largest bank, announced yesterday that Gabriel Hauge, 56 years old, would assume the chairmanship, effective Feb. 1, when R.E. McNeill Jr. reaches the retirement age of 65.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 Four railway unions that had struck three major carriers early this morning instructed their 40,000 striking members to go back to work today.

Garbage was uncollected, many tenants had to climb stairs and some were without hot water yesterday as 9,500 service employes struck 4,500 apartment houses in the Bronx and parts of Westchester and Rockland Counties.
Profit taking sharply trimmed early rises in corn and wheat futures prices on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday resulting in both commodities closing lower than the day before.

MARLBORO, Mass., Sept. 15 The RCA Corporation today introduced a new computer line and marketing policy that the company hopes will catapult it into the No. 2 position in the multibillion dollar, domestic data-processing business.

What may be a hint of how Hollywood proposes to touch on reality and yet preserve the tradition of the happy ending was suggested last night in the seasonal premiere of "Julia" on the network of the National Broadcasting Company.
Governor Rockefeller gave what he called a "genuine answer" to a citizen's question last night and regretted it immediately.

A 38-year-old chauffeur, arrested on charges that con fronted him with a 15-year prison term after he attempted to give the police an envelope full of heroin he had found on a Bronx street, was cleared yesterday after an investigation by District Attorney Burton B. Roberts.

BOSTON, Sept.15 The severest critic of Northeastern University football is Coach Joe Zabilski. Last year his Huskies suffered their first losing campaign in nine years and only Zabilski's sixth in 22 seasons. He termed it unpalatable, and the tone of his voice indicated that the Huskies would have to rectify the situation this season.
New Jersey, as expected, was unable to sell a $75-million bond issue yesterday in a bond market that, over-all, showed an improving tone.
ROCHESTER, Sept. 15 Representative Richard L. Ottinger today called for "drastic simplification" of the tax laws as they apply to the small businessman.

NEWARK, Sept. 15 Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson said today that he had had "indications" that he could have received $31,000 "under the table" if he had responded to "offers" made to him since he took office on July 1.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15 Mr. and Mrs. Logan M. Bullitt 3d have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Benson Bullitt, to Ens. Nicholas A. Prahl of the United States Coast and Geodetic Survey Service. He is stationed in Ketchikan, Alaska.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 15 (AP) South Vietnamese field commanders said today that their forces had withdrawn from one mountaintop base in the northern sector of the country and were planning to pull out of another because of the approaching monsoon season.

WASHINGTON A curious misconception argues the paradox that strength is tantamount to weakness in this complicated post-industrial age of cybernetics. The idea is poetic but untrue. The logic of power remains but it is worthless if it is not applied.

MONTREAL, Sept. 15 The New York Mets dropped from a tie for first place into third place tonight when they were defeated by the Montreal Expos, 5-4, in 10 innings after they had tied the game on a pinchhit home run in the ninth and gone ahead on another home run in the 10th.
General Motors Corporation, world's largest manufacturer, $24-billion in sales last year, $1.7-billion profits, 7.2 million vehicles sold in 1969, 787,000 employes around the world.
Transportation Administrator Constantine SidamonEristoff said yesterday that the Lindsay administration would have a plan ready next year to charge tolls on the East River bridges.
Suppose the New York Stock Exchange had within its grasp a method of reducing the cost of handling securities transactions by from 25 to 50 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 President Nixon outlined to Congress today a series of "fundamental and sweeping reforms" in economic and in military foreign aid to make both more consistent with his plan to maintain a "low profile" in foreign policy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 American officials said today the United States had evidence that Israel had been violating the terms of the cease-fire in the Middle East by making reconnaissance flights over Egyptian territory and by strengthening fortifications along the Suez Canal.

Ruggero Raimondi, the 28year-old bass who scored a notable success in his debut at the Metropolitan Opera on Monday night, is no stranger to triumph on the operatic stage but he still finds its taste very sweet.

LONDON, Sept. 15 British officials are now convinced that Israel holds the key to negotiations for the release of the airline hostages and are pressing the Israeli Government to express some willingness to exchange Arab guerrilla prisoners.
DETROIT, Sept. 15 The Cadillac Division of the General Motors Corporation displayed its 1971 cars to the press today, and while the new models are restyled, they still look like Cadillacs.

Officials of the Metropolitan Museum of Art promised yesterday that the museum would build no further on Central Park land after completion of its present Master Plan, and said they would be willing to amend their 1878 lease with the city to include such a provision.

LONDON, Ontario, Sept. 15--"We're the world champions," said Derek Sanderson, not far from a color poster of a Men's cologne advertisement depicting a model sprawling over him. "And being world champions means that if some humpty-dumpty team has a 16-game losing streak they're gonna wait for you, and if they beat you, then they think they've been successful."

While withholding a formal ruling on Representative Adam Clayton Powell's nomination petitions, the Board of Elections read into the record the official report of its clerk, showing them to be 1,624 short of the required 3,000 valid names.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 15 The United Nations General Assembly opened its 25th-anniversary session today amid expressions of hope that the world organization might recapture some of the glamour, prestige and youthful enthusiasm it once had.

NEW ORLEANS, Wednesday, Sept.16 One young Negro was killed and three others were wounded by police gunfire last night in a grocery shootout near a black militant headquarters raided in a big gun battle earlier in the day. The grocery store was owned by Henry Broussard, a Negro, who also owned the house where the militants established their local headquarters.
The Consolidated Edison Company has asked for electric rate increases of $11.7million a year atop the $90million annual increases that took effect Sept. 8.

NEWTON, Mass., Sept. 15 The Administration would be "pleased" if other major banks were to join the First Pennsylvania Banking and Trust Company in reducing their prime lending rates to 7 per cent from the present level of 8 per cent, a Treasury official said here today.

FARMINGDALE, L. I., Sept. 15--Willis Reed was optimistic but apprehensive about the approaching National Basketball Association season, Walt Frazier said he felt like a rookie and Bill Bradley enjoyed the taste of victory but felt it was too short.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 The Transportation Department, reversing itself after a court challenge by Ralph Nader, said today that wheels installed on 150,000 General Motors pick-up trucks were unsafe.

Earnings of the American Enka Corporation for the 12 and 36 weeks ended Sept. 6 declined from the previous year's periods despite higher sales, "due primarily to generally depressed conditions in the textile industry," the company reported yesterday.
ROME, Sept. 15 Pope Paul VI disbanded all armed and uniformed Vatican organizations today except the halberd-wielding Swiss Guards.

Poor people began electing their representatives in the antipoverty program yesterday, with candidates wondering whether the program had a future and with some potential voters too poor to reach the polls.

CAIRO, Sept. 15 Foreign Minister Mahmond Riad declared today that the United States peace initiative for the Middle East was "dead," but he said that the Egyptians would continue to respect the 90-day cease-fire which began on the night of Aug. 7-8, in the strictest definition of the term.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 15 (Reuters) The International Weightlifting Federation stripped the Hungarian flyweight, Sandor Holczreiter, of his world title today for allegedly having taken drugs. Holczreiter won the title Saturday.

DETROIT, Sept. 15 The United Automobile Workers and the General Motors Corporation have clashed head-on four times once in the Depression, once after World War II, once by error and once in the last year in a strike that revealed the hard lines that are now drawn between the union and the company.
All 2,400 pupils were kept out of two city schools for the second day yesterday in parents' protests over school conditions.
A man suspected of being the leader of a cocaine smuggling ring in Harlem was held in $50,000 bail on his arraignment yesterday in Federal Court in Brooklyn. A hearing was set for Sept. 25.

A three-run pinch homer by Curt Blefary, with one out in the ninth inning of the second game, completed a thoroughly satisfying evening for the New York Yankees at the Stadium last night and a deeply embarrassing one for the Boston Red Sox.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Sept. 15 The Green Bay Packers have a good football team once more and will be a big factor in the National Football League this season. Who says? Ray Nitschke, the team's star linebacker of a dozen years standing, says so.

In the belief that there are antidotes for the decay of the cities of New York State, the state's Urban Development Corporation started commissioning architects and planners 18 months ago to find them.

BRUSSELS, Sept. 15 A wellknown Canadian theologian declared here today that dissident Roman Catholics were developing a religious style that enabled them to remain within the church, but on their own terms rather than those of the bishops and the Pope.
The London Stock Exchange closed moderately on the up side yesterday after a weak opening.
BALTIMORE, Wednesday, Sept 16 Senator Joseph D. Tydings won renomination early today in a surprisingly close Democratic primary.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. Sept. 15 Vice president Agnew said today he would confront a group of "militant students" on a national television program in an attempt to persuade them that they should work within the political system.

About 200 natty little sports cars are being tuned up for the Sports Car Club of America Area One races at Lime Rock, Conn., Saturday. There are also about 150 club members preparing to handle all of the chores that are necessary to make the racing program go as ...

AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 15--Arab guerrillas, at a news conference today, denounced the Red Cross, rejected international law and raised their asking price for the release of the airline passengers and crew members they are holding.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 15 No one asked Jim Hardy, the skipper of Gretel II, if he planned to practice "man overboard" drills tomorrow, but someone might have wanted to.

Directors of the First National City Corporation, the holding company of the First National City Bank and other subsidiaries, raised the quarterly dividend yesterday to 66 cents a share from 60 cents. This marks the sixth consecutive year of increased dividends.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 15 Fort Marcy of the Rokeby Stable, the 6-year-old who has established himself as one of the best campaigners on grass on the continent, will make another attempt tomorrow to win the $125,000 United Nations Handicap.
BRIDGEHAMPTON, L. I.--It's there if one is looking for it, an inconspicuous sign staked into the ground that says, without embellishment, Potato House.

Fifteen men, including 12 who were arrested a year ago and charged with running a $70-million-a-year illegal gambling operation in Westchester and Rockland counties, were indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday.

The chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank responded to a letter from the chairman of the House Banking Committee yesterday by asserting that "banks do not like high interest rates and tight money any more than you do."

The Celanese Corporation and Rockefeller Center announced plans yesterday to construct a world headquarters building for the giant chemical concern on the west blockfront of the Avenue of the Americans between 47th and 48th Streets.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 15 A number of diplomats and analysts of Arab affairs here believe that terror and tension are more important to the Palestinian hijackers than the release of their comrades imprisoned in Western Europe and Israel.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Sept. 15--Mr. and Mrs. Felix A. Mulgrew have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Stuart Mulgrew, to John Marshall Goldsmith Jr. of Radford, Va. A November wedding is planned.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 15 Speculation turned to fact on the America's Cup scene today, and the cold facts were not at all encouraging for Gretel II.

LITTLE FALLS, N.J., Sept. 15 A high official of the Nixon Administration said yesterday that it had been a mistake for the Federal Government to agree to provide money to clean up the country's polluted waters.

The people who brought you Reynolds Wrap have come up with a new cooking aid: Brown-in-Bag. The 10by-16-inch nylon film bags for oven use eliminate the need for basting, scouring baking pans and wiping spatters off the inside of the oven.

Congress has taken a small, timid step toward justice for the citizens of the District of Columbia. Both houses have now approved a bill giving the District a nonvoting delegate in the House of Representatives. The new delegate will, in effect, be a full-time paid lobbyist for the voteless people in the city of Washington.

TOKYO, Sept. 15 A two-day meeting here of the non-communist world's major aid-giving nations has made a "significant advance" toward abandoning a requirement that recipients spend aid funds on goods and services in the country supplying the assistance.

The Federal Communications Commission hearings into the challenge So WPIX-TV's broadcast license began here yesterday with Francis M. Flynn, chairman of the board of The Daily News and of WPIX, and Fred M. Thrower, president of the station, defending its news presentation.

Ten Persons from the fields of education, civic affairs, business and the arts have been added to the board of trustees of the Museum of Modern Art. They bring to 39 the number of trustees on the board, one short of the full 40 allowed the museum by the New York State Board of Regents, which recently granted it permission to expand.

REGGIO CALABRIA, Italy, Sept. 16 (Reuters) Police reinforcements were rushed to this town near the southern tip of Italy today after a night of some of the worst violence it has seen since unrest broke out two months ago.

Rising imports of frozen bone less beef has led the New York Mercantile Exchange to establish the world's first commodity futures contract for this product. Llewellyn Watts Jr., chairman of the board of the exchange, announced yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 16 As campaigns in the nation's Congressional districts get under way, a Gallup Poll indicates that voters are expressing greater confidence in the Democrats than in the Republicans as the party better able to keep the country prosperous.
With only four days remaining until Monday night's American Conference opener in Cleveland, six members of the New York Jets remain unsigned to 1970 contracts.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (UPI) The Senate Banking Committee approved today a bill that would lower down payments for dwellings insured by the Federal Housing Administration. It would also subsidize, for the first time, mass transit systems that operate in the red.

LONDON If any find the classic theater a pain then the English have an undeniable genius for making pains. In New York a play restaged after 20 or 50 years tends to have the air of revival about it; in London even after little more than a decade a new staging begins to take on the gleaming patina of a classic. It is an agreeable, and even useful, habit.

TOKYO, Sept. 16 (AP) North Korea proposed today a confederation of North and South Korea as a transitional step to eventual reunification. At the same time it demanded the withdrawal of United States troops from South Korea.
NEW HAVEN, Sept. 16 Young men and women registering at Yale University this week are being handed a 64-page booklet entitled "Sex and the Yale Student."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 Following are some of the companies that have introduced low-lead or unleaded gasoline:

BOSTON, Sept. 16 The nomination of a Jesuit priest to replace a 28-year veteran of Congress and the hard-won primary victory of Mayor Kevin H. White of Boston has political analysts studying a voter profile they thought they knew well.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange moved steadily higher after a slight setback in the first hour of trading and finished near their best levels of the day on moderate trading.

The National Gallery of Art in Washington has introduced a multimedia program in the humanities called "Art and Man." The first installment of the eight-part program will be distributed to participating museums and schools throughout the country starting Monday. The program is being published and distributed by Scholastic Magazines, Inc., under the direction of the gallery.

Rogelio Moret of Guayama, P.R., made his 21st birthday a memorable one at Yankee Stadium last night as he acquired his first major league victory by pitching four shutout relief innings in a 3-1 decision the Boston Red Sox scored over the New York Yankees.

A recent letter from Carlos Barrantes of San Jose, Costa Rica, with whom I angled for tarpon last spring, tells of the splendid fishing for snook to be had at the mouth of the Parismina River this month and next.

ZERQA, Jordan, Sept. 16 Arab commandos in this bullet-pocked provincial town today openly defied Government orders to turn in their weapons. They began digging in for a showdown with king Hussein's new military regime.

The Bankers Trust Company announced yesterday a broad reshuffle of its senior management that will bring Chester Baylis Jr., previously the bank's only executive vice president, into the inner circle of top officers with full-time responsi bility for general management of the bank. Mr. Baylis, who is 62 years old, will be chairman of the executive committee of the bank.

It was just after noon on Sunday, Sept. 6, and Trans World Airlines Flight 741 was cruising 30,000 feet above Belgium. Capt. C.D. Woods's voice announced placidly that the plane was over Brussels and that the 141 passengers aboard could expect to arrive in New York six hours later.

The strike that has cut off garbage collection, elevator service and hot water in many Bronx apartment houses is another round in the battle of the city's landlords against the revised rent-control law that went into effect last July.
SEATTLE, Sept. 16 An effort by the peace movement to defeat Senator Henry M. Jackson failed yesterday as the three-term Democrat won easily in Washington's senatorial primary.

Officials from antipoverty programs throughout the New York Region plan to go to Washington next Tuesday to oppose an anticipated drop of $3.6-million in Federal funds that they say will cost hundreds of existing jobs.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 The President's Box at Ford's Theater was empty. But most of the orchestra seats were Full of Congressmen at the opening last night of "Will Rogers, U.S.A."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept 16 (AP) Four more competitors, three from Eastern Europe countries, were disqualified and deprived of their medals in the world weightlifting championships today. They were charged with taking stimulants.

Controller Abraham D. Beame stopped payment yesterday on all new management consultant contracts because, he said, the Lindsay administration continued to award those contracts without Board of Estimate approval.
ALBANY, Sept. 16 The Public Service Commission today insisted the New York Telephone Company must file new rates, calling for a $120.8-million increase, by Sept. 21.

KITCHENER, Ontario, Sept. 16 Four young players, including the battering Andre (Moose) Dupont and Bob Jones, were dropped from the New York Rangers' "A" team today as Coach Emile Francis began cutting the squad to workable size.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Sept. 16 Vice President Agnew ended his first campaign tour today in a shouting match with antiwar demonstrators and with a plea to blue-collar Democrats to prove their patriotism by voting Republican.

For 103 minutes, James Stewart, who has inherited it, and his equally genial, dimwitted cowpoke pal, Henry Fonda, shuffle around the refined premises of "The Cheyenne Social Club" in pop-eyed reverence. Yes, it's a house not a home, and that's the one joke in the tired, arch prairie comedy opening yesterday, directed and produced by Gene Kelly, of all people.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 16 Terry Bradshaw, the Pittsburgh Steelers' ebullient rookie quarterback, stripped off his wet working clothes in the team's deluxe new locker room today at Three Rivers Stadium and had a dialogue with himself.

Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that the Federal Government had deposited $1-million in Model Cities funds in five Brooklyn banks to encourage and assist the development of minority business ventures.

"What the Butler Saw," "Child's Play" and "You're a Good Man, Charlie Brown" have two main things in common. They are hits and their director is Joseph Hardy. Most successful directors leave a stamp on shows, or the shows by the similar nature of the material leave a stamp on the directors. In Mr. Hardy's case, you can tell that he directed a show only by looking in the program.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 An international group of scientists dedicated to peace issued a warning today that the next possible step-up in the arms race may come in anti-submarine warfare, and they urged it to be avoided.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 16 Miss Donna Louise Moran, a psychologist at the Harvard Medical School, and Dr. Michael D. Robbins, an instructor in psychiatry there, plan to be married next month.
A $100-a-person benefit dinner dance will be held on Tuesday at the Shoreham Hotel in Washington to commemorate the 10th anniversary of the dedication of the hospital ship S.S. Hope.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 The direct popular election of Presidents is a proposition that has been steadily growing in popular favor. The George Wallace Presidential campaigns and the Supreme Court's one-man, one-vote decisions provided a favorable climate for such a sweeping change in the political system. Polls now show it to be the strong desire of most

Mr. Ierardi retired four years ago as editor, but continued as a consultant of Weekly News, which became the National Braille Press, a non-profit organization devoted to helping the blind help themselves, of which he was also a trustee.

Ogilvy Mather's first campaign for its new client National Distillers' Old Crow bourbon breaks tomorrow in newspapers in 137 markets and will be followed by a fat schedule in national magazines starting in October.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 Mayor Lindsay sharply challenged present census-taking methods today as clumsy and and antiquated. He charged they produced inaccurate data, forcing the Government to operate "in a never-never land where the facts are never seen" and the needs of the urban poor are evaded.

The cop on the beat stopped by to see what was going on, and when he was encouraged to take a seat, he did so. Which is how Patrolman Fred Swedish ended up in the front row at the fashion show of men's clothes by Hardy Amies at Whitehouse Hardy yesterday.

PARIS, Sept. 16 The United California Bank in Basel., A.G., closed its doors at 2 P.M. today as known losses from what is now regarded as Switzerland's biggest banking scandal were reported at $40-million.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 16 (AP) Sheriff's deputies used tear gas tonight against 2,000 young persons throwing rocks, bottles and fire bombs at them after a Mexican Independence Day parade.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 16 A veteran city fireman was suspended today and charged with failing to dispatch trucks last Friday night after a citizen called to report smoke odors at a house in which a woman was later found burned to death.
CHICAGO, Sept. 16 Ronald L. Ziegler, the White House press secretary, today confirmed reports that President Nixon would visit Yugoslavia during his projected European tour.

Dean Burch, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, questioned yesterday the commitment of the commercial television networks to children's programing and urged cooperative efforts among the networks for the creation of better children's shows.
MANHATTAN, Kan., Sept. 16 President Nixon made a strong appeal today for the restoration of civility and an end to violence and intolerance in American society.

After two months' experience with the state's new abortion law the most permissive in the country New York City's health chief yesterday proclaimed the program a success, offering an array of encouraging statistics to experts who had forecast heartbreaking chaos.

Last year, before leaving for East Africa, Beatrice Sandler packed a satchel full of what she considers one of the greatest kitchen gadgets, the swivel-bladed paring knife. She took them as gifts on a cooking expedition, and when she came back from Senegal, Liberia, Ghana, Kenya, Tanzania, Zanzibar and Ethiopia, she had replaced them with a satchel full of recipes.
Richard Moncrieff Pott, the architect of the New Senate Office Building in Washington, died of heart failure Tuesday in his home at 66 Park Avenue. He was 75 years old.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16 Mr. and Mrs. Charles Roebling Tyson have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sarah Tyson, to Alejandro Jose Valenzuela-Bock, a student at Wesleyan University. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Aldo Walterio Valenzuela Pena of Tocopilla, Chile.
The subway system's first bullet-proof change booth went into operation yesterday at Times Square.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 16 Black residents of a public housing project have challenged police accounts of the slaying of one Negro and the wounding of three others last night.

Representative Richard L. Ottinger yesterday toured the Queens Children's Hospital, a psychiatric institution, and charged that conditions there were "a real fright" and that children were "being treated like animals."

Lewis Zients, brother of Bernard P. Zients, who is president of the 10 Gimbels Departmet Stores in the New York Area, died yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 312 South Bridgewood Drive, South Orange, N.J.

Fred M. Thrower, president of WIPX-TV, spent his second day on the witness stand yesterday telling a Federal Communications Commission examiner of a series of moves made by his station in an effort to make news programing a financial and ratings success.
A soldier's challenge to orders sending him to Vietnam on the ground that the war is unconstitutional was dismissed yesterday by a Federal judge in Brooklyn.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16 (AP) Manny Sanguillen got three hits and scored twice in leading the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 5-3 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies tonight.
Eight Roman Catholic bishops of the metropolitan area complained yesterday that a WCBS-TV newscast on abortion had conveyed anti-Catholic bias and ignored moral and ethical questions.

BRUSSELS, Sept. 16 Negotiators renewed talks here to day on Britain's application to join the European Common, Market. The British asked for a year's grace from the financial burdens of membership if she is accepted.
MENTALLY RETARDED GET BROOKLYN HOME The first community residence for mentally retarded young adults was officially opened yesterday by Governor Rockefeller.
More assistance from citizens, closer surveillance of militants and stiffer sentences for assailants were recommended yesterday to combat the growing number of attacks on the nation's police.

LONDON, Sept. 16 The Post Office announced today that it was going ahead with its controversial plan to computerize Britain's telephone directories, in which names appear out of strict alphabetical order.
Edward V. Regan, the Republican candidate for State Controller, said yesterday that "a bomb" had been dropped on his campaign and that the bombardier was his own running mate, Governor Rockefeller.
BONN, Sept. 16 (UPI) Palestinian refugees trained in guerrilla terrorist techniques have been infiltrated into West Germany, a top official in the West German counterintelligence agency said today.

Forty investigators gathered yesterday at Kennedy International Airport at the site where an Alitalia DC-8 jetliner split in two while landing. The accident injured 76 of the 156 people on board, none seriously.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 The Internal Revenue Service said today that it was looking into the tax status of Representative Martin B. McKneally, Republican of Newburgh, N.Y.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Sept. 16 The newly elected President of the United Nations General Asembly, Dr. Edvard Hambro, today put his personal prestige behind moves to have the Assembly take action against aerial hijackings and the seizure of hostages.

One of the nations' leading spokesmen for black nationalism, Roy Innis, the national director of CORE, has criticized Arab guerrillas for holding American Jews as hostages, and has asked "our wing" of the black movement not to ignore "what happened in Amman."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) The chief Senate sponsor of a constitutional amendment providing for election of the President by direct, popular vote, conceded defeat today on a key test of strength.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Sept. 17 Enemy gunners shot down and destroyed nine United States helicopters and damaged eight others in the last six days, killing four Americans and wounding six, the United States command reported today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 In a report, to the White House Council on Environmental Quality, the Department of Transportation said today that the supersonic transport plane might have some effects on the environment. But it rated these effects as ranging from "insignificant" to "trivial."

Education officials around the state enthusiastically praised yesterday a proposal by Ewald B. Nyquist. New York's Commissioner of Education, to create an "external degree" program for people unable to attend regular college classes.
COLD SPRING, N.Y., Sept. 16--Former Justice James W. Bailey of the State Supreme Court died yesterday. He was 80 years old and lived at 30 Paulding Avenue.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 (AP) Robert E. DeNisco, the Brink's Inc. security guard who shot and wounded a former mental patient and thwarted the hijacking of a Trans World Airlines jet at San Francisco Airport yesterday, received a $5,000 bonus check today from Edgar A. Jones, president of Brink's.

A stylish symbol of British history and military tradition, got up in scarlet tunics and pleated kilts, marched into Madison Square Garden last night, piping a rousing musical affirmation by Irving Berlin "There's No Business Like Show Business."
Alfred Strogoff has joined the Sun Chemical Corporation as executive vice president for corporate development.
The commercial paper market contracted during August for the third month in a row, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
Organized Bronx landlords reported yesterday that they had begun a "defensive shutdown" of services, even in apartment buildings not yet struck by service employes.
High officials of the Lindsay administration said yesterday that it was "very, very likely" that a special lane for bicycles would soon be set aside on a major avenue.
AMMAN, Jordan, Thursday, Sept. 17 Heavy fighting began at dawn today between Palestinian guerrillas and Jordanian Anny troops in what the guerrillas said would be a final confrontation.
Let's take a look at the computer industry that burgeoning industry in which nothing can go wrong.

The Israeli Consulate here refused yesterday to divulge the name of the hotel at which Premier Golda Meir would stay, but the WaldorfAstoria issued a press release announcing, "Golda Meir arrives at the Waldorf-Astoria today."

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 16 Fort Marcy has finally succeeded in adding the United Nations Handicap trophy to his extensive collection. The star grass campaigner from the Rokeby Stable of Paul Mellon had tried three times in the last three seasons to take the 1 3-16-mile event, but his best previous finish had been third.

BROOKVILLE, L.I. Sept. 16 When only 52 candidates showed up for the first day of football camp at C.W. Post, Dom Anile, starting his third year as the Pioneers' coach, took a good look and immediately crossed his fingers.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 Four railway unions and the nation's carriers moved today toward a major strike next Thursday despite Government efforts to start negotiations.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 The Nixon Administration, increasingly concerned that a showdown between King Hussein and Palestinian guerrilla groups may be imminent in Jordan, is preparing contingency plans.

BONN, Sept. 16 West Germany's first trial of airplane hijackers ended in Munich today with prison terms ranging from two and a half years to eight months for eight Czechoslovaks who diverted a domestic flight into West Germany last June. The sentences of five defendants were suspended.
PARIS, Sept. 16 President Nixon is understood to have turned down an invitation to visit Paris during his forthcoming European tour.

DETROIT, Sept. 16 The Ford Motor Company raised its 1971 car prices today an average of 5 per cent, or $153, and hinted that it might raise prices again, depending on its contract settlement with the United Automobile Workers.
Following are excerpts from President Nixon's address yesterday at Kansas State University in Manhattan, Kansas, as recorded by The New York Times:

JERUSALEM, Sept. 16 Premier Golda Meir left for the United States today to meet with President Nixon. Israeli officials believe that the time is ripe to try to bring together Israeli and American policies on peace and war in the Middle East.
The considerable political power of Brooklyn and Queens will be joined against any effort to impose tolls on the East River bridges, the chief executives of the two boroughs said yesterday.

The Campbell Soup Company achieved an increase of 22 per cent in earnings for the fiscal year ended Aug. 2 on a sales gain of 9.1 per cent, while its fourth-quarter net income was up 4.4 per cent and sales were 5.5 per cent above the year earlier level.
With the first major strike against General Motors in a quarter of a century grinding through its second day, the stock market assembled a surprising rally along a broad front yesterday.

The first faint signs of optimism are creeping back into Wall Street, infusing the denizens of downtown Manhattan with hope, if not outright confidence, that the worst of the bear market is over and that life will be better once again.
Net income of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company fell in the third quarter of 1970 despite an increase in revenues, the utility reported yesterday.

Kidder, Peabody Co. headed a group of underwriters who were awarded yesterday two issues of New York State Housing Finance Agency taxexempt bonds totaling $76,- 320,000 with an effective interest rate of 6.8575.
GENEVA, Sept. 16 A new chief negotiator for the International Committee of the Red Cross left for Amman today to try to obtain the release of the hostages from airliners hijacked by Arab commandos.
Motorola, Inc., announced yesterday the election of William J. Weisz as president of the electronics company. Mr. Weisz, 43 years old, succeeds Elmer H. Wavering, who was named vice chairman.

SIEGEN, Germany, Sept. 16 The United States team, following a first-round setback and fighting a cautious battle, drew two games with Rumania and adjourned two, one in a winning position and the other with a fair chance, in the second round of the 19th Chess Olympiad today.

Stanley Kramer's "R.P.M.," which opened yesterday at the Loew's State I and Loew's Orpheum Theaters, is about one of the gut questions of our time. Should Ann-Margret, a graduate student an sociology, continue to Sleep with Anthony Quinn, her bleeding heart liberal of a professor, after he becomes acting college president and sends the pigs in to clear out the administration building?

BRUSSELS, Sept. 16 Participants in the Roman Catholic theological congress here asserted today that the reform of church structures must be extended well beyond the changes prescribed by Ecumenical Council Vatican II.
TACOMA, Wash., Sept. 16 The voters of Tacoma last night in a special recall election voted five of their nine City Councilmen out of office and left the city with the problem of how to replace them.

Hundreds of IND subway riders were evacuated from trains between the Canal Street station and 42d Street at the height of the evening rush hour yesterday after a southbound. A express train had brake trouble at Canal Street.

A television program with four channels of sound will be broadcast by WNYC-TV (Channel 31) and WYNC-FM at 8 P.M. Friday to mark the opening of the 1970 New York High Fidelity Music Show that day. The broadcast will be presented by the Institute of High Fidelity, which is sponsoring the show.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 16 Representative George H. Fallon, the 68-year-old chairman of the House Public Works Committee, conceded today his defeat in Maryland's primary election by a young lawyer who had campaigned against the big Federal highway program sponsored by Mr. Fallon's committee.

MANILA, Sept. 16 Government forces captured Faustino del Mundo, second in command in the older faction of the Hukbalahap dissident movement, today. He surrendered after being sealed off in a tunnel connecting two houses in Angeles City, near Clark Air Force Base.
MOSCOW, Sept. 16 (Reuters) Three persons have died of cholera in the Crimean city of Kerch, the Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia reported today.

CHATHAM, N.Y., Sept. 16 (AP) A spokesman for the A. supermarkets said today that a petty larceny charge against Harry Belafonte would be dropped, although the village police justice said he was unaware of any such action.

Patrolman Raymond Schue, 28 years old, assigned to duty in the East 126th Street Precinct, Manhattan, was in critical condition in the Hospital for Joint Diseases yesterday after suffering a gunshot wound from his service revolver late Tuesday night.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 The United States and the International Monetary Fund announced today a complex set of transactions whose net effect will be to reduce the United States' gold stock by $322million.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Sept. 16 Charlotte De Cozen of Westchester Country Club defeated Mrs. Albert B. Bower of Pelham C.C. by two strokes at Winged Foot Golf Club today in an 18-hole playoff for the Elizabeth Wheeler Trophy and the 41st annual open championship of Fairfield and Westchester counties.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 (AP) Ted Simmons's homer started a three-run fourth inning and Joe Torre hit a two-run homer in the ninth today as the St. Louis Cardinals downed the Chicago Cubs, 8-1, for Bob Gibson's 22d triumph.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 15 Mrs. Regina M. McCloskey Rubicam, who was married for 25 years to Raymond Rubicam, founder of the advertising firm, Young Rubicam died today in the Lawrence Hospital after a long illness. She was 77 years old and lived at the Gramatan Hotel here for 12 years.

PENSACOLA, Fla., Sept. 15 Dr. Suresh N. Chinai, manager of the Acrylic Fiber Research Division of the American Cyanamid Company in Stamford, Conn., died here today while attending a business meeting. He was 42 years old and lived at 845 West End Avenue in New York City.

At the beginning of his fall fur collection, Jacques Kaplan promised "everything for everyone." Then he marched out 123 coats to an audience of 600 customers and press crowded into the grand ballroom of the Plaza Hotel yesterday and kept his promise.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) The Baltimore Orioles clinched a tie for a second straight American League Eastern Division title tonight despite losing to Washington, 2-0.

NEWARK, Sept. 16 A key prosecution witness testified today in the extortion conspiracy trial of Simone Rizzo (Sam the Plumber) DeCavalcante that the defendant had received $3,800 to adjudicate a shakedown dispute among participants in a crooked dice game.
The State Public Service Commission yesterday authorized the Consolidated Edison Company to make an additional 1.4 per cent rate increase in bills for electricity effective Oct. 1.
The American Enka Corporation announced yesterday that it had raised prices by 10 per cent across the board on all B.F.C. (bulk continuous filament) carpet nylon yarns, effective immediately.
SAN DIEGO, Sept. 15 (AP) Tommy Fults, a favorite in the Gold Cup hydroplane championships, was thrown from his speedboat and killed in a trial run today.
Within a few minutes, on a recent evening, three television channels presented these three episodes:
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 16 The leftist governments of Syria and Iraq assailed the military regime imposed in neighboring Jordan today as the work of "reactionary imperialist authorities."

The indictment of a suspended New York City Housing Authority patrolman on charges of assault and felonious weapons possession arising from the shooting of a man after a traffic altercation was announced yesterday by Bronx District Attorney Burton B. Roberts.

NEWARK, Sept. 16 The Passaic River, generally regarded as one of the country's dirtiest waterways, was proposed today as a model demonstration project where the nation's best minds would be concentrated on finding more effective ways to control pollution.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (Reuters) The State Department confirmed today that Israel had been conducting reconnaissance flights over the Suez Canal area beyond the limits agreed upon in the Middle Eastern cease-fire and standstill agreement.
One of the two biggest tournaments on the New York calendar, the Long Island regional championships, begins today at Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L.I. Scheduled events are:
LONDON Excerpts from a royal diary:

The Penn Central Transportation Company, whose freight yards and terminals have been incredibly snarled, hired a vice president yesterday to try to restore order. He is J. Hansford Sharp, president of the Terminal Railroad Association of St. Louis, a job in which the Penn Central's present president, William H. Moore, preceded him.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 16 (Reuters) Harry Mance, chairman of Lloyd's of London, said today that aviation insurance rates would rise but that he could not foresee that airlines would be refused coverage because of the hijacking menace.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 16 The widows of South Vietnamese soldiers are angry, and their reasons are the same ones that so many South Vietnamese cite: the growing inflation, the red tape in Government agencies that are supposed to help them, the lack of housing in the cities.

The "new politics" scored two major victories in this week's primary contests for the House of Rep resentatives. Democratic voters in Baltimore rejected Representative George Fallon, chairman of the House Public Works Committee and loyal servitor of the highway lobby. In Massachusetts, Representative Philip J. Philbin, vice chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, was turned out of office after 28 years.

VANDALIA, III., Sept. 16 Miss Susan Yvonne Froehly, an assistant district attorney for Bronx County, New York, and Leonard Max Teich, a senior analyst for the Eastern Hemisphere Petroleum Division of the Continental Oil Company in New York, plan to be married here on Nov. 28.

DORADO, P.R., Sept. 16 Ponce de Leon, the first governor of Puerto Rico, made a fruitless trip to Florida in 1513 to find the Fountain of Youth. Alexis J. Rodriguez Pou of Bayamon went to Florida 450 years later to attend the University of Miami and had much greater suc

MOSCOW, Sept. 16 Grigory V. Romanov was named today as First Secretary of the Leningrad Communist party organization, replacing Vasily S. Tolstikov, who has been appointed Ambassador to Communist China.
TRENTON, Sept. 16 Angelo Bruno, the reputed boss of organized crime in Philadelphia and Southern New Jersey, testified for nearly an hour in secret today before the State Commission of Investigation.

James L. Buckley, Conservative party candidate for United States Senator, drew cheers yesterday as he assured thousands in his audience at a noontime rally in Wall Street that "the 'silent majority' will no longer remain silent."

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 16 An invasion of refugees, panicstricken by the prospect of a Marxist President in Chile, as a result of the election Sept. 4, has packed hotel rooms here and jolted the Argentine economy.

In the recent fourth PanAmerican chess tournament in Havana, 18 players from 15 countries competed. At the end of the round robin there was a three-way first-place tie among International Masters Eleazar Jimenez and Eldis Cobo of Cuba and Orestes Rodriguez of Peru.
CHICAGO, Sept. 16 (AP) The Quaker Oats Corporation said today that Donold B. Lourie had retired as chairman of the board.

DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 16 The Fairfield County Hunt Club's No. 2 team broke a tie with four goals in the last chukker today to defeat the Ox Ridge Hunt Club, 11-8, and ad- vance to the semifinal round of the Governor's Cup polo championship. The game was played at Ox Ridge.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 16--One of Brazil's chief complaints against United States trade policy was satisfied today with the signing of an agreement giving an American import quota to Brazilian textiles.

Arthur J. Goldberg told a crowd of 500 in a Brooklyn synagogue last night that the Nixon Administration had made "one of the worst mistakes ever made by an American Administration," in its handling of the critical Middle East cease-fire negotiations.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 16 "Get out the boat!" has been 3 recurrent war cry in 15 years of Federal efforts to clean up polluted waterways.
The London stock market moved ahead yesterday in quiet trading.

According to the most recent estimates of military strength in Jordan, King Hussein's army has 50,000 to 52,000 men, including four armored brigades, as it faces the Palestinian commandos who have vowed to destroy the state of Israel.
TEL AVIV, Sept. 16 Israeli authorities believe that Jordan is approaching an inevitable showdown between King Hussein and the Palestinian guerrillas.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Sept. 16 Last season, Wesleyan University had its fourth undefeated team since it took up football in 1883 and won its ninth Littie Three championship.

The Walter E. Heller International Corporation, one of the nation's leading commercial finance houses, announced yesterday that it was holding preliminary merger talks with the Security National Bank, Huntington, L.I., and the Abacus Fund, Inc., a closed-end investment company that owns 24.9 per cent of Security.
Three leading singers finally had a chance Tuesday night to appear in roles at the Metropolitan Opera, for which they had been scheduled 11 months earlier.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 16 Miss Elaine Lois Berol, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Berol of New York and Waynesboro, Ga., was married here this afternoon to Scott Bevan Taylor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm P. Taylor of Darien, Conn., and Pompano Beach, Fla.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 16 If Gretel II intends to beat Intrepid, she's going to have to do it on the water and not on the blackboard.
AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 16 If the Texas oil and gas industries are ever to get well, now would appear to be the time, for them to do it.
HARTFORD, Sept. 16 (AP) Janitors did a thorough job of cleaning out Trinity College's art building over the summer but apparently had some trouble deciding what was art and what was junk.

Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers and the Publishers Association of New York City have reached agreement on a new three-year contract, it was announced yesterday by Michael Takvor, business representative for the local. He said a membership meeting last night had ratified the agreement.

The Whitney Museum of American Art has received a grant of $57,000 from the New York State Council on the Arts to be used for 12 scholarships for state students of art and art history and for the museum's exhibition program.

AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 16 The only mediator who has thus far been successful in freeing a single hostage from his Palestinian commando captors is a slender, soft-spoken Oxonian name Michael Adams. Mr. Adams said that he heard news of the hijacking operation from television at his home in Sussex last Sunday. "I had just been watching 'Tom and Jerry' my favorite program an absolute parable of the Mideast situation," he said.

Windfield Farm's talented filly, Deceit, who started her career last March by beating everything in sight while putting together a string of six victories, finally returned to the winner's circle at Belmont Park yesterday.
Three leading singers finally had a chance Tuesday night to appear in roles at the Metropolitan Opera, for which they had been scheduled 11 months earlier.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 16 Miss Elaine Lois Berol, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Berol of New York and Waynesboro, Ga., was married here this afternoon to Scott Bevan Taylor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm P. Taylor of Darien, Conn., and Pompano Beach, Fla.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 16 If Gretel II intends to beat Intrepid, she's going to have to do it on the water and not on the blackboard.
AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 16 If the Texas oil and gas industries are ever to get well, now would appear to be the time, for them to do it.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 16 William Frederick Moore, a member of the board of directors of the Washington Natural Gas Company in Seattle for 20 years, died here Monday in Greenwich Hospital after a brief illness. He was 68 years old and lived on Parsonage Lane.

SOMERVILLE, Mass., Sept. 16 Francis B. Ierardi, the blind man who founded in 1927 Weekly News, the first Braille newspaper published in the Western Hemisphere, died Monday at his home. His age was 84.

Ten persons who visited theCommunist capitals of Asia returned here last night and said that 374 letters from American prisoners of war to their families had been seized by United States Customs agents at Kennedy International Airport. The service declined to confirm or deny the allegation.

TRENTON, Sept, 14 This is not a state where a lot of judges sleep late on weekdays and take an early leave on Friday. Chief Justice Joseph Weintraub won't let them; he checks up to see if they're working and, as he puts it, "'gives them the needle" if they're not.

A Federal jury of nine women and three men was seated yesterday for the trial of eight men from New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Florida accused of unlawful security transactions involving control of the Crescent Corporation, a New Yorkbased conglomerate, and the Pakco Company, Inc., an investment holding company.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 The idea of introducing unleaded gasoline to help clean up the nation's air ran into opposition today from both business and labor on the ground that the cost would be too high.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 16 The 1970 primary election season, which began in Illinois on March 17, came to an end yesterday, with the exception of run-offs in Florida and Georgia and Hawaii's bolloting on Oct. 3.

MONTREAL, Sept. 16 Not even Tom Seaver could stop the slide of the New York Mets tonight as Steve Renko pitched the Montreal Expos to a 4-2 victory and dropped the Mets two full games out of first place.

An apparent case of mistaken identity was resolved yesterday in the Bronx when one brother was replaced by another as the defendant in a case involving the shooting of a child and a man during a purported robbery attempt last year.
Mrs. Ellen James Lewis, wife of Robert J. Lewis, an investment banker, died Tuesday in Presbyterian Hospital. She was 70 years old and lived at 10 East 70th Street.
ARCADIA, Fla., Sept. 16 (AP) Walter Lee Martin, a twice-wounded Vietnam veteran who is now 15 years old, became the father of a son today as he prepared to re-enter the eighth grade.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) A Pentagon official said today that attacks by campus militants and antiwar critics have had little effect on the Reserve Officers Training Corps program and that it would continue to be used as the primary source of officers for the military.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Sept. 16 Al Del Greco, sports columnist for The Record of Bergen County for more than 40 years, died in the Hackensack Hospital today of a coronary embolism. He was 64 years old and lived at 36 Park Avenue in Lodi.

In another significant show of financial muscle, reminiscent of his struggle to solidify the American Football League, Lamar Hunt signed Arthur Ashe to a five-year contract with World Championship Tennis yesterday.

DETROIT, Sept. 16 When a break comes in the General Motors strike and positions begin to change hour by hour, the leaders of the United Automobile Workers will take each new offer from G.M. and ask, "What do you make of it, Irv?" In most instances, Irving Bluestone, the director.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 The Senate passed the bank holding-company bill today, after approving one restrictive amendment and one liberalizing one. The final vote was 77 to 1. The lone opposition vote was cast by Senator William Proximire, Democrat of Wisconsin.

"The Storefront Lawyers," which had its debut last night at 7:30 on the Columbia Broadcasting System, gives every appearance of handily making the grade. Its concept was inspired by the increasing number of young lawyers who want to become socially involved. But, more than that, last night's premiere was a professional hour of television that carried a warning to the gullible not to sign contracts for house repairs at a seeming bargain.

Federal Judge Constance Baker Motley has ordered the receiver for Charles Plohn Co., a liquidating brokerage house, to show cause why he should not be restrained from selling the firm's remaining seat on the New York Stock Exchange to cover obligations to customers and other creditors.

Eileen J. Garrett, trance medium, psychic researcher and author, died Tuesday at St. Roch's Hospital in Nice, France, near where she was attending a conference of the Parapsychology Foundation, Inc., of which the was president. She was 77 years old and lived at 50 Sutton Place South.
The New Yorker Club, an integrated business and social club for businessmen, Government officials and others, got under way yesterday with a firm base, great expectations and a cocktail party.
Sales and earnings of the Beatrice Foods Company for the quarter and six months ended Aug. 31 set records with substantial increases over last year, William G. Karnes, president, reported yesterday.
MOSCOW, Sept. 17 The Soviet Union announced today that its unmanned Luna 16 spacecraft, launched on Saturday, had gone into orbit around the moon.
The executive committee of the Kings County Liberal party last night endorsed Morris Kirsch, the Republican candidate for Brooklyn Borough President, as the Liberal candidate for that office.
The Allied Chemical Corporation announced yesterday that it had increased prices on its entire line of continuous fila-' ment nylon carpet yarn, effective immediately.
CHICAGO, Sept. 17 (AP) The St. Louis Cardinals pounded their season high of 22 hits today including four each by Lou Brock, Joe Torre and Luis Melendez and trounced the Chicago Cubs, 9-2.

Flip Wilson scored last night as the television season's first new hit in variety. The impish comedian not only registered with his own resourcefulness but also was blessed with good material and singular support by David Frost and two of the favorite "Sesame Street" muppets. The show appeared on the National Broadcasting Company network.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 17 (AP) The Sierra Club lost its battle today to block the development of the $35-million Mineral King resort by Walt Disney Productions in the Sequoia National Forest.

YONKERS, Sept. 17 Carmine Abbatiello reported from his home at Colt's Neck, N.J., today that he had shaken off the effects of the spill that hospitalized him last Tuesday night and would drive Ulysse Mab in tomorrow night's $50,000 United Nations Trot at Yonkers Raceway.

GENEVA, Sept. 17 An autoritative source here said today that the question of Israel's direct participation in the negotiations for the hostages' release had become so critical that it would be referred to President Nixon and Premier Golda Meir for settlement.
City housing officials moved yesterday to restore essential services in Bronx apartment houses where they found health hazards resulting from a strike by maintenance workers.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 17 About 1,500 Cambodian relief troops moved today within a few miles of a 4,500-man Government force stalled some 40 miles north of Pnompenh on the road to Kompong Thom, according to a military spokesman.
Scientists reported yesterday two new weapons that, it is hoped, can slow the Dutch elm disease epidemic, which has killed 12 million American elms since the nineteen-thirties.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 Mrs. Dorothy Andrews Elston, the Treasurer of the United States, and Walter Lawrence Kabis, a Wilmington school principal and Delaware state official, were married here tonight, at the chapel of the American University.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 The United States, reacting to the outburst of heavy fighting in Jordan, stepped up precautionary military moves today and left open the possibility of an intervention if American lives were put in peril.

PARIS, Sept. 17 Following, in unofficial translation from the Vietnamese, is a text of remarks made here today by Mrs. Nguyen Thi Binh, head of the Vietcong delegation to the Vietnam talks, on Communist proposals for a peace settlement:
NEWARK, Sept. 17 Phil Foster, the television and nightclub comedian, was indicted on perjury charges today by a Federal grand jury investigating organized crime in New Jersey.

DAYTON, Ohio, Sept. 17 Arthur Beerman, a leading businessman and philanthropist here, died of a heart attack yesterday morning in the Good Samaritan Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 3301 Philadelphia Drive.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (UPI) The front portico of the White House was transformed into a movie set today with all the trappings of the Civil War era.

You don't have to be modern-minded to find "Love" or "Peace" appealing as a furniture motif, or so W J Sloane believes. Two wrought iron chairs incorporating the different messages in their Victorian curlicued backs are now available in the store's remodeled Young Sloane shop

MOSCOW, Sept. 17 Soviet officials have told diplomats and journalists here that they believe a Middle East solution is still possible, but only if the United States applies enough pressure to end Israel's boycott of the United Nations peace talks.
CAIRO, Sept, 17 (AP) The official Middle East News Agency said today that a young man attempted to hijack an Egyptian airliner yesterday between Cairo and Luxor.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 17 American combat casualties in the war have been reduced by about one half in the last year, according to figures released today by the United States command.
The Pontiac Motor division of General Motors has unveiled a new prestige model called the Grand Ville to head its 1971 line-up of 36 models.

RAMALLAH, Israeli-Occupied Jordan, Sept. 17 The men and women of this quiet town on the west bank of the Jordan felt close to the civil strife in Jordan today, knowing their personal and political futures were at stake.
LONDON, Sept 17 She remains in a rented apartment on Davies Street, and when she does go out, moving silently and quickly into a waiting Mercedes-Benz, she is accompanied by Scotland Yard detectives.

The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange, approved yesterday in principle an amendment to the exchange's rules and endorsed several rule changes requiring fuller disclosure of pertinent financial data by member firms.
MILAN, Italy, Sept. 17 (Reuters) Rudolf Nureyev confirmed today that he would dance with the Soviet ballerina Natalya Makarova for the first time later this year.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 17 A lower court judge has been indicted on charges of misconduct in office in connection with the disposition of traffic tickets.
Two youths attacked a blinds man on 42d Street at the height of the evening rush hour yesterday, took his wallet and stole his guide dog.

Activities. President Nixon, in Chicago, met with newspaper editors. He conferred with leaders of Chicago's Polish community and marked Citizenship Day by attending naturalization ceremonies for more than 100 immigrants before returning to Washington. The President also requested Charles W. Yost to revaluate the United States role in the United Nations.
The United States is about to suffer a total loss of one of its least expendable national resources the humorist S.J. Perelman.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 A key antitrust official proposed today that Congress find a middle ground between the two versions of bank holdingcompany legislation that have been approved by the House and the Senate.

Irving Rudd, a former Yonkers Raceway publicity director, was named yesterday to an identical post for New York City's Off-Track Betting Corporation. Howard Samuels, the president of the corporation, made the announcement.

Somehow, Offenbach's "Les Contes d'Hoffmann" never fails to make its effect, and that is not only because of such sure-fire numbers as the Barcarolle and Olympia's aria. A stronge, even uncanny, feeling of doom hangs over the opera in the figure of Hoffmann, that perpetual loser, that fish who is compulsively being hooked on the same bait, that idealist who has the Devil on his heels, constantly being thwarted by him.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 17 Kerala state, which has twice voted communists to power in recent years of political instability, held elections today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 Nicholas Johnson, a member of the Federal Communications Commission, said today that a study group named by President Nixon had reached the wrong conclusion in proposing reorganization of Government agencies, like the F.C.C. that directly regulate business.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 Following is a comparison of the position taken in Paris today by the Vietcong with those put forth in May, 1969, plus those set out by President Nixon in a June, 1969, speech and by President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam in various statements.

There are no surprises in President Nixon's proposals for "fundamental and sweeping reforms" in American foreign-aid programs. The recommendations are based on the report last March of his Task Force on International Development and thus contain most of its strengths but also its shortcomings.

If there is any good reason to support the right of unlimited debate in the Senate at all, there is certainly no good reason for a small minority to prevent a constitutional amendment from coming up for a vote on its merits. Yet thirty-six members of the Senate yesterday joined to prevent a vote on a constitutional amendment abolishing the Electoral College and providing for the direct, popular election of Presidents and Vice Presidents.

Some private universities and colleges in the New York area enrolled 30 to 40 per cent fewer freshmen this month than they had anticipated and officials of the schools attributed the falling off to the City University's open-admissions policy, which guarantees a piace to any high school graduate in the system's tuition-free colleges.
Borough President Percy E. Sutton of Manhattan took issue yesterday with Mayor Lindsay's plan to use several Manhattan piers for cultural and recreational events and urged him to reconsider.
When the the New York Jets open their American Conference season against the Cleveland Browns on Monday night, two rookie cornerbacks will be in their starting defense Earlie Thomas and Steve Tannen.

Dun Bradstreet, Inc., and Vance, Sanders Co., Inc., a large, Boston-based manager and distributor of mutual funds, were sued here yesterday in Federal District Court, in an effort to block the sale for $450,000 by Moody's Investors Service, Inc., a Dun Bradstreet subsidiary, to Vance, Sanders of the right to manage the $30-million Moody's Capital Fund.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 17 Danny Decarlo, who quit as leader of a motorcycle gang to join Charles Manson's "family," testified today that the bearded hippie leader masqueraded as the "devil" in the weeks preceding the murder of the blond movie star Sharon Tate and four others in August, 1969.
DETROIT, Sept. 17 Teams of United Auto Workers and General Motors Corporation officials fanned out around the country today in an effort to activate bargaining on plant level problems.
SIEGEN, Germany, Sept. 17 The United States team scored 2 points against Argentina in three games and adjourned one in the third round tonight of the 19th Chess Olympiad.

DETROIT, Sept. 17 An experimental program designed to put more foot patrolmen into high-crime areas on a permanent basis in an effort to gain community respect and cooperation may be brought to New York City by its new Police Commissioner, Patrick V. Murphy.

ROBINSON, Ill., Sept. 17 (AP) Slender Rich Bassett of Miami, a nonwinner since he joined the Professional Golfers' Association tour in 1967, took a one-stroke lead today in the first-round of the $100,000 Robinson Golf Classic. He scored birdies on eight of the first 12 holes and finished with a 65.
Two unrelated performers, Dave Cooper and Reg Cooper, brought a touch of the English folk clubs on Wednesday night to the Folklore Center, 321 Avenue of the Americas.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 The occupational health and safety bill, which organized labor and must Democrats are committed to passing in this session of Congress, appears to be in trouble in the Senate.
The Chelsea Theater Center of Brooklyn will open its sixth season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Oct. 28 with the New York premiere of Edward Bond's "Saved." Alan Schneider will direct.

BELGRADE, Sept. 17 The scheduled meeting between Presidents Nixon and Tito, the first visit by a United States head of state to Communist Yugoslavia, will be an "opportunity for asserting and further promoting" the good relations between the two countries as well as for "an exchange of views on topical international issues," an official Foreign Ministry spokesman said here today.

Although the news from Jordan and the violated Suez cease-fire zone may be more dramatic, the meeting of Israel's Premier Golda Meir with President Nixon today is likely to have greater long-term impact on the prospects for peace or general war in the Middle East.

The heads of the Conservative ticket openly differed with each other last night on the handling of the narcotics problem. The two candidates were making a joint appearance before Queens supporters at a $100-a-plate fund-raising dinner at Riccardo's Restaurant in Astoria, Queens.

TANNERSVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 17 In a farewell speech, George P. McManus, retiring chief insepctor of the New York City Police Department, appealed today to policemen for unity, and warned them not to fall victim to "increasing polarization" along racial or religious lines.
DETROIT, Sept. 17 The General Motors Corporation said today it would begin installing a new type of antipollution device in its cars in two years and all of its 1975 cars would carry it.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 The United States is considering providing Israel with up to $500-million in financial assistance by allowing her to defer payments on old and recent arms agreements, reliable Administration sources said today.
BUFFALO, Sept. 17 Two State University campus security policemen were slashed with razor-like knives yesterday by youths.

Mrs. Diana Crocker Redington of New York, daughter of the late William W. Crocker, who was president of the Crocker Citizens Bank of San Francisco, was married here yesterday to Edmond J. Nouri of New York and Amagansett, L.I., president of E.J. Nouri Associates, general agents for the New England Mutual Life Insurance Company.
A newly impaneled grand jury is trying to find out how many policemen are stealing and selling confidential information of the city Police Department.

An assistant professor of history, under indictment for allegedly threatening to destroy a computer installation at New York University last May, was dismissed by the school yesterday for what was described as disruptive conduct.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17 A sold-out audience of 3,000 gave the Philadelphia Orchestra, under Eugene Ormandy, and Rudolf Serkin, the pianist, a warm reception last night at the first gala non-subscription concert in the orchestra's 71st season.

In beautiful weather, with no more than 6,000 people in Yankee Stadium to disturb the peacefulness of the Bronx, the New York Yankees messed themselves up in various ways yesterday and officially eliminated themselves from the American League East pennant race by losing to the Boston Red Sox, 5-4, in 10 innings.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 The House Commerce Subcommittee completed action today on a broker-dealer insurance bill that is somewhat more to the liking of the securities industry than the Senate Banking Committee's version.
FORT HOOD, Tex., Sept. 17 (AP) S. Sgt. David Mitchell listened intently today as he was accused on a television news film of ordering an old man shot during the alleged Songmy massacre.
