Cockatoo a parrot and a bird of paradise: Cocteau mimicked others ("Orphee," "Antigone," "Oedipus Rex") and preened his feathers in Parisian salons. Cocktail-an appurtenance, a concoction:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 President Nixon has intervened with all the Republican members of the Senate Finance Committee and most of the Democrats in a last-ditch effort to save his welfare reform program.

Fred M. Thrower, president of WPIX-TV, testified yesterday that he was unaware that his station had used audio reports from a Daily News writer during the 1968 Soviet-Czechoslovak crisis, but had identified him on the air as a WPIX newsman.
Sudden seizures of idle curiosity about why Culdesac, Idaho, is called that, or how such places as What Cheer, R. I., or X-Ray, Texas, got their names need no longer go unsated.
One of the most ambitious urban-renewal plans in the city's history, covering a 40acre area of downtown Brooklyn, was approved by the Board of Estimate yesterday after a raucous public hearing.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 17 Mrs.A.C. Randolph's Lord Sutler, who has won 10 championships in a row, captured two classes in the green conformation hunter division today as the Piping Rock horse show opened for a four-day run.

SAN DIEGO, Sept. 17 John V. Tunney, a Democrat, is 36 years old weighs 190 pounds, stands 6 feet 3 inches tall, has a Dutch wife, three children, and a wide smile. He has been in the House of Representatives six years and would like to become a Senator.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) Virginia Knauer, Presidential assistant for consumer affairs, said today that corporate concentration was at the heart of consumer problems and that "vigorous antitrust activity may well be the consumers' best friend."

LONDON, Sept 17. The British Government issued a plea to Arab guerrillas today to safeguard the lives of the eight British hostages in Jordan and said that it was taking steps with other governments to protect all the hostages.

MILFORD, Conn., Sept. 17 The strike of teachers here which began Sept. 9, the third day of the new school year ended today following unanimous acceptance last night of a contract giving raises ranging from $780 to $1,300.

BEIRUT, Lebanon; Sept. 17 Following are excerpts from broadcasts today by the three commando radios, the Central Committee of the Palestine liberation movement, broadcasting on the Damascus radio, the Central Commitee from its own radio broadcasting from Baghdad, and Voice of Al Asifa, the radio voice of Al Fatah, the largest commando organization, broadcasting from an undisclosed location:

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 17 A one-sided battle between a 32-boat Coast Guard fleet and a 1,000 boat spectator fleet provided the only America's Cup excitement here today. It was no contest, the Coast Guard winning easily.
Indians, saints and accidents of spelling are among the sources from which places get their names.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (UPI) The Senate voted today to revamp Federal manpower training programs drastically and create 150,000 public service jobs for the hard-core unemployed before next summer.
ROME, Sept. 17 Howard R. Leary, who resigned as New York City's Police Commissioner less than two weeks ago, is vacationing in Europe in a new role that of ordinary tourist and very private citizen.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 Officials of the Treasury Department and the White House insisted today that the Nixon Administration's proposed tax on gasoline lead additives was primarily intended to help reduce smog, rather than raise more funds, as some critics have contended.
LONDON, Sept. 17 (Reuters) Insurance rates for freight shipped to and from the Middle East were increased up to 400 per cent by the Institute of London Underwriters tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 Instead of attacking rock music for spreading a "drug culture" among youngsters, Vice President Agnew should worry about political contributors whose corporations sell drugs, cigarettes and liquor, a Federal Communications Commission member said today.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 17 (AP) Gennady Ivanchenko of the Soviet Union lifted a world record 1,113 pounds tonight to capture the light-heavyweight title in the world weight-lifting championships.
In the oil exploration game, a world in which puffery is not unheard of, Charles Hann definitely must be regarded as a low-key operator.
At a private luncheon with New York news executives yesterday, Mrs. Meir stressed Israel's need for secure and recognized borders but refrained from mentioning any specific areas as nonnegotiable.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 17 (AP) The denial of a college stadium for a rally was blamed by some today for touching off Mexican-American violence last night that injured 88 persons 18 days after an outburst that left three dead.

WASHINGTON, Sept 17 (AP) The Food and Drug Administration said today that more than half a million Oh Henry nut roll candy bars manufactured in June were possibly contaminated with potentially hazardous bacteria.

HAMBURG, West Germany, Sept. 17 Prosperous West Germany is currently watching the rare spectacle of a troubled chemical-fiber company seeking reorganization through the abrupt cutting of almost half of its producing capacity.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 The proposal for direct popular election of the President was dealt a serious and probably fatal blow today when the Senate refused to shut off debate on the issue.
The senate of New York University rejected a proposal yesterday calling for a recess prior to the November election to enable students to work for political candidates.
The city's Board of Health ruled yesterday that physicians here must stop performing abortions in their private offices by Oct. 19.
Yulian Grigoryevich Oksman, a Russian literary critic and social historian, died Tuesday in Moscow. He was 75 years old.
The American Stock Exchange made a strong advance yesterday as the exchange's price index closed at its highest level in almost five months in active trading.

A month after the start of Governor Rockefeller's radio and television campaign, Arthur J. Goldberg began this week a limited radio and television campaign highlighting his new campaign theme. "Leadership for a Change."
More than 2,000 welfare mothers and children paraded from City Hall across the Brooklyn Bridge yesterday, demanding Federal aid to buy school clothes.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 17 (UPI) Bob Watson's tie-breaking grand-slam homer in the seventh inning gave the Houston Astros a 10-5 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight. The outcome enabled the idle Cincinnati Reds to clinch first place in the National League West.
After a two-hour hearing, the Board of Estimate postponed a decision last night on a controversial plan for rezoning lower Third Avenue for a mixture of luxury and public housing.

HARRISON, N.Y., Sept. 17 Mrs. E.C.K. Finch of the Country Club of New Canaan, Conn, scored 40, 35 75 over the 5,655-yard, par 72 South course at Westchester Country Club today in rallying to win the 47th annual championship of the United States Senior Women's Golf Association by two strokes. She totaled 161 for 36 holes.
The stock market extended yesterday its current rally, which is based mainly upon anticipation of a broad-scale cut in the 8 per cent prime rate by major banks.

Vincent D. McDonnell, chairman of the State Mediation Board, met yesterday with negotiatiors for the Publishers Association of New York City and for Paperhandlers Union No. 1 in an effort to help resolve the impasse in their bargaining talks.

Opponents of Consolidated Edison's proposed pumped storage hydropower generating plant at Storm King Mountain filed with the Federal Power Commission in Washington yesterday an 8,000-word application for a rehearing.

AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 17 Troops and tanks under the orders of King Hussein's new military Government swept into the capital today for a showdown battle with the Palestinian guerrillas, and by midafternoon the army seemed to be gaining the upper hand.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 The Navy announced today plans to deactivate 58 ships, including the aircraft carrier Shangri-La, currently operating off Vietnam.

Sir Walter Scott's life resembles nothing so much as a stretch of faultless spring days or a series of youthful holidays. Everything conspired to make his life one to envy: his unremitting successes, his family life, his standing in the community, his winning and attractive character, He was a good neighbor, a responsible citizen, an unsullied magistrate. SUMTER, S.C., Sept. 17 Robert E. Scoggin, former Ku Klux Klan grand dragon, was arrested by the state police today after he and nine klan associates had been charged. with conspiracy to commit robbery and accessory after the fact of murder.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 Administration officials found nothing promising for negotiation in their initial readings today of the Vietcong's revised peace proposals at Paris.
The new television season is upon us in case you haven't noticed. And the word from the three networks is that for the fall at least the commercial time has sold pretty well.

Eldridge Cleaver, head of the Black Panther party's international section, in Algiers, headed a group of 11 persons who filed suit here yesterday demanding the return of 9,000 feet of film seized Wednesday by United States Customs agents at Kennedy International Airport.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 17 A spokesman for the Palestinian hijackers said today that, the heavy shelling in Amman made no difference in the hijackers' terms for release of the 54 or 55 airline hostages presumably still held in or near the embattled Jordanian capital.
The restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored where indicated.
The director of the city's $35-million loan program for building owners was suspended yesterday after he refused to complete a financial questionnaire for the Department of Investigation.
LONDON, Sept. 17 (AP) King Hussein of Jordan talked over his amateur radio set with fellow "hams" in the United States last night as troops and guerrillas battled in Amman.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 The television industry and several drug companies have agreed to tone down commercials for stimulants, depressants and sleeping aids.
Mrs. Wallace Whittaker's Tingle Creek covered the 2 mile steeplechase course in the record time of 4 minutes 37 seconds yesterday in taking the $17,500 Broad Hollow at Belmont Park.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) Personal income rose $4-billion in August to an annual rate of $807.4-billion, with wage and salary disbursements accounting for more than half of the increase, the Commerce Department reported today.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 17 Major violence in this city gave way to sporadic fire-bombings last night.

BUFFALO On Halloween, 1968, Governor Rockefeller broke ground on a 1,200-acre tract of land in suburban Amherst near here for a new campus of the State University at Buffalo that he said was "the most promising new development to emerge in Buffalo since the opening of the Erie Canal in 1825."
BRUSSELS, Sept. 17 A congress of ranking Roman Catholic theologians called today for more democratic methods of selecting popes, bishops and pastors.

Interest rates moved down sharply in the money and capital markets yesterday amid more talk that the nation's biggest banks would cut the prime rate or that the Federal Reserve would reduce the discount rate.

The American Jewish Committee honored the Roman Catholic Bishop of Brooklyn yesterday on his recent appointment as moderator of the secretariat for Catholic-Jewish Relations of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops.

Albert A. Walsh, head of the Housing and Development Administration, yesterday called the city's record for building suitable housing for old people "very poor." He proposed that a separate nonprofit corporation be created to handle only the building of housing for the elderly.

Surendering to a court order, the State Athlete Commission indicated yesterday that it would grant Muhammad Ali a boxer's license when he submitted an application. But relicensing will not automatically reinstate recognition of him as the world heavyweight champion.
LIVERPOOL, N.Y., Sept. 17 Governor Rockefeller reject ed another request today that the state investigate corruption in the New York City Police Department.

KITCHENER, Ontario, Sept. 17 The long-awaited clash in hockey between management and players erupted at the New York Rangers' camp today as Coach Emile Francis suspended four of the team's stars for refusing to play a preseason game tonight without contracts.
The Big Six mayors will seek more money and more homerule power from the state in an encore to their successful campaign that pressured Albany into raising state aid this year.

MIAMI BEACH, Sept. 17 (UPI) Cassius Clay, training here for his bout with Jerry Quarry, today after learning of the New York State Athletic Commission's decision to grant him a boxing license, said: "I think it's good, really, really good. I just hope I'll be in shape when the time comes for me to earn a living again.

ALBANY, Sept. 17 A group of 200 international scientists and industrial representatives began meeting here today to study ways of converting waste heat from power plants from a conservationist's bane into a possible ecological boon.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 Attorney General John N. Mitchell expressed confidence today that the terrorist bombings occurring around the country could be brought under control by curtailing the supply of explosives and rounding up the "maniacs" he said were committing the bombings.

The American Medical Association has charged that the Food and Drug Administration is trying to make it more difficult for physicians to prescribe drugs under certain circumstances and thereby is attempting to "regulate the practice of medicine."

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Sept. 17 (AP) Tupamaro guerrillas sent an antigovernment manifesto to news media today and demanded its immediate publication as ransom for Claude L. Fly, United States soul expert kidnapped in early August.

PORT JERVIS, N.J., Sept. 17 Charles William Hagen, Sr., a retired New York admiralty lawyer, who had served as a special commissioner in connection with the claims filed in the Morro Castle disaster, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in Cahoonzie.

WASHINGTON Sept. 17 The president of the Airline Pilots Association International, an official of the airline stewards' union and a stewardess who had flown aboard a hijacked plane expressed strong reservations today about President Nixon's decision to put armed guards on passenger planes to prevent aerial piracy.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Sept. 17 When President Nixon's tough Kansas State speech against the fist and bullet university activists gets serious praise on the much more liberal Stanford University campus, it is a fairly good sign that the 1970 school year is opening on a different note.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 Heeding demands of reformers, the House passed by a 326-to19 vote today a bill to streamline Congressional procedures.
Once again Arabs are fighting Arabs in Jordan.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Sept. 17 Mrs. Walter Cooperstein of Glen Oaks, the defending champion, led the way into the final of the 15th annual Women's Cross-County Golf Association match-play championship today with a 4-and-2 victory over Mrs. Gordon McGrath of Piping Rock at the Cold Spring Country Club. Par for the 5,861-yard course is 37,36-73.
WASHINGTON An immense distinction must be drawn between the positions of Premier Meir and President Nixon as they meet in the White House. Mrs. Meir is negotiating for Israel's existence.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 17 International action against hijacking and the kidnapping of hostages was urged here today in speeches and in private meetings.

Judge John P. Fullam of the Federal District Court took under advisement yesterday the petition of the trustees of the Penn Central Transportation Company to defer payment of some $45-million of state and local property taxes that have become payable since June 21, or will fall due by Dec. 31.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 The Department of the Interior announced today that it would soon begin sending questionnaires to all segments of American industry in order to compile an inventory of the plants that are polluting the nation's waterways, and the nature and amount of the pollutants.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17(AP) Senator William Proxmire says the Air Force is rewriting a contract for production of the costly C-5A transport plane and has engineered "one of the greatest Government giveaways ever attempted in a single stroke."

The City Center of Music and Drama, Inc., has announced plans for its third edition of "A City Center Sampling," a series of 16 events to be given from October through March. The programs will be presented at the New York State Theater, at the City Center's West 55th Street theater and at the ANTA Theater.

ALBANY, Sept. 17 Francis Patrick Fleming, director of the office of public information of the State Civil Defense Commission here for the last 10 years, drowned Monday while swimming in Bergen Lake near Troy. He was 52 years old and lived in Slingerlands.

PORTMARNOCK, Ireland, Sept. 17 (AP) Bruce Devlin, an Australian now living in Florida, managed to control his game during gale force winds today and posted a threeunder-par 69 for the first round lead in the Alcan Golfer of the Year tournament. He gained a three-stroke edge.

The New York Giants are going to see Jack Concannon at quarterback for the Chicago Bears in the opening game here of the National Football League season tomorrow night. Concannon is the quarterback the Giants beat last season in the third game, and on that occasion
The London stock market advanced moderately yesterday in quiet and cautious trading.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 Still buoyed by his reception yesterday at Kansas State University, President Nixon bounced around Chicago today for a series of appearances designed in part to help the political fortunes of Senator Ralph T. Smith.
SEATTLE A few weeks ago, a Seattle newspaper carried a brief article under the headline: "Flow of Raw Sewage Into Elliot Bay Ends."
The New York and American Stock Exchanges have just issued their latest reports of changes in holdings by major stockholders, directors and officers of listed companies.

The only pennant race in the four major league divisions gets down to an eyeball-to-eyeball confrontation tonight at Shea Stadium, where neither the Pittsburgh Pirates nor the Mets need spend much time looking at out-of-town results.

TEANECK, N.J., Sept. 17 Harold Gold, public relations manager of WPIX, Inc., died here yesterday at the Jersey City Medical Center after a brief illness. He was 54 years old and lived at 728 Chestnut Avenue.

The World Bank's latest report on its expanding role in assisting developing countries is both dramatic and timely. It coincides with President Nixon's proposal to channel an increasing share of American aid through such international institutions and it provides solid evidence for the wisdom of this move.

Goodbody Co., one of the nation's largest brokerage houses, will be acquired by the Shareholders Capital Corporation, a major mutual fund organization, for about $9.4-million in securities under terms of an agreement disclosed yesterday.

Senator Charles E. Goodell told 2,000 students at Queens College yesterday that "violence is to be abhorred Whether it is pursued in the name of revolution or in the name of law and order, whether practiced by students or sheriff's deputies, whether perpetrated by Weathermen or Minutemen."

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 17 Marshal Habes Majali, commander of the Jordanian armed forces, proposed a cease-fire late in the day, following which the guerrillas would move out with their arms to bases along the Jordan River facing Israelioccupied territory.

PARIS, Sept. 17 The Vietcong, with the support of North Vietnam, declared today that in exchange for an agreement on the withdrawal of all American and other foreign forces from South Vietnam by June 30 of next year, the Communists would refrain from attacking the withdrawing troops.
Officials of the Lindsay administration said yesterday that the city was drawing up a plan to allow buses to operate on four local parkways where they have previously been banned.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 The Securities and Exchange Commission warned investors, banks and others today to beware of accepting what it flatly labeled the "spurious" financial instruments of J.P. Morgan Co., Ltd., of London.

Profit taking and speculation sent grains and soybeans futures tumbling, yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Oats, iced broilers and soybean oil and meal futures also fell under the onslaught of selling orders.

Robert H. McBride, the United States Ambassador to Mexico, asserted yesterday that improved relations of this country with its southern neighbor were generating encouraging progress in economic and trade cooperation.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17 The "adventurous" Pittsburgh Pirates, wasting a strong comeback performance by Dock Ellis, preceded their four-game visit to New York by losing to the Philadelphia Phillies, 3-2, tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 The Securities and Exchange Commission closed its case today against Winfield Co., Inc., and some affiliated firms and individuals with an announcement of the acceptance of long suspensions and other penalties by the defendants in the case.
Two Boeing 747 jetliners, one headed for Kennedy International Airport yesterday and the other taking off from it, ran into contrasting troubles but came through unscathed.
CHICAGO, Sept. 17 (UPI) Like many visitors to Chicago, President Nixon went shopping today at Marshall Field Co.

GENEVA, Sept. 17 Among the more than 50 hostages still held by the Arab commandos is Specialist 4 Kenneth Hubler, an American soldier who was on his way back to the United States after he escaped from Vietcong captivity, a spokesman for Swissair said in Zurich today.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 17 The five-race national championship in Shields Class yachting began today with Patrick O'Neal and Shawhan Fox, both of the sponsoring Larchmont Yacht Club, sharing two victories. Protest hearings in wholesale lots followed the races.
REGGIO CALABRIA, Italy, Sept. 17 (Reuters) Demonstrators fired on policemen from the city's cathedral tonight with pistols, rifles and submachine guns, the police said.

Winning two national titles in one tournament is a rare feat, and it is necessary to search the record books carefully to find cases in which a single player has won three major events.

PESCARA, Italy, Sept. 17 (Reuters) Alfredo Bonazzi, a convicted murderer, has received his 12th poetry prize after a special trip from jail to get the award in this eastern Italian town.
UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 17 Clary Anderson gave up a most successful coaching career at Montclair High School last year to take the football coaching position at Montclair State College.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 17 (UPI) Eight black players suspended from the Syracuse University football squad signed a statement today indicating a desire to rejoin the team.

WINONA, Minn., Sept. 17 Miss Elizabeth Tweedy, a researcher with the Whitney Museum of American Art in New York, and Marshall G. Streibert, who is with the John Price Jones Company, a fund-raising concern in New York, plan to be married here next month.
NEW HAVEN, Sept. 17 Fourteen union leaders were jailed today after they had refused to pay fines of $100 each for continuing the seven-day strike by 2,000 teachers here and in West Haven, a suburb.
MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 17 When Hubert H. Humphrey is up, he is very, very up. Last night he was in vintage form as he savored his victory in Tuesday's Senatorial primary election here.

"Temporarily Out of Order" was the operative phrase yesterday at "Software," the Jewish Museum's new show concerning information processing systems. On its opening day, the, exhibition was plagued by a short-circuited computer that crippled some electronic gear, the destruction of a series of, films about participating artists, and charges by two of the show's contributors that the museum had censored their work.
Fernard Legros, an art dealer living in Switzerland, filed a $55-million libel suit here yesterday against the author and publisher of the book "Fake," which was published last year.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) The shipping industry and its unions have helped to raise a $37,000 campaign fund for the chairman of the House Merchant Marine Committee, who is unopposed for reelection.
The Federal Reserve System's credit policy was easy and the demand for loans at money-center banks was sluggish during the last two weeks, banking data published yesterday showed.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Sept. 17 Larry Catuzzi expressed confidence today that his Williams College football team would be able to play on even terms with any of its opponents this fall.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 Freight traffic on United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage in the latest week ended Sept. 12 were both considerably below the volume in the corresponding week of last year.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 17 Israel watched the long-expected civil war across the Jordan River cease-fire line today and waited.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 17 Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Langstaff Crow Jr. have announced the engagement of Mr. Crow's daughter, Miss Deborah Montgomery Crow, to Peter Westbrook Mills, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Ensign Mills of New Canaan, Conn., and Schermerhorn Landing, Thousand Islands. The wedding is planned for January.

When the expanded peace talks in Paris began to take shape late in 1968, even some members of the National Liberation Front's delegation hinted that Mrs. Nguyen Thi Binh's leadership of its side would last only as long as the talks were in the preliminary.

A spokesman for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that the agency's officials were in general agreement with criticisms of the subway system cited in advertisements by the Transport Workers Union.

It's an ill wind, indeed, that blows the cosmetics companies no good. Pollution, for instance. The stories emerging daily about this country's dirty environment are inspiring new creams and lotions to protect women's faces from the ravages of soot-filled air and questionable water.

ATHENS, Sept. 18 A panel of magistrates has ruled that there were no grounds for taking criminal action against Stavros S. Niarchos in connection with the death of his wife last May. The case is not closed, however, since the decision can be appealed to a higher tribunal. [The prosecutor plans to appeal the decision, The Associated Press reported.]

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 The White House was reported today to have ended an unusually long and difficult search for a qualified Republican to head the United States Bureau of Mines by selecting Dr. Elburt F. Osborn, vice president for research of Pennsylvania State University, for the job.

There is little danger that a gunfight aboard a hijacked airliner could cause serious enough damage either to the structure or to controls to cause a crash, Government and airlineindustry experts agree.

PARIS, Sept. 18 A Chase Manhattan Bank economist warned Europeans today that their efforts to construct a common currency would be successful only if steps were taken to deal effectively with the deeply rooted differences between European nations.

BEIRUT, Sept. 18 "If the commandos can score a real military victory, and by that we mean forbidding an army victory, then we will be able to force our conditions," a guerrilla intellectual said in Beirut today.

A defense lawwyer asked a Criminal Court judge yesterday to find someone more "impartial" than Manhattan District Attorney Frank S. Hogan to prosecute his client, a rabbi charged with disrupting a temple service last spring.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 The White House announced today that President Nixon had accepted "with regret" the resignation of Carl L. Klein as Assistant Secretary of the Interior for water Quality and Research.
LONDON, Sept. 18 Jimi Hendrix, the American rock star whose passionate, intense guitar playing stirred millions, died here today of unknown causes. He was 27 years old.

A 20-year-old man accused of beating a one-year-old child to death to stop him from crying was indicted yesterday by a Bronx grand jury on charges of murder and criminally negligent homicide. The defendant,
ELIZABETH, N. J., Sept. 18 Joseph L. Kaplan of 13 Tudor Court, a lawyer with offices in Newark for many years, died yesterday in Beth Israel Medical Center, Newark. His age was 63.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Sept. 18 A policeman was shot and killed early this morning while sitting in his patrol car with a partner a short distance from the headquarters of the Black Panther party here.

PARIS, Sept. 18 (AP) David K. E. Bruce, head of the United States delegation to the Paris talks, scrambled the wine and the bottles yesterday in talking about peace proposals presented by Mrs. Nguyen Thi Binh of the Vietcong.

Pledging to "involve community people in the decisions of government" and to work for better housing and more job opportunities, Sebastian Leone was formally sworn in yesterday as the interim Borough President of Brooklyn.
LONDON, Sept. 18 Pergamon Press, Ltd., battered and torn by rows, litigation and a Government inquiry, estimated today that it would lose $3,177,000 in the fiscal year ending Sept. 30.

GENEVA, Sept. 18 $5-million of a loan of up to $15-million being made by the International Controls Corporation of New Jersey to Investors Overseas Services has been placed in escrow, an I.O.S. spokesman said tonight.
Bertram Weal, manager of the Tuscany Hotel, 120 East 39th Street, from 1938 to 1969, died yesterday after a heart attack in New York Hospital. He lived in the Lombardy Hotel, 111 East 56th Street.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 Employes of the Government do not enjoy unrestrained freedom to criticize its policies in public, a high Justice Department official said today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 18--Foreign Minister Tran Van Lam of South Vietnam said here today that the Vietcong proposal might be a trap and was in any case a propaganda move. He noted that Mrs. Binh "said they would stop attacking during the withdrawal of American troops."

SIEGEN, Germany, Sept. 18 The United States team defeated Argentina this morning when Bobby Fischer of California, playing first board, won his adjourned third-round game with Miguel Najdorf, posting a 3-1 victory in the 19th Chess Olympiad here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 Middle-level officials of the Food and Drug Administration are considering placing limits on the amount of saccharin that may be consumed, although they have no proof that the artifical sweetener is harmful to human beings.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) Representative Wright Patman, chairman of the House Banking Committee, today accused David Rockefeller of "a shameful charade of tired excuses for failing to lower interest rates."

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 18 Mrs. Jacqueline Riordan, widow of Michael R. Riordan, founder and head of the Los Angeles-based Equity Funding Corporation, and George F. Getty 2d, operating chief of the Getty Oil Company here, plan to be married in the spring.

Jim Hall, the jazz guitarist, made a concert tour of Japan a few weeks ago during which he renewed an old acquaintance with a cellist, Isao Suzuki. For his current engagement at the Guitar, 10th Avenue at 51st Street, Mr. Hall had planned to team his guitar with Mr. Suzuki's cello. However, en route here from Japan, Mr. Suzuki was snapped up by Art Blakey's Jazz Messengers.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UPI) The Nixon Administration went on record today against legislation to ban disposable beverage bottles and cans at this time.

Lusterware at its best is the subject of the current exhibition of 15th-century Hispano-Moresque pottery that will be on view at the Cloisters until Dec. 1.

LARCHMOIVT, N.Y., Sept. 18 The national championship of the Shields Class is on the verge of leaving Long Island Sound for the first time since the sailing event originated five years ago. Lance McCabe of the Balboa Yacht Club in Southern California sailed to victory in one race and was seventh in another today. Tomorrow's fifth and last race will tell the tale.
LONDON, Sept, 18 The British Government made it clear to Israel today that it felt some Palestinian prisoners must be freed for the airline hostagcs now held in Jordan.
HIGHLAND PARK, N. J., Sept. 18 Mr. and Mrs. George W. DeVoe have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Edith Marion DeVoe, to David Charles Klink.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 18 The South Vietnamese Senate passed a bill today allowing President Nguyen Van Thieu to devalue the piaster for certain transactions, but it refused to give him the special economic powers that he had sought. The bill now goes back to the House of Representatives.

NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 18 "Don't you think the American people are terribly interested in the America's Cup?" asked B. Devereux Barker 3d. He quickly answered his question. "I think the American people are terribly interested in the America's Cup. They prize it. America has lost a lot in recent year's, here's one thing we've never lost. Even Americans who know nothing about sailing know about the America's Cup."

David L. Wasser, a New York lawyer, said yesterday that he had filed a suit against the New York Stock Exchange on behalf of customers of Robinson Co., a former member of the exchange that has filed under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

A $500 reward was offered by two humane societies yesterday for the return of a guide dog stolen from a blind man who was beaten and robbed by two youths on 42d Street near Fifth Avenue at the height of

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 18 Fierce fighting persisted for a second day in Amman and northern Jordan today as the Jordanian Army failed to score the quick knockout of Palestinian guerrilla forces it had presumably expected.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 Robert J. Affeldt, a civil rights official in the Department of Housing and Urban Development, resigned today, charging that the Nixon Administration was "encouraging and perpetuating racial discrimination."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 President Nixon has underscored the strong American interest in the survival of the Jordanian Government by saying privately that he would be inclined to intervene in Jordan if outside countries such as Iraq and Syria were to join the fight against King Hussein.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 The scenario for Vice President Agnew's appearance at a Republican rally in Albuquerque, N. M., the other night called for him to "enter stage left" and "exit stage right."

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept 18 Easy Money, a former national junior high-point champion, captured the amateurowner jumper title with strong performances in two classes today at the mist-shrouded Piping Rock Horse Show.

In New York City, an organizer of the New York branch of the Black Panther party was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court, the Bronx, to a 25-year-to-life term in prison in connection with a fatal shooting last year.
Controller Abraham D. Beame has hired an outside lawyer to help him in his legal fight with the Lindsay administration over the hiring of oustide consultants without public hearings.
SKOUN, Cambodia, Sept. 18 Some 3,000 Government relief troops and a supply convoy today linked up with a task force of about 4,500 soldier seeking to liberate Kompong Thom from enemy encirclement.
ALBANY, Sept. 18 Supreme Court Justice A. Franklin Mahoney today ruled Richard L. Ottinger's Conservation party back on the ballot for the Nov. 3 election.
RAMALLAH, Israeli-Occupied Jordan, Sept. 18 Dr. Hamdi Taji Farouki, a physician and political leader here, paused in a discussion of the fighting in Jordan and said:

After several days in which white youths had harassed and assaulted some black students at South Shore High School, officials, students and neighborhood youths met yesterday in an attempt to ease the situation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 The National Committee for a Political Settlement in Vietnam announced today that 16 Senators had joined 14 others in urging President Nixon to propose a cease-fire in South Vietnam.

If the late George Orwell were writing a sequel to "1984" today, he would probably reject as archaic the propaganda techniques for controlling people's minds described in his famous anti-Utopian classic. Today, for example, he might envisage a society in which a newborn baby's first experience would be neurosurgery, an operation in which the child's brain was fitted with miniaturized radio devices connected to every major center controlling reason and emotion.

NEWARIC, Sept. 18 The indictments of six men described by Frederick B. Lacey, the United States Attorney here, as members of "one of the largest, if not the largest, shylocking operations in the history of New Jersey" were made public here today.

Elbridge W. Stein, a handwriting expert who had testified on the authenticity of signatures and documents in leading court cases, died Thursday in Sarasota, Fla., where he had lived in retirement since 1950. He was 90 years old.
REGGIO CALABRIA, Italy, Sept. 18 Hundreds of rioters battled with the police and built barricades today following a night of clashes in which two persons died.
NEWPORT, R. L, Sept. 18 Gretel II, the sloop the Australian press ridiculed as a "blunderboat" earlier this week, packed a lot more thunder than blunder today on the America's Cup course.
DETROIT, Sept. 18 (AP) Senator Philip A. Hart, Democrat of Michigan, today condemned youths who shouted obscenities at Vice President Agnew in Michigan Wednesday.

MONTREAL, Sept. 18 (AP) The United States called on member countries of the Inter national Civil Aviation Organization today to suspend air services to and from countries that fail to act against hijackers.

YONKERS, Sept. 18 Fresh Yankee of Canada defeated Une de Mai of France and six other standardbreds in the $50,000 United Nations Trot at Yonkers Raceway tonight. The 1 -mile race, timed in a comparatively slow 3:08 1/5, was one of the roughest events staged here in recent years.
Roger C. Wilkins, president of the Travelers Insurance Companies, criticized the life insurance industry yesterday for talking in language that many people find difficult to understand.

MOSCOW, Sept. 18 (AP) Jordanian students staged a peaceful two-hour sit-in today at Jordan's embassy here to protest King Nussein's proclamation of a military regime and "Government atrocities" against Palestinian guerrillas.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y. If there isn't enough cheesecake batter in a batch to fill the last crumb-lined pan, then Arthur Reid knows he has made a mistake.

Representative Richard L. Ottinger, meeting yesterday with 15 editors of foreign-language newspapers in the city was questioned closely about his views on foreign policy by the journalists, many of whom had had first-hand experience with dictatorial regimes abroad.
Suppose you decide to put your shares in a "street name." These shares, held in the broker's name for the customer's account, provide ease of trading since they can be delivered by the broker direct.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 18 Dr. Warren Porter, a young zoologist, was overjoyed when his desert lizard emerged from its burrow at 10.23 today. It was only a minute earlier than the Professor had predicted after weeks of studying how the slightest environmental changes affect a lizard's daily life.
LONDON, Sept. 18 Philympia, the 1970 international stamp show, opened here today with an attendance estimated at 10,000 people.

CAIRO, Sept. 18 This capital, to which Arabs seem to look in times of strife and crisis, was trying urgently today to halt the fighting in Jordan without giving offense either to the Jordanians or the Palestinian guerrillas.
A group of black businessmen in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn announced plans yesterday to develop 100 new businesses employing more than 1,000 people in the next two years.

Continued friction between Fred M. Thrower, president of WPIX, and Pat Valicenti, a Federal Communications Commission examiner, marked yesterday's session of the hearings into the challenge of WPIX's broadcast license.

Governor Rockefeller stepped up his effort to involve the Federal Government in narcotics control yesterday by calling for political, economic and diplomatic pressure on France and Turkey, the sources, Mr. Rockefeller said, of most of the raw heroin imported here.

An obscure bidding situation arises when an opening minor-suit bid is followed by an overcall of two no-trump. After a major suit it is clear that such a bid should be "unusual," promising length in clubs and diamonds. Some players retain this interpretation after a minor suit has been bid, but such a treatment is open to question.

Dr. Dan M. Gordon, a leading eye specialist, died Thursday in New York Hospital, after a brief illness. He was 63 years old and lived at 435 70th Street and at 78 Hampton Road, Scarsdale, N.Y. His office was at 441 East 68th Street.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UPI) Attorney General John N. Mitchell was quoted today as having said that students, professors and "these stupid bastards who are ruining our educational institutions" were uninformed about the issues within government.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) Secretary of State William P. Rogers forecasts that the United States trade balance might improve significantly this year and could reach a surplus of $3.5-billion, the State Department said today.
The stock market managed to finish ahead yesterday, although the final gains were nowhere near the midday highs.
A group of 130 young men and women who had been high school dropouts but made comebacks and entered college were guests yesterday at a graduation reception in Harlem.
College football begins its first major weekend today with three highly regarded teams Penn State, Texas and Houston risking winning streaks in opening games.

The new "flexibility" that was promised when Ambassador David K. E. Bruce went to the Paris peace talks as chief United States negotiator was not in evidence in the hasty American reaction to Communist proposals this week.

LOS ANGELES Amid pools of oozing asphalt in the heart of this sprawling metropolis, housewives, students and other volunteers decked out in their worst clothing are making a contribution to science and their own sense of wellbeing by digging into the world's richest deposit of Ice Age fossils.
A Criminal Court judge here has accused city policemen of frequent lying in court to conceal violations of the Fourth Amendment ban on illegal search and seizure.

The Columbia Broadcasting System introduced two tepid premieres last night, symptoms of a production malaise that could be one of this season's defects. Both flirted with issues of social relavancy but in such mild and unconvincing terms as to be hardly worth the trouble and cost.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Sept. 18 A 28-year-old New Yorker of Puerto Rican and Italian extraction today for the murder last March 24 of a Michael M. Petito, a Family Court judge in Nassau Count. L. I.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 18 Lonnie McLucas, who was the first Black Panther to stand trial in connection with the slaying of Alex Rachley, was sentenced today to 12 to 15 years for joining in a conspiracy to murder.
Dean Chance started his day in Cleveland, waiting for a plane to Baltimore, but finished it in Shea Stadium, waiting for a possible chance to pitch in his first game for the Mets.
LONDON, Sept. 18. The six-week-old strike at an automobile component factory that nearly crippled the British car industry was settled today.
NORFOLK, Va. Sept. 18 (AP) Atlantic Fleet headquarters reported today that the West German merchant ship Samba was listing severely and her crew was abandoning her about 600 miles west of the Azores.
FREEHOLD, N. J., Sept. 18 (AP) House Call paid $24.80, $11.40 and $5.40 for $2 in win ning the Bordentown pace today at Freehold Raceway.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 18 Danny Decarlo, a prosecution witness at the murder trial of Charles M. Manson, testified today that he was in an alcoholic and marijuana daze during the six months that he was a follower of the hippie "family" leader.

ALBANY, Sept. 18 (AP)--Today the state made its largest grant to date under the $18-million program of aid to cultural institutions, by awarding $360,000 to the Buffalo Philharmonic Orchestra Society.

BOSTON, Sept. 18 An exhibition of 100 masterpieces from the Metropolitan Museum of Art has opened at the Boston Museum of Fine Arts as part of what has been described as the largest museum exchange ever undertaken.

The Metropolitan Opera will offer its first performance this season of Donizetti's "Lucia di Lammermoor" on Oct. 15 with a cast headed by Renata Scotto, in the title role, and Luciano Pavarotti, who will take the part of Edgardo for the first time with the company. Carlo Franci will conduct.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18-- Representative Howard W. Robison, the senior Republican House member from New York, has warned Vice President Agnew that his recent attack on Senator Charles E. Goodell could aid the election of a Democratic Senator from the state this fall.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 18 The Israeli authorities today released the last of the 450 Arabs from the occupied territories rounded up last weekend in connection with the airliner hijackings, an army spokesman announced.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 18 (AP) The trial of three black prisoners accused of murdering a guard during racial turmoil at Soledad prison has been moved to San Diego over defense objections.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 18 Prime Minister Indira Gandhi scored a surprising victory in yesterday's state election in Kerala, where the Communists had been voted into power twice in recent years.
The American Stock Exchange scored its third consec utive gain yesterday on mod erate trading although late profit taking reduced some of the earlier gains.

The Ex-Cell-O Corporation, producers of machine tools, packaging equipment and aerospace and electronic components, showed a sharp drop in earnings for the third fiscal quarter and nine months ended Aug. 31, the company reported from its Detroit headquarters yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept.18 (UPI) The Senate passed a bill today to stop the illegal use of secret foreign bank accounts but killed a provision intended to crack down on United States citizens who buy and sell American stocks abroad to evade taxes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 Premier Golda Meir said to day that Israel would continue to observe the cease-fire along the Suez Canal but would not participate in peace talks until there was a rollback of missiles from the cease-fire zone on the Egyptian-held side of the canal.
The divided four-member Liberal party City Council minority, after a heated meeting, concluded yesterday that it would remain an ineffective legislative force.
Dr. Thure Conrad Peterson, chiropractor and educator, died yesterday in the New York Infirmary after a short illness. He lived in Bernardsvilte, N. J., and maintained an office here. His age was 71.

Bernardo Bertolucci, who is associated with Italy's avant-garde because of such films as "Before the Revolution," "Partner" and "The Spider's Stratagem" (which was shown at the New York Film Festival Thursday night), has at last made a very middle-class, almost conventional (in the context of his other work) movie that turns out to be one of the elegant surprises of the current New York Film Festival.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 18 (AP) Vasily Kolotov, a 26year-old laborer from the Soviet Union, established two unofficial world records today to win the middle heavyweight crown in the world weight-lifting championships.
MOSCOW, Sept. 18 The Soviet Union expressed serious concern today over the situation in Jordan and warned outside nations that intervention could only widen the conflict.

A prediction by the Illinois Farmer's Union that corn production this year would fall below the estimate of the Department of Agriculture sent closing corn futures prices higher yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 A group of 4,390 economists urged President Nixon today to veto the import-limiting trade bill if it reaches him in the version now pending before the House.

DETROIT, Sept. 18 Ron Klimkowski, who had toiled most of the season in the New York Yankee bull pen, got his third starting assignment of the year tonight and tossed a glittering three-hit shutout as the Yanks solidified their hold on second place in the American League East with a 5-0 victory over the Detroit Tiers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) Customs agents will begin within the week to search all hand luggage carried by passengers boarding international flights at the nation's 33 "gateway" airports, the Treasury Department said today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UPI) The Government charged the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) today with fixing prices at arbitararily high levels on gasoline and other products sold under the Sohio label.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 18 Foreign Minister Maurice Schumann of France made a strong appeal here today for the admission of Communist China to the United Nations and for a larger role in world affairs for France and Britain alongside the two superpowers, the United States and the Soviet Union.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Sept. 18 Mrs. Walter Cooperstein of Glen Oaks defeated Mrs. Cutting Gushing of Meadow Brook, 6 and 5, today in the scheduled 36-hole final of the 15th Women's Cross County Golf Association championship at the Cold Spring County Club. Par for the 5,861-yard course is 37, 36-73.
ALBANY, Sept. 18 (UPI) State Controller Arthur Levitt's office today confirmed that Mario A. Procaccino has held a part-time $150-a-day state job as a hearing officer on pension cases since March.

James E. Gibson, president of the hosiery division of J. P. Stevens Co., Inc., has resigned. He will be succeeded by Robert J. Stahlsmith, a corporate vice president who will hold the title of acting president of the hosiery division.
Gail Phillips, an illustrator and portrait painter, died Friday at his home, 400 East 57th Street, after a short illness. His age was 63.

The Belmont Futurity, which had its first running in 1888, will be contested today, with a field of 13 named for the 6 -furlong test. The large field will make for a gross purse of $159,800 and a winner's share of $99,320.

The Sun Oil Company announced yesterday that it had increased its refinery and terminal prices on most solvent-refined industrial products, including industrial lubricating oils and specialty products.

The Penn Central announced yesterday that it had obtained Federal court permission to start a formal "demonstration" program of the high speed Metroliner trains between New York and Washington under contract with the Department of Transportation.

NEW PALTZ, N. Y., Sept. 18 This town of 10,000 population, known for its sturdy, 17th-century stone houses built by Huguenot settlers to fend off the Indians, is caught up in a very modern controversy: how to treat drug addicts.

Prices on the London Stock Exchange registered gains for the fourth consecutive day yesterday. The advance accelerated midway during the session on news that a 6-week strike at GKN-Sankey, an automobile components concern, had been settled.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 18 (AP) The prosecution in the case of three Black Panthers charged with firing a machine gun at a police station here agreed today to drop its request for a new trial. The defendants agreed to plead guilty to other charges.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 18 Tom Johansen, a Danishborn Canadian citizen who graduated from Colorado Mines, kicked a field goal with 11 seconds to play tonight that gave the Jersey Tigers a 13-10 victory over the Long Island Bulls. The Atlantic Coast Football League game was played at Hofstra Stadium.

DETROIT, Sept. 18 (UPI) Today was the last full payday for the duration for more than 355,000 striking General Motors Corporation workers in the United States and Canada. The effects of the shutdown of the world's biggest manufacturing corporation began to mushroom.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass. Joseph McNamara is a New York police lieutenant from a family of New York policemen. His father was on the force for 26 years; his brother Michael has been there for twenty, and Joe for fourteen, a traditional New York cop except that he has been at Harvard for a year.

New schedules promising more and faster evening rushhour commuter trains from Grand Central Terminal on the New Haven division are to go into effect Monday but without the parallel increase in single-ride and 10-ride fares sought by its parent, the Penn Central, and rejected by the New York State Public Service Commission.

LONDON, Sept. 18 (Reuters) Gabriel Hauge, the president of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, advocated today the use of the "organized" transitional float technique where adjustment in important currencies became necessary.

SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 18 Dr. John A. Hannah, the administrator of the United States Agency for International Development, assured South Koreans today that the United States would continue to aid the economic development of this country.

Troops, ships and planes sufficient for effective American military intervention in support of King Hussein of Jordan should such action be decided upon are deployed in the Mediterranean and Central Europe.

DETROIT, Sept. 18 (Ap) The automotive industry produced its five millionth car of the calendar year this week despite a sharp cut in auto production resulting from the United Auto Workers strike against the General Motors Corporation.

The Christian Democratic party is justified in its demand for a firm commitment to preserve Chile's democratic system before it delivers the votes necessary to elect Senator Salvador Allende as President on Oct. 24. It may seem naive to believe that such a pledge would be honored by a Marxist-Socialist President, governing in harness with a disciplined, Moscow-line Communist party, but there is valid reason for the demand.
ROME, Sept. 18 The Vatican called today for intensified ecumenical discussions to foster unity among Christians.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell, who was defeated in the June Democratic primary for his Congression seat, was ruled by the Board of Elections yesterday to be ineligible to run as an independent candidate in the November election.
HONG KONG, Sept. 18 Pointing to the exploits of a host of heroines, the Peking press has proclaimed that "what men can do, can also he done by women."

MONTREAL, Sept. 18 (AP) Ron Santo hit a 10th-inning single, scoring Don Kessinger with Chicago's winning run tonight as the Cubs beat Montreal, 5-4, in the second game to complete a sweep of a double-header and take over second place in the National League East race.
Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, disclosed an unsuspected facet of his controversial personality yesterday his ability as a painter.
Senator Charles E. Goodell accused Representative Richard L. Ottinger yesterday of a "callous attempt" to use a scheduled $1.5-million television advertising campaign to win a Senate seat.
PORTMARNOCK, Ireland. Sept. 18 (AP) Bruce Devlin salvaged a one-under-par 71 today and clung to a diminishing lead in the second round of the Alcan Golfer of the Year tournament.
The new-issue market continued listless this week as only two companies sold their shares.

Since it is thought in some musical circles that the traditional conventions of concert presentation are due for an overhaul, Michael Sullivan's attempt to do something a little different with a guitar recital may not be so far-fetched as it seemed at times during his "theatrical occurrence" at Carnegie Recital Hall on Thursday night.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) President Nixon entertained over 1,000 Congressional staff members at the White House late today, then took off by helicopter for a weekend at Camp David, Md.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 18 An official of the American Federation of Teachers used $1,400 in national union funds today to bail out 14 members of the striking local who were jailed late Thursday after refusing to pay $100-contempt-of-court fines.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 18 The New Orleans police department confirmed today that two of its undercover agents had been discovered and beaten by members of a Black Panther group. The beating touched off a night of violence Monday and a massive police attack on the Panthers Tuesday morning.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 18 The Foreign Ministry of South Vietnam today described as "old, oft-repeated, absurd demands" the eight-point peace program presented yesterday at the Paris peace talks by Mrs. Nguyen Thi Binh, foreign minister of the Vietcong's provisional revolutionary government.

An agreement yesterday ended a strike by maintenance workers in apartment houses in Westchester and Rockland Counties, but the contract dispute continued in the Bronx.

Millions of consumers across the country stand to gain hundreds of millions of dollars in damage payments if a flurry of private test cases filed under the new Federal truth-in-lending law against some of the nation's largest corporations succeed in court.
Louis N. Bookbinder, a furtrade publisher for more than 50 years, died yesterday at the Florence Nightingale Nursing Home, 175 East 96th Street. He was 78 years old and lived in Cedarhurst, L. I.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18? President Nixon acted today to ward off a nationwide railway strike that had threatened to start early next Thursday morning.

Exchange. The President appointed Robert McClellen, Assistant Secretary of Commerce, as a member of the President's Commission on Personnel Interchange. Mr. McClellen will replace Kenneth Davis on the commission, in which Government and industry executives learn about each other's jobs.
Miss Carola Teegen was married yesterday afternoon to Guy Walton in the chapel of the Episcopal Church of the Epiphany. The Rev. Dr. Hugh McCandless performed the ceremony.

Once again producing too little too late, the New York Mets slipped back into third place last night in the threeway battle for the National League East championship by losing to the Pittsburgh Pirates, 3-2, at Shea Stadium.

The Chicago Bears are one of the rare teams in professional football to have two legitimate superstars in their peak at the same time. Last year, they were also one of the rare teams in pro football to win one game and lose 13.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 18 (AP) Perry T. Jones, internationally known tennis administrator and developer of young players, died today at the age of 80.

The Federal Reserve System will have to "throttle back" its monetary policy in the next "two or three months if the United States is to avoid a renewal of inflationary pressure later in 1971," a leading commercial bank economist warned yesterday.

"There's always something to be done," said Julius Hersch Borenstein as he contemplated his role as president of the Bronx Real Estate Advisory Board, representing the owners of 2,500 buildings in the borough.

The police began a citywide search yesterday for Zayd Malik Shakur, the New York minister of information for the Black Panther party, after a city marshal with an eviction notice broke into Mr. Shakur's apartment and allegedly found "a small arsenal" of weapons and ammunition.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 The Nixon Administratton has decided to resume full-scale arms shipments to Greece, lifting restrictions imposed in April, 1967, when the military junta seized power, informed sources said today.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Sept. 18 Charles P. Rockwood, special assistant to the managing partner of Haskins Sells, international public-accounting concern, died at his home here last evening. He was 53 years old and lived at 214 Old Army Road.

Frank D. Gilroy, the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright, and Shirley MacLaine will jointly produce a screen version of Paula Fox's "Desperate Characters," with the actress appearing in one of the two key roles. Mr. Gilroy also will make his debut as a film director, working from his adaptation of the book. He previously adapted two of his plays for the screen, the award-winning "The Subject Was Roses" and "The Only Game in Town."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) Approving a railroad merger for the first time in more than a year, the Interstate Commerce Commission today gave approval for acquisition of the Monon Railroad by the Louisville Nashville.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 18 (UPI) Roman Gabriel topped off two long marches with short scoring passes and Alvin Haymond sprinted 98 yards to a touchdown with the second-half kickoff tonight to lead the Los Angeles Rams to a 34-13 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals in their National Football League opener.

The French painter Francis Picabia (1879-1953) first came to the United States at the time of the Armory Show in 1913. His own first one-man show in this country took place at Alfred Stieglitz's "291" gallery that same year. He was already one of the legendary leaders of the modern movement in Europe, and looked to America to take up the challenge of the highly controversial avantgarde then enjoying its heyday in Paris.

A total of 316 manuscripts and documents, including a letter written by George Washington and a copy of a l7thcentury book annotated by John Milton, were sold for $46,190 by the Charles Hamilton Galleries Thursday night in an auction at the WaldorfAstoria.
Despite the bear market in stocks, mutual fund redemptions continued to decline last month, The Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

More than three of every 10 times that New York City firemen answered a call last year, they found it to be a false alarm.

MADRID, Sept. 18 Spain is consulting with the United Arab Republic in an attempt to work out proposals for breaking the deadlock in negotiations for a settlement between Israel and the Arab countries, informed Spanish sources disclosed today

The distinguishing factor in the New York City Opera's production of "La Traviata" is Frank Corsaro's stage direction. Its unconventionality, its attention to logical detail were in evidence again in the first performance this fall of the Verdi work at the State Theater.

BASEL, Switzerland, Sept. 18 (Reuters) The United California Bank in Basel, A.G., which was closed last Wednesday, today attempted to clarify the situation surrounding its recent losses and denied reports that these could reach 300 million francs ($68.4-million), instead of the announced figure of $40-million.

ABINGTON, Mass., Sept. 18 Miss Janet Marie McSorley and Kenneth S. Leavee, 1970 graduates of Emerson College, plan to be married next summer.

RYE, N. Y., Sept. 18 Marvin Kapilow of the Greenhaven Yacht Club, Rye, sailing his, Lorrainc, took the lead today in the second annual Etchells22 Class national championship. After the first two races in the five-race series had been completed in faltering breezes on Long Island Sound off the American Y. C. Kapilow had 2 points. He led Randy Bartholomew of the Sea Cliff, L. I., Y. C., by 2 points.

ALBANY, Sept. 18 Joseph C. Swidler, the chairman of the State's Public Service Commission, said today that the shortage of fuel was so serious in New York State that it might be necessary to resort to rationing for the first time since World War II. Mr. Swidler said he felt his agency would have the authority to ration oil, coal and natural gas supplies to electric power generating plants but not to individual homeowners.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 18 (AP) Dr. A. Bernard Drought, the first civilian to serve as dean of the United States Naval Academy here, died of cancer early today at Anne Arundel General Hospital. He was 55 years old.

Albert R. Jube, a lawyer specializing in estate and corporation work, an industrialist and until recently the president of the Palisades Interstate Park Commission, died yesterday in St. Barnabas Hospital, Livingston, N. J. He was 82 years old and lived at 226 Elmwynd Drive, Orange, N. J.

The establishment of a fund in memory of Edward S. Greenbaum, one of New York's leading lawyers and court reformers, who died last June 12 in Princeton, N. J., at the age of 80, was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UPI) President Nixon plans to see a show at Ford's Theater the first President to do so since Abraham Lincoln was assassinated there 105 years ago.

Disclosure that the Lindsay administration has ended its long indecision on the advisability of charging tolls on East River bridges raises hope of easing the massive traffic jams that have been making midtown streets virtually impassable in business hours.

A Liberal party official said yesterday that Mayor Lindsay might be asked to endorse Arthur J. Goldberg for Governor at the party's state dinner on Oct. 6.
SIEGEN, Germany, Sept. 19 The United States team last ground in the fourth round of the 19th chess Olympiad here today when it played the lastplace Canadian aggregation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. In St. Mary's Chapel in the Cathedral of SS. Peter and Paul here this afternoon, Miss Daphne de Blois vom Baur, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. F. Trowbridge vom Baur, became the bride of Patrick William Green. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Henry Tinniswood Green of Itchenor Park, England.

Floats carrying girls in peasant attire and men marching in Bevarian mountain apparel gave an Old World flavor yesterday to the 13th annual Steuben Day parade on Fifth Avenue. Marchers in old-fashioned German military uniforms added a musical-comedy touch.
Meadowbrook will oppose Bethpage today in the final of the Shaw W. Robinson Memorial polo tournament at the Bethpage (L.I) State Park field at 3:30 P.M.
CHICAGO, Sept. 19 (UPI)The Chicago Cubs began accepting applications today for tickets to National League playoff names at Wrialev Field.
MEMPHIS, Sept. 19 (AP)Archie Manning ran for two touchdowns and passed for a third in leading Mississippi to a 47-13 victory over Memphis State tonight.

SEDALIA, Mo. (AP) Al Unser of Albuquerque, N.M., clinched the United States Auto Club national driving championship today by winning his eighth championship race of the season. The victory came in a 100-mile event at the Missouri Fairgrounds.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 19 (Reuters) American helicopter gunships attacked North Vietnamese troops in northernmost Quangtri Province early this morning and killed 18 with heavy machine guns, a United States spokesman said today.

SAN FRANCISCO The oldest trick in politics is to identify your opponent with all the things the voters fear the most. This season of the year has often been described in country parlance as "dog days." It is a peak time for certain infectious diseases, some of which, like poliomyelitis, have been little understood or preventable until recently. Today the No. 1 headliner in this group in international health news is cholera.

IN AN INTRODUCTION to "The Forsyte Saga," Mrs. John Galsworthy recalls a letter her husband once received from a reader who had just returned from London.
