Members of New York's contemporary Jewish community visited yesterday the site where the first Jewish immigrants to America the victims of a pirate's hijacking landed in New Amsterdam over 300 years ago.

SAN DIEGO, Sept. 20 (AP) Miss Budweiser, the defending champion boat from Tampa, Fla., captured the triple crown of unlimited hydroplane racing today by sweeping the final Gold Cup heat with an average speed of 101,848 miles an hour on Mission Bay.
Arthur J. Goldberg, a former United States Supreme Court Justice, asserted yesterday that the state's judicial system was in "enormous disarray." He proposed a five-point program for its improvement.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 20 If it lasts 45 days, the strike at General Motors Corporation will reduce consumption of steel by a million tons.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 20 Syria's role as a storm center in the Arab world was illustrated again today with the Jordanian charge that Syrian forces had invaded Jordanian territory to fight along with Palestinian commandos.
MONTREAL, Sept. 20 (AP) Ron Fairly's disputed two-run double off Ferguson Jenkins sparked a four-run rally in the eighth inning today as the Montreal Expos scored a 6-4 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 20 (UPI) A thief reached inside a wrecked automobile while accident victims were still inside, grabbed a purse containing $30,000 worth of jewels, and raced away through a crowd of onlookers.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 President Nixon's proposal for a sweeping reform of manpower training a major part of his "new federalism" appears to be dead in the 91st Congress.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 Scientists here and abroad are watching with interest the progress of two little girls in West Germany who have been infected deliberately with a virus that causes harmless wart-like growths in rabbits.

GOSHEN, Conn., Sept. 20 A 3 -year-old silver, gray and black Norwegian elkhound, Ch. Vin-Melca's Vagabound, owned and handled by Patricia V. Craige of Monterey, Calif., won his 15th best-in-show award at the 25th annual Northwestern Connecticut Kennel Club show and obedience trials today on the grounds of the Goshen Agricultural Fair Grounds.

RIVERSIDE, Calif., Sept. 20 Miss Mary Elizabeth Wilson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Roberts Wilson of Hemet, was married here last night to Ralph Iversen Peer 2d, of New York and Tahoma, Lake Tahoe. He is the son of Mrs. Ralph Sylvester Peer of Los Angeles and the late Mr. Peer.

A report in the Journal of the American Medical Association urges Physicians and parents to reconsider the controversial subject of circumcision. The report, written by Dr. E. Noel Preston, a pediatrician, challenges the view of many American physicians that routing circumcision of newborn males is a useful and justifiable procedure.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 20 At dawn each Sunday, hundreds of hippies worship on a bluff overlooking the Pacific. For instruction, up to 1,500 fill a ballroom for Monday Night Class.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 20 (AP) North Vietnamese gunners shot down a United States helicopter trying to land a reconnaissance team a mile south of the demilitarized zone today, then fired mortars into an armored relief force. Eleven Americans were reported killed and 11 wounded in the two attacks.
Governor Rockefeller presented a four-point legislative package yesterday outlining ways to reduce the discharge of toxic metals and other hazardous substances into the state's waterways.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 For the third time in as many months, President Nixon has asserted that the university community itself bears the responsibility for restoring "order and discipline," and an atmosphere in which free academic inquiry can flourish, on college campuses.
Back in the first century A.D., when Decimus Junius Juvenalis [Juvenal] lived in Rome, the trials and tribulations of big-city life seem to have been much the same as they are 2,000 years later.

MOSCOW, Sept. 20 The Soviet Union was believed to be seriously concerned today by reports of Syrian intervention in the Jordan crisis, and Soviet officials were believed to be trying to persuade Damascus to avoid further exacerbation of the situation.

One hundred and thirty buildings involved in the Bronx apartment strike were reported yesterday to have received telegrams from the city warning that they had become "health hazards" because of lack of services and that the city would restore such services if landlords did not do so within 24 hours.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 20 (UPI) Pancho Gonzales and his doubles partner, 18-year-old Jim Conners, walked off the court at the Los Angeles Tennis Club during a first-round match in the $50,000 Pacific Southwest tournament today in a dispute over a change in the tiebreaker rules. About 2,000 of the 2,300 fans left with them.
REGGIO CALABRIA, Italy, Sept. 20 At least 6,000 policemen from many parts of Italy are now concentrated in this rebellious southern city of 150,000 people.

MIAMI, Sept. 20 (UPI) A six-man jury here found Jim Morrison, the rock musician, guilty today on two misdemeanor charges for his behavior at a concert here last year. He was found innocent on two other charges.

Roswell Rudd, a big, bearded trombonist, has served as a bridge in recent years between the jazz avant-garde and listeners whose ears are accustomed to more traditional sounds. He has a broad, burry, slippery style that fits as readily with the swoops and shricks of the avant-gardists as it does with the joyful exuberance of the older forms of jazz.
Miss Madeline Ivy Messing was married at the Plaza last evening to Roger Lewis Levy, who is with the London law firm of Taylor and Humbert Co. Rabbi Herbert Weiner performed the ceremony.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 20 For Edmund Sixtus Muskie, United States Senator from Maine, the 1972 Presidential campaign has begun.

BRUSSELS, Sept. 20 Ireland will ask the European Common Market for permission to continue helping her burgeoning industry with special incentives to foreign investors for some time after she has entered the Community. Ireland's External Affairs Minister, Patrick J. Hillery, announced this today upon his arrival here for the membership talks, which start tomorrow.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 20 Yesterdays have never had much worth in professional football.

The largest crowd of the season in Shea Stadium saw the New York Mets divide a tumultuous double-header with the Pittsburgh Pirates yesterday and remain 3 games out of first place with only nine left to play.
Engineers are racing the onset of the Arctic winter to complete a preliminary survey on the feasibility of constructing a railroad and highway link to Alaska's far north.
The bond market rallied spiritedly last week, and it will likely continue to climb this week even though the schedule of corporate bonds for sale is the heaviest in three months.

"Asians are not like or unlike Europeans;" writes Dennis Bloodworth, who may be remembered from his first book, "The Chinese Looking Glass." "They are both. They are possessed of the human conscience, the sex urge, five senses or so, and forty-six chromosomes per cell nucleus. They are hard-wearing, edible, com

NEWBURYPORT, Mass., Sept. 20 (AP) A National Guard armory here was heavily damaged today by an explosion and fire that the authorities believe was set. Four hundred rounds of M-1 rifle ammunition were reported stolen.
LTTITZ, Pa. To many people, pretzels are merely crunchy, funny-shaped tidbits that taste best with a glass of foamy beer.

DETROIT, Sept. 20 Rookie Steve Kline pitched the finest game of his brief major league career today, setting down the Tigers, 5-1, on three hits to give the Yankees a sweep of a three-game series at Tiger Stadium.
Guess it's time to take a cook at the (ugh!) fourth quarter.

COLLEGEVILLE, Pa., Sept. 20 Ch. Naris Du Posty Arlequin, a 6-year-old Bouvier des Flandres owned by Mr. and Mrs. Chester F. Collier of Irvingtonon-Hudson, N.Y., gaited to best-in-show honors today at the 23d annual Valley Forge Kennel Club fixture. A field of 1,068 contended.
About 100 male and female members of a group calling itself the Gay Students Liberation began a sit-in at a New York University building late, last night.

Berkey Photo, Inc., announced yesterday that its directors have authorized creation of a reserve in the amount of $7.5million against obligations owed to it by Movielab, Inc., from the sale in June, 1969, of the operating assets of its Pathe professional film processing and optical effects division.
LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 20 Rod Jenkins rode the winners of three championships at the concluding session of the Piping Rock horse show today.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 20 Terry Bradshaw, the rookie quarterback who has been described as a "Namath with knees," flunked his first National Football League test today while learning that experience can be more important than ability or publicity.

STOCKHOLM, Sept. 20 Premier Olof Palme's Social Democratic party lost its parliamentary majority in the Swedish general election today, but a stronger-than-expected showing by the Communist party made it unlikely that there would be a change in the Government.

The National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences has to decided the limit the annual Emmy Awards telecasts, which have been running for two hours or more, to 90 minutes. The decision was announced yesterday following the fall meeting of the academy's trustees at the Essex House.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 20 The Jordanian Government reported tonight over the Amman radio that "Syrian armored troops, backed by heavy artillery" crossed the Jordanian border during the day for the second time.

ROBINSON, Ill., Sept. 20 (AP) George Knudson of Canada, after a close 40-hole battle with George Archer, won the $100,000 Robinson open golf classic today on the fourth suddendeath playoff hole when Archer three-putted for a bogey.

It was after a violin concert on a warm summer evening in 1942 when Martin Abzug, 25 years old, stood up on a crowded bus in Miami Beach and offered his seat to a young woman he wanted to meet. Her name, he learned later, was Bella Savitzky.
Well, Dick Butkus didn't toss any Giants into the Harlem River on Saturday night and Gale Sayers didn't romp all over the Bronx with a football in his hands.

Among the distinguished competitors in the recent United States Open Chess Championship in Boston was Dinah Dobson, women's chess champion of England. She topped the women's contingent in the 12-round Swiss system by a 7 -4 score.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 Nearly 750,000 citizens of the District of Columbia at last will receive a portion of the democratic representation that most other Americans have taken for granted for generations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 The Nixon Administration and the United States business community which has extensive operations in Chile are facing with resignation the prospect of a Marxist regime in Santiago and the expected nationalization of American property.

ROME, Sept. 20 The two houses of parliament met in joint session today to celebrate the 100th anniversary of the conquest of Rome by the troops of unified Italy, which ended the temporal power of the papacy.

Fenton Benedict Turck, an international consulting engineer who specialized in problems of distribution and marketing, died Saturday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 150 East 72d Street.

St. John's University has announced the appointment of Msgr. George A. Kelly as university research professor. He will be the first holder of the John A. Flynn Chair in Contemporary Catholic Problems.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 20 When Jim Hardy, the skipper of the Gretel II, was asked if he planned to take advantage of the early 6-1 odds against the Australian yacht, he shook his head and said, "I'm a Corinthian, an amateur, you know" Above his head was an advertising display for Rolex chronometers, cleverly hung from the ceiling of the state armory here so it would appear in all televised news conferences.

KINSHASA, the Congo, Sept. 20 (Reuters) An international consortium signed an agreement this weekend to develop Katanga's rich copper deposits after beating a bid by the Belgian mining company Union Miniere.

BALTIMORE--Baltimoreans find implausible rumors that the Vice President proposes to become this city's second H. L. Mencken. Yet those most inclined to scoff are given pause by Karl Marx's comment on Hegel's assertion that, in a way, history does repeat itself. "He might have added," said Marx, "that it appears the first time as tragedy, the second time as farce."

Dr. Mohammed H. el-Zayyat, Egypt's delegate to the United Nations, said yesterday that there was a possibility of an Egyptian rollback of missiles to Suez Canal Zone positions that they occupied before the Middle East cease-fire began on Aug. 7.
THE SPRINGS, L.I., Sept. 20 Two men and a woman ventured aloft here today in a patched balloon, bound for Europe from a meadow that was dotted with wide-eyed children and incredulous adults.

SPRING VALLEY, N.Y., Sept. 20 A woman was fatally injured and her infant son was seriously hurt early today in an automobile collision that led to the arrest of a motorist on charges of criminally negligent homicide, driving while intoxicated and driving with a suspended license.
Led Zeppelin edged the Beatles out of the No. 1 popularity spot in a recent British poll, and it showed evidence of that popularity in two concerts in Madison Square Garden Saturday.

WASHINGTON Historians have shown us, with painful conviction, how the World Wars could have been avoided if a few men had been wiser. But the sovereigns and the generals and the diplomats acted as if they could not escape events; they marched toward disaster, saying stubbornly that there was no alternative.
WATCHUNG, N.J., Sept. 20 Mrs. Diane Ward's Traveler survived a three-horse jumpoff to capture the open jumper championship today at the Watchung horse show.
Representative Richard L. Ottinger called upon the United States yesterday to make an outright gift to Israel of jets, antimissile missiles and other sophisticated military equipment.

Amid all the talk about air pollution, there's one cheerful note. Perfumers seem to feel that 1970 is a good year to introduce new perfumes. This fall, the air may not be cleaner, but it ought to smell a good deal better.
CAIRO, Sept. 20 The risk of entry by Arab armies into the fighting in Jordan was underlined tonight when Libya urged that a Libyan-Algerian force be sent to Jordan.
GROSSINGER, N.Y., Sept. 20 (AP) State Commissioner of Education Ewald B. Nyquist told 1,000 school administrators today that his chief priority was "to make the educational system more humanistic."

Altman's annual fall explosion, "This is Altman's," gets underway today, and as usual, the store has decided to stage a series of special events rather than concentrate on merchandise from one particular country. The storewide event, which runs through Oct. 3, will be high
UPPERVILLE, Va., Sept. 20 "Horses are like potato chips; you can't stop with just one," said Mrs. Harry F. Stimpson, who almost always has one more horse than she has stalls.

Under pressure from a strong combination of industrial and labor interests, Congress now seems ready to enact in the form of the trade bill approved by the Ways and Means Committee the most protectionist and reactionary trade legislation in forty years. This bill poses grave dangers to the national interest and to world trade.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 20 (AP) A six-weekold Minneapolis boy received a kidney transplant today at the University of Minnesota Hospitals. He was believed to be the youngest person ever to undergo the procedure.

Prof. James M. O'Neill, educator, author and lecturer on the relations of church and state in the United States, died yesterday at the Emerson Convalescent Home in Watertown, Mass. He was 88 years old and lived in Lakeville. Conn.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 Last Wednesday, the day after she was nominated director of the Volunteers in services to America, Carol Maver Khosrovi paid an unannounced visit to the headquarters of the national VISTA Alliance here.
TEL AVIV, Sept. 20 The Israeli authorities indicated tonight that they believed King Hussein's army had won its internal military struggle.

BOSTON, Sept. 20 (AP) The Massachusetts Port Authority, which operates Logan International Airport in Boston and Hanscom Field in Bedford, says it will not file legislation to construct a second international airport.

Harvard University announced yesterday that its year-old AfroAmerican studies department would give "the highest priority" now to developing a projected W.E.B. DuBois Institute for Afro-American Research.
HONG KONG, Sept. 20 The Peking-based exile government of Prince Norodom Sihanouk announced steps today to transfer its operations gradually to Cambodia.

TEL AVIV, Sept. 20 (AP) El Al, Israel's national airline, was partly grounded today as 450 mechanics and workship technicians walked off the job. Only 4 of the 10 international flights scheduled to leave here today were able to take off, a comany spokesman said.
TOKYO, Sept. 20 Senator Strom Thurmond called on Japan today to step up her defense effort and "to undertake a greater proportion of the leadership necessary to the defense" of non-Communist Asia.

TORONTO, Sept. 20 Participants in the recently resumed Canadian-American energy negotiations are quietly confident that, despite considerable opposition within Canada, the talks will lead to a permanent increase in Canadian oil and natural gas sales south of the border.

The city is planning to send the City Council proposals for reducing what it considers "excess" litter, including no-return bottles and cans, a spokesman for Environmental Protection Administrator Jerome Kretchmer said yesterday.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 20 (Reuters) Syrian and Jordanian military strength is fairly evenly matched as far as the front-line army manpower is concerned.
PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 20 Don't start, a 5-year-old chestnut gelding making his first start in the ring, won the open jumper championship at the Stratford Stable's horse show today.
SIEGEN, Germany, Sept. 20 The United States team met the Soviet aggregation today in the sixth round of the 19th chess Olympiad at Siegerland Hall.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 20 Despite a wasp sting that puffed his face to the size of a grapefruit, Steve Van Dyck hopes to return to action as Intrepid's tactician for the next America's Cup race.
ST. JOVITE, Quebec, Sept. 20 (UPI) Jacky Ickx of Belgium won the Grand Prix of Canada today, beating out his Ferrari teammate, Claude Regazzoni of Switzerland, at the Mont Tremblant track.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 20 The America's Cup finally became, competitive today when Gretel II of Australia caught Intrepid from behind and sailed on for a thrilling 1-minuteseven-second victory.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 20 The Federal authorities, in the most sweeping move to date against "thermal pollution," have decided to impose a ban on hot-water discharges from power plants into Lake Michigan.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 20 Evidence that a black man was among the 23 founders of Brooklyn, that a Long Island slave was the first published black author in the United States and that Long Island slaveowners were among the cruelest in the nation were among the featured exhibits at the opening here today of the Black History Museum of Long Island.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 20 A distinct caution has marked all but the most partisan newspapers and radio stations in Chile's capital since a Marxist won a plurality in the presidential election.
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 20--Six miles north of a tossing buoy that marks the America's Cup Yacht Race, the city of Newport sits like an uninvited guest at a party in his own front yard.

Dr. Paul L. Adams, the Conservative party candidate for Governor, stood firmly yesterday hehind his call for imposing the death penalty on persons convicted of importing, wholesaling or distributing narcotics illegally.

Luis Bunuel, the Spanish director who has had to live and work most of his life in exile in France and Mexico has been making movies since 1928 ("Un Chien Andalou"), but it wasn't until 1961 and the international critical success of "Viridiana" that he could pick his properties with any degree of independence. There has followed a kind of Bunuelian age d'or, nine years
Eight black men and women were honored last night by the Black Academy or Arts and Letters at its first annual banquet.

ATLANTA, Sept. 20 A magazine reporter has charged in Federal Court that his call to active duty in the United States Army last week was punishment for uncomplimentary articles he wrote on the military.

Motorist are apt to have trouble finding the New Jersey Turnpike, the Garden State Parkway and the Atlantic City Expressway on the highway map just produced by the New Jersey Transportation Department. The map-makers forgot to label the roads.

The second week of the television season opened last night with the American Broadcasting Company introducing "The Young Rebels," the first of its 11 entries, while the Columbia Broadcasting System came in with the last of its fresh contenders, Tim Conway in his own variety show.

MOSCOW, Sept. 20 The Soviet Union announced today that its unmanned Luna 16 spacecraft had made a soft landing in a relatively unexplored region of the moon's surface and had begun sending signals back to earth.

PARIS, Sept. 20 The fickleness of the female of the species applies to equus caballus also. The winners of the English, Irish and French Oaks were to have made today's running of the $222,462 Prix Vermeille at Longchamp the European championship of 3year-old fillies.

ALBANY, Sept. 20 State Controller Arthur Levitt charged in an audit report today that a nursing home in New York City had billed the city for $8,185 for the care of five patients who had already died or been discharged.

Premier Golda Meir of Israel appealed to American Jews last night to provide financial aid to Israel through the purchase of bonds. She said the contribution was needed "not only for itself" but also as a "demonstration to your Government, a democratic Government, that you will it so."
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 20 A trawler's fishing net weight, first thought to be a rusted World War II mine, created a flurry of excitement today before the start of the second America's Cup race.
This is the first of three articles exploring the relation of our domestic agenda and our policy in Asia.

COPENHAGEN, Sept. 20 South Africa has lived up to both the "letter and the spirit" of the agreement with the International Monetary Fund on disposal of newly mined gold, Pierre-Paul Schweitzer said here on the eve of the Fund's annual meeting.

The Rockefeller family has decided that its 4,180-acre estate at Pocantico Hills in Westchester County will eventually be "preserved and dedicated to the public interest," and not chipped away by haphazard development.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UPI) Mrs. John N. Mitchell, wife of the Attorney General, said today that professors and educators were destroying the country. "They are totally responsible for the sins of our children." she said.

CAIRO, Ill., Sept. 20 (AP) The police chief of this Southern Illnois city has resigned, saying he could no longer work among citizens who "advocate violence, hatred and animosity to their fellow men."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 An unpublished report drafted for the Department of Labor contends that industrial accidents causing death and injury in the United States may be 10 times higher than shown in official figures.

HARTFORD, Sept. 20 (UPI) The Democratic candidate for United States Senator in Connecticut, the Rev. Joseph D. Duffey today urged the State Water Resource Commission to veto a dredging project that could endanger two unspoiled islands in Long Island Sound off Norwalk, Conn.

PINE BUSH, N. Y., Sept. 20--The firemen of Pine Bush, in the foothills of the Shawangunk Mountains in Orange County, got help in fighting a barn fire today from an unexpected source --the firemen of North Merrick, L. I., who had participated in a parade here.
BARRINGTON, R.I., Sept. 20 (AP) Dr. Robert A. Passy, chairman of the elementary education department at Rhode Island College, died today after a heart attack at his home. He was 44 years old.

When it is finished, according to the Department of Transportation's Bureau of Public Roads, the National System of Interstate and Defense Highways will link more than 90 per cent of the nation's cities with populations of 50,000 or more as well as hundreds of smaller cities and towns.
Most prudent persons make out a number of wills over a lifetime to keep up with changing conditions.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Sept. 20 (AP) Mel Fan scored two touchdowns and Errol Mann kicked four field goals today as the Detroit Lions crushed the Green Bay Packers, 40-0, in a National Football League opener.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 20 Vice President Ngoyen Cao Ky went on South Vietnamese national television tonight to confirm that he would make his trip to Washington as planned and that he would participate in the controversial prowar March for Victory rally to be held Oct. 3 on the grounds of the Washington Monument.

The area around First and Second Avenues on the Upper East Side, once known for its dullness after sunset, has been transformed into a lively night-life district that is attracting young people from throughout the city and out of state.

PEKING By early September the weather in Peking has cooled from the "tiger heat days"; already everywhere there is cleaning and painting; the little hutungs are swept clean; every hand seems busy; whether it is grandmothers who run bicycle stands and public telephones, or vegetable sellers with their carts.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 Secretary of State William P. Rogers called on Syria today to end her "invasion" of Jordan and warned that Syrian intervention raised the danger of a wider war.

NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 20 Robert Colborn, a writer and publisher and the former managing editor of Business Week, died today of cancer in Norwalk Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived at 33 River Street in New Canaan.
PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Sept. 20 (UPI) Frank Sinatra replied today to accusations made against him after a Las Vegas casino altercation on Sept. 6.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 Following is a list of the principal United States corporations with capital investments in Chile or in business or service activities there, with revenue figures and number of employes in 1968. The sales figures are not available in all cases. The parent companies in the United States are listed, rather than Chilean subsidiaries or offiliates. The extent of United States ownership of the subsidiaries is noted.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Sept. 20 The Central Synagogue of Nassau County was the setting here at noon today for the marriage of Miss Ellen Roberta Krieger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Krieger, to Lawrence Elliott Holler, son of Mrs. Ferdinand Holler of New York and the late Mr. Holler. Rabbi George B. Lieberman performed the ceremony. He was assisted by Cantor Ira Shur.

Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation deliberately misled Justice Department officials during an investigation of the 1968 shooting of 30 black students at Orangeburg, S.C., according to a book by two newsmen who covered the incidents.

GENEVA, Sept. 20 Sir Eric Wyndham White, new strong man of Investors Overseas Services, has scored his first success in his search for partnerships of "prestige and quality" to bolster his severely battered mutual fund empire.

BORDEAUX, France, Sept. 2O Premier Jacques ChabanDelmas was re-elected today to a seat in the National Assembly, gaining a decisive victory over Jean-Jacques ServanSchreiber, his reformist challenger.

PARIS, Sept. 19 "We have a very active investment department whereby we not only trade on the main United States stock exchanges but also on most European markets. We also do trading in precious metals, commodities and foreign exchange."

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20 (UPI) Roger Staubach, who played quarterback for the entire game, lofted a 31-yard tiebreaking pass to Lance Rentzel late in the third period today and the Dallas Cowboys went on to a 17-7 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles.

LONDON, Sept. 20 West German and Israeli relations have become strained and uneasy as a result of efforts to free the airline hostages, held in Jordan by Arab guerrillas, Western diplomats said today.

A weekday parking ban from 7 A.M. to 7 P.M, in a triangular 50-block area of Lower Manhattan goes into effect today in an effort to cut congestion and provide a freer flow for taxis, buses, emergency vehicles and trucks delivering mail, food and other supplies.
ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 20 (AP) Two men were arrested yesterday and charged here with first-degree kidnapping of a Staten Island man.
Leading Democratic politicians in all sections of the country except the Deep South regard John V. Lindsay as a potential Presidential candidate who could run well as a Democrat in 1972.

Teams captained by Ira Ewen of New York and Monroe Granovetter of Jersey City were scheduled to meet last night in the finals of the knockout event of the Long Island Regional Championships at Roosevelt Raceway.

GLENCOE, Ill., Sept. 20 Miss Sheilah Rae Bernstein, an actress and singer known professionally as Sheilah Rae, was married here today to Dr. Elliott George Gross, an assistant professor of neurology at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in New York.
MILESBURG, Pa., Sept. 18 America's interstate highway system is opening new social and economic frontiers.

DAYTON, Ohio, Sept. 30 Dr. Franklin R. Turner, dean of undergraduate studies at California State College, Dominiguez Hills, announced plans yesterday for an institute to develop a "new breed of future managers who would be known as urban environmental managers."
DAMASCUS, Syria, Monday, Sept, 21 (Reuters) Jordanian armored units entered Syrian territory and took nine Syrian soldiers prisoner, a military spokesman said here today.

BOSTON, Sept. 20 (UPI) Trailing by 11 points, the Boston Patriots converted three Miami errors into 17 points in the final 3 minutes 19 seconds of the first half today and went on to a 27-14 victory over the Dolphins.

Mayor Lindsay's two Deputy Mayors charged yesterday that Controller Abraham D. Beame was hurting city operations for political purposes by halting payment on new management consultant contracts awarded without Board of Estimate approval.

NAPLES, Italy, Sept. 20 (UPI) The police announced the arrest today of a man believed to be the acrobatic motorcyclist who touched off rioting last month. They identified him as Antonio Mellino, 23 years old.

At his piano recital debut in Town Hall late Saturday afternoon, James V. Cresce showed how effectively one can use familiar musical materials in the building of a program with a fresh outlook. His way was to make Chopin and Liszt his principal composers and to add pieces by Poulenc and Liszt his principal composers and to add pieces by Poulenc and Bloch for variety.

ROME, Sept. 20 On the morning of Sept. 20, 1870, artillery fire tore into the ancient Roman walls near the Ports Pia, and the soldiers of unified Italy, wearing plumed hats, penetrated through the 36-foot breach into a city that received them with eerie silence and offered no resistance.

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 21 (AP) A citizen of West Germany was arrested here yesterday and charged in connection with a bomb threat extortion of $25,000 from Western Airlines in Anchorage, Alaska, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

STOCKHOLM, Sept. 21 Despite a shift to the center in yesterday's general election, Olof Palme, Sweden's Social Democratic Premier, was expected today to press forward with his program of spreading more social benefits to the poor and increasing the role of the state in private industry.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 21 (AP) The revised "hamlet evaluation system" used by United States officials to measure pacification in South Vietnam indicated today that as of Aug. 31, 92.8 per cent of the country's population was under government control, and only 184,700 people were under Vietcong control.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 The acting head of the United States space program congratulated the Soviet Union today for obtaining a sample of lunar matter from a part of the moon not yet explored by man.

Organized landlords yesterday obtained a State Supreme Court hearing, which will be held this morning, in an effort to stop the city administration from taking over services in buildings affected by the weekold Bronx apartment strike.

Ira and Linda Ewen of Flushing, Queens, and Robert and Sara Lee Bowers of Kings Park, L. I., were the winners of the knockout team championship Sunday night in the Long Island regional tournament at Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L. I.
The manufacturers of the goods and services that companies use to protect their premises and personnel put there on display at the New York Hilton Hotel yesterday before an interested audience.
Vice President Agnew, wrangling with student leaders here last night, said it was "understandable" that construction workers attacked antiwar demonstrators.

BIRMINGHAM, Mich., Sept. 21 The engagement of Miss Cheryl Ann Simons to Thomas Joseph McGee Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McGee of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Simons of Birmingham and North Haven, L.I., parents of the future bride.

Botched electoral procedures and inordinate judicial delays have combined to produce several re-run primary elections today in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens. Some of these races concern only party leadership posts. Two, however, involve Democratic nominations for State Assemblyman and have an importance that transcends their district lines.

BILOXI, Miss., Sept. 21 The moderate governors tried to avoid a light over school desegregation at the Southern Governors Conference today by keeping the focus of the meeting on the mutual problems of the future instead of the rancorous divisions of the past.

Fred M. Thrower, president of WPIX, testified yesterday that Nancy McCarthy, a former WPIX news writer, had reported to him at least nine instances of what she considered news misrepresentation by the station in the latter part of 1968.

Two men and a woman attempting the first trans-Atlantic crossing in a balloon were caught in a heavy rainstorm 500 miles east southeast of St. John's Newfoundland, last night and radioed for assistance, saying they were preparing to ditch into the sea.

WASHINGTON, Sept.21 The first Congressional hearings in 20 years on national health insurance, a plan to cover the medical needs and costs of all Americans, open Wednesday amid uncertainty as to the Administration's stand.
SYDNEY, Australia, Tuesday, Sept. 22 The news of Gretel II's disqualification spoiled the breakfasts of Australians today and brought angry and cynical reactions from newspapers.
BONNEVILLE SALT FLATS, Utah, Sept. 21 (UPI) Speed runs of the Blue Flame rocket car were stopped today because of damaged injector nozzles and repairs were expected to take another day.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 Representatives of leading lawyers' organizations have started a fight against a proposed regionalization of the Federal program of legal services for the poor.
TEL AVIV Sept. 21 (AP)--More than half the striking Israeli El Al Airlines ground employes returned to work today and officials expected flight schedules to return to normal.

THE PRESIDENT Signings. The President signed a bill authorizing the Secretary of Interior to reimburse the Ute Indian tribe for an irrigation project. He also signed a bill to clarify the promotion system for reserve officers of the Coast Guard.

A new syllabus for teaching American history in secondary schools that emphasizes the role of such minorities as Negroes, Puerto Ricans, Indians and Mexican Americans was published yesterday under the auspices of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
In the tumultuous recent history of the Middle East, Jordan's tough young King, Hussein Ibn Talal el-Hashim, has achieved a reputation as a master of self-preservation.

A court order barring the International Longshoremen's Association from picketing six Manhattan piers was rescinded yesterday. The union opposes the city's plans to utilize the piers for cultural and recreational activities.

Bache Co., Inc., the nation's second-largest brokerage house, indicated yesterday that it had stemmed a tide of heavy internal losses. At the same time, it called for speedy passage of legislation to protect customers of financially troubled securities firms.
The Phillips Petroleum Company announced yesterday that it had discovered oil in the British sector of the North Sea about 25 miles west of the large Ekofisk field in Norwegian waters.
The Coast Guard Search and Rescue Center here reported early today that a cargo ship identified only as Martha Endeavour had sent an SOS off the western coast of Ireland and was taking on water.

ROCHESTER. Sept. 21 Governor Rockefeller kicked off the 1970 Republican campaign upstate tonight in a joint appearance with Senator Charles E. Goodell and did, not once mention his running mate by name.

As a fashion show, yesterday afternoon's event wasn't particularly unusual. A beautiful setting on the terrace of a Tudor City penthouse. Taped ballet music. Models flitting like butterflies to show the fluidity of Jon Haggin's newest resort and spring designs. And, at the end, a beautiful bride in all her starry-eyed glory.
Avnet, Inc., engaged in electrical, electronic and automotive products, had a sharp earnings decline for the fiscal year ended June 30 on record Sales, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Sept. 21 Joseph W. Rao, founder and president of the Rao Electrical Equipment Company of New York, died at St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains yesterday. He had been stricken earlier with a heart attack while playing golf at the Westchester Country Club.
MOSCOW, Sept. 21 The Soviet Union's Luna 16 started back today on the first return voyage to the earth by an unmanned spacecraft from the lunar surface, after scooping up samples of rock.

The conflict between management and players over pro football's riches exploded in Boston when Clive Rush, the rash Patriots' coach, suspended two defensive backfield regulars, John Charles and Larry Carwell, minutes before Sunday's game after they refused new contract offers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 It will be obvious to all who have witnessed the marketing of politicians on television recently that the Constitution of the United States must be amended quickly. At present, and even a Southern lawyer would have to agree on this, a product must be human in order to qualify for Congress or the Presidency. (Even the Vice-Presidency
LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Sept. 21 (AP) The ninth annual art show and sale at the Federal penitentiary here brought in $21,600, about $3,000 more than last year's event.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UPI) The mortgage interest rate for the purchase of new homes rose to a record average of 8.51 per cent in August, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today. The July average was 8.49 per cent.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 21 A firearms expert testified today that he found on the Spahn Ranch north of Los Angeles 15 shell casings that had been ejected from the 22-caliber revolver used in the five killings at the home of Sharon Tate in August of 1969.
Interest rates throughout the money and capital markets declined yesterday in the wake of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company's decision to cut its minimum lending rate.
BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 21 (UPI) Gov. John J. McKeithen declared a state of emergency in Houma, La., today following a weekend of mounting racial tension in two coastal Louisiana parishes.
EUGENE, Ore., Sept. 21 John R. Froines, who was acquitted at the Chicago Seven conspiracy trial, resigned today as an assistant professor of chemistry at the University of Oregon.

A bartender arrested in connection with a series of bank robberies in the metropolitan area last spring pleaded guilty yesterday to five counts of an 11-count indictment, United States Attorney Edward R. Neaher said.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 Senior American military planners said tonight that United States forces were being alerted for either of two possible military actions in Jordan.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 21 Mr. and Mrs. Daniel G. Tenney Jr. of Locust Valley and Paul Smiths, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Pamela M. Tenney, to Keith E. Simpson, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Leonard Simpson of Richmond, England.
For more than 40 years, American children have watched Tarzan alternately bamboozle and bedevil the black cannibals who cavort through the jungles on the comic pages of the nation's newspapers.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 Ralph Nader asked the Transportation Department today to require the Ford Motor Company to notify owners of what he said was a safety defect in more than 4 million cars.
CASS LAKE, Minn. A northwest wind buffeted our cottage at Birch Villa shortly after midnight, and in the morning it was still blowing strong out of the same quarter.

A private economist told the 83d annual meeting of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants here yesterday that the time had come for the United States to meet foreign competition with a coordinated program of cooperation among industry, management and labor.

Explaining that "nobody wants to place their lives in the hands of a third person," the lawyer for the four suspended Rangers yesterday said he did not want to take their salary disputes before an arbitrator.

DETROIT, Sept. 21 (AP) Joe Frazier and Bob Foster signed today for a 15-round world heavyweight title fight here Nov. 18. Frazier is the defending champion and Foster the light-heavyweight titleholder.
CHICAGO, Sept. 21 (AP) Pregnant women should avoid taking aspirin as the time approaches when they are to give birth, two doctors advised today.
Eight brothers from New Jersey, a couple from upstate New York, and a resident of Pennsylvania were winners of $100,000 prizes in the New York State lottery yesterday.

Mrs. Charles Taylor, associate director of research and evaluation of the Children's Television Workshop, producer of "Sesame Street," died yesterday in New York Hospital after a brief illness. She was 30 years old and lived at 252 West 85th Street.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 21 (AP) Sheldon Selikoff, 44 years old, a Boy Scout leader, was indicted today by a Westchester County grand jury on eight counts of morals violations stemming from operation of what the police called a "clearing house" for pornography.
CAIRO, Sept. 21 Arab leaders will convene in an emergency meeting in Cairo tomorrow morning to seek a solution to the "deteriorating situation" in Jordan, the United Arab Republic announced today.

Among leaders of the homeconstruction industry, a sector of the economy that has felt the high-interest pinch acutely, the lowering of the prime rate yesterday was seen, around the country, as encouraging.

SKOUN, Cambodia, Sept. 21 The Premier of Cambodia, Gen, Lon Nol, and his top military leaders flew by helicopter today to visit the column of troops stalled for more than a week by enemy positions on the road to Kompong Thom, a provincial capital 85 miles north of Pnompenh.

A group of business, labor and civic leaders estimated yesterday that the heads of more than a quarter million families in the city work full time, pay taxes, but are impoverished and eligible for welfare aid.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 Treasury bill rates declined at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 21 Robert S. McNamara, president of the World Bank, painted a somber picture today of the outlook for poor countries and, hence, for the world at large.
Four persons were seriously wounded in the East Village section last night by shotgun blasts in what the police said had begun as an argument over garbage disposal.

President Nixon's preparations for possible military intervention in the Middle East underscores the gravity of the international crisis created by Syria's armed intrusion into Jordan's internal conflict. In view of the wider explosion that could be touched off by continued deterioration of the situation in Jordan, the President has no alternative but to prepare for the worst in an area where American lives and other important American interests are at stake.

Former City Controller Mario A. Procaccino dropped the other shoe yesterday and announced his expected endorsement of Conservative party candidate James L. Buckley for the United States Senate seat now held by Republican Charles E. Goodell.

A grand jury is investigating charges that the Harlem River Consumers Cooperative was struck because it would not deal with a food supply company in which the striking union's business agent had an interest.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 The Nixon Administration announced a series of arrangements today to deal with hijacking as a continuing menace to air transportation.

Two Democratic primary contests will be rerun today in Brooklyn's 44th and 51st Assembly Districts. The special elections were ordered by the State Supreme Court because of "irregularities" during the June 23 primary.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 21 (AP) Workers at the Nevada test site voted today to end a strike that has crippled the nation's nuclear testing program for almost four months.
EAST ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 20 Upsala College is not a power in football. The Vikings' coach, John Hooper, has to juggle as if he were a circus performer flipping hot irons in the air 22 at a time.

A 23-year-old Brooklyn teacher who was hijacked to Jordan Sept. 6 sued Swissair for $75,000 damages yesterday under terms of a 1966 agreement with the United States Government signed by more than 85 airlines.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel said today that the Federal Government often lost sight of its obligation to protect American Indians' rights because it coveted Indian lands and waters.

Herman Malamood, who made his United States operatic debut on Sunday night in the New York City Opera's third "Madama Butterfly" of the season, came to the stage by a well-traveled path. Like Jan Peerce, Richard Tucker and a number of other tenors, Mr. Malamood is a product of the cantorial tradition (New York City born, he officiates at a Catskills resort hotel during the high holidays).

The Rev. Charles T. Carow, who led a successful six-year fight in the 1940's to free bowling from racial discrimination, died of a heart attack Sunday in the rectory of his church, SS. Phillips and James in St. James, L.I. He was 62 years old.
The prime lending rate on business loans was reduced yesterday to 7 per cent by at least a score of major banks across the country.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Sept. 21 Abdul Halim Muazzam, the Sultan of Kedah, became Paramount Ruler of Malaysia today amid the boom of cannon and ruffles and flourishes, but with public interest limited largely to school children waving paper flags issued to them.
Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff toured a slum area in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn yesterday and immediately labeled it "a national disaster."

The heads of the three counties Nassau, Queens and Kings adjacent to Kennedy International Airport came out yesterday in opposition to proposals to increase the airport's capacity by extending runways into Jamaica Bay.
Production of steel in the week ended Saturday totaled 2,536,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

Soccer's greatest scorer, Pele, meets up with the game's finest defensive player, Bobby Moore, when their clubs meet tonight at Randalls Island at 8 o'clock. Pele, the Black Pearl of Santos of Brazil, scored his 1,095th goal the other night in California. Moore, a sweep who stays, behind the defensive wall, is American football's version of a free safety and middle line-' backer rolled into one.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 21 New Haven teachers tonight voted overwhelmingly to reject the latest contract proposal from the Board of Education, while teachers in Somers, in the northern part of the state on the Massachusetts border, returned to their classrooms today after a nine-day strike.

MIAMI BEACH, Sept. 21 In one of the strongest public's attacks ever made by an insurance company executive against Federal regulation, Judson B. Branch, chairman of the Allstate Insurance Company, assailed the Government today for seeking to move into the automobile insurance business.

If there ever were any questions as to what the role of the Black Academy of Arts and Letters should be, they were answered repeatedly last weekend during the academy's first annual meeting, which ended early yesterday morning.
Three Long Island Railroad policemen went an trial in Criminal Court here yesterday, charged with the third-degree asault of a commuter who died a few hours after the aleged beating.

Stella D'oro, maker of Italian cookies, is diversifying into Chinese almond cookies. And in an effort to outdo the original it will top each and every cookie with several almond slices instead of the traditional one. Darn clever, those Italians.

"We" in this context meant for the most part a New York cultural elite primarily involved with literature, but not less caught up in the politics of the age, especially as these involved the interpretation of texts.
Hydrologist of the Meadow Stable made up ground in the stretch to win the $27,350 Stymie Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday.

Simon Lazarus, general counsel for the city's Consumer Affairs Department, said yesterday that the agency was drafting a regulation that would bring dealer warranties on second-hand automobiles under the city's Consumer Protection Act.
BERLIN, Sept. 21 A new ambassador from Peking arrived in East Berlin today, marking the formal resumption of full relations between Communist China and East Germany.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 The United States alerted infantry and paratroop units in this country and in Europe today for possible movement to Jordan, apparently after receiving a Jordanian appeal for military help.

One of Wall Street's favorite rumors of recent weeks an impending cut in the prime rate by major New York banks began to crystallize yesterday. As a result, the stock market turned downward as investors and traders followed the maxim of "selling on the news."

While there's something different about the texture of the cookies offered here, many people will probably find it hard to identify the unusual ingredients. They are soft, moist style cookies that keep well and carry well in a lunch box.

Only one game into a new season, the Grants are already talking of getting themselves together again, as a result of Saturday's 24-16 loss to Chicago.
Madison Avenue, from 61st Street to 79th, will be converted into a pedestrian mall tonight and livened with special events, including pavement painting and strolling singers, from 7 P.M. to 10 P.M.
Arthur .J. Goldberg, the Democratic-Liebral candidate for Governor, said yesterday that the passage of auto-title legislation "is long overdue" and promised its enactment if he were elected Governor.

ATLANTA, Sept. 21 Michael Reagan, son of Governor Reagan of California, and Miss Pamela Putnam, daughter of Duane Putnam, line coach for the Atlanta Falcons football team, plan to be married.

Murray C. Bernays, a New York lawyer who planned the prosecution of Nazi war criminals after World War II, died Saturday in Harkness Pavilion of Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital, after a long illness. He was 75 years old.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 More than one doctor out of every three who has received substantial income from treating patients under the Medicare and Medicaid programs appears to be cheating on his income tax, a Treasury official told Congress today.
ROCKY POINT, L.I., Sept. 21 The Atomic Energy Commission opened a hearing today in this small Long Island village that could affect all future nuclear plants in the country.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 21 It happens all the time at race tracks a foul is claimed by one jockey against another, the inquiry sign lights up on the tote board and the stewards study the films of the race.
Confusion reigned at Grand Central Terminal during the evening rush hour yesterday as new "zone" and timetable schedules went into effect on the New Haven division of the Penn Central.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 21 (AP) Dave Danforth, a former American League pitcher credited with originating the controversial "shine ball," died Saturday at the age of 80.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 21 King Hussein's battered forces fought retreating battles today against Palestinian commandos reinforced by tanks rolling down from Syria. All the cities of northern Jordan except the capital, Amman, appeared to be in the guerrillas' hands.

Added ammunition for New York Yankee fans who are awaiting the opportunity to harass Met fans over the winter was provided last night by Fritz Peterson as he pitched a 5-2 victory over the Washington Senators at Yankee Stadium.

The Winter Garden Citrus Products Cooperative, one of the largest suppliers of privatelabel frozen orange juice concentrate to supermarket chains, announced yesterday it would follow price cuts initiated by other producers.
The American Stock Exchange turned in its first loss in four sessions yesterday as the list declined in slower trading.
Fights between white and black students broke out yesterday morning at the new South Shore High, School in the Flatlands section of Brooklyn, and for a while they threatened to force its closing.
Short interest on the New York and American Stock Exchanges fell sharply in the month ended Sept. 15 in an apparent reflection of the turnaround in the stock market.

Mayor Lindsay disclosed yesterday the results of a survey that shows that women constitute 26 per cent of all New York City government employes earning $10,000 a year or more.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) Eastern and Western railroads renewed their request today for a 15 per cent rise in freight rates as the Interstate Commerce Commission prepared to begin a nationwide investigation of railroad revenues.
OAKLAND, Sept. 21 (UPI)--Vida Blue, a rookie left-hander, deprived of a no-hitter only 10 days ago, pitched hitless ball against the Minnesota Twins tonight as the Oakland Athletics triumphed, 6-0.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 21 (AP) , officials of Syracuse University said today they would meet tomorrow with the State Commissioner of Human Rights, at his request, to discuss charges of iscrimination against the football coaching staff filed by suspended black athletes.
SIEGEN, Germany, Sept. 21 The United States team dropped to third place after losing to the Soviet team by the score of 2 to 1 in the sixth round of the 19th chess Olympiad.

Representative Richard L. Ottinger said yesterday that "massive Republican defections" from Senator Charles E. Goodell gave James L. Buckley "a respectable crack at winning" the three-way United States Senate race.

Three of the state's major Republican officeholders Governor Rockefeller, Senator Charles E. Goodell and Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz turned their attention to environmental problems yesterday as they continued their election campaigns.
The London stock market moved ahead briskly yesterday in the strongest buying activity in several months.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 21 (UPI) Arthur Ashe had to go all out today to beat 49-year-old Pancho Segura, 7-6, 6-4, in a firstround match at the $50,000 Pacific Southwest open tennis championships today.
ALBANY, Sept. 21 The State Department of Health today requested bottlers of Normanskill Water to remove all containers from store shelves, pending further bacteriological studies.

Shareholders of the American Forest Products Corporation and the Bendix Corporation approved at separate meetings yesterday the merger of American Forest Products into a subsidiary of Bendix.

BEDFORD, N.Y., Sept. 21 Robert E. FitzGibbon, a New York public relations executive, died at his home here today after a long illness. He was 65 years old and lived on Indian Hill Road.
Negotiations between The New York Post and the New York Newspaper Guild continued yesterday with a target date of Sept. 30 for achievement of a new contract.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (Reuters) The Federal Reserve Board's Open Market Committee unanimously voted to maintain a moderate growth in money and bank credit at its June 23 meeting, it was disclosed today.
Strict no-parking rules went into effect in Lower Manhattan yesterday as the city strove to relieve traffic congestion in the narrow streets of the bustling financial district.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 21 Fluttering yellow penalty flags signaled the entry of the New York jets to the National Football League tonight.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Sept. 21 (UPI)--Six of seven Long Branch, N.J., policemen charge with conducting an orgy with the teen-age daughter of an area minister pleaded guilty to reduced charges today. The seventh man is still standing trial.

TRENTON. Sept. 21 (AP) The last of nine companies cited by the state for polluting the air in Linden agreed today to begin installing devices that may clean up the stench along the New Jersey Turnpike.

GEORGETOWN, S.C., Sept. 21 A former New York director of the Congress of Racial Equality and a woman companion have been found dead beside the wreckage of a light plane five miles northwest of here.
ROME, Sept. 21 A spate of kidnappings in Sicily and Sardinia is confronting the Italian police with an old dilemma how to hunt gangsters without endangering their hostages.

AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 21 The army briefly lifted its order to shoot on sight today and the women of Amman went into the streets, dodging sniper fire, to find food.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 21 President Tito, who is 79 years old, said today that the question of who would succeed him as head of state would be solved with the creation of a collective presidency.

Malaria cases diagnosed in this country increased by almost 50 per cent last year over the figure for 1968; and preliminary data for 1970 show a further sharp rise, the Center for Disease Control has reported.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Sept. 22 (AP) The City Council voted last night to permit offtrack betting, under the state law passed by the 1970 Legislature, to help increase local tax revenues.
ATLANTA, Sept. 22 (AP) The Chicago Cubs purchased Hoyt Wilhelm, the 47-yearold knuckleball pitcher, from the Atlanta Braves on waivers today.

The Federal Government gave the Hudson River Fishermen's Association a check for $2,000 yesterday for its help in obtaining a conviction of the Penn Central railroad for pol luting the river at Harmon, N.Y.
The city announced yesterday that 80 old people would be hired to accept applications for food stamps at the 58 centers for the elderly operated by the Department of Social Services.
STRATFORD, Conn., Sept. 22 Sikorsky Aircraft demonstrated today a helicopter that it hopes might give it a second chance to win a Pentagon contract potentially worth more than $300million.
Fred M. Thrower, president of WPIX, conceded yesterday that he was aware of instances in which his station had mislabeled news reports in the latter part of 1968.
Jim Garrett is a peppery little chap who scouted for the Dallas Cowboys last season and is now coaching the specialty teams for the New York Giants.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 President Nixon signed into law today a bill giving the nearly three-quarters of a million people in the District of Columbia a single nonvoting Delegate in the House of Representatives.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 22 For those Chileans frightened by the prospect of a Marxist President, what is most worrisome is the Communist party, the core of the coalition that carried Dr. Salvador Allende to his leading total in the election on Sept. 4.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 White House speculation that Argentina, Bolivia and Peru might join Chile if she turned Communist has deeply disturbed Latin-American diplomats here, who fear that such statements may be playing into the hands of revolutionaries as well as military dictatorships in the hemisphere.

WEST ISLIP, L.I., Sept. 22 Dr. and Mrs.Benjamin Tucker have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Daiva Jody Tucker, to James Arnheim Staman, son of Dr. and Mrs.Harry Staman of Uniontown, Pa.
Sitting sadly in the rear of the chartered airliner. Mike Battle wasn't accepting sympathy.

MOSCOW, Sept. 22 The unmanned Luna 16 spacecraft, carrying a cargo of moon rock, continued on its return voyage toward earth today as the Soviet Union exulted over its most significant space accomplishment in several years.
Revere Copper Brass, Inc., said yesterday that it had reduced its price to distributers for standard sizes of sheet, roll and strip copper by four cents a pound.
PARIS, Sept. 22 Alain Peyrefitte, former Gaullist Minister of Education, predicted at a meeting of Gaullists last week that "we can be in power for 30 years if we don't do anything stupid."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 A threat by organized labor to withdraw its support for two bills designed to strengthen the enforcement powers of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has jeopardized passage of the bills, proponents said today.

Do you take "perverse pleasure in baiting the poor banker?" If you do, you are a target for John P. LaWare, senior vice president of the Chemical Bank New York Trust Company and a defender of the bank credit card.

WINDSOR LOCKS, Conn., Sept. 22 (AP) Sargent Shriver called Vice President Agnew a "radical rightist" today and suggested that Mr. Agnew make a nationwide tour with Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam.
Plans for a mail order sale of box and reserved seats to a possible National League Championship Series at Shea Stadium, were issued yesterday by the New York Mets.

PARIS, Sept. 22 Two basic Communist proposals rejected up to now by the United States and the Saigon Government as conditions for a settlement of the Vietnamese war were reiterated today as "legitimate demands" by Mrs.Nguyen Thi Binh, foreign minister of the Vietcong's provisional revolutionary government.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 Despite the efforts of private black organizations, black citizens were seriously undercounted in the 1970 census, Whitney M. Young, executive director of the National Urban League testified today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 The United States put its emphasis today on diplomacy with the Soviet Union rather than military preparations in its effort to prevent the Jordanian conflict from expanding.

The failure of the attempted Arab summit in Cairo imposes a solemn responsibility on the United Nations, and especially on the Big Four members of the Security Council, to act in the Jordanian crisis.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 22 Mr. and Mrs. Knight Edwards have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara McKay Edwards, to James Alan Diamond of Arlington, Mass., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Diamond of Rochester, N.Y.

DETROIT, Sept. 22 (UPI) The Michigan Credit Union League and the Council of General. Motors Credit Unions denied yesterday a published report that Flint credit unions had pledged $500 in financial support to 56,000 striking G.M. workers in Flint.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) Maj. Gen. Howard McCrum Snyder, who served President Dwight D. Eisenhower as medical adviser and physician, died today at Walter Reed Hospital. He was 89 years old. The cause of his death was not disclosed.

MISSOULA, MONT. Dear Waiting Student: If you haven't discovered it yet, now is the time. Upon what meat does the violent, rockthrowing, buildingburning campus militant feed? On yours, Sir, your very own flesh. You, the standers-by; the doubters concerning the question of whether the American system can work.
Three patrolmen were injured last night when a mob of 200 to 300 people attacked them in a Harlem street after one of the policement had ticketed a double-parked car.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 President Nixon asked Congress today to authorize prompt Federal intervention in cases of bombing or arson on university or college campuses.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 22 "The liberation of Palestine passes through Amman," President Nureddin al-Attassi of Syria proclaimed more than three years ago.

Electric power blackouts were imposed for the first time on hundreds of thousands of people in the metropolitan area and in the Middle Atlantic States yesterday as a final summer heat wave and generator failures caused the worst power crisis of the season.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 22 Laurence W. Fairfax, a lawyer and financial analyst, died today in Lawrence Hospital here. He was 66 years old and lived at 5 Thomas Place.
TOKYO, Sept. 22 (Reuters) Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam arrived here from Saigon today en route to Paris and Washington.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22Several thousand antipoverty workers and poor people from New York State gathered, here today to protest a $3.6-million cutback in Federal aid to antipoverty programs. The cuts are scheduled to go into effect Oct.1.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 22 Dr. Paul L. Adams, the Conservative gubernatorial candidate, made a one-day campaign swing through this stanch conservative city today, banging away on his themes of the failure of Governor Rockefeller to deal with the state's drug problem and his refusal to debate him on television.

Fabian M. Crystal, a retired builder and real-estate operator, died on Monday as a result of a fall from the roof of the Kaufmann building of the Young Men's-Young Women's Hebrew Association, Lexington Avenue at 92d Street, where he was visiting. His age was 71.

ROCKY POINT, L.I., Sept. 22 An Atomic Energy Commission hearing board opened the door a little wider here today to allowing environmental dangers to be considered in licensing the controversial Shoreham nuclear power plant.
Carl Ally, Inc., has landed the Travelers Corporation account with its some $3-million in billings.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Sept. 22 Mrs. Hazel Osterhoudt Fowler, a descendant of early Dutch settlers, died here today. She was 82 years old and lived with her son-in-law, and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Philip Azoy, at 537 Mount Kemble Avenue.

COPENHAGEN Sept. 22--Representatives of the central banks and finance ministries of 115 countries, assembled here for the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank, are looking anxiously toward Washington as the Congress...
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 23 (AP) Unusual security precautions were reported early today at the United States Air Force base at Incirlik.

Attracted by Pel , who is probably the sports world's greatest attraction, a crowd of 22,143 jammed Downing Stadium on Randalls Island last night, for an exhibition soccer game between Santos of Brazil and West Ham United of England. The fans were not disappointed.

Dave Feld, the boxing referee who was ejected from Madison Square Garden before last week's Floyd Patterson-Charlie Green bout, after he refused to leave the ring, was indefinitely suspended yesterday by the State Athletic Commission.

William E. Humphreys, who has been president of Abercrombie Fitch since Sept. 1, told the annual meeting here yesterday that he was "not happy" with the chain's advertising and that he would do his "best" to discontinue the store's famous remnants sales "because the man who buys an item for 99 cents isn't our customer."
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 22 (UPI) Nate Thurmond signed a two-year contract with the San Francisco Warriors today at an undisclosed increase in salary.
"Dangerous levels" of lead poisoning, the debilitating ailment that afflicts slum children, have been found in nearly 1,800 youngsters so far this year, city health authorities reported yesterday.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 22 (UPI) A Teamster Union official was shot dead on a street here this morning as he stepped into a truck on his way to work. The police identified the victim as William Reckhow, 36 years old, of 456 Central Avenue. They could not immediately discern a motive for the killing.

Supreme Court Justice Thomas C. Chimera refused yesterday to grant an organized landlords' petition for a temporary stay to stop the city from taking over services in struck Bronx apartment buildings.
The Council of Churches of the City of New York said yesterday that a WCBS-TV newscast on abortion on Sept. 14 was "an attempt at informing the public in a responsible manner."
HANOVER, N.H., Sept. 22 Dartmouth and Wellesley Colleges are considering an annuals exchange of up to 200 students and five or more faculty members, beginning next fall.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UPI) A Senate House conference committee tentatively agreed today on most key portions of proposed new wheat and feed grain support programs, including rigid support loan floors under grains from 1971 through, 1973.

TEL AVIV, Sept. 22 The District Court here today rejected an atheist's application to change his entry in the national population registry from "Jew by nationality" to "Israeli." The decision will be appealed.

Operations of the Republic Corporation in the quarter and nine months ended July 31 resulted in sharply lower profits with sales higher for the three-quarter period, according to figures issued yesterday from the Beverly Hills, Calif., headquarters.

Edwin S.Cohen, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for tax policy, outlined yesterday several areas of possible tax reform under consideration for introduction next year, including a concept known as the value-added tax.

ROWAYTON, Conn., Sept. 22 Otto Scherer of Laurel, Md., and Gene Miller of Annapolis, Md., the North American champions for three of the last four years, went after the world championship for Class C catamarans today and won the two races that began a seven-race series.

After searching thousands of square miles of choppy seas off New foundland, the Coast Guard said last night that it had found no trace of two men and a woman who disappeared Monday while trying to cross the Atlantic in a huge balloon.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 22 Jordan's decision to use her tiny air force against two armored brigades invading from Syria was seen in Israel tonight as a significant move that could alter the magnitude of battle is northern Jordan.
The London stock market moved ahead strongly yesterday for the second successive day, although trading was less active than on Monday.

The United States Treasury is not offering any more of the finest refined silver, or that known as grade 999, at its weekly auctions, it was learned yesterday. According to the General Services Administration, which conducts the auctions, this type of silver has been offered in small amounts at various times since the sale was started in July, 1968. Government auctions of all types of silver will cease on Nov. 10.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 The House Rules Committee voted today to send a comprehensive occupational health and safety bill to the floor for debate.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Sept. 122 The Uruguayan Government today reiterated its refusal to offer ransom of any kind to Marxist guerrillas holding a United States soil expert and a Brazilian diplomat as hostages.

KFAR RUPPIN, Israel, Sept. 22 The sun set in the Biblical hills of Gilboa to the west; from the east came the intermittent pounding of artillery fire tonight between Arab forces on the heights of Irbid a few miles away.

MEMPHIS, Sept. 22 When Vice President Agnew's campaign jet landed at a remote corner of the Memphis Airport today, there was Senator Albert Gore, the man the Vice President had come to demolish, elbowing his way into the Republican receiving line.

The Kerr-McGee Corporation announced yesterday that it had found "significant" copper mineralization in four of five recently completed deep diamond drill holes on its Red Mountain property near Patogonia, Ariz.

Judges, lawyers and prosecutors who had been more than a little pessimistic when they heard last June that the city's Criminal Court would have to give jury trials, admitted yesterday that they had been wrong. The court already had more work than it could handle, they warned, and now, with an added burden, its chaos and clutter might become complete.
SIEGEN, Germany, Sept. 22 The United States team defeated West Germany 2 to 1 in the adjourned seventh round games of the finals of the 19th Chess Olympiad this morning.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 22 (UPI) Charles H. Keating Jr., President Nixon's only appointee to the Presidential Commission on Pornography, filed suit yesterday to block the closed-circuit televised showing of the musi-...
LONDON, Sept. 22 Amid mounting confusion and concern, the British Government held urgent meetings through the day on the crisis in Jordan.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Sept. 22 The engagement of Miss Karen Greenspan to Richard B.Lind has been announced by Dr. and Mrs.Ezra Greenspan, parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Daniel Lind of Riverdale, the Bronx, and Mrs.Charles Rubenstein of New York.

The last weekend was a busy one for those mythical persons who place crowns on racing drivers' heads and dethrone those who have lost them crowns not heads. Foremost of the new champions is Al Unser of Albuquerque, N.M., who clinched the United States Auto Club national...

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 Original plans called for Mrs. Emil Mosbacher Jr. to wear the real Hope Diamond to the 10th anniversary Hope Ball tonight, a benefit for the hospital ship Hope. Mrs. Mosbacher is the benefit chairman and the wife of the Chief of Protocol.
DETROIT, Sept.21 A quarter century ago a 28-year-old Henry Ford 2d seized control of his grandfather's crumbling empire.

GLEN COVE. L.I., Sept. 22 Commuters from this North Shore community who are often too tired after a day's work in New York City to attend local school board meetings had an opportunity to engage in a "speak-out" on school problems with the local Superintendent of Schools while traveling on the Long Island Railroad this morning.

WASHINGTON The world is drifting into the most dangerous confrontation since the 1962 cold poker played by President Kennedy and Chairman Khrushchev. The stakes remain the same total but there are more players and some of them are mad.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 President Nixon announced today that he would nominate Dr. Sydney P. Marland Jr. of New York to be Commissioner of Education. The post has been vacant for more than three months.
Following is an excerpt from Mayor Lindsay's news conference yesterday dealing with his political plans:
John V. Lindsay said yesterday he was now planning to retire from political life when his term as Mayor ended in December, 1973.

The most militant miniskirt advocate will be hard put to resist Maximilian's new collection that makes the short fur coat look as dated as the tea cozy.
