A renewed attempt to obtain a United States Supreme Court order staying their trial has been filed by lawyers for 13 Black Panthers accused of plotting to bomb public places.

BUFFALO, Sept. 22, (AP) Justice Walter P. Mahony of State Supreme Court today ordered the name of Representative Richard Max McCarthy, running for re-election as an independent, placed on the November ballot.

OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 22 A wind-driven fire, believed to have been set by arsonists, roared out of the Berkeley hills today, destroyed about 40 woodland houses, left hundreds homeless and forced the evacuation of a wide area, including four schools.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 22 (AP) Eight black athletes suspended from the Syracuse University football squad will be reinstated immediately on the recommendation of Floyd Ben Schwartzwalder, head coach.

CAIRO, Sept. 22 Arab leaders put off today the emergency conference on Jordan that they had scheduled and sent a fourman delegation to Amman to confer with King Hussein and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian guerrilla leader.

Twenty-five years ago, Gyorgy Sandor stood in front of the house at 309 West 57th Street and watched as medical attendants lifted a slight, white-haired man into an ambulance that was to take him to a hospital. Bela Bartok, ill with leukemia, was leaving for the last time the tworoom apartment that had been his American home. A few days later, on Sept. 26, 1945, he died at the age of 64.
The stock market retreated yesterday for the second day in a row as investors kept a wary eye on the tense military situation in Jordan.
Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday a new procedure to review protests regarding the fairness or correctness of questions and answers on Police Department examinations for promotion.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 The United States formally announced the resumption of fullscale arms shipments to Greece today, but said it remained "fully committed" to a return to parliamentary democracy in that country.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 22 Israeli health authorities today offered medical treatment to noncombatants wounded in the fighting sn Jordan if they were allowed across the bridges spanning the Jordan River, the border between Jordan and the Israeli-occupied west bank.

In the aftermath of Cambodia and Kent State last May, Princeton University decided that it would shut down for two weeks before the November elections to give students and faculty every opportunity to work for the candidates of their choice. The recess is to be offset by extension of the academic year.

The Coronet Theater Corporation, of which Lester Osterman is president, has leased the Lunt-Fontanne Theater, 205 West 46th Street, for one year with, options for a renewal in the second year and purchase in the third year.

Two Democratic primary contests were rerun yesterday in Brooklyn 44th and 51st Assembly Districts. The special elections were ordered by the State Supreme Court because of "irregularities" in the June 23d primary.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 The Justice Department urged the Supreme Court today not to rule on the constitutionality of the Vietnam war, warning that if the Court should order a sudden end to the war, disastrous military and diplomatic results could follow.

Senator Charles E. Goodell and his Democratic rival, Representative Richard L. Ottinger, focused on the subject of youthful violence yesterday in separate appearances in upstate New York and Washington.

BRUSSELS, Sept. 22 The European Common Market finished its first round of talks today with three candidate members, Ireland, Denmark and Norway, and found that, of the three, Norway's entry might be the most difficult.
DENVER, Sept. 22 (UPI) The Colorado Superme Court, saying it lacked jurisdiction, has dismissed a challenge of the results in Denver's Democratic primary election by Representitive Byron G.Rogers.
Mrs. Deborah Cantor, wife of Arthur Cantor, the theatrical producer and publicity man, died yesterday in New York Hospital after a long illness. She was 48 years old and lived at 1 West 72d Street.
NEWPORT, R.I. Sept. 22 Intrepid showed the cynics she could fight her own battles by outslugging Gretel II of Australia today in an 18-knot sou'wester.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Sept. 22 Abdul Razak succeeded Prince Abdul Rahman as Prime Minister of Malaysia today and voiced hope for the future in a Southeast Asia whose peace and neutrality would be guaranteed by the United States, the Soviet Union and Communist China.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 22 Leading European countries expressed differing views today on the issue of more flexibility in exchange rates among currencies but moved closer to an actual experiment in narrowing the fluctuations within Europe itself.

Lybrand, Ross Brothers Montgomery, one of the nation's largest public accounting firms, has tentatively agreed to settle for $4.95-million the claims arising from its role in the collapse of the Mill Factors Corporation almost two years ago.
LONDON, Sept. 22--The British Cabinet discussed in a two-hour meeting at 10 Downing Street today the fate of the airline hostages being held in Jordan.
DETROIT, Sept. 22 The United Automobile Workers tightened its own belt today for a long strike against the General Motors Corporation, outting the salaries of its officials sharply.

The Board of Education's transportation director opposed yesterday a City Council bill that would mandate seat belts in school buses. Instead he suggested that school buses have seats facing the rear.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 Wilbur D. Mills the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, predicted today that the Administration would ask for postponement of some of the income tax reductions scheduled to go into effect in 1972 under legislation passed last year.

The oil industry began bracing for a major upheaval in world oil prices as the Marathon Oil Company announced yesterday an agreement with the Libyan Government calling for sharply higher tax payments to the Arab country.

Pro football was a success in its debut as a regularly scheduled prime-time television commodity. Initial ratings for Monday night's exciting game between the Cleveland Browns and the New York Jets were strong, indicating that the American Broadcasting Company had made ha good start in its gamble with Commissinner Pete Rozelle's plot.

The New York office of A.C. Nielsen, Inc., the research Pooh-Bah of television, reports that in the metropolitan area the Monday night game between the Cleveland Browns, and New York Jets walked off with 33 per cent of the available audience, handily outdistancing the entertainment shows on rival chains. Heretofore, the American Broadcasting Company has been a Monday night straggler.

Dr. William A. Schonfeld, a specialist in child and adolescent psychiatry, died Monday of a heart attack at Bard Hall of Columbia University. He was 64 years old and lived at 918 Parkway, Mamaroneck, N.Y.

The Machinists Union has reached tentative agreement with the city's four major daily newspapers on the terms of a new contract to replace the one that expired March 30, the parties announced yesterday.
MONKTON, Vt., Sept. 22 The body of a New York City governess was found here today but there was no sign of the missing 5-year-old girl she was suspected of having kidnapped.
The first known hatching of a tufted puffin in captivity was reported yesterday by the Bronx Zoo.

THE PRESIDENT Disaster. The President de dared Arizona and Colorado major disaster areas because of extensive damage caused by heavy rains in early September. Money allocated through the Office of Emergencies Preparedness from the Presidents disaster fund as a result of today's action may be used to assist the states in relief activities.

The European championship to be contested in Estoril, Portugal, next month will be a particularly interesting event for two reasons: For the first time in a decade Italy must win the European title to qualify for the Bermuda Bowl world championship event; and Pierre Jais and Roger Tr zel of France, one of the world's greatest partnerships, will reappear after a lengthy absence from the international scene.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Sept. 22 The Republican and Democratic candidates in New Jersey's campaign for United States Senator agreed here tonight that President Nixon should seek Congressional approval before committing American military forces to war in the Middle East.

ZANZIBAR, Tanzania On this tropical spice island, partner with the former Tanganyika in the union of Tanzania, Communist influence is more evident than it is on the mainland, but even some foreign Communists have had their troubles here, and the United States is increasingly popular.
Such meager information as the families of Americans held hostage in Jordan have been receiving has come from the State Department, Trans World Airlines and newspaper reports.
General Dynamics Corporation announced yesterday the formation of two new divisions Convair Aerospace and Electroynamic.

CAIRO, Sept. 22 The United Arab Republic is making efforts for a special flight to Jordan to rescue more than 100 correspondents besieged in the Jordan Intercontinental Hotel in Amman, Mohammed Hassanein Heykal, the Minister of Guidance, reported today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) Rock and bottle attacks on the police broke out for the second straight night tonight in a gheto area about a mile from the White House.
Arthur J. Goldberg opened a children's day-care center at his campaign headquarters yesterday to symbolize a program to eliminate child neglect.
The cost of money dropped across a broad front yesterday.

MIAMI BEACH, Sept. 22 B.P. Russell, president of the Crum Forster Insurance Companies, asserted here today that the profitability of insurers was being seriously threatened by what he called the "creeping cancer" of insurance pools imposed on the industry by Federal and state regulators.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 The House and Senate held an unusual joint meeting today to hear a former astronaut, Frank Borman, plead for greater attention to the plight of Americans held as prisoners of war in Vietnam.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange ended mostly lower yesterday in slower trading although some stepped-up buying in the afternoon managed to reduce some of the earlier losses.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 22 (AP) Bob Hewitt, the husky, 30year-old South African tennis star, was reported today in good condition with a slight concussion after having been knocked unconscious yesterday by a 75-year-old fan apparently angered by his court conduct at the Pacific Southwest tournament.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 22 Two men who took part in a police raid on Charles M. Manson's hippie hangout last summer testified at the Tate murder trial today that Manson had urged the police to join with his band to fight the Black Panthers.
A splendid running catch in right center by 'Bobby Mitchell supplied the final out and sealed a 2-1 victory for the New York Yankees over the Washington Senators at Yankee Stadium last night.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 The Senate, by a vote of 73 to 0, approved tonight a clean air bill far broader in its reach, and far tougher in its deadlines and penalties, than any of its three predecessors.

Two states that have not been prominent in the annals of American song, Utah and Idaho, got a smidgen of attention thrown their way Monday night at the Washington Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22 I The New York Mets rekindled their pennant hopes in outrageous fashion tonight, reducing the Pittsburgh Pirates lead by half a game to three, when they scored two runs in the ninth inning to defeat the Philadelphia Phillies, 7-6, just after the Phillies had scored four in the eighth.

PERTH, Australia, Sept. 22 (AP) Walter L. Rice, the United States Ambassador to Australia, said today the American yacht Intrepid should decline the award of the second race in the America's Cup series.
Controller Abraham D. Beame accused Deputy Mayor Richard R. Aurelio yesterday of "nonsensical" and "patently absurd" statements in the controversy over the city's contracts with consultants.
VOLCANO, Hawaii, Sept. 22 (UPI) Molten lava poured down the side of Kilauea Volcano and across a barren flatland into the Pacific Ocean today, sending clouds of steam into the sky.

GENEVA, Sept. 22 The Berne coordinating committee, consisting of representatives of five countries whose nationals are being held hostage in Jordan, displayed concern today over the possibility that some of the hostages might disappear without a trace.
EDGARTOWN, Mass., Sept. 22 The president of Volkswagen of America, I. Stuart Perkins, predicted today that the trend toward small cars would continue for at least the next five years.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 Senator John L. McClellan accused the Federal Government today of "monumental hypocrisy" in forcing Southern schools to desegregate to a level that he said was intolerable in the North.
Theodore Granik, the radio and television broadcaster and lawyer, died of a heart attack Monday in his office here. He was 63 years old.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 Confronted with the possibility of a nationwide rail strike at 12:01 Thursday morning, the Interstate Commerce Commission ordered emergency measures today to move people and goods by bus and truck.

Ralph S.Saul, president of the American Stock Exchange, cautioned yesterday that strict application of antitrust concepts to the securities markets might be adverse to the interests of small investors.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 22 The New York Yacht Club Race Committee must have breathed a sign of relief today when Intrepid and Gretel II crossed the finish line. It was the first race of this America's Cup series that did not have a protest, postponement or abandonment.

There is no substitute for a seashore. Men cannot manufacture one. They can admire it, walk on it, swim, sail and fish off it, share its solace and partake of its lifegiving qualities. Or they can mess it up, befoul it with oil, drain its marshes, level its dunes and pave it in concrete. But whether men are decently respectful of its works or ruthlessly egocentric, nature is inimitable. There is nothing like a seashore.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 22 The Pirates had to settle for their second straight split of a doubleheader tonight, but the performances of two pitchers from their sore-armed brigade seemed to dissolve any concern they might have had over the firstgame loss.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 22 If cars seem to waver as they pass in front of the Moose House at 32 Ellicott Street in Batavia, do not blame the Department of Transportation, blame Governor Rockefeller.

Muriel is moving on Oct. 15. Because of the recent assignment of a new cigar product to Lennen Newell by Lorillard, Consolidated Cigar has decided to move its Muriel brand to a new agency. It bills about $2.5 million.

A motion to form an artists' union, or guild, was passed Monday evening at an open meeting attended by some 300 artists from throughout the city. The artists also elected to stage "a major demonstration" Oct. 20 at a major museum in the city, in collaboration with simultaneous artists' demonstrations abroad "for a new and greater role for the artist in society."
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 22 Amman underwent its sixth day of fighting today as both sides ignored the new cease-fire proclaimed by King Hussein in the Jordanian civil war.
Dr. Alice Hamilton, a retired physician who pioneered in occupational medicine, died yesterday in her home in Hadlyme, Conn. She was 101 years old.

A Thomas Eakins exhibition opened yesterday at the Whitney Museum of American Art. It could be faulted here and there, no doubt, if you tried, but the thing to do is to applaud, to cheer and to get there before it closes on Nov. 22.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 Federal officials forecast today that the coming winter would be colder than normal along the East Coat and warned that a shortage of fuel oil for heating and electric power generation way almost inevitable.
CHEYENNE, Wyo., Sept. 22 (UPI) Judge J.J. Hickey, who had been Governor of Wyoming and a United States Senator, died today at Memorial Hospital here. He was 59 years old.
The Pan Ocean Oil Corporation announced it had agreed in principle to merge with United Bata Resources, Ltd., of Calgary, Alberta, through an exchange of stock.
Dr.Margaret Mead, the anthropologist, yesterday called for changes in society's attitude toward the role of women.

BUFFALO, Sept. 22 Security guards at the State University at Buffalo resumed their patrol duties on the campus today "under protest" after the university administration had refused the guards' demands that they be permitted to carry firearms.
Leonard Sillman has completed casting for his revival of Noel Coward's comedy, "Hay Fever," which opens at the Helen Hayes Theater on Nov. 9.

The Consolidated Edison Company filed a request with the Public Service Commission yesterday for an increase in gas rates effective Oct. 22 that would affect 1,230,000 customers in Manhattan, the Bronx, Westchester and parts of Queens.

N.M. Rothschild Sons, the merchant banking house founded in 1804 in London by Nathan Mayer Rothschild, has decided to cease operating as a partnership and incorporate as a private company, effective Sept. 30. The new concern, will be a limited liability company and will operate under the name N.M. Rothschild Sons Limited.
Interest rates again moved lower yesterday under the continued impact of the prime-rate reductions announced by major banks this week.

There was little surprise this week when a number of the nation's largest banks announced that they were cutting their prime interest rate from 8 per cent to 7.5 per cent. It has long been common knowledge that demand for bank loans was sluggish and that the Federal Reserve System has been working energetically to ease credit by expanding bank reserves.

That disclosure brought a flurry of official promises to step up public programs for combating exploitation of the working poor.

Wallkill, N.Y. a small town near Middletown in Orange County, negotiated the sale last night of $4.5 million of tax-exempt industrial development bonds--believed to be the first such issue sold in New York State.
OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 22 (AP) The Minnesota twins scored a 5-3 victory over the second-place Oakland Athletics tonight, clinching the American League West title for the Twins.

The euphoria was fun while it lasted. There we all were, a covey of critics, returned to work, fit, bronzed and smiling, ready to face another New York theater season. Chattering like reunited schoolboys, as happy as larks, and ready for anything.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 22 (Reuters) Cambodian troops pushed slowly through flooded rice paddies and heavy undergrowth today in an attempt to surround some 3,500 Communist troops blocking the route to the strategic provincial capital of Kompong Thom, according to military spokesmen here.

Dr. John Cashin, the black candidate for Governor who is running against George C. Wallace in Alabama, opened yesterday a financial drive that he hoped would take, Mr. Wallace out of national politics.
BILOXI, Miss., Sept. 22 The Southern Governors Conference adopted today an antibusing resolution that fell far short of the position some of its more conservative members had championed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22, President Nixon has now spoken three times about campus disorders must recently in yesterday morning's newspapers even though no widespread campus disorders have yet occurred in the new school year.
First Vanessa Redgrave marched for peace. Then Jane Fonda worked for peace, American Indians and Black Pantners. Now Yvette Mimieux is selling fashions made by poor Haitian women.

VENICE, Sept. 22 Discussions in Washington between European space officials and representatives of the United States appear to have removed a major obstacle to large-scale European participation in the American post-Apollo program.

Robberies and assaults against taxicab drivers have decreased sharply since the Police Department's new taxi surveillance unit started cruising the streets in midsummer in decoy cabs, the fleet owners said yesterday.

What is Asia? Asia is where about 60 per cent of humanity new lives and will continue to live. In the year 2000 Asia's population will be more than ten times that of the United States say, 3.7 billion souls.

Franklin E.Devlin former president of Monticello Raceway and the Harness Tracks of America and most recently the president of harness racing's Grand Circuit, died Monday night at St.Francis Hospital in Port Washington, L.I. He was 72 years old.

Although Columbia University still managed to wash its 8,000 windows and repaint 990 bedrooms in Wedgwood blue or sand, its annual end-of-summer housekeeping operations were curtailed this year by a severe financial crisis.
TRENTON, Sept. 22 Former Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio of Newark was sentenced to 10 years in prison and fined $25,000 in Federal Court here today for conspiracy and extortion.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23-- The Senate, by a 59-to-2 vote, approved tonight a comprehensive, $4-billion housing bill that includes a new Democraticsponsored program for development of "new cities" outside urban centers.
Sixty-five per cent of special delivery mail in Manhattan's business district--south of 59th Street--is being, delivered only along with regular mail, Representative Edward I. Koch said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UPI)--Mrs. John N. Mitchell has made the cover of next week's Life magazine, much to her delight.
There was some tactical regrouping at the WPIX license hearings yesterday, occasioned by the unexpected absence of Fred M. Thrower, president of the station.

Governor Rockefeller campaigned among construction workers and former football players yesterday, promising the workers thousands of new jobs and announcing to the former athletes that he was creating an "Empire State Medal for Excellence in Sports."
Because of the growing pressure from the independent companies that offer various facets of traditional agency service, Rumrill-Hoyt has restructured its operation.

The city administration stepped up its pressures yesterday on Bronx landlords whose employes are on strike. It reported 65 more notices of potential city takeovers of building services to end health hazards, for a total of 328 so far. It also reported 50 more warnings of rent cuts, for a total of 184.
Autumn arrived yesterday, thoroughly disguised in the trappings of midsummer.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation toned downward yesterday earlier projections of a record earnings year. Donald C. Burnham, chairman and chief executive officer, issued a statement after the close of trading on the New York Stock Exchange in which he said that third-quarter earnings are expected to fall short of last year's third quarter.

JEBEL ROS, Israeli-Occupied Syria, Sept. 23--The guerrilla stronghold known as Fatahland, where Palestinian irregulars roamed the slopes of Mount Hermon to shell and harass Israeli settlements in the valley below, seems to be broken up.
ROME, Sept. 23--John Joseph Cardinal Wright, the highest-ranking American in the Vatican, is learning his job in Rome by staying away from his desk.

ALBANY, Sept. 23--Fourteen Republican legislators, led by State Senator John J. Marchi, today formally endorsed James L. Buckley, the Conservative party candidate for Senator, over Senator Charles E. Goodell, the Republican-Liberal nominee.

The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday that consumer prices here last month rose at twice the national rate-0.4 per cent compared with 0.2 per cent--and faster than in three other major cities.

WALLKILL, N. Y., Sept 23-- Charles L. McKendrick, superintendent of the Wallkill Correctional Facility, formerly the Wallkill State Prison, died yesterday in Horton Memorial Hospital, Middletown. He was 59 years old.

Law enforcement officials in 17 tri-state municipalities will be able to exchange immediately visual and audio information when a new regional television system goes into operation next spring. Photographs, fingerprints and actual suspects will be available for immediate inspection by police officials, and training techniques can be shared by all participants.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 23--Robert L. Braddock, president and a director of the General Reinsurance Corporation of New York City, died Monday in Greenwich Hospital after a brief illness. He was 58 years old and lived at 6 Vista Avenue, Old Greenwich.
BONN, Sept. 23--Dr. Horst Schumann, a Nazi concentration camp doctor, went on trial in Frankfurt today, charged with the killing of 14,549 mental patients under Hitler's socalled euthanasia program.

PARIS, Sept. 23--Bourvil, the comic actor who for two decades delighted French and international movie audiences with his subtle portrayals of the innocent everyman or the notall-that-dumb yokel from the countryside, died here today of an undisclosed ailment. He was 57 years old and had been in poor health all through the shooting of his latest picture to be released next month, "The Atlantic Wall" of Marcel, Camus.

As usual, the Pension Fund Benefit Concert of the New York Philharmonic preceded the opening of the subscription season by two days. The Pension Fund Concert, which netted $30,000, took place on Tuesday evening in Philharmonic Hall with Leonard Bernstein conducting, and the Russian pianist Alexander Slobodyanik as soloist.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23--The United States, feeling that the most acute phase of the Jordanian crisis has apparently passed, announced tonight that it would attempt to evacuate peacefully more than 100 Americans from Jordan tomorrow aboard a chartered commercial airliner.
The city and most of the Northeast were brought to the brink of a massive electric blackout yesterday as a prolonged hot spell strained power supplies that were running perilously low.
Employment increased and unemployment decreased in both New York City and the state last month, the New York State Department of Labor reported yesterday.
ALBANY, Sept. 23--An office employe at the State Labor Department got up from his desk this morning, unwrapped a rifle and shot to death four secretaries. He then killed himself.

Three Chicago doctors have reported that a bacteria-killing antibiotic drug can benefit some patients with severe cases of a bone disease, common among middle-aged people, that is not caused by bacteria.

Miss Marie Smith, Washington Post staff writer and the author of three books, was married Sept. 4 to Arnold Schwartz of New York, president of the Brookdale Hospital Center in Brooklyn. The marriage was announced by her sister, Mrs. Ralph E. MacDonald of Winfield, Ill.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 23--A long-moribund plan for an international system of insurance for private investment in the less-developed countries has suddenly ..

A Manhattan warehouse said by the police to be filled with stolen goods worth about $6million, much of it apparently taken from shipments at John F. Kennedy International Airport--was uncovered early yesterday during a police raid.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23-- Three noted Democratic economists said today that continuation of the present economic policies of the Nixon Administration would doom the nation to a long period of "chronic and creeping paralysis" with high unemployment.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., Sept. 23 --The Internal Revenue Service disclosed in Washington today that it had no records of tax returns from Representative Martin B. McKneally over a 10-year period, including two years he served as national commander of the American Legion.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP)--President Nixon, apparently on the spur of the moment, drove to a suburban country club tonight and wound up playing "For He's a Jolly Good Fellow" on the piano.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) --The Federal Trade Commission accused the three major manufacturers of enzyme detergents today of false advertising in claiming their products are effective against all stains.

MIDDLEBURG, N. Y., Sept. 23--Arthur J. Goldberg carried his Democratic campaign for Governor into this active agricultural community today with a prediction that he and local candidates would "win in a sweep."

KENOSHA, Wis., Sept. 23-- Leslie Aspin, 32 years old, a former White House aide, won a recount today to become the Democratic nominee for the First District House seat held by Henry C. Schadeberg of Burlington, a Republican.

Rebellion over the reinstatement of eight blacks to the Syracuse football squad broke out last night among some of the white players who said they would not compete in Saturday's home opener against Kansas.
Seven Salvation Army "hallelujah lassies" dressed in blue and red claimed America "for God" yesterday in a reenactment of the army's arrival in this country 90 years ago.

Search teams from the United States and Canada continued a vast sea and air hunt yesterday for two men and a women who disappeared off Newfoundland Monday while attempting to cross the Atlantic in a huge orange balloon. The searchers said they had seen no sign of the missing balloonists.

BASEL, Switzerland, Sept. 23 (AP)--An unsuccessful attempt to corner the world cocoa market, or at least part of it, appears to have caused the loss of perhaps $40-million by the United California Bank in Basel, A.G., Swiss officials and trade spokesmen said today.

General Mills, Inc., realized a 10.9 per cent increase in earnings for the 13 weeks ended Aug. 30 on a sales gain of 10 per cent, both establishing records for the period, the report of the packaged consumer foods producer disclosed yesterday from Minneapolis headquarters.

"One Hour of Chamber Music" is the name of the new late-afternoon concert series under the direction of Jens Nygaard that began at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday, and the first event fulfilled the promise. It began at 5:30 and went straight through without intermission to end at 6:30.
Anyone expecting a standard, cutesie-pie show for undemanding tots from such a label as "Disney on Parade" has underestimated the Walt Disney organization and the National Broadcasting Company.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 23-- With the Manhattan skyline dimly visible in the smoggy sunlight across the Hudson, an Army Corps of Engineers survey boat left her temporary, oil-filmed mooring at Harborside Terminal today to show how the New York harbor waterfront needed care and cleaning up.
Miss Angie Oramas had only herself to beautify. She sat in her beauty parlor yesterday afternoon idly drumming her fingers on a desk, her blond locks wrapped around several pink curlers.

An unemployed elevator operator who has lived on the Lower East Side all his life was sworn in yesterday as the third juror in the trial of 13 Black Panthers accused of plotting to bomb public places.
TEL AVIV--Eight of the 20 songs in this week's Hebrew "Hit Parade" are from army shows.
The Redmen's Centennial tournament came to a close yesterday, with L.I.U. downing St. Francis, 11-10, for the title.

Anthony Quinn, the compelling actor with a face compared to the proverbial Telief map of the Alps, and Peggy Lee, the sultry singer, were paired last night on the Kraft Music Hall over the National Broadcasting Company network. Kraft, which actually is more adventurous in TV than many other sponsors, can concoct quite a salad.

The public utility companies of the Middle Atlantic states are not responsible for the hot and muggy weather that has plagued the region these past two days. But they are surely responsible for the poor planning and the equipment deficiencies that produced this week's power crisis and its blackouts and brownouts.

A walking table? That's what Barbara D'Arcy of Bloomingdale's calls it. The store's decorator knows full well that the table actually rolls on casters. But, she insists, it looks like it's walking. Anyway, the casters are not visible. They are hidden from view under a boxlike,
Soviet and Chinese provincial officials have signed an agreement for local trade across the Amur River frontier in the Far East, the Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia reports.

ATLANTA, Sept. 23--Former Gov. Carl E. Sanders of Georgia was decisively defeated today in a primary election bid for a comeback against Jimmy Carter, a wealthy liberal whose tough campaigning won him some of this state's large Wallace vote.
SIEGEN, Germany, Sept. 23 --The United States team split the points in its match with Yugoslavia, 2-2, in the adjourned games of the eighth round of the 19th Chess Olympiad this morning.

Poverty: The President announced the appointment of 18 persons to serve as members of the National Advisory Council on Economic Opportunity. The council will be headed by John E. Robson, a lawyer in the District of Columbia.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23-- The Justice Department demanded today that the Civil Aeronautics Board hold public hearings before acting on a proposal by three major airlines to reduce air service on 15 major air routes.

COPENHAGEN, Sept. 23-- The rather staid annual meeting of the World Bank and its sister organization, the International Monetary Fund, has provoked an unusual series of demonstrations by left-wing Danish students who say the institutions are instruments of neocolonialism.
A Board of Education research staff report on drug addiction among high school students here has come under criticism from top board officials who said that the document contained statistical errors.
The destruction of what was described as the largest and most successful auto theft ring ever to operate in New York City was announced yesterday by Bronx District Attorney Burton B. Roberts.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 23-- Vice President Agnew said today that he did not believe the impending visit of Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam to Washington "is going to serve a useful purpose." He said that such a visit "may be a mistake."

JERUSALEM, Sept. 23--Israeli authorities today welcomed the Jordanian Government's gains over forces from Syria but they said they believed that King Hussein had won only a battle in his internal struggle against Palestinian Guerrillas.
Representative Richard L. Ot tinger yesterday called for re form of the tax laws to end what he said was long-standing discrimination against women, especially working mothers.
At least publicly, the New York Jet coaches are avoiding the Jim Hudson issue.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23-- Consumer prices posted the smallest rise in nearly two years last month. The White House promptly hailed the development as proof that President Nixon's anti-inflationary strategy was working.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23-- The first Congressional hearing on national health insurance in 20 years opened in controversy today and halted abruptyl 102 minutes later.
MADRID, Sept. 23 (Reuters) --Esteban Bilbao, a leading government figure who served for 22 years, until 1965, as president of the Cortes (parliament), died today at the age of 91.

Some 3,000 gallons of gasoline and sulphuric acid spilled into Arthur Kill as the liquid was being loaded on a tanker off Carteret, N.J., early today, and tides threatened to wash the spillage onto nearby Staten Island, the Fire Department said.

Nathaniel J. (Bud) Hyland of Garden City, L.I., was named steward for the New York Racing Association yesterday, succeeding the late Earl Potter. The appointment, made by the N.Y.R.A. board of trustees, was approved by the New York State Racing Commission.

Edward Trenkmann of Spring Lake, N.J., and Delray Beach, Fla., director and treasurer of A. Trenkmann Estate, Inc., a real-estate concern of 187 Lafayette Street, died Tuesday in Jackson General Hospital, Miami, after an operation. His age was 77.

A five-volume set, "Issues Before the General Assemblies of the United Nations (19461965)" was presented yesterday morning to Secretary General U Thant by Joseph E. Johnson, president of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

CAIRO, Sept. 23--A delegation from the Arab leadership conference under way here returned to Cairo tonight from Jordan, accompanied by four members of the Central Committee of the Palestine guerrilla movement, following the announcement of an agreement with King Hussein to end the week-old conflict in Jordan.
Mayor Lindsay urged the City Planning Commission yesterday to legalize the quartering of artists in loft buildings in a 40-block area in lower Manhattan.

The Yale Repertory Theater of New Haven opens its fifth anniversary season Oct. 8 with "Story Theater Repertory," based on Isaac Bashevis Singer's "Gimpel the Fool," Gustav Flaubert's "Saint Julian the Hospitaler" and "Olympian Games," a new version of Ovid's "Metamorphoses."

The mobilization of "senior power"--the 1.4 million people in the state over 65 years of age who vote--to get local, state and national governmental action meeting the needs of the aging was begun yesterday at 10 older Americans' forums around the state.

When the Bull Terrier Club of America held its annual specialty, at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club in Darien, Conn., last week, there were 104 representatives of the breed from as far as California and Canada, the largest number ever assembled on this continent.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 23--Thailand proposed today that the Big Four powers together seek to restore peace in Southeast Asia.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23-- The chairman of President Nixon's Commission on Campus Unrest said today that public figures who tried to win political profit by criticizing student dissenters were risking further turmoil and diminishing the chances of a reconciliation between the younger generation and its worried elders.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23The House of Representatives, with little debate and no roll call vote, passed legislation aimed at reducing, at least somewhat, some of the charges paid by investors in mutual funds.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 23 (AP)-- Bob Gibson stopped the Chicago Cubs on two hits in the first game and Jerry Reuss scattered seven hits in the second as the St. Louis Cardinals swept a double-header by identical 2-1 scores tonight and dealt a damaging blow to the Chicagoans' title hopes.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23--How to translate our campaigning politicians:
Ripples from the liquidation of the First Devonshire Corporation continue to fan out from Wall Street to involve customers of other brokerage houses and even retired people in Miami Beach, Fla.
FARMINGDALE, L.I., Sept. 23--The New York Knicks had just completed practice today at the State University Argicultural and Technical College and Cazzie Russell opened a letter, read it and smiled.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 23-- The Jordanian Army and Air Force counterattacked Arab guerrillas in the north today, and the tanks backing the guerrillas retreated toward the Syrian border.
John T. Maye, president of the Transit Patrolman's Benevolent Association, called on Mayor Lindsay yesterday to add 1,800 men to subway duty because daytime subway crime had "skyrocketed."

MONKTON, Vt., Sept. 23-- Federal agents, state troopers and local sheriffs trudged through thick underbrush as a National Guard helicopter hovered overhead in an intensive search today for 5year-old Leah Sarachik, who has been missing from her New York home since Sept. 10.

A funeral service will be held today for Leopold Rybb, principal second violinist of the New York Philharmonic, at the Louis Suburban Chapel, 1301 Broadway, Fair Lawn, N. J., at 1:30 P.M. He was found dead at Fort Lee, N. J., on Tuesday. The police listed his death as suicide. He was 46 years old.
The American Stock Exchange made a broad advance yesterday as the exchange's price index closed at its best level in almost five months in active trading.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23-- The White House appears to have sent subtle signals to New York Republicans that it would not be disheartened by--and indeed might prefer--the election in November of James L. Buckley, Conservative party candidate for the Senate seat now held by Charles E. Goodell, Republican.

VENICE, Italy, Sept. 23-- American space officials were asked today for assurance that, if the West European nations scrapped their space programs in favor of a joint effort with the United States, the latter would not, in an economy move, back down.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23-- Dick Selma of the Philadelphia Phillies was fined $500 today for his angry outburst charging that last night's game between the Phillies and New York Mets had been "fixed" by the umpires.

The City Planning Commission last night rejected a rezoning plan that would have cleared the way for a major regional shopping center, marina, boatel and cabana club on a 77-acre site in the Mill Basin section of Brooklyn.

BONN, Sept. 23--The West German Parliament's annual budget debate got off to a tumultuous start this morning, when Finance Minister Alex Moller, a Social Democrat, likened the opposition Christian Democrats to the rulers of pre-1945 Germany.
WASHINGTON, Thursday, Sept. 24--Secretary of Labor James D. Hodgson announced this morning that a strike had been averted "for the present" on the nation's railroads.
Kling Kling, the established grass campaigner owned by John M. Schiff, withstood the closing rush of William Haggin Perry's Loud and won the $57,400 Lawrence Realization at Belmont Park yesterday.
Legal Aid Society lawyers blamed the city, Bellevue Hospital and the Manhattan District Attorney's office yesterday for the attempted suicide last Friday of a 21-year-old inmate of the Tombs.

Dr. Irvine H. Page, 69 years old, former director of research at the Cleveland Clinic, and Sir George Pickering, 66, of Oxford University were named yesterday to share equally the $50,000 Stouffer Prize for research in heart disease.

All three major commodities futures traded on the Chicago Board of Trade showed strength on the opening yesterday but corn futures weakened, wheat futures closed relatively unchanged and soybeans finished unchanged to up moderately.

A clubhouse celebration more spontaneous and less inhibited than their predecessors used to produce in winning pennants was staged by the New York Yankees last night after a 6-4 decision over the Washington Senators at Yankee Stadium had clinched second place for them in the American League's Eastern Division.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 23--A witness in the Charles M. Manson murder trial testified today that she overheard one of the defendants tell a friend some of the details of the slaughter on Aug. 9, 1969, at the home of Sharon Tate, the movie actress.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 23--Carl Morton and Mike Marshall brought out the worst in Pittsburgh's hitting again tonight, and the result was a 3-2 Montreal victory that further tightened the torrid Eastern Division race.

The United States, Attorney's office began criminal contempt-of-court proceedings yesterday against the union that refused to obey a court order and kept United Parcel Service drivers off the job for two weeks here last month.
The London stock market extended its strong upturn yesterday for the third day, although trading in leading shares tended to slacken.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23-- The president of the Regional Plan Association warned today that at the current rate of expansion for the acquisition of open space it would take 350 years to acquire the open space that the association believes necessary for the 70 million persons who will be living along the Boston-to-Washington corridor by the year 2000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23--A high Nixon Administration official accused officers of national teachers' groups today of trying to obstruct educational reform experiments in order to preserve bureaucratic power.
OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 23-- Ronald V. Dellums has an unusual political problem. He did so well in the primary June 2 that it might conceivably cost him victory in November.
The guests who have dined and doted on the food of Ruth Dove read like a Who's Who of the international theater, and there is a menu book with recipes to prove it.

The stock market, responding to favorable reports from troubled Jordan, surged forward along a broad front yesterday to register its best advance in three weeks. The DowJones industrial average rose 6.91 points to finish at 754.38.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP)--The Senate Finance Committee concluded today its months-long hearing on major welfare reform and Social Security bills. More than 200 witnesses were heard, and committee members remained unattracted to President Nixon's welfare plan.

HOUSTON, Sept. 23--A grand jury has cleared the police in the slaying of Carl Hampton Jr., the leader of a black militant organization who died after a three-hour gun battle with authorities here July 27.
Sid Tracey, a vaudeville performer, died on Monday in Los Angeles of complications resulting from a fall. He was 70 years old.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 23--Informed diplomats said here today that concerted action by the United States and the Soviet Union had been the key factor in easing the Jordanian crisis.
GENEVA, Sept. 23--The Council of States, the upper house of the Swiss Federal Parliament, approved without opposition today a Government proposal to give women the vote in national elections.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 23 --Harry D. Edwards, who retired as a works engineer for the Linde Division of Union Carbide Corporation in 1946, died today at his home, 6 West Avenue. His age was 84.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23 --Mr. and Mrs. John Menzies have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Melinda Menzies, a merchandising director for Modern Bride magazine in New York, to Nathan Mobley Jr., a candidate for a Ph.D. degree at Columbia University. He is the son of Mr. Mobley of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mrs. Eleanor Smith Mobley.

MOSCOW, Sept. 23--The Soviet Union announced today that the unmanned Luna 16 spacecraft was due to land in Soviet Kazakhstan at 8:20 A.M. tomorrow Moscow time (1:20 A.M. Thursday, Eastern daylight time) with the rock samples it dug from the lunar surface.
LONDON, Sept, 23-The fastest-selling book in Britain today is by Mary Wilson, poet, the wife of Harold Wilson, politician.
The Continental Oil Company fell in line yesterday by announcing an agreement with the Government of Libya calling for sharply higher tax payments to the North African nation.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23-- The New York Mets insisted again tonight that reports of their demise were greatly exaggerated.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23-- The State Department said today that it had been several days since there had been any direct contact with the Palestinian guerrillas in Amman who are holding 54 or 55 hostages from hijacked airliners.

The domestic household worker was described yesterday as "the most exploited woman in America" because she is ineligible for protection of the minimum-wage laws, has no health insurance or job security and often receives less than $60 for a 60-hour week.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 23 (UPI) --Pancho Gonzales, seeded fifth, advanced to the third round of the $50,000 Pacific Southwest open tennis championships today by beating Dick Crealy of Australia in a close battle, 7-6, 3-6, 7-6.
"Modern Opening Chess Theory," No. 100 in the chess players series originating in England, is now available from the United States Chess Federation in Newburgh, N. Y., at $2.95.

QUEBEC, Sept. 23--Premier Robert Bourassa of Quebec will visit California and New York early in October to seek new investments for this largely French-Canadian province and to talk about its plans for a huge hydroelectric project on the eastern flank of James Bay.

MADRID, Sept. 23 (AP)-- Tom Kite of Austin, Tex., finished with three birdies on the last four holes for a 71 today that gave, the United States a one-stroke lead over South Africa in the first round of the Eisenhower Cup world amateur golf championship.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 23--The Cambodian military spokesman said today that government troops had occupied several villages near the enemy stronghold of Tangkok.

LONDON--It is hard to realize, but it is still less than ten years since Presidents of the United States did away with the last safety controls over their words to the people of the United States and to the world.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UPI)--The Securities and Exchange Commission today proposed a tougher reporting rule for broker-dealer firms that withdraw from membership in national security exchanges.

Business loans at large banks across the country increased a scant $177-million in the week of Sept. 17, when corporations normally borrow large amounts to pay Federal income taxes, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday. By contrast, in the similar week of 1969, business loans increased $966million.

After an inexcusable delay, the Supreme Court in Queens has handed down an inexplicable opinion. Yesterday, three months after the June party primaries and one day after rerun races in several boroughs, the court ruled that former President of the Borough of the Bronx Herman Badillo would have to undergo a rerun contest in his quest for the Democratic Congressional nomination in the city's new triborough 21st Congressional District.

YONKERS, Sept. 23--The New York State Harness Racing Commission ordered the eighth race canceled tonight at Yonkers Raceway, marking the first time in the 21-year-old history of the Westchester track that a race was called off on a regularly scheduled program. Yonkers opened in 1950.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23-- Every autumn in recent years there has been some confusion about how much desegregation has been achieved in Southern schools. The trouble arises from the complexity of the subject and conflicting interpretations by those involved.

The Philadelphia Coke division of the Eastern Associated Coal Corporation announced yesterday that it would raise prices of foundry coke from $42.75 a ton to $49.75 a ton, effective Oct. 1. The increase was attributed to higher costs.

The International Business Machines Corporation announced yesterday a new computer system that for the first time in the history of generalpurpose computers utilizes semiconductor circuits for the entire main memory of the machine.

The Nixon Administration has reason to be cheered by the official announcement yesterday that living costs rose only two-tenths of 1 per cent last month. No single month provides a reliable guide to price trends, but the August report on consumer costs--especially when coupled with the simultaneous decline of four-tenths of 1 per cent in the wholesale price index--does represent the strongest evidence thus far that inflationary pressures are easing.
