CRANFORD, N. J., Sept. 23-- Adolph Ulbrich, a lawyer in Elizabeth and a former Mayor of Rahway, died yesterday at his home. He was 79 years old and lived at 30E Parkway Village here.
Just before 4 P.M. Tuesday, a systems operator punched two buttons in Consolidated Edison's Energy Control Center at West End Avenue and 65th Street.

New York enthusiasts are suffering from a surfeit of regional championships this month. Four days after the close of the Long Island Regionals, the New York-New Jersey Conference Regional begins today at Grossinger's in the Catskills.

ROWAYTON, Conn., Sept. 23 --The three boats that fared best in the two opening events of the world championship for Class C catamarans yesterday fared best again today. Among them, Scimitar was the winner once more.

Anyone willing to pay $1.1 million to the city can be in the running for the ownership of some 20 acres of island in the East River that is heavy with maple trees, thick with wild plants, whirring with pheasants and dappled with stone buildings and a bit of history.

Do New Yorkers ever have fun any more, plain old fun? Are there any adults left who actually play? We all know the catechism: No, of course not. Why? Because New Yorkers are hardened, while fun and play are properties of innocence.

DETROIT, Sept. 23 (AP)--The United Automobile Workers said today that 6,300 more workers would be called out on strike against the General Motors Corporation tomorrow, raising the number made idle by the strike in the United States and Canada to 373,437.

The freshest, funniest and most endearing entertainment crew in town moored at a cabaret Wednesday night. "Dames at Sea," glory be, is back intact, after its original Off-Broadway smash and several other ports of a call. Has the bloom gone? Heck, no.
GENEVA, Sept. 23--The International Committee of the Red Cross today appointed Kai J. Warras, a Finnish relief expert, to head a new committee for the coordination of its relief program in Jordan.
Time is running out for final Congressional action this year on President Nixon's most imaginative domestic proposal, reform of the socially destructive welfare system.
MIAMI, Sept. 23--Cuba announced today that her military forces had killed one and captured eight armed "mercenaries who came from the United States" and landed in Oriente Province on Sept. 14.
ROME, Sept. 23 (AP)--Pope Paul VI appealed for a truce in Jordan before the fighting led to "incredible catastrophes." He offered his help in any peace initiative.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., Sept. 23 --When the Dallas Cowboys released Otto Brown a couple of weeks ago, the 6-foot-1-inch, 190-pound defensive back had an idea that maybe the New York Giants could use him and he was right.

The New York March of Dimes will open its annual fund-raising campaign Oct. 19 with the 16th annual luncheon and fashion show of the Nelson Rosenthal Group in the Grand Ballroom at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Mrs. Trinette Dewey Royce, president of the Gage Tollner restaurant at 374 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, died Tuesday of a heart attack in Perth Amboy (N.J.) General Hospital. She was 64 years old and lived in Matawan, N.J.

A newly discovered copy of the first printing of the Declaration of Independence, one of the broadsides that on the night of July 4, 1776 and July 5 was rushed to patriots on horseback and by stage, is on exhibition today and tomorrow at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.
NEW HAVEN, Sept. 22-- George Edwards, one of the seven Black Panthers facing trial here in the murder of Alex Rackley, pleaded guilty today to two counts of aggravated assault.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23--Attorney General John N. Mitchell has permitted a new Mississippi election law to go into the statute books, reportedly despite advice from his civil rights staff that the law is designed to prevent the election of Negro candidates.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23-- Mayor Lindsay, citing warnings that New York City faced the threat of fuel rationing, said today that the Nixon Administration lacked a "coherent national fuel policy."

Former Bronx Borough President Herman Badillo's Democratic nomination for Congress in the new three-borough 21st District--was voided yesterday on the ground of irregular votes. A Queens Supreme Court justice ordered a new primary to be held Oct. 8.

John Weitz is feeling strangely out of things these days. You know, old-fashioned. One of the first designers of women's fashions to seek to revolutionize men's clothes, he's not much in favor of peacocks or dandies. He advocates color, strong prints and a "cheerful, healthy disposition," which is a far cry from ruffles and beads for men.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23 (UPI)--An uncontrolled forest fire destroyed hundreds of acres of timber today in a remote section of Northern California's redwood forests.
WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 23 --Mr. and Mrs. William J. Halpern have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sharyn Denis Halpern, to Gary Michael Kevin, son of Mrs. Mac Chase of Atlantic Beach.

A turnabout in consumer confidence was apparent in July and August, the National Industrial Conference Board said yesterday. Optimism concerning the business outlook improved for the first time in more than a year, as shown in an increase in buying plans for automobiles and new homes.
AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 23-- King Hussein flashed a V-forVictory sign last night and declared: "I believe the brunt of the problem is over."
This week's trend toward lower interest rates ran into some snags yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 23--The California Savings and Loan League is asking its 221 members to provide some $500-million to finance low-cost housing in the state.

TOKYO, Sept. 23 -- The Japanese chemical fiber industry is feeling the first warning signs of a downturn after a long, heady boom during which production, investment and exports soared and the industry rejected American pleas for voluntary export restraints.

Stern Brothers, which suffered the severest blow in its 102-year history when it closed its big New York store last year, will open its first new store in seven years today in the Willowbrook Mall in Wayne, N.J.

NEWARK, Sept. 23--A Federal grand jury that is investigating organized crime in New Jersey today indicted John Riggi, a reputed lieutenant in the Mafia family headed by Simone Rizzo (Sam the Plumber) DeCavalcante, on charges of violating Federal labor statutes.

QUITO, Ecuador, Sept. 23 (UPI)--The armed forces chief of staff, Gen. Edmundo Baquero Salgado, quit today in a dispute with President Jose Maria Velasco Ibarra over the reshuffling of high armed forces commands by the President.

SUVA, Fiji, Sept. 23--South Sea Island leaders meeting here are concerned with a struggle to meet the demands of youth without eroding the traditional dreamy existence that has enchanted Western travelers for two centuries or more.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23-- With law and order emerging as perhaps the key campaign issue, the Democratic-controlled Congress moved swiftly today to give President Nixon the anticrime and drug-abuse legislation he has long sought.

Joseph Puro, president of the Purofield Down Products Corporation, died Tuesday of a heart attack in his office, 319 Fifth Avenue. He was 51 years old and lived at 46 Hawthorne Lane, Great Neck, L. I.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 23--The Presbyterian Church of Southern Africa has defied a warning by Prime Minister John Vorster to withdraw from the World Council of Churches.

Champion boxer Sugar Ray Robinson had a bout with the Internal Revenue Service some years ago, and he won what could be called a technical knockout. It also turned out to be a victory for many other taxpayers.

DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 23 --On the eve of the Silver Anniversary Little Brown Jug, the celebrated test for 3-yearold pacers, word came today from New Egypt, N.J., that Rachel and Stanley Dancer had sold Most Happy Fella, the colt favored to capture tomorrow's classic, for $1-million. The son of Meadow Skipper-- Laughing Girl has been ac-...
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23-- Two dissenting members of the Commission on Obscenity and Pornography urged Congress today to disregard the commission's forthcoming majority report.
AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 23 --"There's coffee for breakfast today!" cries a telephone operator, named Nasser, who flinches only a trifle as a detonation--probably from a mortar shell--sounds outside.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 23-- "I have a personal question for Ted Hood," Bill Ficker said mysteriously after having won the third race of the America's Cup yesterday.

The New York City Opera Orchestra voted yesterday afternoon to go on strike against the New York City Opera following the performance of Massenet's "Manon" on Sunday night if an employment contract between the orchestra and the company has not been negotiated by that time.
DEY ETH, Cambodia, Sept. 23--The war came to Dey Eth the day before yesterday at 7 P.M.

WASHINGTON. Sept. 23-- Warning that several major preventable diseases are increasing sharply, Dr. Paul B. Cornely, president of the American Public Health Association urged President Nixon today to sign a bill authorizing federally supported vaccination programs.

As long ago as the early nineteen-fifties some educators and Federal officials marked down Dr. Sidney P. Marland Jr., who was then superintendent of schools in Darien, Conn., as "a comer" in his field. On Tuesday President Nixon nominated him to become the 19th United

HONG KONG, Sept. 23-- The death of Kung Peng, for many years a close associate of Premier Chou En-lai and a high-ranking functionary, in Communist China's Foreign Ministry, was announced today by Hsinhua, the Chinese press agency.
The Reading Company's chairman, William R. Daley, has liquidated his interest in the railroad, it was disclosed yesterday in the New York Stock Exchange's insiders' list.

The great strength of photography as an art often lies in its concreteness, in its power to isolate, define and ennoble a subject that, to the naked eye, is simply part of some larger and undifferentiated mass.
Three Long Island Rail Road policemen who had been accused of beating a commuter who later died were acquitted yesterday by the unanimous vote of a three-judge Criminal Court panel.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 The House passed tonight a bill designed to crack down on narcotics traffic and use, but with reduced penalties for lesser drug violations. The vote was 341 to 6.
Three editors were sworn in yesterday as members of the jury that will try 13 Black Panthers for plotting to bomb public places. They bring the total chosen to six.

These are excerpts from the Government brief filed Sept. 22 in the U.S. Supreme Court replying to Massachusetts' challenge of the legality of the Vietnam war. It was signed by Solicitor General Erwin N. Griswold and Assistant Attorney General William D. Ruckelshaus:
The rise of the computer has helped to bring about a matching increase in the number of research companies offering syndicated services to the worlds of marketing and advertising.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24 Aprosecution witness who testified that she had overheard Susan Denise Atkins giving details of the murder of Sharon Tate said today that she had been in a mental hospital with in the last two weeks.
Members of The New York Times unit of the Newspaper Guild voted overwhelmingly yesterday to authorize guild officers to call a strike against the newspaper.

President Nixon's call for Congressional action to authorize Federal intervention in the wake of campus bombings or arson is so patently redundant that its motives as well as its effects raise serious questions.

TOKYO, Sept. 24 The United States took an important step toward removing a major irritant in relations with Japan today by notifying the Japanese Foreign Ministry that it would soon remove B-52 bombers from Okinawa.

NEWARK, Sept. 24 Robert H. Finch, a personal counselor to President Nixon, toured a predominantly black slum neighborhood of Newark today, but some black Democrats accused him of making the tour in order to campaign for Nelson Gross, the Republican Senatorial candidate.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. As if the United States were not sufficiently beset by problems in Southwest and Southeast Asia, it is about to enter a new time of troubles in Latin America. Already two points of possible and probable danger are discernible.

These news-analysis articles reflect how the events in Jordan are interpreted in Cairo, Jerusalem and Washington. National interests and varying factual information have produced different conclusions, including these on key factors in the crisis:
ALBANY, Sept. 24 (AP) The State will conduct a second million-dollar lottery this year, the Tax Department announced today.

Fashion and protest are no strangers to each other, but never has a new fashion encountered as much hostility or been embroiled in as much controversy as the midi hemline, a length that hovers around the calf.

Herman Badillo said yesterday there was only a "one-in-abillion" chance that irregular votes could have affected his victory in the June 23 primary in the 21st Congressional District, but that a Queens Supreme Court justice prevented introduction of testimony to this effect before voiding Mr. Badillo's nomination.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 24 Red Cross officials here have arranged for the transfer of 205 wounded Jordanians tomorrow to hospitals in the Israeli-occupied west bank.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 24 (UPI) Ken Holtzman, aided by a second-inning homer by Joe Pepitone kept the Chicago Cubs in the thick of the National eLague East race tonight by stopping the St. Louis Cardinals on seven hits in a 7-1 victory.
Dr. William J. McGill, the president of Columbia University, has issued a set of rules on campus political activity to avoid jeopardizing the tax-exempt status of the university.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 24 (AP) A United States Military Academy spokesman said today that Cary Donham, the cadet who tried to leave the academy as a conscientious objector, had formally departed as an enlisted man on leave.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Sept. 24 Stanford University's trustees today named the institution's second-ranking academic officer, Dr. Richard W. Lyman, as Stanford's seventh president, succeeding Dr. Kenneth S. Pitzer.
One of the Nixon Administration's top economists rejected yesterday a characterization that the economy had been in a "growth recession" during 1969 and 1970.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 Despite economic troubles and reported conservative leanings, the nation's workers are sending more money to union political organizations than in 1968.

NEWAR, Sept. 24 Simone Rizzo (Sam the Plumber) DeCavalcante, reputed boss of a New Jersey Mafia family, was convicted by a Federal jury with two co-defendants here tonight of conspiring to extort money from the operators of an illegal dice game.

SIEGEN, West Germany, Sept. 24 The United States and Czechoslovakia split their game points, 2-2, in the four-board ninth-round match here this morning, when all adjourned games were completed. Thus the United States team has posed 20 of a possible 36.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) Despite a flood of rumors, Agriculture Secretary Clifford M. Hardin does not plan to quit his job to take over as head of Purdue University or any other institution, one of his top assistants says.

DUBLIN, Sept. 24 United States Embassy officials here have been scouring the Irish countryside for distant cousins to meet President Nixon and Mrs. Nixon the former Patricia Ryan during their forthcoming visit here.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 24 Miss Anne Carlisle Campbell, who expects to receive a master's degree in art history fmm the New York University Institute of Fine Arts next month, plans to be married in November to Michael Timothy Ryan, who is studying for a Ph.D. in history at N.Y.U.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 24 (UPI) The United States command said today that 52 Americans were killed in the Vietnam war last week and 333 were wounded. The number killed, the same as reported for the week ended Aug. 22, was the lowest in nearly four years.
MADRID, Sept. 24 (AP) Steady but unspectacular play by the youngsters of the American team today lengthened the United States lead in the Eisenhower Cup world amateur team golf championship.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) Arthur A. Fletcher, Assistant Secretary of Labor for Wages and Standards, accused labor unions today of exerting heavy influence in Congress to avoid fully opening their membership to nonwhites.
The Manhattan District Attorney's office is investigating the death of a man who was arrested by the police on Aug. 31 and died the next morning after spending the night in the 14th Precinct station.
Several notes of universality were struck on Wednesday evening by D. (for David) Nzomo, a singer and guitarist from Kenya, in a concert at the Folklore Center, 321 Avenue of the Americas.
Paul L. Adams, the Conservative party candidate for Governor, asked the New York State A.F.L.-C.LO. yesterday to hear his views before deciding on which candidate to endorse.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 The antiballistic missile debate in Congress was ended today with a decision to restrict the Safeguard ABM system to the protection of Minuteman intercontinental missile bases.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 24 The pallbearers were waiting at sea for Gretel II's America's Cup burial today, but the Australian challenger in the world's most celebrated yacht competition refused to be buried.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 Union, railroad and Government officials resumed negotiations today in the firemen's dispute after agreeing early this morning to postpone a strike threat for two weeks.

Sophia Loren, standing alone on the Music Hall's vast stage, scored a personal hit in a mass interview with about 100 newspaper, radio and television reporters and a capacity audience of 6,000 before the first showing yesterday morning of "Sunflower," her latest film.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 Senator Birch Bayh's campaign to force a Senate vote on the merits of electoral reform opened in row gear today with no immediate prospect of success.

Muhammad Ali, shorn of both his boxer's license and his heavyweight championship 3 years ago when he refused induction into the armed services, made a formal and subdued application for a license yesterday at the offices of the New York State Athletic Commission.

SAN DIEGO In this seawashed city where the sun shines an average of 353 days a year and the mean high temperature of the coldest and warmest months varies by only 14 degrees, autumn comes imperceptibly.

The mysterious case of Don Maynard's inconsistency in practice sessions has Weeb Ewbank "puzzled" as to the wide receiver's status for the New York Jets' game against the Patriots in Boston on Sunday.

They sound like names for crunchy new breakfast foods. And when you lump them all together, they look like the remnants at the bottom of a bowl of alphabet soup: SMACK, SOCK, POOFF, STEMS, MOXIE, WHIM, GAMS, FADD, MAMMA, BALL.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 The Cuban Government, in the first action of its kind, returned an American airplane hijacker to the United States today.

The greatest gypsy violinist of all Hungary, in the opinion of many connoisseurs of the gypsy violin, is Sandor Lakatos, and he would not strenuously disagree. "I hope you realize," he cautioned a visitor during a rehearsal break in the Abbey Victoria Hotel ballroom, "that this is not the average level of gypsy-violin playing in Hungary."

HONG KONG, Sept. 24 Three weeks ago a weary, dust-covered contingent of young men and women, some carrying hoes and shovels to symbolize their peasant origin, arrived on foot at Peking's Tien An Men Square after having walked 50 miles from Tientsin in four days.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (UPI) The Ford Motor Company, prompted by a Senate ethics Committee admonition to legislators, announced today that it was abandoning its practice of leasing Lincoln Continentals and other luxury automobiles to members of Congress at heavily discounted rates.

The Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company announced yesterday it has agreed to acquire the Missouri Kansas Pipe Line Company through an exchange of stock worth about $24 million. Directors of both companies have approved the agreement.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 24 (UPI) A five-member Appellate Court panel ruled unanimously today that Representative Richard Max McCarthy could not run for re-election in his 39th Congressional District under the Conservation party banner.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 George Meany, head of the country's largest labor organization, told a Congressional committee today that national health insurance would inevitably become law even though the Administration was hostile to it.

PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., Sept. 24 Dr. and Mrs. Charles Taintor have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Deborah Ann Taintor, to Dr. John Sampson Toll, son of Oliver. Wolcott Toll of Chevy Chase, . Md., and the late Mrs. Toll. The wedding is planned for this fall.
The Federal Reserve continued to pursue an expansive credit policy during the latest two weeks, banking data published yesterday disclosed.

Provisions in the State Corrections Code that allow longer prison sentences for women than men for the same crime were among the many discriminatory practices examined yesterday at a public hearing on the status of women.

Serena Saunders was sitting on a doorstep on East 101st Street yesterday with her 7-month-old daughter, Deirdre, cradled in her lap. As soon as she saw Bruce Davidson she called out, "Hey, will you photograph me and the baby?"

TEL AVIV, Sept. 24 The Israeli Deputy Premier, Yigal Allon, warned King Hussein of Jordan tonight that his decisive military victory meant he must accept full responsibility for guerrilla, actions along the cease-fire line with Israel.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 24 Win or lose, the New York Mets will remember 1970 as the year they learned some harsh lessons, and No. 1 is that pitching is a fragile commodity.
The stock market moved decisively along the comeback trail yesterday as volume on the New York Stock Exchange whooshed to 21.34 million shares in the second heaviest trading day on record.
A company headed by Zsa Zsa Gabor, Miss Hungary of 1936 and a reigning queen on Broadway and television, may soon be swallowed up by a conglomerate. She is altogether happy about the prospect.
DETROIT, Sept. 24 The General Motors Corporation today sharply raised its prices on 1971 cars and warned that another price increase might be forthcoming.
MOSCOW, Sept. 24 The Soviet Union's Luna 16 landed successfully today in Soviet Kazakhstan, completing the first round trip flight by an unmanned spacecraft to the surface of the moon.

PARIS, Sept. 24 The White House was understood today to have proposed that President Nixon start his European trip a day earlier with a visit here Saturday, apparently in a gesture to President Pompidou.

DETROIT, Sept. 24 (UPI) Contract talks between the striking United Automotive Workers and General Motors moved at a leisurely pace today while both sides put pressure on local units to resolve their unsettled differences.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (UPI) A rancher, a former professor, a labor-management consultant and the heads of several big businesses were reported today to be among nine men who will be nominated by President Nixon to run the new United States postal service.

Gordon T. Wallis, the 51year-old vice chairman of the Irving Trust Company, has been named the new chairman and chief executive officer of the bank, effective Dec. 13, it was announced yesterday. He will succeed George A. Murphy, 64, the present chairman and chief executive officer, who will retire on that date.

Construction of a City College building was halted yesterday because of fear of a confrontation between workers and picketing black and Puerto Rican construction workers, who demanded jobs on the project.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) The Navy told the Senate today that it was sharply restricting weapons exercises around the island of Culebra off Puerto Rico.

BOSTON, Sept. 24 (AP) The police obtained today warrants charging two women identified as students at Brandeis University and two men with murdering a policeman during a $26,000 holdup yesterday at a branch bank.
OAKLAWN, Ill., Sept. 22 Outside the new split-level house on the new, largely treeless block, a sign proclaimed: "This Home Is a Stevenson for Senator Home Headquarters."

A 10-inch-long pipe bomb exploded in a women's rest room yesterday near offices of the Japanese and Kuwait Governments at 235 East 42d Street. No one was injured in the blast, which demolished a toilet and shattered tile.

DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 24 The Little Brown Jug, the time-honored pacing stake, that traditionally has been kind to favorites, wound up today with the prerace choice, Most Happy Fella, the victor after threeone-mile heats at the Delaware County Fairground.
The London stock market continued to advance yesterday in active trading after absorbing light profit taking.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 24 One of the two American seamen who hijacked an ammunitions ship and won asylum in Cambodia six months ago is now confined in a mental hospital near Pnompenh, according to United States officials following his case.
KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., Sept. 24 Representative Richard L. Ottinger said today that he had agreed to two more televised debates with his Republican and Conservative rivals for the United States Senate.
A New York representative of the Palestinian guerrilla movement brushed aside as "irrelevant" yesterday the question whether the 54 or 55 hijacked hostages under its control were alive and well.
A new centralised public address system, designed to tell passengers when trains are running late, went into operation yesterday at all Long Island Railroad stations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 If Senator Birch Evan Bayh Jr. has "a full understanding of the art of the possible," as a political friend once said, he may yet win the fight for Senate approval of his constitutional amendment for election of the President by popular vote.
Miss Burma Haiblum and Charles Reid Hulten were married here last evening by Rabbi Hershel Levin at he Hampshire House.
Train timetables are getting thinner and thinner these days, but the one thing never in short supply on the railroads is an impending strike deadline.

AREA A Off-shore anglers are taking albacore in the 8-to-14-pound range and 2to-3-pound bonita southeast of Barnegat Light. Best pickings seem to be about five miles off the beaches. Plenty of weakfish have appeared closer in and are being taken with bait in water 15 to 20 feet deep. There are plenty of small blues along the beaches while weakfish and kingfish are being taken in Barnegat Bay by boats chumming with large shrimp.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 The President, the Secretary of State and the Attorney General went off golfing at Burning Tree this afternoon (with, of all people, George Meany, the labor leader) to celebrate the end of the most nerve-racking week of the unending crisis in the Middle East.

The Realty Equities Corporation, a diversified real estate company also engaged in entertainment-oriented businesses, reported yesterday a loss of $13,157,905, or $5.17 a share, after provision for recoverable taxes for the year ended March 31, 1970.

MOSCOW, Sept. 24 Aleksei G. Stakhanov, the coal miner whose name became the catchword for the superworker in the nineteenthirties and forties, has been restored to public attention by being designated a Hero of Socialist Labor, the highest civilian honor.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 24 The British Foreign Secretary, Sir Alec DouglasHome, called today for urgent United Nations action to end the "horrifying series of events" in the Middle East. However, he ruled out the idea of foreign intervention.
GENEVA, Sept. 24 The board of Investors Overseas Services Management, Ltd., declared today a third-quarter dividend of 20 Canadian cents.

HOUSTON, Sept. 24 (UPI) The women tennis stars who bolted the United States Lawn Tennis Association to play in this week's Virginia Slims invitation tournament plan to make their break with the U.S.L.T.A. permanent and form their own tennis tour, Mrs. Billie Jean King said today. She said they hoped to start the tour with a series of tournaments on the West Coast, Texas, Boston and in Florida next January and February.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 24 (UPI) Dave Bristol, who was discharged a year ago after piloting Cincinnati to third place in the National League, was rehired today as manager of the Milwaukee Brewers of the American League a fifthplace team.

MONKTON, Vt., Sept. 24 Two determined New York parents stood vigil near an apple orchard here today while special teams of state troopers completed a futile field-byfield search for 5-year-old Leah Sarachik.
DETROIT, Sept. 24 Leo Walsh, a fireman on the Penn Central Railroad, believes that firemen still have a vital job in keeping the nation's railroad running safely and efficiently.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Friday, Sept. 25 Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian guerrilla leader, agreed early today to receive a delegation representing Arab governments that are seeking to end the civil war in Jordan, now in its 10th day.

W. Hustace Hubbard, a retired New York cotton broker and former member of the board of managers of the New York Cotton Exchange, died Wednesday in Elizabeth town, N.Y., where he lived. His age was 89.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) College presidents and student government presidents from nearly 400 campuses begin a weekend conference here tomorrow to organize a nationwide forum to improve the student's image.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 23 (AP) Palestinian guerrilla resistance was reportedly collapsing today in northern Jordan before a Jordanian Army attack, and King Hussein appeared to be regaining oontrol of the country.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 24 The New York Mets must have thought it was all a practical joke. They had heard that the Pittsburgh Pirates, the team they'll try to overtake this weekend, suddenly had forgotten how to reach home plate, and some of them came tonight to see such a funny sight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 The Defense Department plans to cut three more divisions from the standing Army over the next nine months, bringing the number of divisions to the lowest point in more than 10 years. Additional cuts are under consideration.

Now that Jordan seems to be calming down, the continuing buildup of Egyptian and Soviet SAM missiles in the Suez truce zone in flat violation of the cease-fire agreement demands urgent attention as the chief obstacle to revival of hope for peace negotiations between Israel and the Arabs.

COLUMBUS, Ga., Sept. 24 (AP) Bert Greene, hampered since May by bursitis in his left shoulder, sank a 35-foot birdie putt on the first hole today and carded a five-under-par 33, 32 65 for the opening round lead in the $60,000 Green Island open golf tournament.

Davey Feld, who was replaced as referee for the Floyd Patterson-Charlie Green fight less than an hour before the bout on Sept. 15 and bodily ejected from Madison Square Garden by special policemen, said yesterday he planned to "sue everyone responsible."

Dr. Elsie Regina Kengla, professor emeritus of education at Hunter College, died Wednesday at Flushing Hospital in Queens at the age of 71. A resident of Flushing, she had been on the Hunter College faculty for 39 years before her retirement in 1962.
AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 24 About 60 Americans and other foreigners were evacuated from Amman today while shots rang out in the battered city around them.

BOZEMAN, Mont., Sept. 24 Alfred Iddles, the former president of the Babcock Wilcox Company, a supplier of conventional and nuclear-power systems and components, died here yesterday. He was 80 years old.
Senator Charles E. Goodell made an appeal for campaign contributions last night by telling a group of financial contributors: "I need it desperately."

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Sept. 24 James L. Buckley declared today that he was "the only choice" New York voters had this year if they were interested in having a United States Senator "who can work in cooperation with the Nixon Administration instead of lobbing hand grenades at it."
Government bond prices declined yesterday for the first time in two weeks as the trend toward lower interest rates lost some of its momentum.

AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 24 (UPI) Frank Salzhandler, a University of Texas swimming star, will appeal to the school administration the coach's edict that his shoulder-length long hair must be cut by Monday or he would be ruled off of the team.

Rent reduction hearings scheduled in the Bronx as a result of the impact on services of a building workers' strike were postponed yesterday until 24 hours after the conclusion of a State Supreme Court hearing that begins today on a landlords' challenge to the city's powers.

Maybe this time they can pull it off. Certainly, they are determined. Most of them don't belong to any protest organizations, will not march in any parades and are not about to tear up their charge accounts.

ALBANY, Sept. 24 The State Crime Control Planning Board has awarded $4-million of Federal funds for combating crime to New York City, including nearly half a million for eliminating delay and inefficiency in the Criminal Courts.
Another sophomore has won a starting quarterback job. This one is Don Jackson, who will make his varsity debut at Baker Field tomorrow when Columbia opens its 1970 football season against Lafayette.
Irving J. Louis Sr., a senior vice president of Bache Co., Inc., international investment bankers, died yesterday at his home, 75 Central Park West. His age was 86.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 24 Signs have been received by American officials that the Japanese Government is considering making an important gesture toward the United States that would improve the trading climate between the two nations, it was learned today.
CAIRO, Sept. 24 The death, destruction and suffering in Jordan during the last week are viewed in Cairo as an inevitable result of the over-all Arab need to end the deadlocked conflict with Israel.

LITCHFIELD, Conn., Sept. 24 Watson Beach Day, who retired in 1954 as chairman of the board of the Clark Estates, Inc., 30 Wall Street, New York, a management company, died yesterday at his home on South Street. His age was 88.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 Freight traffic on United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage last week were both below the volume in the corresponding week of 1969.
Columbia University has ordered a reduction in teaching staff and the elimination of a "signficant" number of courses in its 28 academic departments of arts and sciences.

ROWAYTON, Conn., Sept. 24 While adversity struck four of the other contenders and compelled their withdrawals, Otto Scherer and Gene Miller sailed blithely toward the world Class C catamaran championship today.

LONDON, Sept. 24 Absent from the theater for seven years, Terence Rattigan returns with a piece that joins the growing list of middle-brow history plays with which the West End is rallying its old public. "A Bequest to the Nation" at the Haymarket Theater is about Nelson and Lady Hamilton, and, apart from Zoe Caldwell's loose language as the hero's disreputable consort, it could have been written at any time since Pinero.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 Key sources within the Nixon Administration and the Senate indicated today that they would have no difficulty accepting the House Commerce Committee's additions to the Federal loan guarantees for the preservation of rail passenger service.
HADLYME, Conn., Sept. 24 (UPI) A funeral service for Dr. Alice Hamilton, who was a pioneer in the field of industrial medicine in the United States, was held today at her home here.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 24 Jimmy (The Greek) Snyder doesn't think much of the Mets' chances to catch Pittsburgh in the National League East baseball race.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) The nation's imports rose to a record last month while exports fell, reducing the favorable balance of trade to its lowest point since April, the Commerce Department reported today.

The old idea that it is a mistake for husbands and wives to play bridge together may be due for revision, judging by some recent tournament results. Several young married couples, most of them little known in expert circles, have captured major team titles in the New York metropolitan area during the last year.

CORTLAND, N.Y., Sept. 24 Two young men and a young woman were arrested late last night and charged with setting a fire last Thursday that heavily damaged a building containing the local draft board offices.
Lead industry officials strongly opposed yesterday a proposed law that would ban the sale of leaded gasoline in the city by January, 1974.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 Morton L. Simons, who has been Washington counsel for the New York State Public Service Commission for nine years, resigned today because of what he termed a "drastic change" in the commission's stand on consumer-protection issues.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 24(AP) Rabbi Morris Lieberman, active in civic affairs and spiritual leader of the Baltimore Hebrew Congregation since 1937, died yesterday at Sinai Hospital. He was 61 years old.

Walter D. Engels, former news manager of WPIX, testified yesterday that during the Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968 a news report on his station had represented a telephone report from Vienna as coming from Prague.

A group of 15 stockholders, claiming ownership of 3,700 shares of the General Time Corporation prior to its merger into Talley Industries, Inc., through their lawyer, William Klein 2d, brought a $62.5million damage suit yesterday charging fraud against Talley, Peat, Marwick, Mitchell Co., Smith, Barney Co., Inc., Lehman Brothers and the American Investors Fund.
Stock prices climbed yesterday as trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange soared to 21.4 million shares the second-highest turnover on record.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) Available evidence "strongly indicates" that insiders of the money-trouble Penn Central Railroad may have violated Federal securities laws, Representative Torbert H. Macdonald, Democrat of Massachusetts said today. He emphasized, however, that he was not taking the position that violations had actually occurred.

While 23 other big-league managers gnawed at their fingernails last spring and worried about the season that was soon to begin, Earl Weaver of the Baltimore Orioles lolled in the Miami Stadium dugout and smiled a smile of seraphic contentment. All he he had to do was count his blessings.

Miss Victoria Goree Tarpley and Gilbert Pierson Schafer Jr., a partner of Pershing Co., stockbrokers here, were married yesterday afternoon in the Chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Donald C. McFerren.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 Complete integration of schools is neither legally required nor practically possible so the nation should try other ways to improve the education of poor children, a Yale University law professor testified today.

The N.A.A.C.P. Legal Defense and Educational Fund, Inc., filed suit in Federal Court here yesterday to block tests determinging who would be eligible to serve as principals of hundreds of city elementary schools in the next five years or more.

Mrs. Edna Fischel Gellhorn, a former Civil Service Commissioner in St. Louis and widow of Dr. George Gellhorn, a noted gynecologist and member of the medical faculty of Washiington University, died yesterday in St. Louis, where she lived. She was 91 years old.

Tree youths riding in an unregistered car were arrested on the Lower East Side last night after a stop-and-go chase in which they allegedly ran two red lights, sped away from two pairs of foot patrolmen who had halted them and collided with a police car all in the space of four blocks.

Safeway Stores, Inc., achieved record earnings in the 12-week and 36-week periods ended Sept. 5, the company reported yesterday from its Oakland, Calif., headquarters. The 12-week sales exceed $1billion and the 36-week sales topped $3-billion for the first time in Safeway's 44-year history. The company is the nation's second largest food chain (behind the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company).

ALBANY, Sept. 24 The State Education Commissioner ruled today that a local school board had acted properly in dismissing a teacher for wearing a black armband to class in support of last year's Vietnam moratorium activities.

A member of Mayor Lindsay's staff was appointed Relocations Commissioner yesterday, succeeding an official suspended when city authorities learned that he had been indicted for alleged immigration law violations.

TIBERIAS, Israel, Sept. 24 Israeli analysts believe that King Hussein's power is shattered and that the real strongmen in Jordan today are the army commanders, mostly Bedouins, who have led the fight against the Palestinian guerrillas.

The National Endowment for the Arts has awarded $148,976 in dance fellowships for the creation of 18 works by 16 choreographers. The total grant to each choreographer will encompass a set fee and funds for dancers' salaries for a four-week rehearsal period.
The General Electric Company let the world know yesterday that it was still in the computer business by announcing a major expansion of its computer time-sharing network.

Voltage cuts were imposed for the third successive day in the metropolitan area and the Middle Atlantic states yesterday as a hot, muggy blanket of smoggy air again led to a strain on the narrow reserves of electric power.
ORANGEBURG, S.C., Sept. 24 A jury of nine whites and three blacks was selected in a tightly guarded courtroom here today to hear riot charges against Cleveland L. Sellers Jr.
The Board of Education was accused yesterday of "defiance and deceit" in not supplying the City Council with a report on narcotics addiction in city schools.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 24 (AP) Veronica Tyler, a soprano with the New York City Opera, and a Baltimore music educator were named yesterday as the first black members of the Peabody Institute's board of trustees.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 24 Sourness turned to wine in Newport today. Heartburn gave way to smiles and bells chimed in the tower of the 17th-century Trinity Church overlooking the harbor as a victorious Gretel II entered a mob scene of horn-blowing party boats.

PARIS, Sept. 24 David K.E. Bruce, chief of the United States delegation at the Vietnam peace talks, told delegates of the other side today that their proposals of last week had not changed their basic position.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark Sept. 24 Secretary of the Treasury David M. Kennedy reasserted today the United States policy of converting foreign-held dollars into reserve assets such as gold, but noted that the United States is in a "passive position" on this issue.

Christopher Plummer, who stopped here briefly on his way to Canada, where he will receive today his country's highest medal, will star this fall as Frederick the Great in a London production by Robert Whitehead.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 24 The New York Knickerbockers opened their National Basketball Association preseason campaign tonight with a 100-86 victory over the Detroit Pistons before 13,433 fans in Crisler Arena on the campus of Michigan University.
The last time traders took a ride on shares of Energy Conversion Devices was late in 1968.

Governor Rockefeller was endorsed for re-election yesterday by the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association as the union's president, John J. DeLury, repeatedly praised the Governor for refusing to call up the National Guard during the city's 1968 garbage strike.

"Black Roots," a documentary of racial concern, which Lionel Rogosin, the directorproducer, presented in the special events portion of the New York Film Festival, had its official theater opening yesterday at the downtown Bleecker Street Cinema. For all the burning sincerity of this picture, and its fine blues numbers, the effect is fragmentary and unforceful.

There is nothing new about corporations evading the statutes governing campaign contributions, which are notorious for being nine parts loophole to one part law. Figures compiled by the Citizens Research Foundation show that 49 companies heavily involved in production for defense and space exploration put up $1,335,402 in the elections of 1968, much of it through the numerous evasions invited by the Corrupt Practices Act.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 24 The Chilean economy went from expansion to recession almost overnight, according to the outgoing Government, after the election early this month that made a Marxist the probable next President.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24 (UPI) Tony Roche of Australia, the third-seeded player, was ousted today by Marty Riessen of Evanston, Ill., 2-6, 6-2, 6-3, in a third-round match of the 44th annual $65,000 Pacific Southwest open tennis tournament.
Bill Stowe, an Olympic gold-medal winner in 1964, has resigned as Columbia's heavyweight crew coach, a position he has held since 1967.
BROOKVILLE, L.I., Sept. 24 As the New York Giants' director of professional personnel and superscout, it is part of Jim Trimble's job to stay one up on the opposition.
Soybean futures took the spotlight yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade as buying became brisk shortly after the opening and improved steadily until the last half hour, when profit taking set in.

SUVA, Fiji, Sept. 24 France walked out of a meeting of South Sea Island leaders today after several island delegates sharply condemned the French nuclear tests near Mururoa Atoll in French Polynesia earlier this year.

What emerges from this painstaking, objective biography, which carries Douglas MacArthur's career up to Pearl Harbor, is not so much how the general differed from his colleagues and co-workers, but how much he fit the mold of the conventional warrior. Those whose impressions of Mac
MIAMI, Sept, 24 (AP) Francisco Batista Zaldivar, brother of Fulgencio Batista, the former Cuban dictator, died here today of a heart attack. He was 59 years old.

DALMAHOY, Scotland, Sept. 24 (AP) Tony Jacklin, the United States Open champion, captured the lead from the United States Masters winner, Billy Casper, at the halfway point of the $24,000 Wills golf tournament today with a seven-under-par 65 that equaled the course record.
Arthur J. Goldberg said yesterday that Governor Rockefeller supported the White House in its reported acceptance of, if not preference for, James L. Buckley for the United States Senate.

FRANKFURT, West Germany, Sept. 24 To moviegoers and buyers of her popular records, Hildegard Knef (Neff in the United States) is the sad-eyed actress and husky-voiced singer of biting Berlin chansons that celebrate love and satirize society in the tradition of Lotte Lenya and Marlene Dietrich.

Andrew Lozyniak has been elected president and chief executive officer of the Dynamics Corporation of America. Walter E. Dennis, partner of Paine Webber Jackson Curtis, was made a director and chairman of the finance committee.

YONKERS, Sept. 24 The bizarre case of last night's mysterious eighth race, which was canceled because seven of the eight starters were listless and sweaty and appeased to have been drugged, remained unsolved at Yonkers Raceway today when blood, urine and saliva tests of the eight horses came back negative.

It is outrageous. It is unfair to honest playwrights. It is even unfair to dishonest playwrights. But the inescapable fact is that a twoman show called "Bob and Ray The Two and Only" is one of the zaniest shows to hit town in many a season. It is also first-rate theater. These people are simply unfair to playwrights.
Miss Deborah Nan Schoen plans to be married in June to George M. Stern, who is preparing for the rabbinate at the Hebrew Union CollegeJewish Institute of Religion in New York.

ABOARD U.S.S. INDEPENDENCE, in the Mediterranean, Sept. 24 Clustered around two aircraft carriers, the bulk of the United States Sixth Fleet is cruising 150 to 300 miles off the Mediterranean Sea's east coast, capable of striking far inland.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 Treasury bill rates declined at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.

The Maryland-bred Inkslinger of the Derry Meeting Farm conttributed a record-breaking performance in winning the $16,950 Elkridge Hurdle Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. Only five competed in the 1 7/8-mile contest and Michael O'Brien guided Inkslinger to a four-length success over Summer Crop.
Dr. Daniel J. O'Connell, Director of the Health Department for Manhattan, died Wednesday of a heart attack in Montefiore Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived at 3260 Perry Apenue, the Bronx.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Sept. 24 Mrs. Jeanne Robert Ollivier Foster, a leading figure in international literary circles from 1910 to 1930, who earlier had been a model and who later became a social worker, died yesterday at the age of 86.

Mayor Lindsay and other city officials coupled ground-breaking ceremonies yesterday for a new Bronx police station with a plea to residents in the Wakefield section for information in the knife slaying Wednesday of a 23-year-old off-duty patrolman.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) Senator Allen J. Ellender, who has been in the Senate 33 years, said today, on his 80th birthday, that he wanted to serve longer in that chamber than any other man.
The American Stock Exchange came alive yesterday as prices made brisk advances in the heaviest trading of the year.

The New York and American Stock Exchanges have issued their latest reports on changes in share ownership by director, offices and major stockholders in listed companies. The lists include the following:
A City Councilman and the State Attorney General clashed yesterday over the alleged role of the Attorney General's office in the conversion of rental apartments to cooperatives.

PARIS, Sept. 25 (Reuters) --King Hussein was quoted here today as having said that he had been misled by Jordanian intelligence officials about guerrilla strength and that there were Palestinian commandos among his palace servants.

The drug abuse bill passed overwhelmingly by the House this week reflects the slow national realization that there is no single answer to the drug problem and that present laws imposing the same penalties on pushers of hard narcotics and on users of soft hallucinogens must be modified.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP)--The pending importquota bill is part of a dangerous wave of United States economic isolationism that could hurt American shippers, manufacturers and consumers, Senator Walter Mondale said today as Senate opposition to the measure began to take shape.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Saturday, Sept. 26--Cambodian troops captured the enemy stronghold of Tangkok late yesterday after they had been stalled for two weeks, a Government spokesman announced this morning.

Senator Charles E. Goodell charged yesterday that "men of the hard right have infiltrated" the White House staff and are trying to influence President Nixon to support James L. Buckley, the Conservative party candidate for the United States Senate.

Henry Waldman, a retired lawyer and a founder of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, died Thursday at the Florence Nightingale Nursing Home. He was 95 years old and lived at 1199 Park Avenue.

The last time Leonard Bernstein conducted the Mahler Ninth Symphony in New York, about five years ago, he prefaced it with the Ives Third Symphony. On Thursday evening he again chose the Mahler Ninth, to start the subscription season of the New York Philharmonic. This time the Mahler stood alone on the program. But there was something solemn about the occasion. The concert was given in memory of Sir John Barbirolli and George Szell.

The Federal Joint Strike Force against organized crime here is now well into its second year, with a record of arrests and indictments of more than 100 defendants and six convictions so far, but one of its biggest cases is one it made against one of its own members.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 25 (AP)--Lieut. William L. Harris of the Air Force received a 12-to-65-year prison sentence after confirming in court yesterday that he had bombed two department stores as adiversion for robbery. No money was taken, but 13 persons were hurt.
HONG KONG, Sept. 25 (UPI) --North Vietnam has ordered increased conscription and recruiting for its armed forces, according to Western analysts specializing in Communist affairs.

Former Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio of Newark has been convicted and sentenced on sixty-four counts of extortion and conspiracy. The new Mayor, Kenneth A. Gibson, has discovered that Newark was paying about ten per cent more than it should have been paying on virtually every contract to cover the cost of kickbacks to city officials.

PELHAM, N.Y. (AP)--Raymond J. Keiser, a former Associated Press editor and bureau chief, died today at his home here. He was 67 years old and had retired in 1968 after a 35year career with the news agency in New York, Detroit and Phoenix, Ariz.
Despite the slowdown in retail sales, leading chain and mail-order companies achieved a gain of 6.1 per cent last month over the level of sales in August, 1969.

BROOKVILLE, L. I., Sept. 24--Mr. and Mrs. Alfred F. Bevilacque have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Ann Bevilacque, to William Joseph McElligott, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. McElligott.

At 78, President Tito is still remarkably vigorous. Nevertheless it has become increasingly evident that he is much preoccupied with sparing his country the agonies of a prolonged succession struggle--such as that which shook the Soviet Union after Stalin's death--once he has passed from the scene or been incapacitated.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25-- The first specially trained military guards to prevent hijackings will start riding commercial airliners within a week, the Nixon Administration announced today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25-- Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's adviser on foreign policy, has scheduled a Paris meeting tomorrow with Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam to try to persuade him not to attend a "March for Victory" rally here next week.
A program that was wellbalanced and intelligently planned received playing of the same order from Daniel Graham, a pianist who gave his first local recital in Carnegie Recital Hall on Thursday night.

SEATTLE, Sept. 25 (UPI)-- A young man alleged to have robbed a bank in Canada and shot two policemen sailed into United States waters on a hijacked sailboat with three hostages today and surrendered to the Coast Guard.

The total demand for longterm funds over the next five years will reach $418-billion, a leading commercial bank econ omist said yesterday, but the estimated supply available to meet those needs will only total $325-billion.

PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 25-- Dr. Robert A. Bearor, a prominent radiologist, died in the Maine Medical Center here today of cancer. He was 48 years old and had been an associate radiologist at the hospital since 1960.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25-- The National Transportation Safety Board said today that it had urged the Federal Aviation Administration to promulgate strict new restrictions affecting the design of airliner seat belts, stowage of life vests and emergency warnings to passengers.

BUFFALO, Sept. 25 (AP)-- State and county prosecutors decided today to drop an investigation into charges that Representative Richard Max McCarthy had offered the Democratic candidate for his seat a judicial nomination and a $10,000 campaign contribution.
ALBANY, Sept. 25(AP)-- For Mr. and Mrs. Eliot Saxe the parents of Susan Saxe, last night was a nightmare that dragged on and on.
MILAN, Italy, Sept. 25-- Angelo Rizozli, the publisher and film producer who headed a communications empire, died last evening at the Columbus Clinic here. He was 80 years old.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 25-- The cease-fire announced today in Jordan left the Palestinian guerrillas in control of three key northern towns, Irbid, Ramtha and Jarash--all encircled by the Jordanian Army of King Hussein. Ramtha commands the guerrillas' vital supply routes from Syria.

LONDON, Sept. 25--American exhibitors at Philympia, the international stamp exhibition that closes here tomorrow, received 106 medal awards, although none was in the grandaward class. In addition, five were presented with special awards, which might be considered as a bracket slightly under the five top honors.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 25 (AP)--Planes evacuated 102 refugees from Jordan to Beirut today. Twenty-two of them were Americans.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 25 (AP)--Bishop Elias Muawad of Aleppo, Syria, was elected today the 163d patriarch of the Greek Orthodox Church of Antioch and the entire East. He will reign as Patriarch Elias IV.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 25--The New York Mets Lived through the Perils of Pauline without the luck of Pauline tonight when they were defeated by the Pittsburgh Pirates, 4-3, in Round One of the battle for first place.
OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 25 (UPI)--Superior Judge Harold B. Hove today set Jan. 11 as the date for the second manslaughter trial of Huey P. Newton in the 1967 killing of an Oakland policeman.

Walter D. Engels, former news manager for WPIX, admitted at a Federal Communications Commission hearing yesterday that he had authorized the identification of three reporters for The Daily News as WPIX newsmen during the Democratic National Convention in August of 1968.

NEWARK, Sept. 25 (UPI)-- Phil Foster, the comedian, pleaded not guilty today to charges that he lied to a Federal grand jury about how much he paid for furniture from a reputed leader of organized crime. He was freed on $2,500 personal recognizance bond. Mr. Foster remained silent while his lawyer entered the plea of not guilty to each of the five counts in the indictment.

The stock market, which entered the week like a lamb, exited yesterday looking more like a lion. There were small gains in the popular averages, but Wall Street analysts regarded as far more significant the apparent rebound in investor confidence. This, in turn, stemmed from encouraging reports on the military situation in Jordan, as well as the improved flow of economic and anti-inflation developments on the home front.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 25 --The spokesman of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine said today that its commandos had released some of the hostages in Amman presumably because they could not feed them.
Consumption of newsprint during August declined 4 per cent from the year-earlier level, the American Newspaper Publishers Association reported yesterday.

Dear Mr. Vice President: Congratulations on your coolness. and quick articulation under fire from the four student critics on the David Frost show. I watched you tape the program, and I was impressed.

VENICE, Italy, Sept. 25--If the views that dominated a conference of space officials and industrialists there this week prevail, Europe will soon have its counterpart of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and will commit itself to a significant role in development of the next generation of American space vehicles.

MADRID, Sept. 25 (Reuters) --The United States team con tinued to play steady, unspectacular golf today and increased its lead in the Eisenhower Trophy world amateur team championship to nine strokes with one round to play.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25-- The 1,490 women had come to see Hubert de Givenchy's boutique collection and they wore their most fashionable clothes to the event.

COPENHAGEN, Dennmark, Sept. 25--As the annual meeting of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the International Monetary Fund ended today, the large United States delegation also ended a very busy week.

The reform of State Assembly committees implemented last year--reducing them from a total of 38 to 21--has since been followed by the creation of 47 subcommittees, which Democrats contend exist mainly for Republican politicking.

BUFFALO, Sept. 25 (AP)-- Salvatore Pieri, identified by the Federal Bureau of Investigation a former boss of Mafia operations in the Buffalo area, was convicted today in United States District Court of tampering with the jury.

The New York Stock Exchange announced late yesterday that it had appointed a liquidator for Blair Co., one of its most troubled member firms, and disclosed that the exchange's Special Trust Fund probably would be used in the concern's liquidation.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 25--A teen-age prosecution witness in the Sharon Tate murder trial ended her testimony today with a declaration that she fled from Charles M. Manson's hippie "family" in the late summer of 1969 because she had come to fear Manson.
Mayor Lindsay warmly endorsed Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday but added that he did not know how much his support was worth, in Mr. Lefkowitz's race for re-election.

Woody Hayes brings Ohio State out of hiding, Syracuse tries to solve a sensitive problem, Penn State takes its winning streak into the Rockies and Purdue climbs its annual mountain against Notre Dame.
Because of a deficit of almost half a million dollars, the Dow Jones open, the richest event on the 1970 pro golf tour, has been canceled for 1971 but may return to the schedule in 1972.

ROWAYTON, Conn., Sept. 25 --Otto Scherer of Laurel, Md., and Gene Miller of Annapolis, Md., lost their first sailing race in two years today, but they gained the world Class C Catamaran championship anyway with plenty to spare.
Sidney P. Marland Jr., who has been nominated by President Nixon to be United States Commissioner of Education, has the administrative skill and toughness the Office of Education needs.

A horse by Social Climber and Crowding In, bearing the nonracing name of Joe Namath scored an "in season" victory at Belmont Park yesterday With Bobby Woodhouse riding, the 3-year-old colt, owned by Mrs. Cloyce Tippett, beat French Steak by a half-length in the six-furlong spring, and paid $14.60 for $2 to win.
Jimi Hendrix, the rock guitarist, died without leaving a will disposing of his estate estimated at $500,000, according to a petition filed yesterday in Surrogate Court.

Standard bidding methods often run into trouble when a very strong hand, short of a forcing opening, faces a very weak one. A case in point is the diagramed deal, played earlier this week on the S.S. Santa Rosa during a Caribbean cruise.
The London stock market maintained an upward trend yesterday as the Jordan ceasefire agreement added to optimism generated by the advance on Wall Street Thursday.

BOSTON, Sept. 25--The police in three states were hunting today for two men and two women who the authorities said were wanted in a bank robbery, a murder and the looting of a National Guard armory that the Boston police have linked to revolutionary student activities.
YANKEETOWN, Fla., Sept. 25--Herbert M. Kempton, a former college football player and prep-school athletic coach, died Wednesday. He was 78 years of age.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) --The Air Line Pilots Association asked the Federal Aviation Administration today to require installation of bulletproof cockpit doors and bulkheads in all large passenger planes.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 25 (AP)--United States helicopters carrying South Vietnamese infantrymen into combat six miles south of the demilitarized zone today flew into a hail of enemy small-arms fire, and about 10 of the aircraft were hit, field reports said.

AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 25--The Jordanian Government announced today that it had "rescued." 15 British, German and Swiss hostages held by Arab commandos since Sept. 6, when airliners on which they were traveling were hijacked.
The Metropolitan Opera is reviving Donizetti's "Don Pas quale," which has not been given by the company since the 1964-65 season, and will present the opera for the first time this season on Oct. 20.
Dr. Lawrence W. Hanlon, as sociate dean of the Cornell University Medical College, died yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 55 years old and lived at 445 East 68th Street.
GENEVA, Sept. 25--The International Committee of the Red Cross announced tonight that its representatives had received permission to visit 10,000 prisoners of war in Jordan.

ROCHESTER, Mich., Sept. 25--Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Eduard Kruger have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Juliane Eve Kruger, to Robert David Bailey, resident vice president of the First National City Bank in Mexico City. Mr. Bailey is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Wood Bailey of St. Thomas, Virgin Islands.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 25 (AP)--The estate of the late oilman A. Otis Birch, reputed to be worth $200-million and the object of a three-year court battle, may be almost worthless, according to attorneys in the case.

Miss Mary Estelle Carroll, an assistant editor in the publications department at the Famous Artists Schools, International, here, and John Peter Cosgriff, a student at the Boston College Law School, plan to be married in June.
RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 25 --Irving C. Marcell, who retired as president of Marsales, Inc., of New York, makers of surgical dressings, died yesterday at his home, 399 Glenwood Road. His age was 73.

BRUSSELS, Sept. 25--The Executive Commission of the European Economic Community announced today it had ended preparatory discussions with Japan on a nonpreferential trade treaty, which would be the first trade agreement the Common Market as a whole would have with Japan.

GENEVA, Sept. 25--Erich Maria Remarque, the Germanborn author who attained world fame with his World War I novel "All Quiet on the Western Front," died at noon today of a heart collapse at the Sant Agnese clinic at Locarno, Switzerland. He was 72 years old.
James L. Buckley yesterday urged the explusion of all college and university students who committed criminal acts or "violate the rights of others."

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 25-- At least 100 homes were destroyed tonight and several hundred more were badly damaged as two wind-whipped brush fires swept out of control across the tinder-dry hills of Los Angeles County.

AMMAN, Sept. 25--The first reporters to visit a Jordanian hospital since the out break of civil war found it jammed with almost triple its capacity in wounded patients, moaning and crying out for water and bread.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25-- The Democratic National Committee demanded today that the Justice Department investigate four corporations for sponsoring rebroadcasts in 14 cities of President Nixon's televised speech last week on campus unrest.

Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that the picketing of a West Side pier by longshoremen had forced the city to shift the locale of a major experimental recreational program away from the waterfront. He called it "nothing less than an outrage that the Manhattan I.L.A. has interposed its will against the people of this city."

Dr. John George Glover emeritus professor of management at the New York University School of Commerce, died Wednesday in Presbyterian Hospital, Newark. He was 75 years old and lived at 22 Fairway Drive, West Orange, N.J.

CAIRO, Saturday, Sept. 26-- President Gamal Abdel Nasser, after having heard a report from the mission of Arab leaders to Jordan, sent a strongly worded telegram to King Hussein early today. He accused the Jordanian authorities of violating cease-fire promises and of carrying out a plan "to liquidate the Palestinian resistance."
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 25 --Dr. Cameron Haight, a leading thoracic surgeon who initiated several operating techniques, died today. His age was 69.
Soybean futures, which advanced sharply Thursday, fell yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.
AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 25-- King Hussein's Government and the Arab commando leadership agreed on a cease-fire today and silenced their armies' guns.

Record sales and earnings were attained by the Grand Union Company in the 13 weeks and fiscal half-year periods ended Aug. 29, Charles G. Rodman, president of the food and general merchandise retailing chain, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UPI)--The Senate Democratic leader, Mike Mansfield, sought for the second time today to shut off debate and bring to a vote a proposed constitutional amendment calling for direct popular elections of Presidents.
Representative Richard L. Ottinger, Democratic candidate for the Senate, asked Governor Rockefeller today to call a conference to deal with mounting unemployment on Long Island.

Local 32E of the Building Service Employes International Union said yesterday that the owners of more than 450 struck apartment houses in the Bronx had signed new contracts and that men were going back to work in those buildings.

Not many weekend sailors can dream of crewing for --or even getting into--the New York Yacht Club, but everyone in American sporting circles knows whom to root for: the underdog. That is why landlubbers who wouldn't know a tiller from a spinnaker are cheering the victory of Australia's Gretel II over the America's Cup defender, Intrepid, after three successive losses (one on a heartbreaking, disputed technicality).

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 25 (UPI) --Rod Laver of Australia, who is top-seeded, won the final five games of the third set to beat Stan Smith of Pasadena, Calif., 6-3, 4-6, 6-1, today and advanced to the semifinals of the $65,000 Pacific Southwest open.
He does not look to be the stuff of which legends are made.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25--Mr. and Mrs. Jack Cookman Hand have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Laurie Lee Hand, to Richard Louis Baggelaar of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard L.H. Baggelaar of Roslyn Estates, L.I.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25--The Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee approved today legislation giving the Federal Government broad new powers to establish indus trial safety standards. Thus the stage was set for one of the most intense labor-management battles in Congress in recent years.
CANANDAIGUA, N.Y., Sept. 25--Thomas Tongyai, also known as "Tommy the Traveler" while working as an undercover agent for the Ontario County sheriff, is studying police science in college here.
The New York Yankees scored five runs in the eighth inning of the second game last night to split a double-header with the Detroit Tigers at Yankee Stadium.

NEWPORT, R.I., Saturday Sept. 26 (AP)--The New York Yacht Club Race Committee rejected early today the Australian bid to reopen a protest that had led to Gretel. II's disqualification after beating Intrepid in the second race of the America's Cup.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) --Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel spoke out today against "the rhetoric of polarization."

The new-issue market displayed signs this week of emerging from nearly a yearlong slump as half a dozen companies made first public offerings of their shares, and trading activity picked up substantially.
The restaurants reviewed on this page are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored where indicated.
Glass collectors are willing to pay a premium for the American version of Bohemian glass, so it is important to be able to distinguish it from European work.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25--A top Administration official declared today that the United States was prepared to give Jordan weapons to replace those lost in the fighting there.

LONDON--Just before Christmas last I emerged from the London drug scene for the last time--at least for the present--having spent practically every spare moment among the street addicts, the end result of those who tread the dangerous road of drugs misuse. After eighteen months I was still no wiser than when I started as to why they do it.

PEKING, Sept. 25 (Agence France-Press)--Prince Norodom Sihanouk said today that a majority of his government-inexile now were members of the Khmer Rouge rebel movement "and the power already belongs to the Cambodian Communist party."
SIEGEN, Germany, Sept. 25 --The United States team lost to Hungary, 2 to 1 , in their adjourned games in the nextto-the-last round of the 19th Chess Olympiad today.
The Armco Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it would establish two new classifications for cold rolled steel, in effect allowing customers to buy some steel more cheaply.

R.H. Macy Co., Inc., which currently operates a chain of 63 department stores, rang up record sales in the fiscal year ended Aug. 1, but earnings declined for the first time in seven years, according to yesterday's report.
JERSEY CITY, Sept. 25 (AP) --Three policemen and three youths were injured today after a dispute over money lost in a luncheonette jukebox turned into a street brawl.
A gasoline fire of potentially dangerous proportions in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn was brought under control quickly yesterday by a large force of firemen and equipment.
Dr. Robert E. Marshak, president of City College, expressed his determination yesterday to eliminate hard drugs from the college's campus, where heroin is being bought and used openly.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 25--William J. Watts, a senior media buyer at SSC B, Inc., an international advertising agency, died yesterday at the New Rochelle Medical Center. He was 66 years old and lived at 40 Robins Crescent.

Ken Smith, one of the leading football scorers in Queens last season, scored both touchdowns yesterday to pace Adams to a 12-0 Public Schools Athletic League victory over Clinton at Wilson Field, Ozone Park, Queens.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25-- The Federal consumer-protection authorities called on soap manufacturers today to sponsor immediate tests on the "possible harmful effects" of using laundry detergents containing enzymes.

A 16-year-old high school girl filed a complaint with the City Commission on Human Rights yesterday charging the Board of Education with "arbitrary and unreasonble discrimination" in refusing to allow her to play on boys' tennis team.
GENEVA, Sept. 25--Investors Overseas Service an pounced tonight the appoint ment of Robert L. Vesco, president of the International Controls Corporation to the board of its parent company.
Followers of the sticky negotiations between major oil companies and the Libyan Government have been wondering why Royal Dutch Shell hasn't settled, thereby following the lead of its Libyan partners.

TORONTO, Sept. 25 (Canadian Press)--The Jockey Club, after an investigation by its security agents, said today it had banned employes of offtrack betting shops from its tracks in Ontario and had called for prosecution of the shops by Federal and provincial authorities.

YONKERS, Sept. 25--A State Harness Racing Commission spokesman said today the commission's investigation into the strange behavior of seven horses scheduled to start in the same race had "led up a blind alley," with no leads uncovered.
The hottest Sept. 25 on record prolonged the power crisis yesterday, forcing voltage cuts in the metropolitan area for the fourth consecutive day.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Sept. 25 (UPI) --The New York Knicks fought off a last quarter rally by the Detroit Pistons tonight to gain their second straight National Basketball Association exhibition victory, 107-103.
