The Federal National Mortgage Association announced yesterday that it plans to sell $750-million of debentures next Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25--A civil rights-organized labor coalition has agreed to oppose pending legislation that would strengthen the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission if provisions desired by labor are not added.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 25--Vice President Agnew described for a Republican audience tonight his political mission for 1970: to arouse Americans to a desire for stronger national self-discipline and to help elect candidates who oppose "the trend toward permissiveness."

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 25--Policemen scouring the western portion of this city on the fifth day of an intensive search for a missing 5-year-old girl reported today that they had found several items of the child's clothing.

Favorable producer reaction has been received to a coordinated drive by 25 of the country's largest furniture and department-store chains this week to limit the home furnishings industry's two fashion introductions a year to only one in the spring.

FRANKFURT, Sept. 25--Officials of the Frankfurt Book Fair voted tonight to close the exhibit of a small right-wing publisher after finding that the concern's books celebrating Hitler and Nazism violated West Germany's Constitution.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25-- Senator Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina accused the Nixon Administration tonight of feeding upon "the disunity, of the nation."

A constructive use of television--seen at 8:30 on Channel 5 in New York and at other hours in different sections of the country, was the taped discussion last night between Vice President Agnew and four college students highly critical of the Administration's domestic and international policies.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 25 (Reuters)--Senator Salvador Allende, a Socialist who led the presidential balloting Sept. 4, said in an interview today his Government would not be Socialist but multiparty and pledged that free elections and press freedom would continue.

ORANGEBURG, S.C., Sept. 25--Two top police officials testified today that the only violation of law they saw Cleveland L. Sellers Jr. commit in racial clashes here in 1968 was failure to disperse immediately when an order was given.
The lawyer for a New York detective accused of having accepted a $500 bribe said yesterday that the money had been planted on his client by the chief prosecution witness.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 25--Foreign Minister Walter Scheel of West Germany and Deputy Foreign Minister Josef Winiewicz of Poland met for two hours today in an effort to speed negotiations on the normalization of relations between their countries.
PARIS, Sept. 25--Georg Solti will take over from Herbert von Karajan as conductor of the Orchestre de Paris in November of next year.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 25--Miss Helen Neuman and Duncan Lawrence Marshall Jr., seniors at Boston University, plan to be married in May.

The House of Representatives has made progress in opening up its procedures to public scrutiny. The reform bill which the House debated in desultory fashion for two months before the August recess and has now passed overwhelmingly puts an end to unrecorded teller votes. It also eliminates an occasion for hypocrisy in which members secretly voted one way on critical amendments and the other way publicly on final passage.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25-- The Wall Street law firm that lost two of its leading partners when President Nixon and Attorney General John N. Mitchell came to Washington has found itself the reluctant subject of continuing public attention.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 25-- Two women members of the Black Panther party pleaded guilty to reduced charges today in the slaying of Alex Rackley, opening the way for the trial of the Panther national chairman, Bobby G. Seale, and another woman member of the party.

MOSCOW, Sept. 25--Soviet officials have indicated to senior Western diplomats here that the Kremlin's effort to persuade Syria and Iraq not to intervene in the Jordan crisis were aided to a considerable degree by the American military build-up in the eastern Mediterranean.

COLUMBUS, Ga., Sept. 25 (AP)--Bob Stanton of Australia and Harry Toscano of New Castle, Pa., young golfers without victory on the pro tour, fired par 70's today and tied at 136 for the halfway lead in the $60,000 Green Island open tournament.
HOUSTON, Sept. 24 (UPI) --Mrs. Billie Jean King and the eight other women who joined her tennis rebellion were expeled today from the United States Lawn Tennis Association for becoming contract pros.

A major segment of the insurance industry declared here yesterday that crime in the cities had reached such staggering proportions that the cost of providing burglary and theft coverage should be borne by the Federal Government.

A union of letter carriers asked a Federal Court yesterday to declare that there was no longer anything special about the United States Post Office's special delivery mail, and to order the Government to refund to mail users $5-million in extra postage.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25-- Stanford R. Ovshinsky, the Michigan inventor who attracted attention with his electronic switches made of amorphous, glassy materials, was granted a broad patent this week for a related product--a memory film. The film, called Ovonic after its originator, may be applicable for use in computers, displays, print ing and office copying machines and cameras.

FRANKFURT, West Germany, Sept. 9--Often nicknamed Little New York because of its hectic pace and milling crowds, this ancient city on the sewage-blackened Main River has managed to preserve a high standard of street cleanliness.
The Air Force said last night that search planes had sighted what appeared to be an empty raft and part of a large balloon floating 100 miles apart off Newfoundland.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP)--Attorney General John N. Mitchell announced today the indictment of 15 Detroit area men, seven of whom have been identified as Mafia figures, on Federal bankruptcy fraud charges.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 25--Dr. and Mrs. Hans Osborg have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Amires Elvira Osborg, to Eugene Wisner Hutchinson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Hutchinson of Hadley, Mass. The wedding is planned for Oct. 17 in Boston, where the future bridegroom is on the public relations staff of the New England Conservatory of Music.
Estelle Liebling, singer and teacher of singers, died last evening in her home in the Hampshire House, 150 Central Park South. She was 90 years old.
MONTICELLO, N.Y., Sept. 25--Governor Rockefeller said today that if he was re-elected, he would propose legislation to eliminate automobile junk yards and to clear abandoned cars from city streets.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25 (AP)--Successive home runs by Tim McCarver and Don Money in the sixth inning helped the Philadelphia Phillies post a 5-3 victory tonight over Chicago, jolting the Cubs' National League Eastern Division title hopes.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 25--The annual meeting of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund concluded today with almost unanimous support for the present international monetary system in all its main essentials.

The state Public Service Commission yesterday gave the New York Telephone Company two more weeks to put into effect a $12.4-million reduction in rates. The reduction is from a $136.7-million interim rate increase approved last February.
GENEVA, Sept. 25--The Swiss Government announced today that it was calling on the nation's army of militiamen to help guard its two major international airports.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25-- The White House, recalling the Moscow-Washington understanding that ended the Cuban missile crisis of 1962, warned the Soviet Union today against building a strategic submarine base in Cuba.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 25--a student boycott of tomorrow after noon's home football opener with Kansas and the immediate resignation of Coach Floyd (Ben) Schwartzwalder were demanded by two student presidents at Syracuse University today.

The flow of funds into the nation's thrift institutions is improving steadily, the Government reported yesterday. This, in turn, is increasing the availability of money for home mortgages. In time this should lead to a fairly general reduction in lending rates.

Arthur J. Goldberg, the Democratic-Liberal candidate for Governor, yesterday received the endorsement of Theodore H. Kheel, the labor mediator and then took his campaign to Poughkeepsie and Monticello.

SIEGEN, Germany, Sept. 26 --The United States team defeated Spain, 2 -1 , in the 11th and final round of the 19th Chess Olympiad today and finished fourth in the tournament. The Americans had a score of 24 -19 .
KINGS POINT, L.I., Sept. 26 --Gettysburg defeated the Merchant Marine Academy, 28-15, today before 3,000 sweltering fans.

The New York City Opera will introduce its new production of Donizetti's "Roberto Devereux" on Oct. 15, during the sixth week of its season at the New York State Theater. BROOKVILLE, L.I., Sept. 26 --Dave Ericks, a senior making his first varsity start, passed for two touchdowns today to lead C.W. Post to a 23-7 victory over Wagner. Ericks finished the game with 12 completions in 23 attempts for 147 yards, playing in three quarters.

Michels, professor emeritus of economics of the City University of New York, and Mrs. Michels of Danbury, N.H. and Windermere Island, the Bahamas.

MOSCOW, Sept. 27 Andrei Voznesensky has written a long, rather pessimistic poem in reponse to a plea from the father of a 20-year old girl who froze to death after trying to keep alive by reciting Mr. Voznesensky's poetry.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 27 Miss Lisbeth Margie Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Virgil Milton Smith, was married here this afternoon to Charles Bernard Golson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Golson of Washington. The Rev. John Akers performed the ceremony is St. Mark's Episcopal Church.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 27 (AP) Vietcong forces attacked three villages this weekend, military spokesmen reported today. They said the attacks had been directed against the Government's pacification program.
PARIS, Sept. 27 (Reuters) Three explosions went off within 25 minutes at two Paris air ports today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 The killing of six students in Ohio and Mississippi by the law enforcement authorities last May was "completely unjustified," two members of the President's Commission on Campus Unrest said today.

Yeshiva University dedicated an 11-story classroom building for Stern College for Women yesterday. The $4.5-million structure, on Lexington Avenue at 35th Street, is connected by passageways to the existing five-story building, which has been in use since the school's establishment in 1954.

Since the Ford Motor Company offered stereo tape players as optional equipment in . its cars five years ago, the market for taped music on wheels has been zooming. At prices from $80 to $350, sales of tape players this year are expected to reach more than $400-million.
MATAWAN, N.J., Sept 27 (AP) This shore resort is resorting to a lottery for parking space at the railroad station.

The Women's Council of the Bryant Park Flower Show has arranged a preview of the show for Oct. 7, the eve of its opening, in a striped tent that will cover most of the park. The show will continue through Oct. 13.

The New York City Taxi Drivers Union announced last night that it had asked its members and independent owner-drivers to observe a "24-hour mourning period" for a slain cabby, beginning at midnight tonight.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 27 (UPI) A Negro woman and her 11-year-old daughter were rejected for membership in the all-white First Baptist Church of Birmingham today, prompting the resignation of the minister and a staff member and a massive walkout of church members from the morning worship service.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 27 Since he came out ahead in Chile's presidential election, Dr. Salvador Allende has become, in public at least, steadily less of a Marxist.
Harold Kohn, a lawyer who was counsel to several optometric groups, died yesterday in Beth Israel Hospital following a heart attack. He was 76 years old.

Along with the environment, the telephone company, and Spiro T. Agnew, the New York subway system has lately come under bitter attack. While I am willing to admit that we could improve all these things, I think a word of caution should be sounded to the people who are assailing the subways. I'm a peculiar kind of an expert on subways. I've been a resident of them in my time.
Two persons were killed yesterday and four others injured when a taxi jumped a divider on the Grand Central Parkway in Astoria, queens, and collided head-on with another car.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (Reuters) Senator J.W. Fulbright cautioned the Nixon Administration today against nuclear brinkmanship in trying to prevent the Soviet Union from establishing a submarine base in Cuba, urging instead diplomacy.

The New York State Division of Human Rights said yesterday that the case of an orthodox Muslim who complained that he was discriminated against because of his beard would be heard this fall by the Court of Appeals, the state's highest court.

DENVER, Sept. 27 (UPI) Steve Tensi, taking over at quarterback in the second half, threw a 38-yard touchdown pass to Bill Van Heusen today to give the Denver Broncos a 16-13 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers.
LOS ANGELES, Sept, 27 At least 50 more homes were burned in firestorms in Southern California this afternoon, and the fires were still spreading tonight.

CAIRO, Sept. 27 The Arab leaders conferring here on the crisis in Jordan tonight signed a 14-point agreement that calls for an immediate cease-fire and the appointment of a three-man committee to restore order in the country and oversee military and civilian affairs.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 (AP) Six scientists, testifying on behalf of the Commonwealth Edison Company, have said that a proposed Federal limit on the temperature of water discharged into Lake Michigan is unnecessary.

AMMAN. Jordan, Sept. 27 Occasional shots and bursts of machine-gun fire sounded in Amman last night and early this morning despite the ceasefire and the announcement of a new, largely civilian Cabinet.
SAN DIEGO, Sept. 27 (UPI) Two long fourth-quarter touchdown passes by John Hadl gained the San Diego Chargers a 27-27 tie with the Oakland Raiders today.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27 Each time Larry Hisle of the Philadelphia Phillies came to bat today, the organist played a few bars of the traditional wedding march in honor of Hisle's forthcoming marriage. The organist, however, showed compassion and refrained from playing a funeral dirge in memory of the Chicago Cubs.

When the Soviet Union and France refused to pay their share of the costs of United Nations peace-keeping missions, the United States properly pointed out that such selective use of money power as a lever for political pressure undermined hope for a world society built on law. The World Court formally upheld that view in a decision requiring nations to honor their financial obligations as members of the U.N. and its constituent agencies.
Senator Charles E. Goodell yesterday called for higher rates for commercial and industrial users of electricity during power shortages in order to ration the supply.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 27 Doomsday arrived for the New York Mets at 4:08 this afternoon when the Pittsburgh Pirates defeated them, 2-1, and succeeded them as the Eastern champions of the National League.
Charles H. Coleman has been named winner of the David Sarnoff Gold Medal by the Society of Motion Picture and Television Engineers for his inventions in the color videotape field.

TOKYO, Sept. 27 (AP) Knocked down once and apparently helpless, Yoshiaki Numata of Japan suddenly landed a right uppercut and knocked out Raul Rojas of San Pedro, Calif., in the fifth round tonight. He kept the World Boxing Council's version of the world junior lightweight title.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 27 Seton Hall University's club football team rallied twice today to defeat the Iona College club, 20-13, on rain-soaked Setonia Field.

A three-foot water main burst at the Avenue of the Americas and 43d Street yesterday, causing a 16-by-60-foot section of pavement to collapse and disrupting subway and auto traffic for more than three hours.

The right to strike is regularly hailed by labor and industry as a hallmark of economic freedom, a test of strength in which economic pressures eventually oblige one side or the other or both to give way.
ROME, Sept. 27 Pope Paul VI proclaimed St. Theresa of Avila a doctor of the church in a solemn ceremony in St. Peter's Cathedral today.

"The Woman in the Dunes" (1964) was a shooting script for Hiro Teshigahara. "The Ruined Map" (1969) was a metaphysical detective story. "Inter Ice Age 4" is science fiction, complete with computers predicting the future, submarine colonies and the usual apocalypse.

TENANTS HARBOR, Me., Sept. 28 (AP)--Carl D. Nesensohn Sr., a retired news photographer, died at his home today. He was 72 years old.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) --A Federal hearing examiner ruled today for the first time that a Northern school district was violating Federal civil rights laws and should lose most of its Federal aid.
LONDON, Sept. 28 (AP)--A Landon coroner returned an open verdict today on the death of Jimi Hendrix after a pathologist testified that the rock star had died of suffocation.

JERICHO, Vt., Sept. 28 (AP) --An American student held nearly 10 months in East Berlin has been sentenced to seven years in prison on charges of making propaganda statements against the East German government.

He was 69 years old and lived in West Orange, N.J.

The City Planning Commission voted yesterday to expand and extend for another year the court employment program of providing jobs for selected criminal defendants here.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 28 --Early in the summer-long trials to pick an America's Cup defender, a rare case of panic broke out aboard Intrepid.

A uniform golf ball for, use throughout the world has been declared "feasible" by a committee representing the United States Golf Association and the Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St. Andrews, Scotland.

TOKYO, Sept. 28--A project to build the world's longest tunnel by linking Japan's big underdeveloped northern island, Hokkaido, with the main island of Honshu moved closer to realization this month. The Railway Construction Advisory Council recommended that the 38.6mile-long tunnel be upgraded from a test undertaking to a regular construction project.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28-- Representative L. Mendel Rivers, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, today fired the opening shot in the House battle over the defense budget with a warning that the nation was in "terrible jeopardy" because of rising Soviet military power.

A suspended New York detective was found guilty yesterday by a jury in State Supreme Court in the Bronx of accepting a $500 bribe in return for making sure a car thief he arrested was not brought to trial.
The Chevron Oil Company announced yesterday that it would introduce to the East gasoline containing a new additive designed to reduce air pollution.

Officials of the Federal Food Stamp Program were ordered yesterday to show next Monday why their procedures are not illegal. A suit filed by three poor persons here contends that applicants are being illegally turned away when they apply for the stamps.

Proponents of a constitutional amendment embodying fundamental reform of Presidential elections will try again today to cut off dilatory debate in the Senate and bring the amendment itself to a vote. The Museum of Modern Art and the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the 112-year-old performing arts center at 30 Lafayette Avenue, will present a series of free weekly programs of the museum's film classics for members of both institutions at the academy, starting Oct. 7 and running through May.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., (AP)--Vincent Lombardi was named today the third recipient of the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame's Distinguished Service Award. The posthumous award will be presetned to Lombardi's son at the group's 13th annual awards dinner Dec. 8.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 28 --Thai policemen seized several hundred thousand dollars in goods stolen from United States post exchanges Saturday aand today uncovered two additional truckloads of stolen PX merchandise.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 28 (Reuters)--The United States military command said today that no Americans were skilled in South Vietnam yesterday. It was the second time this month that no deaths were reported over a 24-hour period.

Stockholders of the American Enka Corporation and the International Salt Company, at separate meetings yesterday, approved a three-way combination of the two companies with Organon, Inc. The new enterprise, known as Akzona, Inc., has assets of $360-million and 13,000 employes.

A consortium of five universities has begun a federally funded experimental program to recruit candidates from other professions for training as public school administrators.

OMAHA, Sept. 28--Two leaders of a Black Panther front organization were ordered to stand trial on murder charges after a teen-age member changed his story today and implicated them in the fatal Aug. 17 booby trapping of an Omaha policeman.

YONKERS, Sept. 28--Local harness racing fans got their first look flat the Canadianowned Albatross, generally regarded as the best of this season's 2-year-old pacers, in the Star Pointer at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

A reform plan for governing Hunter College that calls for an ombudsman to hear complaints and a 200-member senate to represent the school's students, faculty members and administrators was suggested yesterday by a special committee, set up after last spring's disruptions.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 28 (AP) --A white policeman was shot to death and his partner seriously wounded early today in a predominantly black area of Cleveland that has been pressing the city for more police protection.
The Police Department is planning a pilot project in a low-crime area in North Queens to prevent the escalation of crime, a department spokesman said yesterday.
New York's cab drivers were enjoined last night by an impartial taxi industry arbitrator from carrying out a 24-hour work stoppage in memory of a murdered cabdriver, one of seven slain this year.

They came back to the Broadway scene yesterday. Ruby Keeler after 41 years. Busby Berkeley after 35. And their sponsors, Harry Rigby and Cyma Rubin, are glad they came back and hope others will be too.

Steel production dropped by 2.8 per cent last week, compared to output the week before, but industry sources said it was unlikely the change could be attributed to the strike against the General Motors Corporation, which began only two weeks ago.

Witnesses at a State Senate public hearing testified here yesterday that a steep rise in medical malpractice suits was forcing physicians to practice "defensive medicine," shirk hazardous modes of treatment that could be of benefit to patients, and pass along the costs of skyrocketing insurance premiums to patients.
Sergio Franchi, who gave a concert Sunday night at Philharmonic Hall for the benefit of Boys Town of Italy, must be unique among formally trained singers who turn from opera to popular music.
The Dow Chemical Company announced yesterday that it would raise prices on two lines of herbicides, effective Oct. 1.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 28--John Dos Passos, the novelist of the post-World War I generation who wrote more than 30 books, including the trilogy "U.S.A.," died today in his apartment.

DENVER, Sept. 28--The United States, increasingly more dependent on foreign raw materials and faced with energy shortages; will undertake its first comprehensive study of the nation's mineral resources since 1950, Commerce Secretary Maurice H. Stans announced today.

The New York-New Jersey Regional Championships played during the weekend at Grossinger's in the Catskills proved to be a personal triumph for Paul Heitner of New York, the biggest man in the tournament.
Union employee of United Parcel Service struck throughout New England yesterday after rejecting the latest company contract offer, The Associated Press reported.
Panther defense lawyers were rebuked yesterday by Supreme Court Justice John M. Murtagh for their method of questioning prospective jurors and directed to be "more lawyerlike."

Hundreds of migrating warblers, thrushes, vireos and tanagers, flying low under a cloud cover and confused by bright lights, crashed into the Empire State Building early yesterday morning and fell onto the setbacks or down to the street.

PARIS, Sept. 28--The followers of the deposed Cambodian Chief of State, Prince Norodom Sihanouk, are closely watching the Vietnam peace talks here as the possible key to political victory in Cambodia.
The idea that Carol Channing is a souffle of vagaries and bewilderments, a notion that her countenance continually supports, is dashed very soon after she starts talking about her work.

The Fall Dance for the benefit of the Boys' Club of New York will be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Pierre on Oct. 22. Mrs. Robert B. Dickson is chairman for the invitational dinner dance. Serving as vice chairmen are Mrs. Merrill L. Magowan, Mrs. Michael P. McDonough and Mrs. David H.M.J. Steavenson.
Several hundred commuters on the Port Authority Trans Hudson lines were trapped under the Hudson River for almost two hours last night because of a faulty signal light.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 28 (AP)--James L. Buckley, Conservative party candidate for the Senate, said today that the United States could not survive in a state of siege, in a reference to attacks on policemen.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28-- Pentagon and Transportation Department officials confirmed today that they had reached no agreement yet to put a "sky marshal" force of military guards on commercial airliners.

Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. asserted yesterday that the Port of New York Authority had failed to meet its "responsibilities" to help New York and New Jersey solve their problems of mass transportation.

Having Played themselves out of the possibility of finishing first, the Mets and Chicago Cubs traded dramatic home-run punches at Shea Stadium last night and wound up tied for second with three games to play.
An unemployed 64-year-old "jack-of-all-trades" who liked to repair radios and who read the financial pages as a child, has left stockholdings worth nearly $4-million. But he did not leave a will.

MILAN, Italy, Sept. 28--Aleksandr R. Tomsky, director of the Bolshoi Ballet Company, died of a heart attack here yeserday, shortly after the Bolshoi troupe of more than 100 members arrived here for a season at La Scala Opera House.

Gamal Abdel Nasser, son of a postal clerk who became idol of Egypt and sought to become leader of all the Arab world, was a tragic and spectacular failure. Nevertheless, his sudden death yesterday leaves a void that can only add to the chaos already threatening to overwhelm the Middle East.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28-- The Senate Government Operations Committee approved today a bill to establish an independent Federal agency with broad authority to act as an advocate and protector of consumer interests.
Senator Jacob K. Javits took potential voters by the arm up to Senator Charles E. Goodell yesterday, re-emphasizing his endorsement of the candidate and warning against "denigrating' his chances.

Booz, Allen Hamilton, Inc., worldwide consulting and engineering organization, announced yesterday the promotion of three top officers with a combined total of 70 years' service to head the new management team, effective Thursday.

Walter D. Engels, former news manager of WPIX, said yesterday that in two instances in mid-November 1968 his station's news programs used old film to illustrate fresh news, but he maintained that the practice was not improper.

MOSCOW, Sept. 28--The Soviet Union and West Germany today signed an agreement on scientific cooperation as part of an improvement in relations envisaged in last month's BonnMoscow treaty, which repounced force and accepted Europe's postwar frontiers as inviolable.
WASHINGTON, Spet. 28-- Treasury bill rates were mixed at today's auction compared to last week's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- A top Treasury official said today that "the economy clearly has moved past a crossover point towards expansion."

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 28-- John Leo Flynn, a movie bit player, testified today at the Tate murder trial that Charles M. Manson told him a couple of days after the murders of the actress Sharon Tate and four others in August, 1969: "Don't you know I'm the one who's doing all these killings?"

ALBANY, Sept. 28--Representative Richard L. Ottinger said today that he planned to spend "somewhere around $750,000" on a television and radio campaign beginning tonight in his bid for election to the Senate. He explained that he was getting the money from his mother, sister, uncle and other relatives.
Those followers of form who believe in following precedent were a happy lot yesterday following the running of the Brighton Beach Handicap's second section at Belmont Park.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 28-- Measures designed to improve the environment will be put before the voters on ballots of eight states in November.
NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 28 --Edward J. Sims, a musician, died today at Norwalk Hospital after a brief illness. His age was 94. He lived at 42 High Street.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 28--Israeli officials are taking a dim view of the accord ending the Jordanian fighting.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- United States officials, startled by the death of Gamal Abdel Nasser, tended to view it today as a blow to peace-making efforts in the Middle East.

JERUSALEM, Tuesday, Sept. 29--A senior Cabinet Minister, hearing of President Gamal Abdel Nasser's death, said last night that Israel faced the prospect of a prolonged stalemate on the decision for war or for peace in the Middle East.
The new interim President of the United Arab Republic is Anwar Sadat, the former Vice President, the Cairo radio announced today.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 29 Miss Nancy Kay Lakeman and Jeffrey Von Kohorn, students at Northwestern University, plan to be wed in June.

STOCKHOLM, Sept. 29 Many a woman, content with her marriage, has been heard to say, "One thing we never quarrel about is money." That can no longer be said about the liaison between Europe and the United States. And, as in so many unhappy marriages, it seems that every other worry

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 29 Secretary of Labor James D. Hodgson told steel union delegates today that the Nixon Administration had succeeded in curbing "tail-chasing inflation" and assured them that the upward trend of unemployment would be reversed by the end of the year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 Prospects for any electoral change by Congress this year dropped to a new low today when the Senate refused for a second time to cut off a threeweek filibuster against the plan for direct, popular election of the President.

Gilbert Seldes, author and critic and one of the earliest and most influential writers on the popular arts in America, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home at 125 East 57th Street, where he had lived for more than 25 years. He was 77 and had been ill for several years.

Miss Ellen Lopin was married here yesterday afternoon to William Granger Blair, public relations manager of The New York Times. State Supreme Court Justice Charles Margett performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Sam A. Lopin, parents of the bride.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 28 The political behavior of the nation's largest state may be a riddle, hut valuable clues are to be found in a pair of tracts called Marin County precinct 1116 and Southgate precinct 14.

The United States must seek an expanding world trade, but it "cannot watch American industries wither." Stanley Nehmer, Deputy Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Resources, told the second day's session of the first International Commodities Conference at the New York Hilton Hotel here yesterday.

To a background of pictures that depicted its programs from the young to the aged, the Federation of Jewish Philanthorpies of New York last night began its $30-million fund campaign at a dinner in the Plaza Hotel attended by 300 people.

ATHENS, Sept. 28 Greek archeologists exploring a city that lay buried under volcanic ash for 3,500 years have discovered a multistory building with an exquisite wall painting in red, blue and golden ocher.
It has been getting difficult again to find an outdoor pay telephone in the metropolitan area that works, according to the state Public Service Commission.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 29 Foreign Minister Abba Eban of Israel said today that the destiny of the Middle East was in the hands of Egypt's future leaders and that he was "utterly incapable" of predicting their course of action.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., Sept. 29 Governor Rockefeller promised financial help to the campaign of Senator Charles E. Goodell today, but was booed later in the day by a Republican audience when he strongly urged the election of his running mate.
The old, citywide conflicts over rent control and decaying housing are being acted out once again in the strike by Bronx apartment house workers, which entered its third week yesterday.
TANGKOK, Cambodia, Sept. 29 The rubble is still smoking four days after the bombing, strafing and shelling of Tangkok ended in an enemy withdrawal.

Delaware, which trounced New Hampshire, 53-12, last Saturday for its third straight victory, was the unanimous choice yesterday for first place in the weekly balloting for the Lambert Cup, awarded after the season to the top middle-sized college football team in the East.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) Maj. Gen. St. Clair Streett, a World War I pilot and then a general in World War II, died yesterday at nearby Andrews Air Force Base. He would have been 77 next Tuesday.

Robert Hopkins, who heads the piano faculty at Youngstown (Ohio) State University, made his New York debut on Monday night at Town Hall. He played an all-Beethoven program, but it had been put together with more imagination than usual. In the center was the customary sonata, Op. 101 in A, but it was preceded by the Six Bagatelles of Op. 126 and followed by the Diabelli Variations.

Barney's which has been calling all men to select, rather than settle for, its men's wear since 1924, will open its $3.5-million International House today next to the site at Seventh Avenue and 17th Street where Barney Pressman started the whole thing.

AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 29 American and West German correspondents who entered the Palestinian quarter of Amman today for the first time since the civil war began on Sept. 17 found an open mass grave containing more than 40 bodies.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 29 (UPI) The South Vietnamese National Assembly today completed and sent to President Nguyen Van Thieu a bill giving him the power to change the official exchange rate for United States military payment certificates being converted to piasters.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 29 (AP) The United States announced three new moves today to disengage its troops and equipment from the war, including completion of the transfer of a big combat base to the South Vietnamese Army.

The New York City Opera Orchestra, which had been playing without a contract since the opening of the fall season on Sept. 9, came to terms with the company in a 12-hour session that ended early yesterday morning. The musicians had votes a strike after Sunday night's "Manon," but no performances were affected. Monday was an off-night for the opera troupe.

STOCKHOLM, Sept. 29 A long absentee ballot count in the general election of Sept. 20, during which doubts were cast at one point over the future of social Democratic rule, showed Sweden's center-right opposition parties today six seats short of a majority in Parliament.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 A predominantly Republican group of 66 members of the House rallied today to defend President Nixon against what they regard as unfair blame placed on him by his Commission on Campus Unrest.
About 1,500 saddened and angry taxi drivers stopped work yesterday morning to attend a funeral mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral for a colleague recently shot to death.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI) Attorney General John N. Mitchell announced today that top Justice Department officials, including himself, would visit college campuses from Maine to California for faceto-face discussions with students.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) The Air Force, recognizing what it called "the recent emphasis on women's rights," rescinded today its rule forbidding women to adopt or have custody of minor children while in the service.

The Olin Corporation announced yesterday expansion programs costing $65-million that will make the company a major producer of polyester film and will quadruple its production of chemicals for urethane foams and coatings.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 29 A 34-year-old member of South Vietnam's National Assembly defied President Nguyen Van Thieu today and renewed a call for the formation of a provisional Government as a step toward peace.

The suit by the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund to block eligibility tests given by the Board of Examiners to potential school principals could turn into a landmark case for the city's public education system.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 29 (AP) The St. Louis Cardinals rehired Manager Red Schoendienst today for a seventh year and released Billy Muffett and Dick Sisler as coaches.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 The Rev. Dr. Carl McIntire, chairman of the "march for victory" scheduled here on Saturday, accused the Nixon Administration today of violating freedom of speech by dissuading Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam from appearing at the rally.

NAPLES, Italy, Sept. 29 President Nixon pledged today to seek good relations with whoever succeeds Gamal Abdel Nasser as Egypt's leader and urged Cairo to honor the Middle East cease-fire and move as rapidly as possible to constructive peace talks aimed at a broad settlement.

The city's rent chief said yesterday the city expected to take over services in 300 to 400 more struck Bronx apartment buildings. Mayor Lindsay added the city was ready to do so in every building certified as a health hazard.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 29 A witness in the Tate murder trial testified today that he did not report to the police Charles M. Manson's contention that he was a mass murderer because he thought Manson "was just doing his thing."

SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 29 The opposition New Democratic party nominated Kim Dae Jung, a 44-year-old national legislator, today as its candidate to oppose President Chung Hee Park next spring in South Korea's presidential election.

The City Council voted unanimously yesterday to set up a 10-member special committee to look into operations of the city's mass transit systems and to make recommendations to "insure a safe, adequate transportation system."

When college football observers termed the 1970 season The Year of the Quarterback, they had in mind such established stars as John Reaves of Florida, Jim Plunkett of Stanford, Dennis Dummit of the University of California, Los Angeles; Archie Manning of Mississippi

The stock market retreated yesterday morning in its initial reaction to the death of President Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt. But later the market rallied in rather impressive fashion to finish the day with modest gains.

The city's methadone program for the treatment of narcotics addicts is expected to double its capacity within the next 10 months, Mayor Lindsay announced at City Hall yesterday. That would put the capacity at 5,000 persons.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 29 (AP) Ted Abernathy singled home Bob Floyd with the winning run in the 12th inning to give the Kansas City Royals a 14-13 victory over the Minnesota Twins today. The game set a major-league record for most players used 49.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 29 Hundreds of families are confronted with the costly and anguishing task of replacing homes that were demolished by the great Los Angeles brush fires of the last few days.
The first woman member of the jury to try 13 Black Panthers accused of plotting to bomb public places was sworn in yesterday.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Sept. 29 Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr. won the Republican nomination for a second term today, and two little-known Democrats upset established party leaders in other key Florida contests.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 Speculation on the most likely succession to President Gamal Abdel Nasser centered here today on three power concentrations: the officer corps of the armed forces, the intelligence services and the Arab Socialist Union, President Nasser's allembracing politiacl front.
It will be much easier to follow the offensive dynamics of the New York Giants starting next Sunday. From here on, only Fran Tarkenton and Alex Webster will be responsible for calling plays.

MOSCOW, Sept. 29 The Soviet Union today mourned the death of Gamal Abdel Nasser with a statement affirming its desire for a political settlement in the Middle East and calling on all Arabs to strengthen their unity in memory of the Egyptian President.
All grain and soybeans futures declined yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. There appeared to be no outside influencing factor other than continuing good growing weather.

The man who announced to the world in July, 1952, that a group of army officers had seized power in Egypt and were demanding the abdication of King Farouk was a young army lieutenant colonel named Anwar Sadat.

Mr. and Mrs. Denison W. Schweppe have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanore Darst Schweppe, to Capt. John Richard Day Baxendale of the Army Judge Advocate General Corps at Fort Monmouth, N.J.
NEW HAVEN, Sept. 29 The national chairman of the Black Panther party, Bobby G. Seale, pleaded not guilty today to murder, kidnapping and conspiracy charges in Superior Court.
The SCM Corporation said yesterday that it had won a patent decision against the RCA Corporation.

GENEVA, Sept. 29 Six Americans, the last of the hundreds of hostages seized by Arab hijackers three weeks ago, were freed today in Amman, Jordan. It developed that their release was part of an arrangement involving the release of 19 Arabs held in Europe and Israel.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Sept. 29 Mrs. Vincent Larkin of the Nassau Country Club posted a 36, 43 79 today to win the Women's Long Island Golf Association eighth annual Reinert M. Torgerson Memorial championship for seniors over her home course. Par for the 5,530-yard course is 36, 36 72.

"The Artist's Father," the large portrait Paul Cezanne painted in 1866 at the age of 27, is one of the most powerful pictures this great painter produced in the difficult, early years of his career. It is a painting that looks to the past, however, far more than it looks to the future.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 Representative John W. Byrnes of Wisconsin, the ranking Republican on the House Ways and Means Committee, proposed today a different approach to the idea of using taxes as an incentive for the sale and use of unleaded gasoline.
"My poor little children are dying it's become a matter of survival," Mrs. Barbara Maltby said yesterday as she looked up at the choking black smoke coming out of a chimney.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 29 Charles Megginson Hackett, president of the NewsJournal Company, and editor in chief of the News-Journal papers, died of a heart ailment Sunday in St. Francis Hospital. He was 61 years old.

BELGRADE, Sept. 29 (AP) The Socialist Alliance of the Working People of Yugoslavia, a Communist-led mass organization, published a proclamation today about President Nixon's visit tomorrow. It read, in part:
The state lost its suit yesterday to bar the sale here of paintings by "master forger" David Stein as long as he signs his imitative work with his own name.
Nasser was the most successful leader of modern Arab history and his death leaves a vacuum not only in Egypt but throughout the area between Iran and the Atlantic.
The late Senator Estes Kefauver once described the Electoral College method of selecting Presidents and Vice Presidents as "a loaded pistol pointed at our system of government."

Earnings of the Avco Corporation in the three and nine months ended Aug. 31 plunged 66 and 62 per cent, respectively, under the impact of high interest costs and the general softening of the economy that adversely affected most of its operations, particularly government business.

Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Window Jones of New York and Redding Ridge, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dale Carter Jones, to Robert Lee Burch 3d, a vice president of the New York investment banking firm of Kidder, Peabody Co.

There never has been anything mandatory about requiring the contesting teams in postseason play to have at least one 20-game winner on their pitching staffs. It's been more or less taken for granted, like having the heaviest hitter bat in the fourth, or cleanup, position. There usually are raised eyebrows when the pattern isn't followed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 Supporters of the Nixon Administration's welfare reform legislation have all but abandoned hope of getting it out of the Senate Finance Committee, where opposition seems to be rising rather than falling.

A plan to bring manufacturers and retailers closer together through the development of combined marketing programs was described here yesterday as the basis for the first acquisition of a resident-buying office by a company outside the retail industry.

Physicians' assistants are needed to help solve the health manpower shortage, witnesses at a State Senate health committee hearing said here yesterday, but there was no consensus on what legislative standards should be set for these paramedical workers.

A freed American hostage, home after three weeks captivity in Jordan, said yesterday that he and 28 other hijacked Americans had appealed to Premier Golda Meir of Israel for a "reciprocal act of goodwill."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 The House approved today the first major Federal program in support of urban mass transit, a Nixon Administration proposal to commit $10-billion for new and improved bus and subway systems over the next dozen years.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 29 The public-address system in the gleaming air terminal plays songs from "Hair." The smell of popcorn perfumes the sidewalks of the Capital's shopping district, a hodgepodge of modern high-rise buildings and shabby storefronts. Downtown newsstands selling everything from Pravda to Playboy are festooned with nudes to catch the attention of hurrying crowds.

ALBANY, Sept. 29 In the second face-to-face confrontation of the United States Senate campaign, Representative Richard L. Ottinger sharply criticized the Nixon Administration today and linked his two opponents to the Administration.
Rosh ha-Shanah, the 10-day period of spiritual self-analysis and prayer and the most sacred in the Jewish faith, begins today at sundown.
The American Stock Exchange made a broad advance yesterday in active trading.
ALBANY, Sept. 29 Extremism is a fighting word, Arthur J. Goldberg said today, pronouncing Governor Rockefeller guilty of "the shabbiest kind of pandering to the voters' worst instincts."

Laurie W. Folmar producing; Annon M. Card sales; James W. Kinnear strategic planning, and John W. Green-Texaco Canada, Ltd., and Caltex Petroleum Corporation, have been named senior vice presidents, newly created positions, and Alfred C. DeCrane has been appointed vice president of the producing department Eastern hemisphere at Texaco, Inc.

GENEVA, Sept. 29 The United States served notice today that it might lodge a formal complaint with the world's leading trade forum against the European Common Market for failing to abide by its international trade commitments.

Francis M. Flynn, chairman of the board of WPIX and of The Daily News, said yesterday that WPIX had been guilty of "inaccuracies" in its news programing during the latter part of 1968, but that they had been the subject of vigorous investigation by station executives.

"I went one way at that last hedge and my horse went the other, but I managed to hang on," said Thomas Skiffington yesterday after scoring with Mrs. F. Ambrose Clark's Madagascar in the 62d running of the $24,050 Brook Steeplechase Handicap at Belmont Park.
Robert L. Meyers, president and chief executive officer of Georg Jensen, Inc., announced his resignation yesterday. Dan Rodgers will take over his duties as chief executive officer.

Edward J. Quigley, who retired as Postmaster of Brooklyn on July 1 after nearly a quarter of a century in the position, died yesterday in Methodist Hospital, Brooklyn, after a long illness. He was 70 years old and lived at 209 Lincoln Avenue.

A benefit party at the New Dramatists, 424 West 44th Street, will follow a first preview performance Wednesday of "The Rothschilds," the musical version of the book by Frederic Morton, at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater.
"I only want to live in peace," a Palestinian businessman told a reporter the other day as he showed visitors the bullet holes in his small home in devastated Amman.

NAPLES, Italy, Sept. 29 Deflected by the death of Gamal Abdel Nasser, the high command of the United States Government wondered today, like everyone else, what happens next along the shores of the Mediterranean.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 29 Thousands of Arabs in Israelioccupied territories displayed their emotions over the death of President Gamal Abdel Nasser today in impromptu street marches, their grief turning briefly into hostility at Israeli policemen and security patrols.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 The Federal Trade Commission accused the Standard Oil Company of California today of falsely advertising that its gasoline additive called F-310 significantly reduced air pollution from auto exhausts.

There comes a time in a football game, Pete Perreault was saying yesterday, "when something happens, and then suddenly your mind becomes devoid of everything else except what you have to do; it's good when that happens to you early."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 American officials said today that the United States had only dubious and dated information to indicate that the Soviet Union might be planning to build a strategic submarine base in Cuba.

Dr. Paul L. Adams, the Conservative party candidate for Governor, asserted today before an audience of students that the voters in this country believed that they had little control over their own political destiny because of the "increasing" centralization of government.

Valerian S. Rybar, Inc., the society decorating concern, was acquired yesterday by Richton International Corporation in a move that may help establish the star system in designing mass-produced furnishings as it has in fashions.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 29 (AP) The Baltimore Orioles and the Cincinnati Reds have been installed by Las Vegas bookmakers as favorites in the baseball playoff series beginning Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (Reuters) The Commerce Department forecast today that the rate of "real" growth in the gross national product in the third quarter would be higher than the 0.6 per cent rate of the second quarter.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 29 (AP) Southern California's worst ordeal by fire seemed to be near an end today.
ROME, Sept. 29 (UPI) Mrs. Richard M. Nixon, surrounded by heavy police protection, motored 12 miles from Rome today to visit an Italian boys' town patterned after the original at Omaha.

BLACKPOOL, England, Sept. 29 Former Prime Minister Harold Wilson warned today that any decision by the Conservative Government to sell arms to South Africa would be repudiated when the Labor party next wins an election.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 29 (AP) Susan Nelsen would like her husband to retire from professional football. She says the game's "hate and kill" are "unsettling things."
DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 29 Miss Ann Elizabeth Miller, a junior at American University, plans to be married here on Dec. 19 to Timothy Gordon Kline, a senior at American.
Encouraged by three state legislators, two groups of demonstrators charged the steps of City Hall yesterday.
Kate McGarrigle and Roma Baran, who appeared on Monday night at the Washington Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street, have the potential to be one of the wildest acts on the folk music circuit.
CANANDAIGUA, N.Y., Sept. 29 (AP) Edith Hinsley swept the first three races on the Finger Lakes program today.

SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 29 Prime Minister John G. Gorton today survived a censure motion based on charges that he had ordered an official photograph "doctored" so that it made Gough Whitlam, the Opposition leader, appear to be making a speech under a Vietcong flag.
DETROIT, Sept. 29 The Chrysler Corporation raised prices close to $200 a car today, following the example of other car manufacturers.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 29 A departing sailbag marked "Gretel II, Spinnaker Staysail" and a telegram arriving from Australia today told a familiar story of America's Cup completion and renewal.

The New York Stock Exchange issued a court challenge yesterday to the contention that its Special Trust Fund should be used to protect the 8,000 customers of Robinson Co., a brokerage house in Bankruptcy proceedings.

MEMPHIS, Sept. 29 The New York Knickerbockers ran their National Basketball Association preseason won-lost record to 4-1 tonight with a 119-98 victory over the Baltimore Bullets at Mid-South Coliseum.

The Justice Department, as part of an antidiscrimination suit it is prosecuting, yesterday cited six buildings in Brooklyn at which, it said, Samuel J. Lefrak and his agents had rented no more than 2.4 per cent of the space to Negroes. The buildings are in the Sheepshead Bay, Flatbush and Bensonhurst sections.
The Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company reported yesterday a decline in net income for the three months ended Aug. 31 despite increased revenues.

There is nothing so heartwarming on a nippy fall day as a sable coat right down to the floor. Which is why close to 600 women were purring so contentedly at Bergdorf Goodman's showing of furs by Emeric Partos.

A Roman Catholic publisher issued yesterday a full translation of the Bible into English from the original languages. The translation, the first such ever produced under Catholic auspices, is known as the New American Bible.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI) Government medical experts assured House investigators today that they were aware of "no evidence" that amphetamines were addicting in children under age 12 who were treated with the stimulant drug to overcome learning disabilities.
RICHLAND, Mich., Sept. 29 (AP) Steve Carrier, who was drafted into the Army 100 numbers too soon, has received good news.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI) Governors Rockefeller of New York and William T. Cahill of New Jersey appealed to Congress today for speedy approval of a bistate agreement aimed at curbing air cargo thefts.

The Board of Education, despite its plans to ask for a $615million school construction budget for 1971-72, came under attack from parents, teachers, and civic groups yesterday for laxity in its methods, contributing to overcrowding and being a party to endless red tape.

BOSTON, Sept. 29 Loyal beyond the call of duty, 14,254 fans showed up tonight with the thermometer at 62 degrees to watch the New York Yankees and the Red Sox go nowhere on the next-to-last day of the season.
The Texaco Overseas Petroleum Company, a subsidiary of Texaco, Inc., said yesterday that it had reached an agreement with the Government of Libya on posted prices for oil.

SIOUX FALLS, S.D., Sept. 29 Vice President Agnew charged here today that the Presidential Commission on Campus Unrest had indulged in "'scapegoating' of the most irresponsible sort" in saying that only the President could offer the moral leadership needed to reunite the country.
Owens-Illinois, Inc., announced yesterday a price increase of 4 per cent on all high-density polyethylene plastic bottles, effective Nov. 1.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 29 Economic and political life in the Arab Middle East came to a virtual standstill today. All Arab governments went into official mourning and their chiefs prepared to fly to Cairo for the funeral Thursday of President Gamal Abdel Nasser.
PARAMUS, N.J., Sept. 29 Cold weather, hard greens and difficult cup placements resulted in high scores as the 55th Metropolitan open golf championship began today.

The bond market dipped nervously yesterday under the impact of this week's big supply of new financing and also perhaps from uncertainty over the death of President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic.
EL HUMMAR, Jordan, Sept. 29 King Hussein, visibly affected by the death of Gamal Abdel Nasser, voiced confidence today that he would succeed in overcoming the chaos in this land.

What promises to be New York's busiest dance season got off to a runaway start last night at the New York City Center, where the City Center Joffrey Ballet opened its six-week fall season. Time was when the Joffrey dancers would drop in to New York for a mere two or three weeks, but now they have developed into a major company, and one of the most engaging in the world.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 Confronted by what it acknowledged to be a potentially serious fuel shortage as winter approaches, the Nixon Administration announced today several actions to ease the situation.

ATLANTA, Sept. 29 (AP) Gov. Lester Maddox cannot block the heavyweight boxing match between Cassius Clay and Jerry Quarry scheduled Oct. 26, the Georgia Attorney General, Arthur K. Bolton, ruled today.

After deliberating for three days a jury declared itself unable to reach a verdict yesterday in an income tax case against Carmine Lombardozzi, reputed to be a member of the New York Mafia family of Carlo Gambino.
NEW HAVEN, Sept. 29 The body of 5-year-old Jennifer Noon, who had been missing since Sept. 21, was found this morning in a wooded area of Hamden, a suburban community near here.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 29 (UPI) Walter Blum guided Paderoso to a three-quarterlength victory over Grate Fire today in the feature race at Atlantic City.

LONDON, Sept. 29 James Fisher, one of Britain's best known authors and broadcasters on nature and wild life, died today of injuries received in an automobile accident on Friday. He had just passed his 58th birthday.

MONTREAL, Sept. 29 (Canadian Press) The National Hockey League announced today that an agreement had been signed with the Bauer division of Greb Shoe, Ltd., of Kitchener, Ontario, making the skate manufacturer's product the official colored skate for the league teams.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 In one of the most difficult and expensive collecting coups in recent art history, the National Gallery of Art has acquired an early masterpiece by Paul Cezanne.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) The House Banking Committee approved by a 24-to-4 vote today a $7-billion omnibus housing bill extending existing programs and starting several new ones.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 29 More than 400 law enforcement agents fanned out through three New Jersey counties before dawn today and arrested 80 persons on narcotics charges during raids the state police described as the largest they had ever participated in.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Sept. 29 Mr. and Mrs. Melvin M. Nager of Great Neck have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sherry Nager, to Gary Richard Diamond of Ardmore, Pa., son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Diamond.

Mrs. Edward M. Kennedy made her concert debut near midnight Monday in the Americana Hotel's Imperial Ballroom. She settled herself on the edge of a chair, raised her tanned hands over the piano keyboard and slowly with a certain dignity despite masses of photographers delivered herself of a Mozart concerto. It was the high point of the Restore Ball, the season's first big gala.

TORONTO, Seat. 29 The Canadian Government announced today that it had authorized a substantial increase in exports of natural gas to the United States but a smaller one than American distributors had sought.
The Penn Central's streaking Metroliners, the nation's fastest trains, may get some new touches of glamour in the airline style hostesses and complimentary meals.

BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 29 (AP) Top-seeded Cliff Richey, the United States Davis Cup star, defeated Mike Machette of Belvedere, Calif., 7-6, 6-3, yesterday in the first round of the Pacific Coast open tennis tournament.
More than 300 firemen paid tribute yesterday to a comrade who was killed last year when he fell from a fire engine responding to a false alarm.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Sept. 29 (AP) Tom Fischer, the Colgate University football team's leading rusher, was dropped from the squad today. He said he had decided to quit anyway because he objected to the tactics of Coach Neil Wheelwright.
George Milton Jones, former president of the Logan County Coal Corporation, died Monday at his home in Phoenixville, Pa. He was 83 years old and lived on Maysfield Farm in Phoenixville.

During Nigeria's civil war, Americans responded generously to the appeals for aid to the hungry and sick in secessionist Biafra. Many contributed indiscriminately and discovered belatedly, if at all, that their money was being used for dubious Biafran political purposes rather than for relief.
PRINCETON, N.J. Mr. and Mrs. Thomas George came here two years ago in search of a castle but with little hope of finding the chateau of their dreams.

John L. Loeb, a leading Wall Street figure, has challenged the New York Stock Exchange to justify the grounds for its preliminary approval of the proposed merger cf Goodbody Co. into a mutual fund management concern.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 The Nixon Administration plans to announce soon some "new approaches" in the Model Cities program that are designed to lead to sweeping revisions in the Federal grant system in urban areas.
The Newspaper Guild unit at The New York Post voted yesterday to strike the paper at 6 A.M. next Tuesday if it did not have a satisfactory contract by that time.
After declining initially on uncertainties caused by the death of President Gamal Abdel Nasser, the London Stock Exchange rallied yesterday but closed slightly lower in active trading.

An inexperienced player who hears his partner bid four no-trump automatically gives a Blackwood response to show the number of aces he holds. Most of the time he is right to do so. Later in his bridge life he learns the obvious exception: four notrump is not Blackwood, but simply a slam invitation, when it is a raise from one no-trump or two no-trump.

ROME, Sept. 29 A team of scientists who have won the confidence of Amazonian tribes virtually untouched by civilization since the Spanish Conquest are using the tools of modern genetics to learn about human evolution in the primitive state.
The New York Mets passed the 1948 Cleveland Indians at the box office and the 1970 Chicago Cubs on the field last night as Jerry Koosman pitched them to a 3-1 victory over the Cubs at Shea Stadium.

"Work in Progress: Architecture by Philip Johnson, Kevin Roche, Paul Rudolph," the exhibition opening at the Museum of Modern Art today and continuing through Jan. 3, may turn out to be this season's most fashionably hated show. That could make it a resounding antisuccess, the only kind of success that has any real intellectual currency these days.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29 (UPI) Michael Saul Fleisher, 21 years old, sought in the slaying of a policeman during a bank robbery in Boston, Sept. 23, was arrested tonight at his home here.
Close your eyes and listen to Jules Freeman and you might think you were talking to a truck driver from the Bronx. You'd be right on the accent but way off on the line of work.

Seven motion-picture companies filed a complaint in Federal District Court here Monday to enjoin the Columbia Broadcasting System and the American Broadcasting Companies and their affiliates from producing, distributing or having any interest in television entertainment programs other than exhibiting them.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 29 The eight black athletes who were reinstated last week after their suspension from the Syracuse University football team rejected their reinstatement today.
The city's Consumer Affairs Department, as part of a new campaign against unlicensed home improvement contractors, charged a basement waterproofing company yesterday with misrepresentation.

Philip Morris confirmed yesterday that it will go national in mid-October with its new brand, New Leaf.
Racial incidents at schools in Syracuse; Brentwood, L.I., and several New Jersey communities resulted in the closing of several schools and a number of injuries and arrests yesterday.

MASSAPEQUA, L.I., Sept. 29 Aleksandr Filipov, the Soviet ballet dancer who defected recently, has obtained his first job in this country with the Eglevsky Ballet Company here. He had been performing with the Moiseyev classical ballet company, Young Ballet, on a LatinAmerican tour.

FORT HOOD, Tex., Sept. 30 (UPI) Formal pretrial hearings for S. Sgt. David Mitchell ended today, and Sergeant Mitchell's trial on charges that he attempted to murder 30 Vietnamese civilians in March, 1968, was scheduled to begin next Tuesday.
'A smoky fire in the Nostrand Avenue subway station in Brooklyn yesterday forced the evacuation of close to 500 passengers aboard three IND trains.

State transportation officials said yesterday that the $3.1billion Federal mass transit bill approved by the House Tuesday could bring to New York more than $400-million for subways, buses, commuters railroads and other transit projects through 1975.
The Board of Education will start a radio series on drug abuse on Monday. The five-program series will be broadcast to public school classes over the school system's own radio station, WNYE-FM.

Howard J. Samuels, president of the city's Offtrack Betting Corporation, said yesterday the corporation might issue credit cards in an effort to draw business away from illegal bookmakers.

Although the death of Gamal Abdel Nasser has been marked by overt and widespread grief in the Arab world, the Moslem religion frowns upon excessive weeping and vocal displays of grief.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 30-Mr. and Mrs. J. Hartley Joys have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Anne Joys, to Patrick Dennis Burke, both of New York. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Burke of Sun City Center, Fla.
CAIRO, Sept. 30 The death of President Gamal Abdel Nasser has raised grave questions among diplomats and analysts here about the political future of the United Arab Republic.

HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 30 (UPI) Perc Westmore, a member of the famous Westmore family of make-up artists, who transformed 2,500 women into "Queen for a Day" on the original television show of that name, died today at the age of 65.
PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 30 A sentence of 15 years' imprisonment was imposed today on Benjamin Ramotse, a militant black leader who was found guilty yesterday of terrorist activities.
Business and industry put up fewer help-wanted signs in August, continuing a trend that set in late last winter.

The first suit bid by a player whose opponents have opened the bidding almost always shows at least a fivecard suit. Awareness of this rule makes some spectacular bids possible. An example is the diagramed deal, splayed last Sunday in the New YorkNew Jersey regional championships.

Remember those winter days long ago when you huddled around the fireplace in your long winter woolies as icy winds howled outside? The flickering flames seemed a frail ally in your fight for survival.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 30?United Nations security guards are threatening a mass sick-leave job action during the 25th anniversary celebration unless promotion policies are improved.

ROME, Sept. 30 Benedetto Cardinal Aloisi Masella, a former papal diplomat who for many years was a pillar of the Roman Catholic Church's central administration, the Roman Curia, died here after a short illness today. He was 91 years old, the oldest member of the Sacred College of Cardinals.

John D. Hughey 3d, who admitted being part of a bombing conspiracy that was led by Samuel J. Melville to plant explosives in eight Manhattan office buildings a year ago, was placed under supervision of the Federal Board of Parole for up to six years yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) The Treasury Department today attributed the decline in the nation's total reserve a assets during the first part of this year to repayments by Britain and France of their currency "swap" lines, or reciprocal credit agreements.
CAIRO, Sept. 30 MIG-21 jet fighters screamed low over Cairo today in rehearsal for the pageantry that is to be part of the funeral tomorrow of President Gamal Abdel Nasser.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 The Federal Commission on Obscenity and Pornography made public today its recommendation to eliminate all legal restrictions on adults who wish to obtain sexually explicit books, pictures and films.
