HARTFORD Sept. 30 Gov. John N. Dempsey called a special session of the Connecticut General Assembly today to create legislation that would enable unemployed workers to receive Federal funds for extended compensation payments. The session will convene at 10 A.M. on Tuesday.

VUNGTAU, South Vietnam, Sept. 30 (Reuters) Gen. Creighton W. Abrams, commander of United States forces in Vietnam, was rushed to a hospital today after he collapsed during a ceremony honoring Australian troops fighting in Vietnam.

Mayor Lindsay on a jovial, quipping trip to Staten Island yesterday took in some new sights the world's largest tank for storing liquefied natural gas and a sprawling container-ship terminal now in the full flurry of construction.

The Theater Development Fund, the nonprofit corporation that financially assists commercial products of artistic merit, has allocated $350,000 for such aid this season, according to Hugh Southern, fund executive director.

The Government has pledged $15-million to $20-million to help in the take-over of the LFC Financial Corporation, a $1-billion saving's and loan holding company based in Los Angeles that has experienced serious financial problems.

H. Ross Perot, chairman of the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, disclosed yesterday he intends to sell publicly about 300,000 company shares he owns. The offering, to obtain a wider distribution of the shares, would be valued at more than $19-million, based on yesterday's over-the-counter quotation of 64 bid, 66 asked.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) A Federal grand jury indicted today on three charges four young men sought by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in connection with the explosion Aug. 24 at the University of Wisconsin's Army Mathematics Research Center.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 The Nixon Administration opened a new hole in Selective Service regulations today that could allow thousands of young men to escape the draft.
The threat of a strike by baseball umpires assigned to the playoffs and World Series appeared to be developing yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 30 (AP) Lou Novikoff, baseball's "Mad Russian," died today at the age of 54.

Silver futures fell again yesterday in heavy trading on the New York Commodity Exchange, with the price of the nearby December contract, the busiest with 1,319 sales dropping to $1.689 an ounce from $1.732 the day before.

ALEXANDRIA, Minn., Sept. 28 Former Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey sat this week at the same table with Representative Clark MacGregor, his Republican opponent, with only a moderator separating them.

SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 30 Senator Frank E. Moss is a typical member of the Democratic class of 1958, which is made up of Senators who won upset victories that year, were swept to re-election in the Johnson landslide of 1964 and now find themselves vulnerable.

In the season's first "Madama Butterfly" at the Metropolitan Opera, on Tuesday night, there was a soprano new to the title role, Jeannette Pilou. The Greek artist, who is now in her fourth year with the company, is a likable and sensitive singer. Her voice is neither large nor very sensuous, yet it projects well and is skillfully used.
Moody's Investors Service, Inc., the oldest securities rating agency, announced yesterday that it intends to charge for grading, corporate and other taxable bonds, beginning Oct. 15.
Blackpool, England, Sept. 30 By a slim margin, the leadership of the Labor party withstood a determined attempt today to turn the party against British membership in the Common Market.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 Twenty-two years after President Truman made such a proposal, the Senate acted today to give a Federal commission power to enforce nondiscrimination in employment throughout the nation.
THE PRESIDENT Activities. The President left Naples and flew to Belgrade, Yugoslavia, for meetings with President Tito.
WASHINGTON, Sept, 30 (AP) Senator Hugh Scott, Senate Republican leader, said today that the last United States combat troops "will be coming out of Vietnam" by next summer.
HOUSTON, Sept. 30 (AP) Harry Walker was rehired today as manager of the Houston Astros for another year. He said he believed the club showed signs of becoming a pennant contender.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 A Harvard economist urged today that the United States conduct a "passive" balance-ofpayments policy and pursue monetary policies that are "best for domestic goals."

Channel 13 will be formally renamed Station WNET this morning as the Educational Broadcasting Corporation and National Education Television are consolidated into a major producing unit providing both national and local programing.
Jim Trimble always is treated so well when he scouts the Giants' next opponent that he tries to wish every team into sounding like a sure Super Bowl winner.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Sept. 30 (UPI) Charlie Tate, in the final year of a seven-year contract, resigned today as head football coach and athletic director at the University of Miami.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 The index of wholesale prices, which generally foreshadows retail price trends by a few months, rose sharply again in September, partly, but not entirely, because of increased food costs.

In the last seven years Josh Napoles, the Cuban-born resident of Mexico City, has won 36 of 37 fights and 32 of them by knockout. Those feats have earned him a reputation as one of the most exicting and most efficient professional boxers in the world.

Douglas E. Ahrendt, an agent with the Penn Mutual Life Insurance Company, died Monday of Hodgkin's disease in Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. He Was 38 years old and lived at 9 Juniper Road, New Canaan, Conn.

EAST BERLIN, Sept. 30 The latest opera by Alan Bush, 70-year-old British composer, whose works are much performed in East Germany, had its world premiere at the East Berlin State Opera yesterday. Entitled "Joe Bill," it treats the imprisonment and execution of the I.W.W. labor movement composer on Nov. 19, 1915, in Salt Lake City. The libretto is by New Yorker Barrie Stavis, based on his play "The Man Who Never Died."

The campaign in New York State's 29th Congressional District is the only race in the country this fall with two incumbent House members running against each other, and it is unusual for other reasons as well.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 The House voted today to increase air passenger taxes to pay for the use of trained guards on commercial airliners. The bill, passed by a vote of 323 to 17, now goes to the Senate for final action.

Executives and professionals at all of the domestic offices of the giant Interpublic Group of Companies learned yesterday that, because of the economic picture, some would be taking pay cuts for the fourth quarter. Only those who make more than $20,000 a year will be affected, with the size of the cut increasing with the salary.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 The Federal Trade Commission moved today to protect householders from high-pressure door-to-door salesmen.

HONG KONG, Sept. 30 Premier Chou En-lai today hailed revolutionary gains in Communist China and pledged continued support for revolutionaries abroad in a keynote speech in Peking on the eve of celebrations of Communist China's 21st anniversary.
LONDON, Sept. 30 Leila Khaled, the Palestinian woman commando who tried unsuccessfully to hijack an airliner 24 days ago, was released from prison tonight and flown out of the country.

An appellate court validated yesterday former Bronx Borough President Herman Badillo's Democratic nomination for Congress in the new threeborough 21st District, countermanding a Queens Supreme Court justice's order that a new primary be held next Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 The Nixon Administration announced today its plan to use, the Model Cities program as a means of decentralizing authority in Federal grants. The plan was promptly endorsed by the nation's mayors.
Vandals patted slogans on a Brooklyn synagogue early yesterday. The eight-inch-high red lettering read "Palestine Liberation," "Free Bobby Now" and "Free Lila."

ATLANTTC CITY, N.J., Sept. 30 The United Steelworkers of America called today for the election of more liberals to Congress to counter what a convention resolution described as the "antilabor direction" of the Nixon Administration.
The London stock market finished moderately firmer yesterday as trading slowed from the recent brisk pale.
BOSTON, Sept. 30 With a little bit of help from Lindy McDaniel tonight, Fritz Peterson became the first New York Yankee left-hander to win 20 games since Whitey Ford did it in 1963.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) The Nixon Administration accepted today a multimilliondollar program for putting the unemployed into federally supported public-service jobs as part of a major overhaul of the Government's manpower-training system.
ENCINO, Calif., Sept. 30 Edward Everett Horton, a character actor who was a master of comic befuddlement, died last night at his home in the San Fernando Valley. He was 83 years old.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 30 (UPI) Results of a survey released today showed that, of 3,182 senior officers and directors in the executive suites and board rooms of the nation's top 50 corporations, three were black.

MALIBU, Calif., Sept. 30 The Presbyterian Church had given Amelia Harrison a pair of blue jeans and a work shirt, but they could not give her back her house. That was gone, a big mound of smoldering, ashen rubble.

While the last of hundreds of hostages from three hijacked and destroyed airliners were emerging from their ordeal in Jordan this week, the governing council of the International Civil Aviation Organization was meeting in Montreal to consider new measures to curb aerial piracy. The results of that meeting are discouraging.
AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 30 The Jordanian Army and the Palestinian guerrillas began withdrawing from Amman to-, day under the terms of a truce agreement reached in Cairo Sunday.
West Germany will send a four-man team, headed by Hans Gunther Winkler, former Olympic gold-medal winner to the National Horse Show for the first time since 1963.
Thomas J. Galligan Jr., president of the Boston Edison Company, has been made chief executive officer, succeeding Charles F. Avila, who will continue as chairman.
TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 30 Thousands of purple and white orchids, flown in from Hawaii, tumbled with fragile grace from the gilt epergnes on the dinner tables.

MOSCOW, Sept. 30 The Soviet Union scoffed today at the White House's expressions of concern about possible Soviet construction of a strategic submarine base in Cuba. It accused the United States of fanning a "war psychosis."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 The President's special representative for trade negotiations, Carl J. Gilbert, warned today that passage of the proposed Trade Act of 1970 might be "playing with fire."

Landlords charged in Supreme Court yesterday that the city administration was seeking to cut rents immediately in the 16-day-old Bronx, apartment strike "despite the understanding to the contrary in open court" that such cuts would not take effect until November.
The stock market closed yesterday the final trading session of the third quarter with small price changes appearing in most issues.

A reduction in the 6 per cent interest charge the Federal Reserve System imposes on loans to its member banks "may happen any time," the chairmandesignate of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company said yesterday.

New York City and six states sued the three largest automobile manufacturers yesterday, charging them with illegal price-fixing in refusing to grant discounts to state and local governments that buy fleets of vehicles from them.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 30 Arthur J. Goldberg, Democratic-Liberal candidate for Governor of New York, told steel union delegates today that the November elections were a crucial referendum on the NixonAgnew Administration.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 The Interstate Commerce Commission allowed the insolvent Penn Central Transportation Company today to discontinue 14 of 34 long-distance passenger trains, but a Federal judge later blocked the move.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 Soviet proposals on the future of West Berlin were outlined today at a meeting of the Big Four in Berlin, informed sources said today.

The last hostages held in Jordan since their jets were hijacked early this month returned yesterday, to be met by police cars that whisked three of them home before sundown and the start of the Jewish New Year.

The National Industrial Conference Board, a nonprofit business and economic research organization, will present a new image to the world in the form of a shorter name, a new insignia and a major restructuring of its research and service activities.

Frederick B. Lacey, the United States Attorney for New Jersey, described Kennedy International Airport yesterday, as an "open city" where a union and a trade association cooperate with criminals to steal $7-million worth of cargo each year.

BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 30 (UPI)3 All of the favorites scored impressive victories to day in the $32,000 Pacific Coast international tennis open, but the tournament director, Barry MacKay fell to the wayside.

Coming on top of the tragic events of the past fortnight in Amman, the sudden death of President Gamal Abdel Nasser constitutes a dreadful blow to the prospects for peace in the Middle East. CAZENOVIA, N.Y., Sept. 30 Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Leighton Hansen have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gillette Kilburn Hansen, to Fred Weckesser Pool 2d, who is serving with the Air Force at Fort Carson in Colorado Springs. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred W. Pool of Littleton, Colo.

DETROIT, Sept. 30 (AP) Both General Motors and the United Automobile Workers reported progress today in solving local-level issues, but 29,376 of these still stood in the way of settlement of the union's 17-day strike against G.M.
Mrs. Afeni Shakur, one of 13 Black Panthers accused of plot ting to bomb public places, was sent back to jail yesterday and her $100,000 bail returned to the people who posted it.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz announced yesterday that she would appeal a ruling Monday by State Supreme Court Justice Arnold L. Fein permitting the sale here of paintings by "master forger" David Stein.

Wometco Enterprises, Inc., whose diversified interest range from television, radio broadcasting and a theater chain to soft drink bottling, vending, fast-food restaurants, outdoor advertising and the Miami Seaquarium, posted records in sales and earnings for the 12 and 36 weeks ended Sept. 12.
Radhakrishna Ramani, Malaysia's Ambassador to the United Nations, who had undergone open-heart surgery here in 1966, died yesterday in his suite at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. His age was 68.

The United States Trust Investment Fund, operated by the United States Trust Company of New York, and the Mad International Fund, organized by Banca Commerciale Italiana, of Milan, and the Banque de Paris et des Pays Bas, Paris, announced plans yesterday to merge the two closed-end funds, which are registered in Luxembourg.
Bond prices rose yesterday as this week's heavy, volume of new issues sold to investors quickly enough to encourage investment bankers and traders.
Wringing every ounce of suspense out of an otherwise lost season, the New York Mets suffered a 2-0 defeat to the Chicago Cubs yesterday and fell back into a tie for second place with one game to go.

Moscow's initial proposals for a provisional Berlin settlement hint at willingness to accept West Berlin's economic ties to Bonn and its right of access to the West. This first indication of concessions in six months of talks was on the table at yesterday's critical meeting of the Big Four ambassadors their first since the SovietGerman treaty.
A film distributor and three theater managers were arrested yesterday after a criminal court judge here authorized the seizure of the film "Censorship in Denmark: A New Approach."
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 30 President Nixon came to Yugoslavia today and heard President Tito warn that "universal peace and stability cannot be achieved by the big powers alone."
Despite a lot of intergovernment talk, few additional international commodity agreements will be made in the nineteen-seventies, an official of the State Department predicted yesterday.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 30 Racial tension between white and black schoolchildren lessened here today following two days of violence that forced the closing of three of the city's four high schools.
Dr. James G. Haughton, the city's second-ranking health official, has resigned to accept an appointment in Chicago as executive director of the Cook County Hospital Governing Commission.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 The United States has issued a visa to Peng Ming-min, a member of the Taiwan independence movement who escaped from house arrest in Taiwan early this year and fled to Sweden.
PARIS, Sept. 30 Former President Charles de Gaulle today made public a personal letter of condolence to the United Arab Republic's Ambassador in Paris on the death of Gamal Abdel Nasser.
The mysterious case of Don Maynard continues as the New York Jets approach Sunday's game with the Buffalo Bills.

The city's Consumer Affairs Commissioner, Mrs. Bess Myerson Grant, proposed five regulations yesterday designed to protect householders from "inconvenience, abuse-and deception" on the part of moving companies.
ATLANTIC CITY, Thursday, Oct. I (UPI) A 27-year-old Canine Corps patrolman was shot to death about midnight when one of two men he stopped to question raised a shotgun to his neck and fired.

The American Stock exchange scored its sixth consecutive advance yesterday although some late weakness erased a portion of the earlier gains.

With a sharp, but restrained, attack on his Democratic opponent and gentle, although qualified, praise for his Republican opponent, James L. Buckley commenced yesterday a decisive phase of his Conservative campaign to become United States Senator from New York.
Vice President Agnew, campaigning in Minot, N.D., declared yesterday that Senator Charles E. Goodell was a "radical liberal' who "has left his party."
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 30 (UPI) A Brandeis University graduate was held in $50,000 bail today pending a further hearing on an accessory charge in the bank holdup-slaying of a Boston policeman.

PARAMUS, N.J., Sept. 30 Jimmy Wright, who has won two Long Island tournaments this year, spun around the Ridgewood Country Club today with a three-under-par 69. It gave him a two-stroke dead in the Metropolitan open, golf championship as he trimmed his first-round total by seven strokes, for a 36-hole aggregate of 145.

An off-duty patrolman was critically wounded yesterday when he was shot as he came to the aid of a Bronx auto wrecking shop operator who, the police said, was arguing with two men over a $100 deposit.
SPRINGFIELD, Mo., Sept. 30 (AP) A dynamite-laden truck, operated by a struck company, was blown up today after it apparently was hit by a sniper's bullet. The driver was killed.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 30 Dr. Salvador Allende, the Marxist candidate who won a plurality in Chile's presidential election on Sept. 5, issued a seven-page statement today that rejected as unnecessary demands by the governing Christian Demorcatic party that he forego, at least for a while, the right to name commanders of the nation's armed forces.

SHOREHAM, L.I., Sept. 30 The population of this minuscule North Shore village has shot up in the last decade, from 164 to 500 people. Otherwise the tiny community on 100 acres of wood land and bluffs dropping down to the scalloped shoreline of Long Island.

The reaction to the latest Mideastern nightmare has been typical; horror at the destruction of those nice shiny airplanes, at the abduction of innocent tourists, at the blood bath that followed in Jordan, shock at the death of President Nasser.

Governor Rockefeller cited yesterday the accomplishments of the two-year-old New York State Urban Development Corporation, set up by his administration two years ago, as he joined in ground-breaking ceremonies at two Bronx housing projects.

The New York City Opera's production of "The Marriage of Figaro," which underwent its fourth performance of the fall season on Tuesday night, is scarcely the last word in aristocratic Mozart style at one point, for instance, the Count Almaviva wins a bellylaugh by threatening to hit the Countess with a sledgehammer.

Directors of the Sperry and Hutchinson Company elected Frederick A. Collins Jr, as president and chief operating officer of the nation's largest trading-stamp company yesterday. He succeeds Frank P. Rossi, 64 years old, who becomes chairman of the executive committee, a post which had been vacant for four years. William S. Beinecke, 56, chairman and chief execuive officer, said the changes were effective today.

The formation of a ninemember Governors' Special Commission on Financing Mass Transportation, set up to study ways and means of obtaining Federal financial aid "administered on a coordinated basis," was announced yesterday by the Governors of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

The National Audubon Society notified Federal health and conservation officials yesterday that some recent tests show that woodcocks, are so high, in DDT content that eating them may be hazardous to human health.

A promising debut was made at Town Hall on Tuesday night by Avon Stuart, a young baritone from Virginia who has come to the professional musical world by way of Howard University and study with Todd Duncan and Phyllis Curtin, among others. Mr. Stuart's qualities were not exactly unexpected, since he was presented in this recital by the New York Singing Teachers' Association.
SOUTHBURY, Conn. One of the most fascinating colonies in America is a small, 200-acre community that lies within the town of Southbury and in the direction of Danbury.

Mrs. Hugh D. Auchincloss, a pillar of Newport and Washington society and the mother of Mrs. Aristotle S. Onassis, spent the whole day yesterday doing something that she thinks will "help raise the standards of taste in American homes."
As V.J. (Lefty)Nickerson, the horse's trainer, might have described it, Burd Alane won big yesterday. End of statement.

Miss E. Wylie Farmer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Farmer of Yokohama, Japan, and London, was married yesterday in the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration (the Little Church Around the Corner), to William. F. Mertz Jr., president of Mertz Industries, Inc., a textile firm here.
Two voices have come to us lately from the heart of darkness Nazi Germany of the nineteen-thirties and forties. One is the voice of a living man. The other is the voice of a dead man.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 31 Charles W. Yost, the chief delegate of the United States to the United Nations, today called on all parties in the Middle East to start moving toward peace negotiations. He added, however, that to achieve this it was necessary to restore lost faith in the integrity of the armistice agreement along the Suez Canal zone.

The Jewish Defense League is trying to raise bail for the young Brooklyn couple who were arrested Sunday as they allegedly prepared to board a flight for London with fraudulent passports, four revolvers and a live hand grenade.
NORWELL, Mass., Sept. 30 Inez Haynes Irwin, an author and suffragette, died here Friday in a nursing home. She was 97 years old and was the widow of Will Irwin, the reporter and writer.

FISHKILL, N.Y., Sept. 30 Dr. Paul L. Adams predicted today that many upstate Democrats would vote for him on Nov. 3 because they were "disillusioned" with the makeup of their party's statewide ticket.
Grandmaster Lubomir Kavalek of Washington, a former Czechoslovak champion, won first place in the recent first Grand International Chess Tournament in Caracas, Venezuela.

The political strike conducted by Bronx landlords against the city's newly modified rent-control standards has obliged municipal officials to take over the role of landlord in several hundred apartment houses that have been deprived of hot water, garbage removal and other services.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) George M. Elsey was installed today as president of the American Red Cross, taking the place of Gen. James F. Collins.
The Monsanto Company announced yesterday that it would follow Owens-Illinois, Inc., is raising prices on all high and low-density polyethylene plastic bottles by 4 per cent, effective Nov. 1.

The New York Film Festival, which concluded a 21-day run at Lincoln Center yesterday, expects a downturn from last year's record receipts and-audience when the official figures are released next week.
MADRID, Sept. 30 (Reuters) Two superb rounds gave France-a four-stroke lead today over the United States team in the Espirito Santo women's world amateur golf championship.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Thursday, Oct. 1 Nigerians began a three-day holiday yesterday celebrating the 10th anniversary of their independence from Britain with parades, a 21-gun salute and dancing in the streets of the flag-decked capital. The festivities are accompanied by persuasive signs that the country is finally beginning to fulfill its promise.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 The Food and Drug Administration announced steps today to make safety glass mandatory in virtually all the new eyeglasses Americans wear.
Three city civil service employes were awarded $1,000 each yesterday by Deputy Mayor Richard R. Aurelio for suggestions submitted to the city's employe-suggestion program.

A high rate of return and safety are in the minds of many small investors, especially older ones worried about inflation. This group has found it difficult to find the right investment combinations yet one in denominations small enough for their wallets.
One meal a week of fish taken from most mercurycontaminated waters is probably safe, according to a report in the September Bulletin of the Sport Fishing Institute.
Merger moves dropped sharply in this year's third quarter, W.T. Grimm Co., merger and acquisition consultants, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UPI) A cigarette industry spokesman termed "specifically and categorically false" today a charge by Ralph Nader that hazardous nontobacco elements were being added to cigarettes, cigars and cigarillos.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 William Cody Wilson is the sort of chap who could come out of the movie "I Am Curious (Yellow)," and remark, "I thought the politics more interesting than the sex."

HAMDEN, Conn., Sept. 30 Fearful parents in this town of 50,000 have taken extraordinary precautions to protect their children since the discovery in a wooded area here on Tuesday of the body of a 5-year-old girl abducted in nearby New Haven on Sept. 21.

YONKERS, Sept. 30 Anyone who was at Yonkers Raceway last Monday night and saw Albatross win the $27,747 Star Pointer Pace by eight lengths would agree that Bert James's colt should be favored to win Saturday night's $53,495.63 Lawrence B. Sheppard Pace here.
Penn State's loss to Colorado last Saturday was not completely unexpected. The Nittany Lions, who went through 31 games without a loss since the third contest of 1967, just had to lose some time.
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 30 George Francis Axt, a retired architect, died today of a heart attack in his home at 442 Valley View Road. His age was 72.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) The Treasury Department said today that a rabbi from Salem, Mass., had been charged with the transportation and concealment of 10 pounds of hashish.
Mayor Lindsay sent a nonpartisan, wait-till-next-year letter yesterday to both the Mets and the Yankees.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UPI) The space agency anpounced drastic new measures today to try to insure that no Apollo astronaut will get sick during a moon flight.

HONG KONG, Thursday, Oct. 1 (Reuters) Chairman Mao Tse-tung, apparently in excellent health, strode today into Tien An Men Square in Peking amid cheers to watch a parade marking Communist China's 21st anniversary, the Peking radio reported.

Four creditors of Blair Co., a major brokerage house in liquidation, charged yesterday that the concern and 10 of its officers had fraudulently solicited $4-million in subordinated loans from the creditors, while withholding information about Blair's financial distress.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 Sources close to the supersonic transport program indicated today that the Senate's crucial vote on this year's $290-million appropriation would probably be held up until after the November election.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 30 (Reuters) An Air Vietnam airliner carrying 26 passengers and a crew of three crashed today in mountains about 10 miles north of Danang.
The deadline for nominations to be submitted for the 1971 Pulitzer Prizes in letters is Nov. 1, it was announced yesterday.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 30 The people and politics of Israel called a pause in a season of exhausting upheavals tonight, opening a three-day holiday to mark the Jewish New Year. The calendar and the pace of events coincided to permit Israel a moment of rest and of national stock-taking.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 President Nixon was reported by key political advisers today to be preparing to veto the bill limiting campaign expenditures for radio and television.
Machinists have rejected a tentative agreement on a new contract with the city's four major newspapers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 The United States is seeking to arrange a conference on the Middle East between Premier Aleksei M. Kosygin of the Soviet Union and Elliot L. Richardson, the representative of President Nixon, after the funeral of, Gamal Abdel Nasser in Cairo tomorrow.
LONDON, Sept. 30 Dr Hans Kronberger, director of reactor development for the Atomic Energy Authority's industrial development group was found hanged in his garage yesterday.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 30 Chester R. Harris, a past president and former chairman of the board of the Kerite Company in New York, makers of insulated wire and cable, died yesterday at a nursing home in Montclair. He was 88 years old and lived at 123 Beverly Road.

The city's Commissioner of Investigation does not have the authority to jail three policemen until they answer questions about alleged graft, State Supreme Court Justice Francis T. Murphy Jr. ruled yesterday.
John M. Kyle, Chief Engineer of the Port of New York Authority since 1947, died yesterday of a heart attack in Midtown Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at 356 East 50th Street.

The financial difficulties of a company whose stock is traded on the American Stock Exchange brought a sharp drop yesterday in the price of another company, whose stock is traded on the New York Stock Exchange.

LACEY, Wash., Sept. 30 (AP) Robert H. Finch, counselor to the President, disagreed today with some of Vice President Agnew's criticism of the report of the Presidential Commission on Campus Unrest. Mr. Finch said he did not know if Mr. Agnew had read the report.

HARRISON, N.Y., Sept. 30 Howard M. Ernst, founding partner of Ernst Co., bond brokers of 120 Broadway, New York, died yesterday in his home on Woodlands Road. His age was 75. He also lived in St. Petersburg, Fla.

The Jewish New year of 5731 began at sundown yesterday as rabbis in Rosh ha-Shanah sermons pleaded for the United States to lead the free world in safeguarding Israel's security, called on the Soviet Union to restore the cultural and religious rights of Jews and urged a greater adherence to the doctrines of Judaism.

Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Ader of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Felice Eileen Ader, to David W. Ostrow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Ostrow of New York, Rockville Centre, L.I. and Hollywood, Fla.
"That would be lovely," sighed Mae Alston.

WASHINGTON Sept. 30 The House Ways and Means Committee decided today to postpone until after the election any further consideration of the tax the Administration wants to put on lead additives to gasoline.
ALBANY, Sept. 30 "Significant weaknesses in managerial controls" and a $2-million excess claim for nursing-home care were laid to New York City today by Arthur Levitt, the State Controller.
A patrolman disguised as a Skid-Row derelict used his bottle of wine yesterday to help thwart the escape of two suspects after a bar holdup in Greenwich Village, the police reported.
WPIX's former chief of news was demoted following a reported misrepresentation of news film by the station, Fred M. Thrower, president of WPIX, said yesterday.

SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 30 Vice President Agnew came here today to deliver a political lecture on decency and wound up telling antiwar demonstrators they should make their points "with your minds, not with your butts."

ROME, Sept. 30 Scientists from 42 countries today endorsed a proposal that the United Nations organize and operate a global system of stations on land and sea and in orbit to watch for subtle but potentially disastrous changes in the environment.
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Sept. 30 (AP) Art Rooney, owner of the Pittsburgh Steelers, and his five sons have purchased the Palm Beach Kennel Club for about $7-million.

Patrick V. Murphy, New York's new Police Commissioner, is understood to have decided that a new generation of top commanders should run this city's 37,000-man police force. From conversations with numerous police experts in and out of the department, it appears that Mr. Murphy's decision will mean the departure in the coming weeks and months of many of the high police officials now in power.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) Representative Emanuel Celler, chairman of the House Antitrust Subcommittee, asked the Justice Department today to prevent a merger between the Warner-Lambert Pharmaceutical Company and Parke, Davis Co.

SEATTLE, Oct. 1 Jimi Hendrix, the rock guitarist who died in London on Sept. 18 at the age of 27, was buried in Greenwood Cemetery in suburban Renton today after a brief and simple funeral service in the Dunlap Baptist Church.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Oct. 1 Mrs. Thorne Dempsey of Piping Rock scored 35, 40 75 today to win low gross in the Women's Long Island Golf Association's one-day tournament at the North Hempstead Country Club. Par for the 5,748yard course is 36, 38 74.
Governor Rockefeller announced yesterday that he was making available on an emergency basis five classrooms in the Kingsbridge Armory to help alleviate overcrowding at Pub lic School 11 in the Bronx.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 1?The pupils of Eastwood Junior High School here were sent home today after Adolph Miller, an industrial arts teacher, received minor cuts while attempting to take a meat cleaver away from a 14-year-old girl. Another girl received an arm injury after being pushed into a wall during a fight.

YONKERS, Oct. 1 As many a baseball general manager would admit, the best deals are often the ones he fails to make. For example, a pitcher he had tried to sell and didn't developed into a consistent winner, or an outfielder taken off the market because the price was not right helped win a pennant.

Mrs. Teresa Golffing Fischer, consumer-relations manager of MEM Company, manufacturers of men's toiletries, in Northville, N.J., died in Lenox Hill Hospital yesterday after a brief illness. She was 83 years old and lived at 250 East 65th Street.

A State Supreme Court Justice upheld yesterday the city's authority to begin rent reduction proceedings when services to apartment house tenants are reduced, even in cases when the diminution of services results from a strike.

The Old Reliable is a friendly neighborhood tavern in the depths of the Lower East Side on Third Street between Avenues B and C. Its cozy back room is a friendly neighborhood theater presenting mostly new plays, free, all season long, Mondays through Fridays. The current production is "Wuziz!" an enticingly titled new play by Donald Kvares whose 16 previous works have appeared all over the off Off Broadway circuit.
The stock market finished yesterday on an even keel as trading fell to its slowest pace in six weeks. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange amounted to 9.7 million shares.
Computer Applications, Inc., one of the nation's first and largest computer software concerns, filed a petition yesterday for reorganization under Chapter X of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

Life magazine, following an industry trend triggered by rising costs, will cut its circulation and its advertising page rates and increase its subscription costs. It will also kill its international editions because of inadequate advertising revenues.
The notion that this year's crop of 2-year-olds was something less than special had to be revised yesterday at Belmont Park after Hoist the Flag won the $65,200 Cowdin Stakes.
DETROIT, Oct. 1 (AP) The Detroit Tigers announced today that a news conference would be held tomorrow at Tiger Stadium, but declined to disclose the subject.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 1 (Reuters) President Nguyen van Thieu submitted to the lower house of the legislature a proposed national budget for 1971 of $16.9-billion, it was disclosed today.

NAIROBI The irony of the Black Panthers and other militant black groups is that though doomed to fail insofar as their own avowed goals are concerned, they will in the end achieve some of the moderate goals for which less militant civil rights groups have unsuccessfully been fighting during the past decade.

Congress can make an immediate and substantial contribution to the war against organized crime by authorizing extension of the policing powers of the Waterfront Commission to include airports in the metropolitan area. The urgency of such action was highlighted by this week's declaration of Frederick H. Lacey, United States Attorney for New Jersey, that Kennedy Airport has become an "open city" for underworld syndicates.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) The Senate completed action today on a $19.9-billion military procurement bill authorizing expansion of the Safeguard antimissile system.

ALBANY, Oct. 1 The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court today reversed a lower court decision and ruled unanimously that Richard L. Ottinger cannot use the Conservation party in his bid for the U.S. Senate.

MADRID, Oct. 1, (Reuters) France increased its lead over the favored United States from four to seven strokes today as scores soared in heavy winds on the second day of the world women's amateur team golf championship.

Martha Graham will not dance tonight when her company opens its season, nor does she intend to dance again before the public. The dancer and choreographer, who made her debut in Ted Shawn's "Xochitl" in Los Angeles in 1920, is retiring from the stage after half a century.

The Chesapeake Ohio-Baltimore Ohio Railroads, the first to issue results for the first nine months of 1970, showed a dip yesterday in third-quarter earnings but a slight rise in the nine-month period, compared with year-earlier levels.

The strength of Vice President Agnew's political campaign against the Democrats is that he has been as plain as a punch in the nose. At a time when people are confused and bored with the complexities of modern issues, he came on clear and strong against sin and blamed it all on the wicked Democrats.
W.H. Conzen, president of the Schering Corporation, announced yesterday that Donald R. Longman had been appointed executive vice president in a realignment of the company's corporate management.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 Not content with enlisting Vice President Agnew, White House advisers hostile to Senator Charles E. Goodell are working to swing President Nixon behind the New Yorker's Con servative opponent, James L. Buckley.

BOSTON, Oct. 1 First degree murder indictments against five persons were returned today by the Suffolk County grand jury as investigators continued to unravel the events surrounding the bank robbery and fatal shooting of a Boston policeman last week.
A procession of 600 chanting Arab-Americans marched slowly up Fifth Avenue yesterday in an outpouring of grief over the death of Gamal Abdel Nasser.

Without any confrontation, demonstration or even artful campaigning, women are securing for themselves another human right: the right to wear pants to work. The privilege is being granted by men in industry, government, and financial institutions who have long since given up the struggle to keep women from wearing pants at home.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 1 The four defendants in the Sharon Tate murder trial were barred from the courtroom this afternoon for singing and disrupting the trial.

The Federal Government announced yesterday a $500,000 grant for an experiment designed to move people faster through the Lincoln Tunnel during the morning rush hour using a special access lane reserved for buses.
Two girls one 3 years old and the other 4 months old, were found dead in their Bronx apartment last night, and a preliminary examination indicated they had been dead from one to two months.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 Figures compiled by Senator Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon showed today that Senator John G. Tower, chairman of the Republican Senate Campaign Committee, had allotted nearly twice as much in party funds to his fellow Texan, George Bush, as to any other, Senate candidate.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y. Oct. 1 Edwin Frederick Clark, who was credited with having conceived the plan of a one-way traffic movement in Normandy known to G.I.'s as the "Red Ball Highway," died today in Phelps Memorial Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived at 2 Highland Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 The National Aeronautics and Space Administration is considering sites other than Cape Kennedy, Fla., as headquarters for its manned flight activities as part of a post-Apollo change of direction that could include participation by other nations.

McGraw-Hill, the American publishing company, has acquired a major interest in Ediscience, a small French scientific text-book publishing house with headquarters in Paris, it was announced here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 The Nixon Administration is drafting a new set of proposals, possibly including a cease-fire, for submission to the North Vietnamese and the Vietcong at the peace talks in Paris, reliable sources said here today.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 1 Harold R. Fee, retired alumni executive secretary and director of placement at Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken, N.J., died here yesterday after a long illness. He was 72 years old and had moved here recently from Summit, N.J.

BOSTON, Oct. 1 The Ballgivers' Ball, a tribute to the organizations that annually stage benefit balls and other fund-raising events in the Greater Boston area, will be given in the Grand Ballroom of the Sheraton-Boston Hotel here next Thursday.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 1 Delegates to the convention of the United Steelworkers of America approved today, by a close vote, substantial salary increases for top officers and directors of the union.

History of a sort a most dubious sort was made at the New York Philharmonic concert last night, when Leonard Bernstein decided to use amplification for his performance of Stravinsky's "Les Noces." It was the first time in the history of the orchestra that electronic reinforcement was used for solo singers at a Philharmonic subscription concert.
BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 1 (UPI) Fifth-seeded Clark Graebner was upset today by Thomas Koch of Brazil in the third round at the Pacific Coast international open tennis tournament.

VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Oct. 1 (Canadian Press) Roy Emerson, 33-year-old Australian, defeated Nicki Pilic, 7-6, 1-6, 6-4, in a match, which lasted nearly two hours, in the $40,000 international tennis tournament last night.
CAIRO, Oct. 1 Gamal Abdel Nasser's people were in the street all night, and long before dawn broke over Cairo their cries could be heard.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 The Nixon Administration responded to complaints that it is insensitive to Negro education by announcing today a 30 per cent increase in Federal aid for predominantly black colleges.

RAMTHA, Jordan, Oct. 1 (Reuters) Guerrillas began handing in their guns and disarming their road mines today after Jordanian Army and Palestinian guerrilla officers signed an agreement to restore peace in northern Jordan.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Sept. 30 John Martocci, retired president of the Empire Color Lithographers, Inc., 200 Varick Street, New York City, died in Memorial Hospital here today of pneumonia while on a vacation. He was 84 years old and lived at 686 Harless Place, West Hempstead, L.I.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 Democratic and Republican leaders of the Senate expressed strong opposition today to the findings of the Federal Commission on Obscenity and Pornography, which were made public yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 1 (AP) Earl Weaver, who has guided the Baltimore Orioles to two consecutive American League Eastern Division titles, signed today to manage the club in 1971 at a salary reported in excess of $50,000.

More than comfortably well-off and in their 30's, Suzanne and Jay Wilcox (Collin Wilcox-Horne and Sam Groom) decide to have the baby that Suzanne can't have by calling on hip, young Tish Gray (Barbara Hershey), who so grooves on pregnancy that she will gladly bear Jay's child for a little cash, for nine months' social security and for the sheer joy of it all.
The Celanese Corporation announced yesterday that it planned to reduce its domestic work force of 25,600 by about 2,000 persons between now and June 1, 1971.

It's called The Men's Boutique, and Saks Fifth Avenue has done it up with ostrich walls, a beamed ceiling, indirect lighting and a Portuguese carpet, but neither the name nor the ambiance has discouraged female shoppers. The boutique, sectioned off from the men's department

Mrs. Helen Crosby West, president of the Women's City Club from 1961 to 1964 and for many years director of the Bureau of Social and Health Agencies at the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, died Wednesday at New York Hospital after a brief illness. She lived at 309 Avenue C and was 78 years old.

MONTREAL, Oct. 1 (Canadian Press) The council of the International Civil Aviation Organization narrowly approved today a United States proposal calling for a multilateral agreement to end air services to countries involved in hijacking planes for "international blackmail."

MADRID, Oct. 1 For three days, bare flagpoles have been standing next to Spanish flags along the route President Nixon is to follow into Madrid tomorrow. On the overpasses, bare billboards have been hanging beside giant portraits of Generalissimo Franco.
The Wholesale commodity price index fell to 108.8 yesterday from 109.3 last week.
In the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

BERLIN, Oct. 1 Informed sources said today that the Soviet Union, in the current fourpower talks on Berlin, was seeking to curtail the city's political ties with West Germany while recognizing its vital economic and financial links.
LONDON, Oct. 1 The Government faced an attack from the right today for having released Leila Khaled and flown her and six other Arab terrorists from Europe to Cairo.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 The Federal Trade Commission, giving the tobacco industry an opportunity to act voluntarily, has temporarily set aside a regulation requiring that tar and nicotine content be disclosed in cigarette advertisements.
Max Rolnik, a senior partner in the accounting firm of Lybrand, Ross Brothers Montgomery, died yesterday, after a long illness, in his home at 1503 East 22d Street in Brooklyn. He was 80 years old.
A dinner will be given on Oct. 13 in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza to benefit Vassar College's $50-million capital campaign begun in September of last year.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Oct. 1 Maj. Gen. Yakubu Gowon, the Nigerian head of state, said today that he did not expect to return the country to an elected civilian government before 1976.
More than 5,000 polling places will be open here to register voters during a threeday period beginning tomorrow and continuing on Monday and Tuesday.

RYE, N.Y., Oct. 1 When turning marks for a distance yacht race that will be renewed tomorrow by the American Yacht Club were being discussed the New Haven Light was accepted as one of them. The late Roger Sherman, in whose honor the race is held, was graduated from Yale in 1910 and Yale is in New Haven, so what better choice for such a mark than one off the Elm City.

Jerry Della Femina, author and talk-show celebrity, is also an ad man and president of Della Femina, Travisano Partners. And it was in that capacity yesterday that he was able to announce a new piece of business Sea Ski Corporation. The client says the billings are over $2million a year.
Miss Mary Collier Marston, an editorial researcher with Reader's Digest in New York, and Andrew Serge Gagarin, who attends the Columbia Graduate School of Business, plan to be married.

WILMINGTON, N.C., Oct. 1 (AP) Deane Beman shot an eight-under-par 63 to take the first-round lead by two strokes in the $60,000 Azalea open golf tournament today. Beman had eight birdies and 10 pars in his 30, 33 round to tie the Cape Fear Country Club course record.

MOUNT. HOPE, N.Y., Oct. 1 Mrs. Thomas J. Hory of Winged Foot carded an 84 at St. Andrew's Golf Club today for a two-stroke victory in the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association one-day tournament, Mrs. Maurice F. Hanson, Round Hill, won low net with 94-18 76.

Governor Rockefeller attempted yesterday to arrange a ceasefire in the battle between Vice President Agnew and Senator Charles E. Goodell, but the Senator planned to attempt to capitalize on the Agnew attack by making a major issue of what he called the Vice President's "hot rhetoric."

An interindustry task force working for the passage of legislation to create a Federally backed investor-insurance program received word yesterday that the Senate version of the bill might be voted on next week.
The Penn Central's new president, William H. Moore, looked over the railroad's vast port operations here yesterday and was not happy with them.
BOSTON, Oct. 1 (AP) Westinghouse Broadcasting Company's WBZ-TV said tonight that Bond had identified himself as "commander-in-chief, Revolutionary Action Force East."
When television announcer Ed McMahon called out, "And here's John" last night at the start of the ninth year of The Johnny Carson Show on N.B.C. there was a surprise walk-on Mayor John Lindsay.

Premier Chou En-lai turned in a low-key performance in his speech on the eve of yesterday's celebration of the 21st anniversary of the Chinese People's Republic. While he sounded no major new themes, he strengthened the impression that China's rulers now seek a return to more normal conditions after the ravages of the great proletarian cultural revolution.

By JACK ROSENTHAL Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 The President's Commission on Campus Unrest accused Mississippi policemen today of "unreasonable, unjustified overreaction" when they fired shotgun, machine gun, rifle and armor-piercing shells into a crowd of black students at Jackson State College last May 14.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 1 From Dakar on the Atlantic to Qatar on the Persian Gulf, in oases in the Sahara and in the Holy Land, Arabs in the millions marched in mourning today for a man they identified with their national aspirations.

Silver futures, which had dropped sharply on the Commodity Exchange here on Wednesday, bounced back yesterday. Most of the previous day's declines were recovered. Trading, however, was considerably slower with only 2,049 transactions, compared with 5,163 contracts moved the day before.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Oct. 1 Lawrence W. Zimmer, a retired associate professor of management at New York University School of Commerce, died today in Nassau Hospital, Mineola, after a long illness. He was 71 years old and lived at 74 Kenwood Road.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 The House passed yesterday a bill that would restrict the authority of the new Environmental Protection Agency to set radiation protection standards. Opposition to the bill was forming in the Senate today.
PARIS, Oct. 1 South Vietnam today denounced as "absurd, arrogant and simply unacceptable" the Vietcong peace plan, but an American spokesman refused to say that the initiative had been rejected.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange finished mixed yesterday as volume dropped because of the religious holiday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 The Senate Finance Committee tentatively agreed today to give 26.2 million Americans a 10 per cent increase in Social Security benefits, effective next January.

A Tennessee walking horse was originally a trotter who would not trot. Instead, he had an odd but attractive gait, half-way between a walk and a trot. Because he could move at a speed of six to eight miles an hour and give his rider a comfortable, rocking chair kind of ride, the Tennessee walking horse became a favorite of overseers and plantation owners in the South who had to ride great distances every day.

ANCRAMDALE, N.Y., Oct. 3--Miss Isabella Hayes Sommerhoff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kurt Sommerhoff, was married here today to William Allen Patty Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Patty of Lambertville, N.J. The ceremony was performed in St. John's Lutheran Church by the Rev. David Vogel.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Oct. 3 (UPI)--Larry Russell scored two touchdowns and passed for another today in Leading Wake Forest to its first football victory of the year, a 27-7 Atlantic Coast Conference decision over Virginia.

KEY WEST, Fla.--Fort Jefferson National Monument, which lies 68 miles west of Key West, is everything a tourist attraction shouldn't be. It has little drinking water, no hot dog stands, no overnight accommodations, only two rest rooms, little shade and no inexpensive way of getting there.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 3-- The announcement yesterday that Vice President Agnew will campaign in South Carolina Oct. 26 for the Republican candidate for Governor, Albert W. Watson, brings the Nixon Administration into a contest in which charges of "racism" are a central issue.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Oct. 3--Gary Hart folded his arms, rubbed his jaw and twirled a ruler. The scene was the engineering building at the University of California campus here, and the fidgety youth at the head of the class could have been a candidate for student body president.
Fordham University made a successful return to varsity football yesterday by defeating St. Peter's College, 14-0, before 6,613 at the Rose Hill campus.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 3-- Harvard University's football team, led by the slashing running of Tom Miller and Eric Crone, the No. 2 quarterback, rolled to a 39-9 victory over Rutgers today before 12,000 fans in Harvard Stadium. Windy conditions made passing difficult.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 3-- Manhattan College defeated Army and St. Johns in a double dual cross-country meet at West Point today to increase their victory total to 11 straight over a three-year period. Many critics beside myself have called Ellery Queen's Mystery Magazine the best of its kind today. Perhaps only those who remember Black Mask (which played a vital role in the formative years of that inherently American manifestation, the hardboiled detective story) will challenge the assertion that E.Q.M.M. is the best in history.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 3--Peaceful uses of nuclear power have outstripped bomb tests as a threat to world health through radiation, the United Nations has been told by a group of scientists that has followed such developments for 15 years.

ROOSEVELT, Ariz.--This is the story of a river--Arizona's Salt River--and a road known as the Apache Trail. The road follows the river over a circuitous shunpike route in the Arizona outback only a whoop and holler from Phoenix. It is a rough ride at points, but the scenery is often genuinely spectacular.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 3--The Southern Pacific Railroad has ended its daily "Sunset" passenger train service between New Orleans and Los Angeles. These trains will now run three times a week.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3--The White House has told the Pentagon to plan on seeking an increase in defense spending next year. The increase would be considerably smaller than the Pentagon had been counting on, but it would represent the first upturn in military spending in three budget years.

MOSCOW--Soviet-American relations, even in the best of times, have never been marked by any substantial degree of mutual trust. KEARNY, N.J., Oct. 3-- Homecoming proved perfect today for Kearny's new coach, Ralph Borgess.

HURST, Tex., Oct. 3--Mr. and Mrs. John M. Erskine have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Betsy Bevan Erskine, to Garrett Goodbody Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Goodbody of Madison, N.J.

Samuel Riker, a member of an old New York family who retired as an officer and a director of the New Jersey Zinc Company at the end of 1965, died Wednesday in Mackay, Queensland, Australia, after a brief illness. DETROIT, Oct. 5 (Reuters) The Parsons group of Michigan investors sold today a block of 34,000 shares of Commerce Bank of Cleveland out of a total 492,503 shares of the bank held by the group.
The New York Telephone Company obtained a court order yesterday barring squatters from several apartment buildings it has taken over on the Lower East Side for construction of a switching facility.

SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 5 A top South Korean military official said today that the United States and South Korea had reached substantial agree ment on a program to modernize Seoul's armed forces to offset the planned cutback of American forces in this country.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 5 The head of the United Nations relief operations for Palestinian refugees estimated today that his agency needed $3-million to make up for the heavy damage inflicted on the two refugee camps in Amman during recent fighting.

CONSTANCE, West Germany, Oct. 5 A leading Soviet scientist described today an experiment in which a Soviet spacecraft, two aircraft and an expedition on the ground worked jointly to test the feasibility of assessing the earth's surface from space.
ADEN, Southern Yemen, Oct. 5 The Tihama region of neighboring Yemen, rainless for more than five years and now desert, has been flooded by continuous rain over the last 30 days.

LONDON Three recent events have cast long shadows over the Middle East. These are, in chronological order, the forward movement of missile sites by Egyptians and Russians in the Canal Zone in violation of the standstill agreement, the Jordanian tank victory over the Syrian invaders, and the death of President Nasser.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 5 The Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Henry Millis Shires have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Millis Shires, to Ens. Walter Terry Maguire, U.S.C.G., son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Wyatt Maguire of Huntington, L.I.
Bernard Tabbat, 54 years old, has been succeeded as president of the Seagram Distillers Company by Arthur F. Murphy, 57, formerly president of the Calvert Distillers Company.
Remember the retort of the player who, after making a 90-yard touchdown run, was balled out by the coach for running the wrong play? "But coach, how was it for distance?"

Two city councilmen charged yesterday that the Lindsay administration was "drawing an illegal veil of secrecy over the operations of city government by refusing to permit the public full access to public information and documents."
Shipments of mobile homes edged up during August from the level a year earlier, the Mobile Homes Manufacturers Association reported yesterday.

The Fedders Corporation, a leading producer of air-conditioners, and makers of washers, dryers, stoves, refrigerators, and heating equipment, achieved record sales and earnings for the fourth consecutive year in the company's annual period ended Aug. 31, it was reported yesterday. Fourth-quarter results also set records.
BUFFALO, Oct. 5 (AP) A judge fined the Mobil Oil Corporation $10,000 today on the ground it had failed to halt the discharge of industrial waste into the Buffalo River.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 5 (AP) Attorney General John N. Mitchell said today that the suggestion by the President's Commission on Campus Unrest that Federal leadership could halt campus disturbances was not "viable."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 The prospects of extending the Middle Eastern cease-fire, due to expire on Nov. 5, were rated "extremely good" today by senior officials of the Nixon Administration.
Harcourt Brace Jovanovich has purchased the publishing house of Johann Ambrosius Barth in Munich. The purchase price was not revealed.

ROME In his role as global peacemaker, the Pope can be used by the Church's friends much more easily than by its enemies. Current Papal policy indicates that the Holy Father will receive the head or emissary of any nation desirous of visiting him, no matter what the religious belief or political persuasion of the national leader or his people.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 Partisan maneuvering broke out today between the Democratic and Republican leaders in Congress over whether to adjourn the 91st Congress before or after the November elections.

MONTREAL, Tuesday, Oct. 6 James Richard Cross, the senior British consular officer in Quebec Province, was abducted at gunpoint from his home yesterday by French Canadian separatists.
The American Stock Exchange continued to move along the comeback trail yesterday as most stocks advanced in brisk trading.

There may have been more Italians at Ohrbach's yesterday than on the Via Veneto. What with the dignitaries, the artisans, the dancers and the designers, anyone with a little imagination could close his eyes and picture himself a long way from 34th Street.

KENNETT SQUARE, Pa., Oct. 5 Miss Elise du Pont Donaldson and Thomas James Bulger 4th plan to be married in December.

A growing number of colleges and universities around the country are issuing new guidelines on campus dissent that generally take a firmer stand against disturbances by students, nonstudents and faculty than in previous years.

The current assault on campus violence may do more harm to student moderates than to bomb-throwing radicals. The aims of those spearheading the campaigns are hard to fault: they want to stop the appalling arson and disruptions of learning.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 5 (Reuters) The United States has approached Thailand for approval to transfer American B-52 bomber's from Okinawa to a United States-built air base here, Premier Thanom Kittikachorn said today.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 5 (AP) The Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, president of the University of Notre Dame more than 18 years, told his faculty today that American universities "face an unprecedented crisis of public confidence."

Cliff Keuter presents the ordinary under an extraordinary aspect. For him sex is not merely sensual, it is surreal; social contracts are meant to be fractured in a variety of interesting ways and the commonplace is fraught with complications. NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 5 Charles R. Stryker, retired research instrument designer in the medical and scientific field, died Saturday evening at Norwalk Hospital after a short illness. His age was 79 and he lived at 270 Newtown Avenue.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Oct. 5 Winifred Bartlett Clark, a poet, author and landscape painter, died of a heart ailment Sept. 18 in a hospital here. She was 79 years old and lived on Fishers Island, N.Y., and in Greenwich, Conn.
PONTIAC, Mich., Oct. 5 Four white youths were shot and wounded today, one seriously, during a dispute with a group of about 20 Negro youths outside Pontiac Central High School, the police said.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 5 The Cambodian Parliament voted unanimously today to proclaim the nation a republic on Friday.

The use of large teams of scientists from different disciplines, brought together under Federal funding, is emerging as a new approach to basic scientific research on matters of pressing national concern.
Top-ranked Ohio State widened its lead over Texas in the weekly Associated Press college football poll made public yesterday.
"This market looks incredibly strong," a Wall Street broker declared at noon yesterday. "I'd say it is essentially a continuation of Friday's rally."
WALLOPS ISLAND, Va. Oct. 5 (UPI) A four-stage Javelin rocket released an artificial cloud of Barium today that was visible along much of the Eastern Seaboard.

The five-day revolt of city prisoners demanding judicial and penal reforms ended early today where it began at the Queens House of Detention in Long Island City with the negotiated surrender of the last 41 inmates barricaded on the top floor.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 5 Three student leaders were released from prison today after a protest fast by them and by fellow students and sympathetic university professors.

RICHMOND, Oct. 5 (AP) Reversing a Federal district court, the United States Court of Appeals for The Fourth Circuit today directed the granting of a preliminary injunction requiring desegregation of a golf course in Durham, N.C.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 20 At a conservative estimate, 70,000 people remain imprisoned in Indonesia on suspicion of having been connected with the abortive Communist coup d'etat five years ago this month. Fewer than 200 have been tried.
Interest rates rose yesterday on corporate bonds and they declined on tax-exempt bonds as investment bankers tried to assess the strength of demand for this week's new issues.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 5 (AP) Communist troops reportedly tried for 11 hours to overrun a Cambodian military base 57 miles southwest of here but were driven off early today in heavy fighting.
J. Paul Lyet has been elected executive vice president and a director of the Sperry Rand Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) Nine private schools in Mississippi have given public notice that they will admit Negroes, the Internal Revenue Service said today.

PEKING, Oct. 6. (Agence France-Presse) Premier Maurice Couve de Murville of France flew into Peking today for a private two-week visit.
The Greyhound Corporation, which owns 86 per cent of the common stock of Armour Co., yesterday made a proposal to minority shareholders of the meat packing concern to acquire their shares.

A sudden flurry of activity raises hope that the 91st Congress may at last acquit itself well in the matter of creating new parkland for the American people. Besides the Apostle Islands Lakeshore bill, already signed into law by President Nixon, the House has already approved four other noteworthy projects. Since it is usually the Senate that takes the lead in park legislation, prospects are bright that all four will become realities this year.
Louis J. Greenburg, a lawyer, died yesterday of hepatitis in the New York University Medical Center. He was 76 years old and lived at 838 West End Avenue.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 6 The union leadership of reporters and editors on Chile's largest newspaper, El Mercurio, has been overthrown in a series of events arising from the country's tense presidential politics.

Alfred E. Penman, former vice chairman of the Penn Central Company and its railroad subsidiary, the Penn Central Transportation Company, has gotten himself a job running trains again. Effective Dec. 1, he will be president of the Western Pacific Railroad.

The offices of the Palestine Liberation Organization were extensively damaged by a bomb blast last night. Several other offices on the third floor of the Architects Building at 101 Park Avenue, near 40th Street, were also damaged. No one was hurt.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 6 The struggle between Brazilian officials and left-wing priests brought harsh words today over the controversial Archbishop of Recife and Olinda, the Most Rev. Helder Camara.

James R. Greenwood, a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration said last night that the airliner that crashed in the Rocky Mountains, killing 30 persons on a Wichita State football trip, may have been 4,000 pounds overweight on take-off.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 Senator John G. Tower, chairman of the Republican Senatorial Campaign Committee, evidently satisfied the Republican Policy Committee today that he had disbursed campaign funds fairly.

Commerce. President Nixon established the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration in the Commerce Department and ordered the transfer of certain programs and activities to the Commerce Department.

Salvatore (Sally Burns) Granello, reputedly a Mafia figure, was found in the trunk of an automoble, shot to death, on the Lower East Side, the police reported last night.

Sir John Gielgud and Sir Ralph Richardson are returning to Broadway as the costars of "Home," the successful London drama by David Storey.
Army, Navy and the Air Fore have no intention of downgrading their football schedules.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 6 The Financial Analysts Federation convention began its second day here in a buoyant mood. As counterpoint, the broad tape never far from sight beat a pleasant tattoo telling of rising stock prices and heavy trading activity.

Crossroads country music was offered Monday night at the Washington Square Church, 135 West 4th Street, by Jeff Guthrie, a fiddler and singer. He is the uncle of Woody Guthrie and granduncle of Arlo Guthrie. Buster Jackson, a pianist, appeared with Mr. Guthrie.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 6 (AP)--An autopsy on a Seton Hall University pre-law student who burned himself to death has shown that he had a massive brain tumor.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 Mayor Lindsay of New York City told a House subcommittee today that the Federal Government, while conducting a number of studies on the fuel shortage, had no strategy for dealing with the problem on a fixed timetable.

Baseball Commissioner Bowie Kuhn will meet with the presidents of the two major leagues and the lawyer for the umpires today in an effort to forestall another walkout by major league umpires before Saturday's World Series opener.

ZOME, Togo Togo, a former French colony that has seen much more political unrest than so small a splinter of land would seem to deserve or justify, experienced another attempted coup d'etat a few weeks ago in which one man was killed and more than a dozen were arrested.

Aristotle Souval, a lawyer who specialized in international maritime law, died Monday, apparently of a heart attack, in his home at 60 East Eighth Street. He was 67 years old.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) A Spartan missile intercepted a ballistic missile nose cone high over the Pacific in the second successful test of the controversial Safeguard antiballistic missile system, the Pentagon announced today.
The Aluminum Company of America said yesterday in Pittsburgh that it would temporarily close one production unit in Tennessee and would slow the construction of a second unit at the same location.
A 37-year-old Navy veteran is going to State Supreme Court this morning in hopes of winning a ruling that will broaden the rights of the transsexual.

The Metropolitan Transit Authority's tentative plans to build a Second Avenue subway with two tracks and with three stops between 57th and 125th Streets was condemned by East Side residents, community leaders and public officials at a public hearing yesterday.

TOKYO, Oct. 6 The Japanese Government appears to be taking the first gingerly steps toward reviving textile negotiations with the United States.
Mayor Lindsay and the man he might or might not endorse for Governor, Arthur J. Goldberg, shared a platform last night for the first time this political campaign season.
A receiver was appointed yesterday in the bankruptcy of Computer Applications, Inc. Federal Referee Asa S. Herzog appointed David P. Alterbaum of New York.
BERLIN, Oct. 6 East Germany closed the autobahn checkpoint of Marienborn at the West German border for 15 minutes today, hampering traffic to and from West Berlin.
DETROIT, Oct. 6 The American Motors Corporation raised its 1971 model car prices approximately $200 a car in line with similar increases by other manufacturers.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 6 (AP)--The Ohio National Guard has asked the Army for nonlethal weapons for use in future disorders but will continue to carry high-powered rifles and to load them on command of a superior officer, Adjutant General Sylvester T. Del Corso said today.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 6 Charles M. Manson and three women co-defendants refused today to promise not to disrupt the court, and the judge ordered them kept out of the courtroom.

Two young filmmakers have been awarded the first $30,000 Schlitz Fellowships, the largest ever given for the study of moviemaking arts and crafts. The eighth New York Film Festival proved disappointing at the box office, as predicted at the end of the event last week. Figures released yesterday by Martin E. Segal, president of the Film Society of Lincoln Center, sponsors of the festival, showed a total gross of $104,063 against $124,481 last year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6--Congressional leaders of both parties concluded today that they could not complete the business of the 1970 session in the next three weeks and agreed to take a campaign recess.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP)--The Interstate Commerce Commission asked Congress today for broad authority over conglomerate and holding company activities such as those involved in the bankruptcy proceedings of the Penn Central Railroad.

Two of New York's largest banking companies reported substantial gains in profits yesterday for both the third quarter and the first nine months of 1970, as well as an improved rate of return on their stockholders' investment.

Luz Morales, a darkly winsome soprano who appeared Monday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, chose a program that testified to her excellent taste. Often during the recital she showed a good grasp of the content of the songs, and the sensitivity to approach them respectfully.

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) will move three of its major divisions to Houston, the company confirmed yesterday.

Elements of the new nostalgia and contemporary brutalism were seen last night at Choreoconcerts' first program at the season at the New School. The evening showed four new works, all commissioned by the sponsoring organization.

BUFFALO, Oct. 6 Declaring that "outside intervention would be prejudicial to the state Republican ticket," Governor Rockefeller said today that he had asked the White House to "please let us handle our own political problems."

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., Oct. 6 A phenomenal growth in population, new industry and residential construction under way in Burlington County are creating massive problems, particularly in the area of taxation. Finding new sources of revenue to sustain such prosperity is the major challenge...

HYATTSVILLE, Md., Oct. 6 Dr. and Mrs. Robert Davenport have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Deborah Ann Davenport, to David Stanton Pollock, son of Mrs. David G. Dickson and stepson of Mr. Dickson, of Malvern. Pa.
SHAWNEE, Okla., Oct. 6 (AP) The death toll rose to four and the damage estimate to $33-million today as a result of yesterday's tornado here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) Consumer installment credit rose $232-million in August, the smallest rise since the $198million increase in March, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 Secretary of the Treasury David M. Kennedy said today that, even if the Nixon Administration should discover it needs more revenue in the coming fiscal year, he did not think it would propose postponement of the reductions in the individual income tax that are scheduled to go into effect then.
