PITTSBURGH, Oct. 6 Vice President Agnew renewed his frontal attack on Senator Charles E. Goodell, Republican of New York, here tonight while backing gingerly away from a potential confrontation with one of Mr. Goodell's defenders, Hugh Scott of Pennsylvania, the Senate minority leader.

KUCHING, Malaysia, Oct. 3 Communist terrorists have reportedly revived their dormant insurgency in the Malaysian state of Sarawak in northwestern Boreno, giving great concern to federal and state authorities and causing nervousness among the population of about a million.

The New York Times yesterday became the first newspaper to receive the World Wildlife Fund's Certificate of Merit. The Times was cited by the fund "for taking the national lead in editorially supporting the conservation of endangered species."

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Oct. 6 Billy Farrell played The Creek course for the first time in practice yesterday. Today the 36-year-old son of Johnny Farrell, the former United States Open champion, led the first round of the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association championship with a record six-under-par 64.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 The Federal Aviation Administration was accused today of dangling high-paying jobs in air traffic control before thousands of black men it never intended to hire.

FORT HOOD, Tex., Oct. 6 Last-minute legal technicalities were apparently cleared away today in the pending court-martial of S. Sgt. David Mitchell, who is charged with participating in the alleged massacre of Vietnamese civilians in the village of Sonmy more than two years ago.
Ask Lee White if he minded sitting on the bench for two years while Matt Snell played fullback most of the time for the New York Jets and his honest answer is no.
A $1-billion avalanche of financing hit the money and capital markets yesterday, and yet it failed to crush the widespread current belief that interest rates were headed downward.

Jorge Luis Borges has observed that "one never feels anything in a Russian novel to be true because the characters are always explaining themselves to each other." Perhaps. But this morning we have two first novels by young writers of definite promise. Both debuts are, of course, flawed, clumsy and sentimental; however, if Mr. Dostoyevsky and Mr. Nabokov keep at it, there may be a future for Russian fiction.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 The House of Representatives voted today to cut off the United States contribution to the International Labor Organization for the first half of 1971. The action virtually assured the first refusal of the United States to pay a financial obligation to an international body.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 6 (AP) Two persons drowned, about 200 homes were destroyed and more than 4,000 persons were evacuated as flooding occurred Over most of Puerto Rico today after three days of torrential rains.
KANSAS CtTY, Oct. 6 (AP) Len Dawson, the Kansas City Chiefs star quarterback, was sidelined again today with another knee injury.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6--The Nixon Administration asked the Supreme Court today to rule that communities might base their school desegregation plans on the "neighborhood school" concept even if some Negro children remained in all-black schools.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 A House-Senate conference committee reached agreement today on a comprehensive bill to combat massive tax evasion, stock fraud and other crimes by the prosperous under the cover of secret Swiss bank accounts, Congressional sources said.
Modern antibiotics and advanced medical practice have caused a slackening in basic personal hygiene that contributes to the continued spread of disease, a medical seminar was told yesterday.
Edith Gregor Halpert, a noted art dealer and collector, died yesterday at New York Hospital after a long illness. She was 70 years old and lived at 136 East 56th Street.

A record registration for New York City in a gubernatorial election year was forecast last night by Maurice J. O'Rourke, president of the Board of Elections, on the basis of the 72,520 names added to the voter rolls in the first two days of local registration.

Members of the Newspaper Guild unit at The New York Post went on strike yesterday in a bid for benefits and contract improvements beyond a three-year, 41.69 per cent wage package offered by the newspaper.

DUBLIN, Oct. 6 (UPI) Vincent O'Brien, trainer of Nijinsky, who lost for the first time in his career at Longchamp on Sunday, said it would be another week before a decision is taken on whether he runs again.
The unbeaten Detroit Lions, on a track toward the Super Bowl, are proof that a chaotic pro football operation can be turned round and it doesn't take forever. Attention, Giant loyalists.

In November 1968 the American air war against North Vietnam came to a halt. But the squadrons that had pounded the Communists almost daily for 45 months remained. They were shifted to ground support missions in South Vietnam and Laos, attacks on the Ho Chi Minh Trail and, more recently, to targets in Cambodia. The headlines gradually faded, but the air war did not.
The Alcoa Foundation has given the Museum of Modern Art $100,000 to assemble and mount its major winter exhibition, "Four Americans in Paris: The Collections of Gertrude Stein and Her Family."

A retired longshoreman and a supervisor for the Welfare Department were added yesterday to the jury that will hear the case of 13 Black Panthers accused of plotting to bomb public places. The jurors were the ninth and 10th selected.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 The Senate passed today a bill reforming long-time Congressional procedures but leaving untouched the seniority system that younger members had sought to sweep away.
The Egyptian leadership has taken an encouraging first step toward assuring stability and continuity in Cairo by choosing Acting President Anwar Sadat to succeed Gamal Abdel Nasser as President.

HARTFORD, Oct. 6 In special session that lasted 24 minutes, the Connecticut General Assembly today passed without debate a bill enabling unemployed workers to receive Federal funds for extended compensation payments.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 6 President Alfredo Ovando Candia resigned today, bowing to demands by Bolivian Army officers. His action touched off a struggle for power between leftist and rightist military forces in which leftists' troops and planes attacked rightist strongpoints.
President Nixon's policy speech to the nation on Vietnam tonight at 9 o'clock will be carried live by the television and radio outlets of the three major networks.

The Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company, the nation's largest food chain, made minor gains in sales but managed to set records for the three and six months ended Aug. 31, according to the company's semiannual report issued yesterterday. Earnings were up 8.2 per cent and four per cent, respectively, marking the sixth consecutive quarterly increase in profits.

A survey of television commercials here and in three Southern cities leads to the conclusion that blacks are to a great extent excluded from appearances in the television advertising of many of the country's largest industries. Where blacks have been shown, their exposures has been "limited to momentary flashes."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) Customs officials at Dulles International Airport tonight seized cocaine that they estimated had a potential maximum value of $10-million and arrested two Colombian citizens.

"Possible acquisition" by the New York Times Company of certain properties of Cowles Communications, Inc., his been discussed by the two enterprises.

Station WNET took its mobile coverage unit out of the garage last night for a fascinating live report of the Guardians Association, the city's largest group of black police officers, at its clubhouse, 504 Marian Street, Brooklyn.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 6 An upstate New York detective sergeant was honored as Policeman of the Year here today for a one-man fight against drug and narcotics addiction that began to pay off only when he admittedly began taking the law into his own hands.

The New York Stock Exchange disclosed plans yesterday to make important changes in the net capital requirements of its member firms, apparently in response to shortcomings in capital rules that became evident in the recent stock market decline.
PARIS, Oct. 6 (AP) A spokesman for the Vietcong delegation to the peace talks said today that he hoped President Nixon would announce acceptance of the Vietcong terms when he made his broadcast.

MONTREAL, Oct. 6--Some 50 Canadian and British businessmen were to gather for cocktails this evening in the high-ceilinged first floor at 1297 Redpath Crescent, a stately mansion of thick stone walls that overlooks downtown Montreal from the side of Mount Royal.
CHARLOTTE, N.C. When Mrs. Jane Love found out that her young son would have to be bused this year to a school 12 miles from their neighborhood, she cried.

HACKENSACK, N.J., A Republican incumbent who supports President Nixon's policies on Vietnam is defending his House seat against a vigorous antiwar Democrat in New Jersey's suburban Seventh Congressional District. But neither candidate is making the war the major theme of the campaign.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 Lawenforcement officers and officials opened Senate hearings today on urban guerrilla warfare by endorsing several tough bills aimed at curbing snipers, bombers and attacks on policemen.

CAIRO, Oct. 6 Foreign Minister Mahmoud Riad declared tonight that the United Arab Republic, despite the loss of the leadership of President Gamal Abdel Nasser, would never remove a "single antiaircraft missile" from the Suez Canal military standstill zone and would refuse even to discuss the subject.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 President Nixon announced today that he would deliver "a major statement" about Vietnam on television tomorrow night and that a new American proposal would be presented at the Paris peace talks Thursday morning.

WICHITA, Kan., Oct. 6 (AP)--A Wichita State University spokesman said today no decision had been made on whether the final six games of the football season would be played. The scheduled game with Southern Illinois this Saturday was canceled.

They were lined up across from St. Patrick's Cathedral a few minutes after the store opened, its nine selling floors filled to capacity, its elevators jammed beyond endurance. Many of the shoppers used the back stairs.
Silver futures, which had dropped sharply on Monday bounded back even more steeply yesterday in active trading on the New York Commodity Exchange on no particularly bullish news.

The Department of Correction displayed yesterday an arsenal of several hundred spears, clubs, molotov cocktails and booby traps that rebellious inmates had fashioned during a four-day rampage that made the Queens Branch House of Detention uninhabitable.

The affluent, shepherded by Josephine Hughes of Bergdorf Goodman, had a guided tour through the fashion pasture yesterday. Miss Hughes, whose talents as a saleswoman are said to be persuasive enough to sell a Corvair to Ralph Nader, does this sort of thing semiannually, always in the name of charity.

Suzanne Farrell and Paul Mejia, who resigned from the New York City Ballet in May, 1969, have joined Maurice Bejart's Ballet of the 20th Century. They will perform wide the Belgian company when it makes its American debut at Brooklyn Academy of Music, from Jan. 25 to Feb. 7.

The American Electric Power Company, Inc., the giant holding company that operates mainly in Ohio, West Virginia and Indiana, raised $96.14-million through the auction yesterday of 4 million shares of common stock, one of the largest such offerings on record.

The New York City Central Labor Council voted yesterday to establish addict-referral centers in local union offices and to push for union contracts that include healthinsurance coverage for union members who need medical assistance to break the drug habit.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 7 Jesse M. Unruh, the ostentatiously shirt-sleeved candidate for Governor of California, leaned over the rostrum the other day at San Fernando Valley State College, pointed a finger at a red-faced young student, and shouted: "You don't know what you're talking about and you're too narrow-minded to listen to anybody else!"
NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 7 The professional organization of Roman Catholic canon lawyers charged today that current church practices discriminated against the "dignity and inalienable rights" of women.

Arthur J. McCusker, who recently retired as a vice president and investment research officer of Hayden Stone, Inc., stockbrokers, now CBWL-Hayden Stone, Inc., died Tuesday in Maimonides Hospital, after a long illness. He was 69 years old and lived at 9437 Shore Road, Brooklyn.

WEST CORNWALL, Conn., Oct. 7 Dr. Russell Potter, director of the former Institute of Arts and Sciences of Columbia University, died yesterday in a nursing home in Torrington. He was 73 years old and lived on Town Street here.

Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that his administration was considering "payless paydays," pay cuts and some layoffs last imposed on city employes by Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia during the Depression before the advent of municipal unions to offset anticipated revenue losses caused by the recession.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Oct. 7 (AP) Nearly 400 firemen went on strike in a pay dispute today in this capital city of 250,000 population, throwing up picket lines that also shut down bus service when union drivers refused to cross the lines.

Harlem's Theresa Hotel, which declined during recent years from its onetime prominence, stands today reincarnated as a modern, well equipped office building catering mostly to a black, community-oriented clientele.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Oct. 7 Former Gov. Philip H. Hoff, Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, acknowledged publicly today that he once had a drinking problem but said he had overcome it.
HONG KONG Oct. 7 (UPI) Prince Norodam Sihanouk, leading a Cambodian government in exile in Communist China, is deeply depressed, according to reports from Peking.

The newly formed women's contract professional tennis group added two players yesterday and announced a series of tournaments separate from men's and apart from the United States Lawn Tennis Association.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 The head of the Federal antipoverty agency vigorously defended today a proposed reorganization that critics say would badly damage the national program of legal services for the poor.

MOSCOW, Oct. 7 A prominent Leningrad mathematician who tried to explain to a Communist party official why scientists were agitating for more political freedom was reportedly told bluntly that Soviet authorities never would allow anyone to write "anything that comes into this head."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) The Federal Aviation Administration said today that the airliner that crashed Friday in the Colorado Rockies, killing 13 members of the Wichita State University football team, had received no valid flying certificate when taken out of storage.

BOSTON, Oct. 7 A Portuguese immigrant who once swept the floors of a textile mill for 62 cents a day was installed amid solemn ceremony today as the spiritual shepherd of Boston's 1.9 million Roman Catholics, most of whom are Irish.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 The Council on Environmental Quality recommended today a national policy to limit the dumping of waste into the oceans and the Great Lakes.

Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Y. Rogers of New York and Prouts Neck, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Porteous Rogers, to Daniel Abdulla Zilkha, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abdulla K. Zilkha of Paris.
HARTFORD, Oct. 7 (UPI) Warren M. Brown of West Hartford, a key witness in the Waterbury conspiracy trial of the late 1930's, died yesterday at Hartford Hospital. He was 82 years old.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 7 A leftist general, Juan Jos Torres, took power today as President of Bolivia with a show of force that toppled his rightist military opponents.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 The United States and Israel were preparing to take coordinated military action in the recent Jordanian crisis, according to American and Israeli sources.

MONTREAL, Oct. 7 The Quebec Separatists who kidnapped James R. Cross, senior British trade commissioner in Quebec, extended today for 24 hours, until noon Thursday, the deadline for meeting their ransom demands for his release.

One of New York's bestknown bridge institutions came of age this year. President Nixon's appointment of Dr. Elburt F. WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 President Nixon was asked today to disclose the name of the nation's chief censor, a private citizen now on standby duty who would assume office in a national emergency.

Skyrocketing relief rolls for the first two months of the city's new fiscal year have tripled the increase forecast in Mayor Lindsay's budget and could add as much as $60-million in new costs if the new rate keeps on.

A poised and prosperous three-member Long Island family that has yet to buy its first New York State lottery ticket was proclaimed the winner yesterday of the $1million first prize in the state's special summer lottery.

Starting Tuesday, visitors will be asked to pay an admission fee to the Metropolitan Museum of Art. WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 The Federal Trade Commission has drafted regulations designed to end what it said was the automobile industry practice of listing prices for new cars that do not accurately reflect the cost to the consumer.

DETROIT, Oct. 9 The Ford Motor Company today raised prices on its 1971 cars again, the second increase in a month. Ford said that by averaging the price increases and reductions it also announced today, the average rise would be "only $14, or three-tenths of 1 per cent per vehicle."

Wrightsman, the oil industrialist's wife, prowled restlessly through the rack of clothes and Mrs. Stephane Groueff, whose husband is an executive of Paris Match, patiently waited on a sofa, Thea Porter spoke quietly in her hotel rooms of the passion for fancy dress that has made her a bright star in the London fashion world in the last three years.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 11 Puerto Ricans gathered here from all over New Jersey this weekend for a serious two-day discussion of their culture, problems and ways to political power, with the hope of forging a statewide Puerto Rican organization.
LONDON Oct. 11 Natalya Makarova, the Russian ballerina who defected here last month, agreed tonight to join the American Ballet Theater.

Canon Walter D. Dennis Jr. of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine urged in a sermon yesterday that the smoking of marijuana be legalized and that the thousands of people now in jail for using it be granted immediate amnesty.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 11 (UPI) Tony Conigliaro, the Boston Red Sox outfielder who made a dramatic comeback two seasons ago, was traded tonight with Jerry Moses, a catcher, and Ray Jarvis, a pitcher, to the California Angels for Jarvis Tatum, an outfielder; Ken Tatum, a pitcher, and Doug Griffin, a minor league infielder.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 The Nixon Administration said today that the United States may have to embark on a "tremendous increase" in defense spending unless accords are reached with the Soviet Union in negotiations on the limitation of strategic arms and in other areas.

PEKING, Oct. 11 Canadian Wheat Board officials are here negotiating a new grain sale to China. Negotiations could be tough. The talks come near the expiration of the old agreement, a one-year contract signed here in September, 1969.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 11 ? About 40 revolutionary leftists withdrew peacefully last night from the central administration building of the University of Chile, where they had sought refuge from the police last Friday.
LAS VEGAS, Nev. Oct. 11 (AP) Tommy Bolt won his third straight National Seniors open golf tournament today with a four-under-par 66 for a total of 267.
HOUSTON, Oct. 11 The 3.5-million-member Episcopal Church opened its 63d triennial general convention here to night confronted with controversial issues ranging from finances to Protestant unity.

LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, Monday, Oct. 12 (AP) Troops and rioters skirmished in the Roman Catholic district of Londonderry through most of the night. More than 100 persons surrounded three policemen in a post near the district and set fire to a police car before soldiers moved in.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Oct. 11 The American Bankers Association is considering a new program to pump additional capital into black-owned banks across the country.

Mary Anthony, whose work has not been performed here in several years, offered a wide range in choreography Saturday night at the Fashion Institute of Technology, where the Mary Anthony Dance Theater presented five of her works as well as Lester Horton's "To Jose Clemente Orozco."

In the recent 19th chess Olympiad in Siegen, Germany, the United States' two highest rated players, Bobby Fischer and Sammy Reshevsky, were together for the first time on an all-American team. These two grandmasters, with economy of force and time, set back two Japanese masters, Nyasaka and Matumoto, during the United States-Japan match.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 11 The United Nations will celebrate its 25th anniversary here during the next two weeks and New York City is going to be host to the party with its fingers crossed.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11 (AP) Alan Page, Minnesota's 255pound defensive terror, lumbered 65 yards with a recovered fumble and Gary Cuozzo's pinpoint passing further stunned the Chicago Bears as the Vikings recorded a 24-0 victory to day.

ST. JAMES, L.I., Oct. 11 The Mill Pond Farm's Rafiki swept the division to score 20 points and win the regular working hunter championship at the Glen Head horse show today. The event was held at the Hollandia Farms here.

TRAVERSE CITY, Mich., Oct. 11 John Spencer, a doctor who moved to this resort community to enjoy its natural beauty, recalled how often during a hike he would get so infuriated at the sight of an abandoned car that it would take several minutes for him to regain his temper.
LONDON, Oct. 11 The new Egyptian coalition, evidently unsure of itself and lacking wide support, is embarked on a diplomatic offensive on the Israeli issue to try to consolidate its power.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 11--The Baltimore Orioles took a two-game lead in the World Series today. They scored five runs in the fifth inning and defeated the Cincinnati Reds, 6-5.

DENVER, Oct. 11 (AP) Arthur Ashe picked apart Charlie Pasarell with well-placed drives and captured the final of the Denver invitation tennis tournament today, 6-2, 5-6, 6-3. The tiebreaker was used at 5-5.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 11 Sagging demand is starting to show up in steel production and steel prices

For two hours yesterday afternoon John F. Kennedy Airport was picketed from Jamaica Bay.

BOSTON, Oct. 11(AP) Don Marcotte scored a pair of goals within 64 seconds with his team a man short in the third period tonight as the Boston Bruins opened defense of their National Hockey League Stanley Cup championship with a 7-3 victory over the Detroit Red Wings.
BOSTON, Oct. 11 (AP) Derek Sanderson, the fiery center who had been holding out for a reported $40,000, signed his 1970-71 National Hockey League contract today with the Boston Bruins.

ZELTWEG, Austria, Oct. 11 (Reuters) Porsche scored its ninth victory in the 1970 world sports car championship today when Jo Siffert of Switzerland and Brian Redman of Britain won the Austrian 625-mile event, 10th and final race in the series.

CAIRO, Oct. 11 (Reuters) Acting President Anwar Sadat said today that the United Arab Republic was facing the possibility of an "electronic" war with Israel and would be ready for it.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Oct. 12 (UPI) John W. Gardner said today that Americans were responding "with extraordinary" enthusiasms to his newly formed citizens' lobby called Common Cause.

BERLIN, Oct. 11 Postwar German theater is famous for its organization and for its lack of new plays, and the three-week autumn festival here confirms both. WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) Representative Byron G. Rogers of Colorado, who was 30 votes shy of renomination in a Democratic primary, lost today his bid to have a House administration elections subcommittee overturn the results.

Sam Levene, whose acting career goes back more than 40 years, will make his off Broadway debut next month in a new drama with music and dance called "A Dream Out of Time" by Irv Bauer.

Carl Tuttle of Rectortown, Va., called Hubert, "personality plus fantastic in head."

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 (AP) Bob Love and Chet Walker scored 28 points each to pace the Chicago Bulls to a 111-96 victory over the San Diego Rockets tonight in a National Basketball Association opener.

The Bank America Corporation, parent of San Francisco's Bank of America, reported yesterday that operating profits rose by 6.5 per cent in the third quarter to $43.88-million, or $1.28 a common share. This compares with $41.18-million, or $1.20 in the comparable 1969 period.

Diamonds are among N.W. Ayer's best friends. (And vice versa.)

Three leading paper producers the International Paper Company, the St. Regis Paper Company and the Kimberly-Clark Corporation yesterday reported a sharp decline in third-quarter and ninemonth earnings. The slumping economy was blamed.
A leading petroleum industrialist said here last night that "our idea or efficiency lies fairly close to the heart" of the nation's growing environmental troubles.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 13 (UPI) Ten more California sea lions struggled onto beaches today apparently suffering from a mysterious malady that has killed at least 25 of them in a month.
LONDON, Oct.13 The Council of Europe has cleared the way for a judicial hearing of a complaint that Britain's treatment of East African Asians violates the European Convention of Human Rights.
The battle between Rockefeller and Goldberg supporters in organized labor brought a sharp exchange yesterday between two labor leaders on opposite sides in the gubernatorial contest.
The Paper Handlers Union reached tentative agreement yesterday with the city's four major daily newspapers on a new three-year contract covering about 350 employes.

Driving along the Grand Central Parkway between campaign stops yesterday, Representative Richard L. Ottinger said he felt that he had the edge over his opponents in the race for the United States Senate. But, he added, Buckley wins if Agnew is successful and Goodell splits the Democratic vote."

The cause of civilized political discourse has gotten a small push forward from Arthur J. Goldberg, the Democratic-Liberal candidate for Governor. His swift removal of two staff aides who heckled Governor Rockefeller on the Lower East Side was a welcome repudiation of tactics that prevent campaigners or anyone else from getting their message to the public.

The owners of the National Football League assemble here today for an unusual midseason meeting. Pressing business includes the completion of arrangements for the All-Star game Jan. 24 in Los Angeles, next year's preseason schedule and the possibility of a change in ownership for the New Orleans Saints.

MOSCOW, Oct. 13 President Pompidou and President Nikolai V. Podgorny today signed a French-Soviet agreement to "extend and deepen" political contacts and to hold consultations during periods of international tension.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 13 Despite a diplomatic gain in achieving recognition by Canada, Communist China is likely to fall short of United Nations membership this year by just about the same vote as last year, according to opinions expressed by diplomats here today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (Reuters) Total manufacturing and trade inventories grew by $640million in August, to $169.27billion, a drop from the $1.26billion increase in July, the Commerce Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) Anti-war demonstrations are being planned for 31 cities three days before the Nov. 3 general elections, much to the dismay of some dovish candidates who fear adverse reactions at the polls.
The Greater New York Savings Bank and the Flatbush Savings Bank were given authorization to combine yesterday by William T. Dentzer Jr., New York State's Superintendent of Banks since last spring.

The city's Director of Labor Relations said yesterday that the city would be able to give no more than cost-of-living increases and fringe benefits to the more than 94,000 employes whose contracts expire Dec. 31. Among the employes are policemen, firemen, sanitation workers, correction officers and social service case workers.

In the men's wear business these days, dress shirts are selling well, casual slacks are one of the hottest categories in the market and consumers are reported to be purchasing accessories in large numbers.

MOSCOW, Oct. 13 The Soviet Union today issued its strongest denial to date that it was building a submarine base at Cienfuegos.
Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that the city's ability to support cultural programs was in trouble, and urged cautious decentralization to bring the arts to more people at less cost.

A New York policeman testified yesterday that he had told the departmet's top uniformed corruption investigator about a secret recording in which another policeman admitted shaking down small Brooklyn businessmen.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) On a 7 to 2 vote the Supreme Court cleared the way today for a six-month jail term for Carlos Marcello, alleged New Orleans rackets figure.

Cliff Keuter, a modern-dance choreographer whose interest lies more in the construction of personal, private images than in movement quality, presented a second program last night at the Cubiculo, 414 West 51st Street.

Arcs Industries, Inc., a financial and technical services concern, announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement to acquire Sassower, Jacobs Schneider, Inc., a member firm of the New York Stock Exchange and an associate member of the American Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 The Nixon Administration has asked the Office of Economic Opportunity and the Department of Labor to cut their antipoverty and manpower training budgets for 1971-72 by about $350-million, it was learned today.

AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 13 King Hussein and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian guerrilla leader, signed an agreement here tonight that termed Jordan "the main base for the liberation of Palestine" and restored a large degree of freedom of action to the commando movement.

A professor reported here yesterday that pregnant rats that breathed marijuana smoke to the equivalent of one cigarette a day for 10 days in his laboratory had produced offspring with serious genetic defects.

An agreement to end the strike of Bronx apartment house workers was annnounced last night by Vincent D. McDonnell, chairman of the State Mediation Board. The accord was reached on the strike's 29th day.

Air Marshal Yevgeny F. Loginov, head of Soviet civil aviation from 1959 until last May died in Moscow last Wednesday. He was 63 years old.
The stock market slumped yesterday for its fourth straight loss as investors displayed wariness over earnings trends andsome worry over the outlook for the economy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 A three-year study has shown that children under 15 in the Province of Quebec who were vaccinated against tuberculosis appeared to have only half the death rate from leukemia as children who were not vaccinated.

She was 66 years old and had returned to France, where she was born, after retiring last June. She was the widow of Newton W. Richards, an architect.

In one not-so-easy lesson at Madison Square Garden last night, the New York Knickerbockers learned what the New York Jets and New York Mets learned before them: that defending a championship can turn out to be harder than winning it in the first place.
Notre Dame took over the No. 1 spot in total offense in major college football, the weekly team statistics showed yesterday.

The Marine Midland Bank, formerly the Marine Midland Grace Trust Company of New York, announced yesterday a realignment in its senior management, a move viewed as providing more depth at the highest levels of the $3.39billion institution.

The RCA Corporation reported late yesterday a disappointing third quarter in which net income toppled by 70.3 per cent on a decline of 4.9 per cent in sales. Net income for the first nine months of the year fell 50.8 per cent under the 1969 level as sales slipped by 3.8 per cent.

Harold Morris, a guitarist who teaches at the Horace Mann School and the Mount Kisco School of Music, came to Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night to play music by Torroba, Ponce, Villa-Lobos and Antonio Lauro.

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 14 Mrs. Justine Cushing of Meadow Brook held a one-stroke lead today after the first round of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's 20th annual 36hole senior championship at the Fenway Golf Club.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (UPI) The Intercontinent Shoe Corporation of New York said today that it had withdrawn its application with the Patent Ofifce to register the peace symbol as a commercial trademark.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 (UPI) Stewart D. Owen, retired managing editor of The Chicago Tribune, died today in St. Francis Hospital. He was 72 years old.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Oct. 14 Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton Pike Smith have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Graydon Calvert Smith, to Alan Douglas Laird, son of Mr. and Mrs. George L. Laird of Houston.

The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., raised the price of nickel yesterday by about 4 per cent. The move by the largest supplier of the metal in the nonCommunist world caught many in the industry by surprise.

The Eastman Kodak Company set records in sales and earnings for the three and nine months ended Sept. 6, but the gains in all instances were limited to 2 per cent, according to yesterday's report from its Rochester, N.Y., headquarters.

Drug-resistant bacteria those that have developed a sort of "immunity" against common antibiotics are on the increase throughout the world in human and animal populations. Such bacteria are potentially dangerous to man because modern drugs might lose their ability to treat many diseases.

PARIS, Oct. 14 (Reuters) A French women's liberation worker, Francoise Parturier, applied today for membership in the Academie Francaise. She is the first woman to do so since 1893.

The concert that Sylvia Marlowe led on Wednesday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, first in a series of four sailing under the name "Contrasts," almost lived up to its portmanteau description. The program promised music "new-old, solo-ensemble, frivolous-serious, simple-difficult, gay-sad, short-long, naive-sophisticated, well known-obscure, majorminor, now-then ..." If it stretched a point to find anything really new, let alone now, or genuinely naive, the results were nonetheless totally palatable and predominantly delicious.

"All around me there were giant unseeing crowds," Frank Lloyd Wright recalled when he first came to Chicago in 1890; "I felt engulfed and terribly afraid." The great architect's fear of the city was not unique to him, nor to his time. The locales for thoroughbred and standardbred racing change today for the last time this year. The flat-racing scene shifts to Aqueduct for a meeting that ends on Dec. 7, while the harness horses move to Roosevelt Raceway in Westbury, L.I., for a 50-night session that concludes Dec. 15.

To a man, the Baltimore Colts denied yesterday that their first visit to Shea Stadium was a crusade aimed at revenge. Nobody made any speeches, announcements or pep talks. What happened in the Super Bowl on Jan. 12, 1969, was past "spilled milk," said John Unitas.

The cold-blooded murder of Pierre Laporte, Quebec's Labor Minister, has shocked and unified in deep sorrow the vast majority of Canadians. In the aftermath of this atrocity, Prime Minister Trudeau probably enjoys much greater support as he should for the vigorous and necessary military security measures he has taken in Quebec. More than ever now, however, his immediate political problem is to avoid excessive use of force that would give substance to charges of "repression."

Representative Wilbur Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, has shocked the public and the financial community particularly by forecasting a Federal budget deficit for the current fiscal year of $12 billion to $20 billion. The original estimate of the Nixon Administration was for a $1.3-Billion deficit. The difference is mainly due to the shortfall of tax revenues resulting from the economic slump.

The dimensions of America's own "body count" cannot be buried by Vietnamization or optimistic rhetoric.

Jerome Rose, the pianist who played at Tully Hall on Sunday night, has enough facility for 10 pianists. He can go up and down the keyboard like a whirlwind. GARDEN CITY, L.I., Oct. 20 Dave Davis came within two pins of a perfect game tonight, but even though he failed to record his sixth 300, the tall left-hander from Miami used his 298 effort to vault into first place in the $75,000 National Championship of the Professional Bowlers Association.

A need for American business to become more responsive to social challenges and for American shareowners to support business in its efforts to adapt to changing times was emphasized yesterday by A.W. Clausen, president of the Bank of America, at a conference on the business outlook in Los Angeles.

WILTON, Conn., Oct. 20 Mr. and Mrs. Robert Snyder Womrath have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Snyder Womrath, to Stephen Bosley Palmer, son of Mr. and Mrs. George B. Palmer of Orange, N.J. The wedding is planned for Nov. 21 at the Unitarian Church in Westport.

A delivery boy bringing sandwiches to librarians rushing to put thousands of books on the shelves of the new Mid-Manhattan Library before it opens on Monday, seemed stunned by the bright orange carpets, royal blue upholstered chairs and the gleaming escalators.

A pilot who has flown for Eastern Airlines for 30 years has been discharged following what the airline calls an unnecessary, procedure that delayed flights. The pilot, however, maintains fihat the procedure was a quick and simple process that could reduce flight hazards and air pollution.

The Council of Supervisory Associations decided yesterday to file a suit to compel Dr. Harvey B. Scribner, Chancellor of the city's schools, and the Board of Education to cancel the appointment of Melvin Taylor as acting principal of Benjamin Franklin High School in East Harlem.
Mrs. Albert D. Lasker, president of the Albert and Mary Lasker Foundation, received the Distinguished New Yorker Award of the City Club of New York last night.

The Republic Steel Corpration, the nation's third largest steel producer and the first of the major concerns to report third-quarter earnings, said yesterday in Cleveland that income in the latest period was down 20 per cent from the 1969 level.
The oil industry began to parace its third-quarter and nine-month earnings reports yesterday with upbeat and downbeat profit tunes just about evenly matched.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 20 Nationalist China urged the member nations of the United Nations today to stand firm against Communist China's admission on the ground that most of those nations were potential targets of Chinese Communist aggression.

Well-intentioned, weakminded and quite totally and unutterably boring, some kind of historical play, laughingly calling itself "Gandhi," dragged its sluggard way into the Playhouse Theater last night. In the first place it is an insult to a great man, in the second place it is an insult to a great man, and in the third place it is a waste of another man who has many claims to being a great actor.

ROSLYN, L.I., Oct. 20 -- Lester L. Wolff, the Democatic Liberal representing Nassau County's Third Congressional District, is confident that his Republican and Conservative opponents will divide the rising Conservative vote and enable him to capture his fourth term.

The West African nation of Senegal--long dependent on peanuts as her main export commodity--is basing her economic hopes for the future on a broad new diversification program, Premier Abdou Diouf told businessmen here yesterday.
PHIDALEPHIA, Oct. 20 (UPI) A second tentative agreement in a three-day wage strike by more than 11,000 public school teachers was reached here today through the efforts of a three-judge panel.
There was speculation at the beginning of the season about the status of Joe Massey, Yale's quarterback. Some observers may have had doubts about Massey's ability to lead the Yale team.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 20 The deadline for supplementing 2-year-old pacers to the Roosevelt Futurity, set for Roosevelt Raceway on Oct. 31, passed last midnight. It was not until this morning, though, that the entry box was opened by Larry Maller, the racing secretary. Inside the box were two checks, each for $7,500, and each making a juvenile pacer eligible for the mile event.

When Ebasco Industries, Inc., was preparing to merge into the Boise Cascade Corporation, the management of Ebasco, which was once known as Electric Bond and Share, went to great lengths to explain the situation to shareholders.
After eight straight defeats in a string that began last June at Belmont Park, Calumet's Our Cadet, finally was returned to the winner's circle at Aqueduct yesterday.

OTTAWA, Oct. 20 (AP)--The Governments of Canada and the United States have embarked on a joint project to reduce the number of auto accidents in which alcohol plays apart, the Transport Minister, Don Jamieson, announced today.

AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 20 Reversing their position on investment income, representatives of the auto insurance industry recommended to the State Board of Insurance today that income from all sources be considered in auto rate-making formulas.

Representative Ogden R. Reid charged before the Public Service Commission yesterday that a fare restructuring proposal by the Penn Central for the New Haven Division would cause hardship not only for commuters but also for students and elderly people.

Arthur J. Goldberg's campaign for Governor has received a massive infusion of Lindsay organization aides, ideas and enthusiasm in the wake of Mayor Lindsay's late-hour. endorsement of the Democratic-Liberal candidate.

ALGIERS, Oct. 20 Algeria has granted political asylum to Dr. Timothy Leary, the prophet of LSD who escaped from prison in San Luis Obispo, Calif., on Sept. 13, the official Algerian press agency said tonight.
MOSCOW, Oct. 20 The Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia today warned Turkey that failure to extradite the two hijackers of a Soviet airliner could "cast a shadow" over Turkish-Soviet relations.

Joe Namath doubted last night that he would play for the New York Jets again this season. The 27-year-old quarterback also acknowledged that the resumption of his career next season was uncertain at this time.
The estate of George M. Humphrey and other large stockholders disposed yesterday of 278,560 shares of Hanna Mining Company common stock at $45.50 that were marketed by a First Boston Corporation...

SANTA CRUZ, Calif., Oct. 20 A wealthy Santa Cruz eye surgeon, his wife, two of their four children and his secretary were shot to death yesterday and their bodies were dumped into the swimming pool at the doctor's mansion in the rugged hills overlooking Monterey Bay about five miles south of here.

HOUSTON, Oct. 20 The 3.5-million member Episcopal Church, meeting here in triennial general convention, agreed today to transmit to its 90 dioceses for study a plan of union that would merge nine major Protestant denominations into one church with a total membership of 25 million.
New York City sold a $233.78-million bond issue yesterday, and if incurred an interest cost of nearly 7.15 per cent the second highest rate in recent years.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 20 --Lammot du Pont Copeland Jr., a great-great-great grandson of the founder of E. I. du Pont de Nemours, the world's largest chemical company, asked the United States District Court here today to supervise his payments to 121 creditors.

PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil, Oct. 20 (AP)--Presdient Emilio G. Medici said today that people who accused Brazilian authorities of torturing prisoners were "bad Brazilians, Communists and subversives." The public statement was his first on the issue.
The St. Louis Cardinals will come to town on Sunday as a first-place football team. The last time they came to town they were a divided team.

A strong third quarter with Willis Reed unavailable for most of it and a runaway fourth quarter in which Reed scored 16 of his 29 points brought the New York Knickerbockers a 115-100 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers at Madison Square Garden last night before the season's first capacity crowd of 19,500.
CAIRO, Oct. 20 Dr. MahMoud Fawzi, a distinguished 70-year-old diplomat, was approved tonight as Premier of the United Arab Republic.

The competition for the saving dollar, which is already intense, appears likely to intensify further in the near future. The First Union National Bancorp., parent company of the $1.1-billion First Union National Bank, which operates statewide in North Carolina, is poised to merchandise a $15-million issue of bonds paying interest as high as 7 5/8 per cent in denominations as small as $2,500.
Clara Louise Penney, an author and scholar, died Sunday at her home in Clifton, Me. She was 82 years old.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Oct. 20 Francis X. Patrey, president of Bourjois, Inc., died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, where he had been under treatment for two weeks for a virus ailment. He was 53 years old and lived at 64 Plymouth Road.
MOSCOW, Oct. 20 (UPI) Soviet industrial production rose by 8.3 per cent in the first nine months of 1970 despite shortcomings in consumer goods industries, the Government announced today.
ALBANY, Oct. 20 (AP) The state's unemployment rate dropped slightly in September but was still greater than the same month a year ago, State Industrial Commissioner M.P. Catherwod reported today.
Prices on the London stock exchange were firm yesterday after a minor rally from lower opening levels.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 TWO tiny pieces of moon rock have apparently been lost in the mail.

CAIRO When Anwar el-Sadat, as a young officer, was imprisoned for conspiring against the British and the corrupt King Farouk he wrote a political novel discussing the relative values of revolution and evolutionary reform. His book was called "The Prince of the Island" and was never published.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation charged yesterday that the vice president of the board of trustees of the Denver Art Museum, wearing a wig and a false mustache, sneaked into New York City to sell paintings stolen not from his museum but from the art collection of a friend.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art played host yesterday, diffidently to be sure but not without grace, to a galaxy of its antagonists. For five hours, from 3 P.M. to 8 P.M., the museum allowed the occupation of its Great Hall in an event that had an assortment of names, among them "opening hearing," "workshop," "popular rally" and "International Artists Demonstration."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 With two weeks to go, the 1970 election campaign shows every indication of remaining one of history's great nondebates. The Republican chairman in one of the Mountain States said last week that he could not remember a year when "so few, issues really gabbed the elector

NEW HAVEN "Two Saints," which the Yale Repertory Theater is performing this month in repertory with "Olympian Games," is a matched, yet contrasting, pair of Story Theater plays. The first, Isaac Bashevis Singer's "Gimpel the Fool" is about a saintly Jewish fool, the second, Flaubert's "St. Julian the Hospitaler," about a murderer turned Catholic saint.

To the prosecutors, the trial of New York's 13 Black Panther defendants is basically a criminal case. They have accused the Panthers of plotting to kill policemen and bomb buildings, including Bloomingdale's and the Bronx Botanical Gardens, and the truth of those charges is all that the District Attorney
LONDON, Oct. 20 (AP) The price of gold rose more than 20 cents in Europe's bullion markets today to its highest point in more than a year.

"Brother Melvin Taylor, principal," proclaimed a bulletin board inside East Harlem's Benjamin Franklin High School yesterday, "He is the students', the parents', the teachers' and the people's choice."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 Rising unemploynment in the third quarter of 1970 struck most severely at the poor, the black and the young, according to a report released today by the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Labor Department.

Interest in cooking has been heightened on many fronts--by the growing number of cookbooks, television cooking shows and cooking schools, by the opening of new restaurants, by the wider availability of exotic ingredients. Now food devotees in New York have two new experiences available to them.
The United States Court of Appeals here ruled yesterday that consenting adults could send obscene material to one another through the mail for their personal and private use.

The New York Stock Exchange disclosed yesterday that it had ordered Goodbody Co. to raise additional capital and said the new funds would be used to strengthen the firm's existing operations, rather than to expand its activities.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 20 (AP)--A Vietcong unit was reported to have ambushed an American convoy today 200 yards from a South Korean outpost in the Central Highlands of South Vietnam.
Declines continued to outpace advances yesterday on the American Stock Exchange for the 11th consecutive session in quiet trading although the losses were considerably less than on Monday.
Some of the Joffrey Ballet's most sparkling ballets were on the subdued side last night at the City Center. The oomph was not missing, just redistributed.

The annual Eastern regional conference of the American Association of Advertising Agencies began its three-day stay at the Biltmore yesterday with some words from the wise that won't prove sufficient.

SUFFERN, N.Y., Oct. 20 Robert Robinson executive director of the Grand Bahama Cruise Development Board, died yesterday in Good Samaritan Hospital here after a short illness. He was 59 years old and lived at l7 Hillside Court here.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 20 Robert H. Finch, counselor to President Nixon, did not hesitate last week to tell Wisconsin audiences that Mr. Nixon was putting his prestige squarely on the line by coming here in behalf of Republican candidates.
Glamour issues bounded upward yesterday to star in a stock market that otherwise registered a small advance.

OLD BROOKVILLE, L.I., Oct. 20 The defending champions. Jimmy Wright and John Langford of Inwood, carded 33, 33 66, with three birdies on each nine, to retain their Metropolitan Professional Golf Association's pro-pro title today with a 133 at the Cedar Brook Country Club. Par for the 6,601-yard course is 36, 36 72.
AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 16 American military doctors have performed surgery on more than 800 Arabs here as part of a $5-million United States emergency relief program after the Jordanian civil war.

A chief spokesman for landlords of New York's 1.3-million rent-controlled apartments warned yesterday that unless the city suspended real estate taxes for the owners of buildings containing 400,000 apartments, these buildings would go into debt this winter.

Senator Eugene J. McCarthy, the peace movement candidate for President in 1968, compared the antiwar credentials of the Democratic and Republican candidates for Senator from New York yesterday. As he saw it, the Democrat won.
A committee of clergymen said yesterday that officials had turned down their request to conduct their own investigation of conditions in city jails.
NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 20 --Miss philippa Clarke Greene and Andrew Sumner Kennedy plan to marry here in March.
SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 20 Patrick Wymark, a well-known British actor, was found dead in his hotel room in Melbourne this evening, apparently of natural causes. He was 44 years old.

A write-in candidate has won an equal-time broadcast ruling from the Federal Communications Commission, and radio station WOR said yesterday that the candidate would get free radio time worth about $10,000.

President Nixon's priority for Republican politicking over state business, combined with shoddy staff work by Zambian diplomats, has produced unfortunate and wholly unnecessary friction between the United States and black Africa. In this instance, a seeming White House snub of President Kenneth Kaunda of Zambia is the source of the irritation.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 20 Israel staked out an advance position today for an expected, but unwelcomed debate on the Middle East at the United Nations General Assembly, warning that she would not be bound by any new resolution that the Assembly might adopt.

A luncheon and fashion show will be held next Wednesday at the St. Regis Roof and Penthouse by the Women's Auxiliary of the Presbyterian Hospital. Among the designers to be represented at the "Caravan of Fashion" are Donald Brooks, Vera Maxwell, Anne Fogarty, Pucci, Geoffrey Beene and Chester Weinberg. Melvin E. Dawley, chairman of the board of Lord Taylor; .will' be guest of honor.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20--The United States Navy, facing the prospect of shrinking budgets and increasing costs, has a plan to mothball up to six of its 18 aircraft carriers, according to authoritative sources.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Exactly one month after ordering the bombing of North Vietnam in February, 1965--a date marking a Significant escalation of the war--President Johnson told his wife that he saw no way out of American involvement.
ROME, Oct. 20 Italians used to buy a few blue jeans from the United States and export plenty of Pucci pants and Gucci shoes. But the terms of trans-Atlantic fashion trade may soon change.

A true virtuoso needs a lot of seasoning and more than a sprinkle of dash to carry off a solo recital. A virtuoso cellist needs even more of these ingredients than do players of more usual solo instruments.

Twenty-second District: James H. Scheuer (Dem.-Lib.) has amply proved his value as a Representative in his three terms in office. His work for job-training, crime prevention and housing especially entitle him to re-election.

TRENTON, Oct. 20 Compared with the furor of some recent election campaigns by Democratic candidates in New Jersey, Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. apparently is in political hiding, with the election just two weeks from today.

The American Electric Power Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in its net income for the three, nine and 12 months ended Sept. 30. The company's report also showed September net income had risen by 10.5 per cent to $9,968,000 from $9,023,000 a year earlier.
MEMPHIS, Oct. 20 The New York Nets opened a twogame road tour by defeating the Memphis Pros, 108-103, at Mid-South Coliseum tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20--Representative Henry S. Reuss criticized the Federal Water Quality Administration today for failing to recommend to the Justice Department the filing of suits against 40 companies discharging mercury into the nation's waterways.

TORONTO, Oct. 20 (UPI) A 21-year-old United States Army deserter who is a demolition expert was released here yesterday after being held in custody for more than 18 hours under the emergency powers invoked against French Canadian separatist terrorism.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 20 Israel staked out an advance position today for an expected, but unwelcomed debate on the Middle East at the United Nations General Assembly, warning that she would not be bound by any new resolution that the Assembly might adopt.

Claude Chabrol's "Que la bete meure" is a revenge melodrama about a young father who sets out to discover and murder the hit-andrun killer of his little son. By providential chance he learns who was in the fatal car. He pursues first a television actress and then her brother-in-law, his intended victim, who, it turns out, is a monster whom everybody (except his own awful mother) would gladly see dead.
PARIS, Oct. 20 For the second time within two months, the Bank of France lowered its discount rate today by half a point.
The Jewish community in America is now living in a situation unprecedented in 2,000 years of Jewish history but only its young people are facing the fact, and even they have just begun to.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (UPI) Interest rates declined slightly today in the Federal National Mortgage Association's biweekly auction of commitments to buy $149.7-million in Federal Housing Administration and Veterans Administration-backed mortgages.
MOSCOW, Oct. 20 (Reuters) A Soviet mathematician, Revolt Pimenov, went on trial today charged with distributing anti-Soviet fabrications, according to dissident sources.

Either Bruce Gamble, the journeyman who was transformed into a super-goalie in Madison Square Garden, or Jacques Plante, the old, broken-nosed wanderer who was strafed for six goals in his last appearance, will man the nets for Toronto tonight at 7:35 when the Rangers face the Maple Leafs.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Oct. 20 Angels are replacing breweries and equipment companies as primary sponsors for touring members of the Professional Bowlers Association.

Increased profits in the September quarter were shownby three drug and chemical producers the American Home Products Corporation, the Bristol-Myers Company and Richardson-Merrell, Inc. in their reports issued yesterday. Only the Celanese Corporation, a leading maker of synthetic fibers that is important in chemicals, plastics and coatings, had lower thirdquarter results.
ACCRA, Ghana, Oct. 20 Ghana's three opposition parties were merged today into a single organization, the Justice party.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 20 The United States Army has awarded a Silver Star for valor to a general in Vietnam based on a description of acts of heroism in Cambodia that were invented by enlisted men under orders.

Joe Namath has been buried on occasions under a much more smothering mass of muscle than flattened him late in the game with the Baltimore Colts last Sunday. Billy Ray Smith of the Baltimore Colts is a mere 250 pounds, modest tonnage for a defensive tackle. It wasn't the weight of Billy Ray that did the damage, though. It was the way Namath toppled with his right wrist taking the shivering impact with the ground.

CAIRO, Oct, 20 Anwar elSadat, the new President of the United Arab Republic, said last night that "if the United States were not behind the Israeli expansion drive, the whole question of the Arab-Israeli conflict would be solved by the Jarring mission within 24 hours."
BONN, Oct. 20 (Reuters) Belkacem Krim, a former Algerian revolutionary leader, was found strangled tonight in a Frankfurt hotel, the West German Interior Ministry said.
Striking members of the Newspaper Guild unit at The New York Post voted overwhelmingly last night to ratify a new agreement with the newspaper and planned to return to their jobs today.

Premier Golda Meir of Israel told Secretary of State William P. Rogers yesterday that Israel was willing to resume Arab-Israeli negotiations only if the United Arab Republic made rectifications for its violation of the Middle East cease-fire.

MONTREAL, Oct. 20 Amid a cordon formed by hundreds of soldiers, a funeral was held today for Pierre Laporte, the Quebec Minister of Labor and Immigration, who was kidnapped and slain by the Front for the Liberation of Quebec.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) With housing leading the way, construction contracts are expected to increase by almost 10 per cent to $74.35-billion in 1971, the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company, a division of Mc-Graw-Hill, Inc., said today.

Manhattan this year offers an unusually bright array of Congressional contenders, but such is the voting complexion of the five districts involved that the contests present a minimum of suspense. As it happens, the five candidates endorsed by this newspaper are overwhelming favorites to win, although that fact has played no part in our decisions.
BUFFALO, Oct. 20 (AP) Hal Greer came off the bench in the second period and led the Philadelphia 76ers to a 98-89 victory over the Buffalo Braves tonight.

Christopher Keene, the 23year-old winner of the first Julius Rudel Award, made his New York City Opera debut Sunday afternoon conducting Ginastera's "Don Rodrigo." Despite his tender years, Mr. Keene has already had considerable operatic experience on the musical staff of the Santa Fe and San Francisco opera companies, and, in 1968 and 1969, conducting at the Spoleto Festival.

FORT HOOD, Tex., Oct. 20 The prosecution in the courtmartial of S. Sgt. David Mitchell for his role in the alleged massacre of civilians in the South Vietnamese hamlet of Mylai 4 unexpectedly rested its case today after calling three witnesses to the stand.

The American Cyanamid Company filed a suit in Federal District Court yesterday to prevent the sale of the Elizabeth Arden Sales Corporation to Eli Lilly Co. Earlier this month Eli Lilly announced it had arranged to buy the manufacturer of cosmetics and operator of beauty salons.

Popular songs of a century ago, which have been transformed by the passing of time to folk songs, formed a focal point for a recital by Joe Hickerson on Monday night at the Washington Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street.
ATHENS, Oct. 20--Thomas A, Pappas, a Greek-born Boston financier with a $200-million industrial empire in Greece, was charged today with breach of trust and violation of Greek corporate laws.
LONDON, Oct. 20 (UPI) Ted (Kid) Lewis, a Briton who was welterweight boxing champion of the world, died today after a short illness. He was 75 years old.

The engagement of Miss Mary Lindsay Dearborn to B.F. Alex Huppe, son of Dr. and Mrs. B.F. Huppe of Binghamton, N.Y., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. James Andrew Dearborn of Jamaica Estates, queens, and Deerfields, Mount Holly, Vt. Miss Dearborn and her fiance will be married Dec. 24 at Deerfields, the family farm.

MONTREAL, Oct. 21 (UPI)-- Bill Goldsworthy scored late in the third period and Minnesota's rookie goaltender, Gilles Gilbert, was outstanding tonight as the North Stars defeated the Montreal Canadiens, 3-1.

FORT HOOD, Tex., Oct. 21-- The court martial of S. Sgt. David Mitchell was postponed today until tomorrow at the earliest to allow defense attorneys time to round up witnesses to testify on the alleged mass killing at the South Vietnamese hamlet of Mylai 4.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Oct. 21. (AP) --Giovanni Liverzani of Italy set a world record of 598 in the rapid-fire pistol match today in the 40th world shooting championships.

BONN, Oct. 21--Chancellor Willy Brandt, marking his first 12 months in office today, dismissed predictions by the Parliamentary opposition that his Government would soon topple. He vowed to serve out his term ending in 1973.
SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 21 (AP)--The Utah Stars won their second straight basketball game at the Salt Palace tonight by defeatiiag the Pittsburg Condors, 140-108, before a crowd of 4,876.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21-- Representative Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, publicly criticized for the first time today President Nixon's proposal to share revenues with state and local governments.
KINGSTON, N.Y., Oct. 21-- Former Federal Judge John M. Cashin of the Southern District Court of New York died today at his home, 166 West Chestnut Street. He was 78 years old.
The Yorkville Youth Council will hold its 11th annual Yorkville Ball Oct. 30 at the Roosevelt Hotel's Terrace Suite. Invitations were accepted by 350 persons, who paid $12.50 for the evening.
Until recently the world's food experts were wondering how to drive off the specter of hunger and frustrate the predictions of Malthus, who warned in 1798 that population was outrunning food supply.
The San Francisco Warriors meet the New York Knicks tonight at Madison Square Garden with what Jerry Lucas calls "the same players, but a different team."

MOSCOW, Oct. 21--The Soviet Union announced today the launching of Zond 8, an unmanned spacecraft, whose flight plan calls for it to swing around the moon on Saturday and return to the earth next Tuesday.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 21 (AP)--Unbeaten Virginia overpowered the Kentucky Colonels, 112-97, tonight to maintain the Squires' lead in the American Basketball Association East.
A special Federal grand jury indicted two major manufacturing companies yesterday on charges of polluting the Hudson and Harlem Rivers.
The President of Communist Rumania met the president of Capitalist Macy's yesterday. They apparently got along well.
David S. Lewis, the 53-yearold president and chief operating officer of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, has been elected chairman and chief executive officer of the General Dynamics Corporation.

NAPA, Calif., Oct. 21-- George Meany, one of the world's top labor leaders, recommended golf today as a healthy exercise for all as he took part in a pro-amateur preliminary to the $150,000 Kaiser international open.

AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 21 --Informed Jordanian sources said today that the 12,000 Iraqi troops stationed in Jordan since the Arab-Israeli war of June, 1967, were being pulled out and that their withdrawal would be completed tomorrow night.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21 (AP) --Jerry West scored 37 points, 16 in the third period, is leading the Los Angeles Lakers to a 141-117 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers tonight in a National Basketball Association game.
Prospects for progress toward peace in the Middle East are being seriously endangered by the rigid position both sides are currently voicing in regard to violations of the standstill cease-fire.

The fact that Joe Namath had played 77 consecutive pro football games before being forced out by his broken wrist this week brought attention to the subject of quarterback durability, and that, in turn, brought up the subject of Fran Tarkenton.

The identity and whereabouts of a man in whose Brooklyn apartment the police found explosives they believe were in tended to blow up several United Nations missions remained a mystery yesterday after four days of investigation by detectives of the special services division and the Brooklyn District Attorney.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21-- President Nixon signed into law today a new maritime program that will build 300 merchant ships over the next 10 years and extend operating subsidies to almost the entire fleet.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21-- The Mayor of Vienna, W. Va., and two other members of the town's antipollution committee have charged the Union Carbide Corporation with failing to meet a Federal deadline yesterday for a 40 per cent reduction in sulphur oxide emissions from its plants in Marietta, Ohio.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 21-- Charles M. Manson returned to the courtroom today and was promptly confronted by a witness who testified that Manson visited the residence of Sharon Tate five months before she was murdered last year.

WICHITA, Kan., Oct. 21 (AP) --A witness testified today that at least one engine of the Wichita State University football plane was misfiring just before the aircraft crashed Oct. 2. But the surviving co-pilot testified that "everything on the plane worked."

The Rev. Laurence Gibney, the Roman Catholic chaplain at the Manhattan House of Detention who was banned from the jail during the recent prisoner uprising there, was returned yesterday to his duties and praised for his attempts to end the crisis.
The stock market, propelled by one of its favorite rumors, got off to a running start yesterday morning. Then it spent the rest of the session slowing down, and finished with mixed results.

Nadia Koutzen's violin recital at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday night divided itself neatly into two sections in terms of the listening pleasure it provided. And the distinctions between the two were so pronounced that they might have been played by different violinists. The second part was the good one. It was given over to Debussy's Sonata, Stravinsky's Duo Concertant and Sarasate's, Introduction and Tarantelle.
Jockeys from south of the border may be dominating New York's racing these days but yesterday at Aqueduct it was a rider born and raised in South Brooklyn who took the play away from the Latins.

The second annual Westchester Art Ball will be held at the Westchester Country Club in Harrison, N.Y., Saturday to raise money for the Iona College Institute for the Arts. The self-supporting program sponsors concerts, theatrical and dance programs, lectures, workshops and art exhibitions in Westchester County.

The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday declines of 3 per cent in thirdquarter net income and 11 percent in the first nine months of 1970 despite higher revenues and sales in both periods.
Mayor Lindsay was greeted with a mixture of boos and cheers when he got up to speak last night at the 25th annual Alfred E. Smith Memorial dinner.
MEXICO CITY, Oct 21-- Gen. Lazaro Gardenas, former President of Mexico, was buried here today in an elaborate state funeral as this nation of 48 million observed a day of mourning.

I'd like to welcome the three of you to The Times--Governor Rockefeller, Mr. Goldberg, Dr. Adams. We're delighted that you've agreed to come together here for your first three-way debate of the campaign. We hope your answers to the questions our reporters will pose will help clarify some of the major issues of the campaign for our readers and we're confident that we'll all leave this conference room enlightened and with no bloodshed.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Oct. 21 (AP)--Jan Johnson, the worldrecord holder indoors in the pole vault, and Brian McElroy, one of the nation's top half-milers, were dismissed today from the Kansas University track squad for training-rule violations.
The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday that consumer prices here last month continued to rise faster than the rate for the entire country.

One of the current delights on the local scene is a fruit that is little known and little used in America, although it dates to Biblical days. This is the quince, which has been said to resemble nothing so closely as a "large, pale-golden apple with a somewhat malformed blossom end." And it has been surmised that the quince was, in fact, the original apple that Eve gave Adam.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 21-- The Canadian Equestrian Team did its utmost tonight to break the West Germans' tight rein on the international events at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show, but couldn't do it.

The Kennecott Copper Corporation, the leading producer of United States primary copper, reported yesterday that earnings in the third quarter fell below the comparable 1969 level, Kennecott said income from United States operations rose, but the advance was more than wiped out by the absence of dividends from its Chilean holdings.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21-- The White House reiterated again today that it would not endorse the Republican candidate for United States Senate in New York and hinted at strong support for the Conservative candidate, James L. Buckley.

OHARLOTTE, N.C., Oct. 21 --The Carolina Cougars outshot the Indiana Pacers from the floor, but got beat on flawless free-throw shooting tonight as the Pacers converted 35 of 35 in a 125-113 American Association game. It was the Pacers' fifth straight victory and the Cougars' third straight loss.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 21-- The two top-ranking American military men in Turkey are missing on a plane that is feared to have crashed in mountainous terrain and bad weather in eastern Turkey, it was announced tonight.

Theodore J. Kauffeld, a consuiting engineer and industrialist, who was chairman of the board and chief executive officer of Devenco, Inc., 150 Broadway, technical consultants and designers, died yesterday at his home, 2 Delaware Road in Convent, N.J. His age was 67.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21--The Food and Drug Administration said today that it, the American Medical Association and the American Diabetes Association concurred with findings of a study that cast serious doubt on the value of a diabetes pill used by about 800,000 Americans.

POINT LOOKOUT, L.I., Oct. 21--John James Murphy, retired stockbroker who was senior partner in the recently dissolved New York Stock Exchange Specialist firm of Murphy Co., died tonight at his home on Baldwin Avenue. He was 71 years old.

ROME, Oct. 21--Pope Paul VI, clearly alluding to Brazil, condemned police torture today as barbaric. In an address to thousands of pilgrims from many countries who attended his weekly general audience in St. Peter's Basilica, the Pontiff also voiced outrage over other forms of political violence, terrorism and crime throughout the world.

DENVER, Oct. 21 (AP)--Don Sidle tallied 24 points and four teammates chipped in with 20 or more tonight as Denver turned back the Texas Chaparrals, 133-115, for the Rockets' first American Basketball Association victory of the season.

As a result of a late filing with the Board of Elections by the Conservative party, Donald J. Walsh, who had been nominated by the party for Representative in the 13th Congressional District of Brooklyn, has been ruled ineligible for that contest.

ROME, Oct. 21--The share of one of the world's larges conglomerates, Montecatini Edison, S.p.A., dropped to their lowest price in the four years of its existence today amid in dications that the embattled company would soon have to undergo drastic reorganization.

CAIRO, Oct. 21--The new Premier of the United Arab Republic, Dr. Mahmound Fawzi, and 32 Cabinet ministers took oaths of office today in a ceremony in Kubbeh Palace, opening a new period in Egyptian political history.

The Rev. William Lombardy of New York, a former world junior champion, is a hard man to turn away from what he considers best in a complicated position. Witness the game played between Lombardy and National Master Ungureanu of Rumania. The game, a Sicilian Defense, was played during the recent 19th Chess Olympiad at Siegen. West Germany.
The claims of the Nixon Administration that it has succeeded in slowing down inflation have been thrown into serious doubt by the new consumer price data for September.

Will the former Presidential yacht, the Julie, become the Good Ship Curly Top? Julius Caruso, the New York hairdresser, and his wife, Aurora, certainly hope so. The Carusos' bid of $43,227 for the Julie proved to be the highest when the sealed bids were opened by the Defense Surplus Sales Agency at Newport, R. I., on Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21-- President Nixon is campaigning more strenuously for his welfare reform program now than he did when it stood a chance of Congressional approval before the election.
Private tow-truck operators demonstrated for higher rates yesterday at City Hall.

"Burn!," Gillo Pontecorvo's first film since "The Battle of Algiers," aspires to be a prole epic but winds up as the sort of prole pageant in which characters always seem to be conceptualizing great issues, mostly freedom, as they pass in front of history, as if it were a scenic view, instead of moving in and out of it.

The American Ballet Company, known more plausibly elsewhere as the Eliot Feld Company, last night opened its fall season at its home at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. It looked in very good shape--with its personal style not only intact but sharpened.
LONDON, Oct, 21--The two biggest independent airlines in Britain are merging to form a so-called "second-force airline"
Dean Witter Co., Inc., one of the nation's largest brokerage houses, reported yesterday that it earned $1,011,000 in the year ended Aug. 31, down sharply from $3,068,000 in the previous fiscal year.
LONDON, Oct. 21--Jack Hood Vaughn, a former ambassador and director of the Peace Corps, and Miss Margaret Anne Weld were married here yesterday.
A 97-year-old New Jersey man was one of three $100,000 winners yesterday in the monthly New York state lottery.

NEW CANAAN, Pa., Oct. 21 (UPI)--The Russian Orthodox Greek Catholic Church of America, which traces its history in America back to 1794, officially became an independent church yesterday by changing its name.

Frederic Hand's guitar program on Tuesday night at Carnegie Recital Hall made several welcome excursions outside the well-thumbed repertory too often heard in such recitals. There was not, in fact, one Spanish or South American piece, revolutionary as that may seem. Mr. Hand further defied guitar-recital practice by including several sizable pieces, two of them of his own composition.
Miss Annie McClure Clarke, a junior at Williams College, plans to be married on Jan. 3 to John Curtis Ager Jr., a Williams senior she met when they were both students at Vassar.

The Phelps Dodge Corporation, the second largest producer of American, primary copper, announced yesterday an, immediate price cut for the metal to 56 cents a pound from 60 cents a pound.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Oct. 21-- Malcolm E. Smith, Jr., the Republican-Conservative candidate in the First Congressional District, conceded the other day that his Democratic opponent. Representative Otis G. Pike, was "likable."

VIENTIANE, Laos, Oct. 21 (AP)--An American air attache who had been in Laos only a few days crashed in northern Laos on Oct. 13 and is presumed dead, the United States Embassy announced today.

The presiding justice of the Appellate Division, Second Department, moved yesterday to alleviate crowded jail conditions in Brooklyn and Queens by speeding the cases of defendants awaiting trial in State Supreme Court.
A Brooklyn policeman was arrested yesterday on an indictment that accused him of trying to bribe another policeman to change his testimony in a marijuana case.
Bill Denehy, the pitcher who went to the Washington Senators in the deal that brought Gil Hodges to the Mets as manager, returned to the New York roster yesterday.

HOUSTON, Oct. 21--The Episcopal Church authorized today the establishment of a youth program designed to develop "new patterns of ministry to youth and young adults focused on issues and institutions important to their lives."
Coach Weeb Ewbank again discounted reports yesterday that the Jets would make a trade to replace the injured Joe Namath at quarterback.

There are many farmers and migrant workers in the east, large numbers of blacks in Central Islip, Bellport and Flanders, and many people engaged in scientific work at the Brookhaven National Laboratory.

ALGIERS, Thursday, Oct. 22 (AP)--Eldridge Cleaver, the Black Panther leader, said today that a "Miss Dohrn" had joined him and Dr. Timothy Leary in exile here, but he refused to say if she was Bernardine Dohrn, the student radical on the Federal Bureau of Investigation's list of 10 most-wanted persons.
