UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 21--Premier Golda Meir of Israel and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union underlined the deadlock in the Middle East today by delivering diametrically opposed statements to the General Assembly on the terms for reopening Arab-Israeli peace talks.
The New York Stock Exchange has acted to strengthen the capital requirements of its member organizations and to insure against sudden capital withdrawals that might weaken brokerage houses.

Schubert's classicaliy formed Symphony No. 5 in B flat and Bruckner's Symphony No. 4 in E flat, which is "Romantic" both in style and subtitle, were programed by Istvan Kertesz in his appearance with the Philadelphia Orchestra in Philharmonic Hall Tuesday night.
PARIS, Oct. 21--President Pompidou has decided to forbid the export of French arms that could be used to suppress uprisings in South Africa or other countries, it was officially announced today.
Copper futures prices rose yesterday on the Commodity Exchange here with the December contract, the busiest with 509 sales, rising to 49.05 cents from 48.40 cents a pound.

Fire Commissioner Robert O. Lowery reported yesterday that an ironworker whose acetylene torch started the fire last Saturday in which a fireman died tried to fight the fine for 20 minutes by hauling buckets of water seven stories to the roof before the Fire Department was called.

The president of the Roya National Bank--which is caught in the middle of a bitter proxy fight between the Security National Bank, Hunting ton, L.I., and the Abacus Fund Inc., Security's biggest share holder--charged yesterday that Abacus had made an "irresponsible and completely unjustified attack" on Royal.

The American Newspaper Publishers Association, which was founded in New York City 84 years ago and has been here ever since, announced plans yesterday to move its headquarters to Reston, Va., primarily because of "unacceptable" rent increases.
Early yesterday, a slender, vigorous, deeply tanned man was busily at work overseeing a special harvest of wheat in a Mexican field.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 21--The Army today announced an official investigation into the award of a Silver Star for valor to a general in Vietnam on the basis of a citation written from the imagination of an enlisted man.

A tough, close and unpredictable contest is being waged in the 16th Congressional District, which takes in all of Staten Island and a bit of Brooklyn, by Jobn M. Murphy, the 44-year-old Democratic incumbent, and former City Councilman David D. Smith, the Republican-Conservative candidate.

KYOTO, Japan, Oct. 21 (AP) --About 300 religious leaders ended a six-day international conference for world peace here today and unanimously adopted resolutions calling for an immediate cease-fire in Vietnam and a "prompt" halt to South Africa's racial policy.
DENVER, Oct. 20--In a way, Mark Hogan has been an albatross around Gov. John A. Love's neck for the last four years, but the voters of Colorado will settle that when they elect one of them Governor.

Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, Under Secretary of the United Nations, and Kingman Brewster Jr., president of Yale University, will receive the eighth annual Family of Man Awards for excellence from the Council of Churches of the City of New York.
The financial distress of the nation's airlines was pointed up yesterday in earnings statements for the September quarter issued by four of the 11 big trunklines.
The Board of Education is taking a new look at its three comprehensive high schools to determine if the experimental schools are working out.

LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, Oct. 21 (UPI)--Bernadette Devlin, the youngest member of the British Parliament, was released from prison today after having served four months of a six-month sentence for helping incite riots in Londonderry in 1969.

A strike by nearly 5,400 stewardesses and pursers against Trans World Airlines ended at 5 A.M. yesterday--29 hours after it began-when the airline and the Transport Workers Union agreed on tentative terms for a new contract.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 21-- According to the Gallup Poll, most Americans favor the idea of establishing a United Nations peace-keeping army of 100,000 men.
Danny Murtaugh of the Pittsburgh Pirates was named National League manager of the year by The Associated Press yesterday.

The countdown for the 1971 Red Cross International Gala, one of the main events of the Palm Beach season, was begun here yesterday when Mr. and Mrs. Owen R. Cheatham gave their annual committee reception at their River House apartment.

Enthusiasts from the New York metropolitan area had a wide choice open to them last weekend. Some stayed in Manhattan and competed in the International Bidding contest; and others participated in a sectional tournament at Westwood, N.J.

Daniel S. Dubbin, president of Canaveral International, Inc., said yesterday that believed that the real estate security for $1.1-million owed to the company by Lammot du Pont Copeland Jr. was adequate protection to Canaveral.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP)--President Nixon told Postmaster General Winton M. Blount today to go to Hanoi, if that is necessary and possible, to deliver Christmas mail to American prisoners of war in North Vietnam.

CAIRO, Ill., Oct. 21 (AP)-- The police said sniper fire temporarily pinned policemen behind an armor barricade in their station tonight and that shots were heard in numerous places throughout this racially divided city.

SANTA CRUZ, Calif., Oct. 21 --The Santa Cruz County Sheriff's Department disclosed tonight that a declaration of war by "the People of the Free Universe" had been discovered on the estate where a wealthy eye surgeon was slain Monday with his wife, their two sons and his secretary.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 21--President Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan of Pakistan declared here today that Pakistan and India had become "the laughingstock of the world" because of their persisting enmity.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21 (AP)--This city's 13,000 public school, teachers were back in classrooms today after winning a contract settlement that will make them the highest paid inthe state and in most of the nation.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 21 --Senator Charles E. Goodell urged voters today to "teach Spiro Agnew a lessen on Nov. 3," but he stopped short of calling for the Vice President's removal from the G.O.P. ticket in 1972.

Lee Konitz, one of the hardy survivors of those turbulent days after World War II when jazz burst its traditional boundaries to explore what became known as be-bop and "cool" jazz, has turned up at the Half Note, Hudson and Spring Streets, where he will be playing through Saturday.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 21--Dr. Borlaug said here today he would use the $78,000 prize to further his research in richer strains of wheat to alleviate world hunger and "perhaps win another Nobel Prize."
NEW HAVEN, Oct. 21--Superior Court Judge Harold M. Mulvey today denied a defense motion to dismiss charges against Bobby G. Seale, and Ericka Huggins because of pretrial publicity.

Mayor Lindsay suggested yesterday that the state's private colleges and universities accept students admitted to the City University under the open-enrollment program, with the city paying their tuition.

The Socialist party of New York endorsed the state Democratic ticket of Arthur J. Goldberg and Basil A. Paterson yesterday as well as the Democratic candidate for the United States Senate Richard L. Ottinger.
Schulte Dieckhoff G.m.b.H., Horstmar, West Germany, which claims to be the world's largest producer of panty-hose, announced yesterday an aggressive program to enter the American panty-hose market.

Timely recognition has been given to the vital role of food in the world's search for peace by the award of the 1970 Nobel Peace Prize to American agriculturist, Dr. Norman Ernest Borlaug. Dr. Borlaug's pioneering work in developing better grains has been a key element in the "green revolution." It has brought new hope to the majority of the world's people, whose chronic hunger has posed a continuing threat to national and international stability.

KENT, Ohio, Oct. 21--The roundup of 25 persons indicted in connection with the Kent State University disorders continued to move slowly today. One young woman turned herself in and a Yippie was told by a clerk to "come back tomorrow" to find out if he had been indicted by the special state grand jury.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) --The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that it had imposed sanctions against seven former employes of McDonnell Co., Inc., a securities firm in liquidation once based in New York, for violations of Federal securities laws.

GARDEN CITY, Oct. 21 (UPI) --The 170,000-member International Brotherhood of Teamsters Joint Council 16 announced today that it was backing Ralph G. Caso, a Republican, in the race for Nassau County Executive.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21--Reports from Saigon that the United States and South Vietnam might announce a unilateral cease-fire in Vietnam before the end of the month drew a categorical denial today from the White House.

MONTREAL, Oct. 21--The Quebec Government announced today that some of the 369 persons arrested in raids since last Friday would be held without arraignment for the maximum period of 21 days permitted under wartime emergency powers invoked by the Federal Government following two political kidnappings and the slaying of one of the victims.

HOUSTON, Oct. 21--The ordinary white bread that most Americans eat every day was described by a scientist here today as being so low in nutritional value that laboratory rats living on it for 90 days died of malnutrition.

CHARENTON, La.--Carl Carline, a swamp Cajun by birth and upbringing and now at age 40 by preference, swallowed the thick coffee his wife had poured and talked about the place he loves, the Atchafalaya Swamp, and how it is dying.

Prices on the London Stock Exchange were firm yesterday although finishing off from their top levels.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 21 --Berthold H. Waldorf, executive vice president of Waldorf Equity Research, a New York investment management company, died yesterday in Greenwich Hospital after a short illness. He was 30 years old and lived at 12 Lindsay Drive.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21--President Nixon has announced plans for more extensive mid-term campaigning than any President has done. The record shows that in the twentieth century there are plenty of precedents for this effort, but few of them suggest that it is likely to be rewarding for the Republicans.
BRUSSELS, Oct. 21--The Belgian National Bank announced a cut in the bank rate today from 7 per cent to 7 per cent.

Mrs. Margaret Collins Carey, wife of Dennis J. Carey Sr., who with her husband founded the Peerless Oil Company (now the Petrochemicals Company), died Tuesday in Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals. She was 87 years odd and lived at 195 Adams Street, Brooklyn.

William DeKoning Jr., a former Long Island labor leader, was convicted in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday of violating a provision of the TaftHartley Act that bans the receipt of a gift by a union official from an employer.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Oct. 21 --Dave Davis, bidding to win this title for the third time in a seven-year professional bowling career, leads 23 others into tomorrow's semifinal round of the $75,000 National championship at Garden City Bowl.
The New York Post prepared yesterday to resume publication today for the first time since the Newspaper Guild went on strike Oct. 6. Guild members ratified a new contract Tuesday night.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 21 --Roosevelt Raceway's oldest pacing event, the $50,000 National Pacing Derby, will be presented for the 25th time Saturday at the Nassau County course. Greeff are co-chairmen for the event. Proceeds will go to the United States Ski Team Fund, which supports the development and continued training of young skiers and racers, who are America's Olympic hopefuls.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) --The Commerce Department said today new orders for durable goods in September declined by $900-million over the preceding month.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 22 Pennsylvania raised its season won-lost record to 10-0 in sweeping to victories today over Princeton and Columbia, by scores of 26-31 and 15-50, respectively, in a triangular Ivy League cross country meet. Princeton also downed the Lions, 15-50.

They see the United States moving from the present state of inflation and relative stagnation in real output to a sharply improved position in the years 1973-75. Then, they forecast, we will enjoy a growth rate of 4.3 per cent; unemployment will be held at 3.8 per cent; and annual price increases will be about 2 per cent.
The Metropolitan Championships of the Greater New Bridge Association begin today at the New York Hilton Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 The Environmental Defense Fund asked seven major airport authorities today to promulgate a rule now to bar future use of their runways by supersonic transports exceeding Federal noise levels for subsonic jets.
The jury in the trial of 13 Black Panthers spent yesterday afternoon reading an article in the party newspaper on how to make bombs and hand grenades.
NEW DELHI, Oct. 22 (UPI) A Foreign Ministry spokesman expressed displeasure today over the treatment accorded Prime Minister Indira Gandhi on her current trip to the United States.

By this time five days A.N.I. (after Namath's injury) one must wonder whether Al Woodall feels more pressure from the task facing him Sunday or from the endless questions everyone is asking him about how he'll face the task.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 Lawrence F. O'Brien, the Democratic National Chairman, accused the Nixon Administration today of converting the 1970 election into "a national tragedy" by using "the politics of fear" to divide the country.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 The Securities and Exchange Commission told the New York Stock Exchange today that the increased sales commissions the exchange had proposed on both the smallest and the largest sized stock transactions were "unreasonable."
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 22 (UPI) A nail-filled time bomb exploded outside a church today, as mourners gathered for the funeral of a policeman who had been killed in a bank holdup.
CAIRO, Ill., Oct. 22 (UPI) Gov. Richard B. Ogilvie authorized today additional state troopers to keep the peace in racially troubled Cairo where Mayor A.B. Thomas said a "revolution" was going on.

LIMA, Peru, Oct. 22 There is satisfaction as well as apprehension in the revolutionary military Government of Peru as her southern neighbor and traditional rival, Chile, prepares to certify a Marxist as President on Saturday.

NAPA, Calif., Oct. 22 Jack Montgomery of Fort Worth, Tex,. who is down at 115th place on the current money list, looked over his shoulder today at 155 other contestants as he led the $150,000 Kaiser International open golf tourney with a seven-under-par 65.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 The American Medical Association joined the Food and Drug Administration today in publicly suggesting that doctors be cautious in prescribing for their patients a widely used diabetes drug that is taken by mouth.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 22 The Environmental Defense Fund filed suit in United States District Court here today to stop the nation's largest maker of DDT from allegedly dumping large quantities of the pesticide into the ocean near the Los Angeles County sewerage system.
HOUSTON, Oct. 22 The Episcopal Church approved today a budget of $23.9-million for 1971, despite a projected deficit of more than $3-million this year in a $14-million budget.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 22 The Jordanian representative at the 25th anniversary session of the United Nations accused the United States today of helping and encouraging Israeli occupation of Jordanian territory.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa The swimming pool is no longer a sign of status here but rather a symbol of what is generally called "the South African way of life."
ATLANTA, Oct. 22 Politicians sparred along with the pugilists today in preparing for Monday night's heavyweight bout between Muhammad Ali, the returning champion, and Jerry Quarry.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22 (UPI) Third-period goals by Bobby Clarke, Jean Guy Gendron and Garry Peters gave the Philadelphia Flyers a 4-2 victory over the Buffalo Sabres tonight. Buffalo gained a 2-0 lead early in the first period on goals by Chriss Schmautz and Gil Perreault. Simon Nolet scored the Flyers' first goal at 11:35 of the first period.
GREAT NECK, L.I., Oct. 22 Miss Laurie Morris, a graduate student at New York University, will be married Nov. 21 to Lewis Novod, a senior at the N.Y.U. School of Law.

Gerald Arpino's "Secret Places," which looks misleadingly like a ballet for fewer than all seasons, has endured surprisingly well since its "Elvira Madigan" days. Two years ago, the use of the same Mozart concerto in the Swedish film and the new duet for the City Center Joffrey Ballet as well as their common young-love theme associated the two perhaps too closely with each other.

What do you remember about childhood? Where were you when your dreams were born, your trauma inflicted, your pattern set? This, I presume, is the theme of Eliot Feld's new ballet at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Called "A Poem Forgotten" and danced, of course, by Mr. Feld's American Ballet Company, this makes a most powerful and enduring impression.

Oil industry reports received yesterday for the third-quarter and nine-month periods continued to be evenly balanced between profit advances and declines.

Emperor Haile Selassie warned yesterday that the United Nations must be strengthened if it is to avoid the fate of the League of Nations.

DURHAM, N.C., Oct. 22 The Rev. Dr. William David Davies, George Washington Ivey Professor of Advanced Studies and Research in Christian Origins at Duke University, and Mrs. Davies have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rachel Mary Davies, to John Ogden Manter, son of Mrs. Florence Ogden Manter of Augusta, Ga., and the late Dr. John Tinkham Manter.

DETROIT, Oct. 22 The Chrysler and American Motors Corporations reported today that their mid-month car sales topped levels for a corresponding period last year. But the continuation of the strike at the General Motors Corporation means that the industry sales totals will trail the Oct. 11-20, 1969, total.
Newspaper machinists indirectly accepted a new contract with the city's newspapers yesterday when they did not muster suffiicent votes for a strike authorization.

SANTA CRUZ, Calif., Oct. 22 The Santa Cruz County District Attorney said tonight that a murder warrant had been issued and a nationwide search was under way for a suspect in the slaying last Monday of a wealthy eye surgeon and four other persons at his mountaintop estate five miles south of here.
President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania expressed hope yesterday for improved relations with the United States but also criticized American foreign policy.
BONN, Oct. 22 The West German Government announced adoption today of a package of price and wage guidelines designed to stabilize further this country's economy in 1971.

Neuberger Berman and Ralph E. Samuel Co., both member firms of the New York Stock Exchange, disclosed yesterday that they plan to consolidate, with Neuberger Berman as the surviving firm. Donald C. Samuel and Bernard Stein, principal partners of the Samuel firm, will become Neuberger partners on or about Dec. 1.

Prices on the London Stock Exchange closed narrowly mixed yesterday after slow trading.
Mayor Lindsay yesterday denounced the armed take-over of a church in East Harlem by the Young Lords as "deplorable and a sacrilege."

The New York Philharmonic is having a sentimental season, celebrating birthdays (Aaron Copland's 70th) and anniversaries. For every football coach in the world, the most important game ever played is the one coming up. The Union Carbide Corporation reported yesterday that its net income for the third quarter of this year dropped to $37,033,000, or 61 cents a share, from $43,751,000, or 72 cents a share in the 1969 period. Sales totaled $763,141,000, against $757,475,000 a year earlier.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 Three weeks after their spokesmen denounced the Vietnam war, members of an officers organization are facing armed forces retaliation, according to the dissenters.

The executive council of the two-million-member United Church of Christ recommended yesterday that "not less than 10 per cent" of its unrestricted funds, or about $1.3-million, be placed in high-risk, low-return investments with "maximum social impact."
Happy days were here again last night for Knick fans in the crowd of 16,244 at Madison Square Garden.

KENT, Ohio, Oct. 22 (UPI) A second student who was wounded last spring on the Kent State University campus when National Guardsmen fired into a group of demonstrating students was arrested today on an indictment of a special state grand jury.
LONDON, Oct 22 A new Sadler's Wells production of Handel's opera "Semele" was dramatically interrupted last night when the leading soprano was taken ill.

BOSTON, Oct. 23 (AP) Don Nelson capped a comeback with a 3-point play that broke a tie with 14 seconds left tonight as the Boston Celtics posted a 131-126 National Basketball Association victory over the Cincinnati Royals.

VANCOVER, British Columbia, Oct. 23 A week after the imposition of wartime emergency powers, Serious questions are being raised here about the longterm implications of the Government's decision on political life in Canada.

KENT, Ohio, Oct. 23 Some 4,000 students at Kent State University gathered on the Commons today for a quiet noon rally to protest the findings of a special state grand jury a weak ago. All regular classes were held today.

Mr. and Mrs. Milton J. Bomback of Neponsit, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ronnie Bomback, to Edward Alexander Grossman, son of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Grossman of Englewood, N.J.

William S. Ladd Jr., a hotel and airline representative, died yesterday in Peninsula General Hospital, Edgemere, Queens, after a long illness. He was 52 years old and lived at 136 Beach 138th Street, Belle Harbor, Queens.

President Nixon has signed the Merchant Marine Act of 1970 with the declaration that it would have "been easy" for him to have simply continued the 1936 subsidy program, but that he was determined to keep his campaign pledge to replace it with something better.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange turned slightly lower in quiet trading yesterday.

DAVAO, the Philippines, Oct. 23 (Reuters) The Philippine Red Cross said today that 1,109 people were killed by two typhoons that struck the country in the last 10 days and that 522,000 had been made homeless.

"I am the man," Mario A. Procaccino declared yesterday in commenting on a charge by Governor Rockefeller that a $70,000-a-year job had been offered to a prominent unidentified person in exchange for a campaign endorsement for Arthur J. Goldberg.

The Connecticut General Insurance Corporation said yesterday it expected "little more than nominal earnings" this year. It attributed the showing to severe group-health insurance losses and unfavorable property and casualty experience.
A portion of the proceeds from the ninth annual Daiquiri Ball for the benefit of the Girls Club of New York will go toward flood relief in Puerto Rico.

The American Stock Exchange revealed yesterday that its board of governors had voted to discipline F.L. Salomon Co. and two of its partners, Burton W. Blank and Benjamin Marks, for violations of exchange rules in handling a block transaction.
ATLANTA, Oct. 23 "Champ," a man asked today, "have you ever been seared?"
A strong demand, supplemented by short covering, sent soybean, corn and wheat futures higher yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (Reuters) The United States' gold stock declined by $323million last month to $11.49billion, the Treasury reported today. The drop in September follows a net decline of $117-million in August.
WATERTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 24 Mr. Buckley said today that he was "confident" of winning the election on Nov. 3.

Mrs. Fontaine Rasmussen, daughter of Robert V. Rasmussen of Palm Beach, Fla., and Antioch, Ill., retired chairman of the board of the National Tea Company of Chicago, was married Monday in Elkton, Md., to Lewis R. Petta, a specialist on the American Stock Exchange here. The civil ceremony was performed in the Elkton Courthouse.
TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 23 Two groups of black residents are competing for control of a parcel of urban-renewal land in a heavily black neighborhood of the Westchester County town of Greenburgh.

SOLVAY, N.Y., Oct. 23 Governor Rockefeller confirmed tonight that Mr. Procaccino was indeed the unnamed person he had referred to in his remarks yesterday in New York City. After an appearance at a Republican rally in this small town near Syracuse, the Governor was asked if Mr. Procaccino was the unnamed man.

To a child, a pumpkin is Halloween; to a cook, it's the makings of a spicy cake. And for those who perefer to take their pumpkin as jack-o-lanterns, but do like spices, there's another recipe for a moist raisin cake.

Bruno Sammartino, weighing in at 265 pounds, rallied after being thrown from the ring three times to defeat Bepo Mongol, 315, after 14 minutes 30 seconds in a Texas-style wrestling exhibition at Madison Square Garden last night. Six weeks ago in the same ring, Mongol won on a technicality from Sammartino.

The city's high schools are badly in need of reform. Educational concepts and personal attitudes cry out for change. Physically, the schools are dehumanized by intolerable overcrowding that aggravates the disadvantages inherent in their excessive size.

Gabriel Chodos, a young pianist who recently joined the Dartmouth College faculty, made his New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall on Thursday night as a winner of the Concert Artists Guild competition. His program consisted of Beethoven's Variations in F (Op. 34), Jon Appleton's Sonata No. 2 (1968), Bartok's Sonata and Schumann's Fantasy (Op. 17).
BUFFALO, Oct. 23 (AP) Ron Anderson's unassisted goal with just over six minutes left gave the Buffalo Sabres a 4-3 victory over the Detroit Red Wings tonight in a National Hockey League game.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23? Years of research into the nature of penicillin allergy has led to a promising quick test to predict severe bad reactions to that widely used drug. Presently available tests are not considered very dependable.

NOVI SAD, Yugoslavia To pose the question of why a man who creates novels, songs, poems, music or paintings is considered the potential enemy of the social system under which he lives seems strange to me. No one who lives in a totalitarian society such as, say, the Chinese or the Soviet, would ask the question. It is clear without any explanation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (UPI) Transportation Secretary John A. Volpe extended today hourly landing and takeoff quotas for another year at four major airports, including Kennedy and LaGuardia. He said that on the average the quotas had cut traffic delays by 30 per cent.

WILTON, Conn., Oct. 23 In the dimly lighted room, thick with incense, the young people stood in a semicircle, erect as fence posts. Eyes closed, they held their hands with palms pressed together in prayer.
A strike by three unions shut down the Long Island Railroad for 10 hours yesterday.
MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 23-A Long Island clothing executive, Jay T. Pobliner, was found guilty late tonight of first degree murder in the slaying of his wife, Brenda, in their Merrick home in 1968.

Joe Foy, who was supposed to solve all the Met third-base problems when acquired from Kansas City a year ago in exchange for Amos Otis, was sold outright to the Met farm club at Tidewater in the International League yesterday.
Puerto Rican families, beset by widespread unemployment on their home island, are migrating to the mainland in record numbers this year. Most have settled in New York.

President Nixon's challenge to the Soviet Union to build detente by "a series of actions," not just a superficial change in atmosphere, voices publicly the deep concern stirred in the West by Moscow's recent power moves. The central question raised by Russia's baffling behavior, which Mr. Nixon and Secretary Rogers evidently have put to Foreign Minister Gromyko, now has been laid before the forum of world opinion at the United Nations.

Guests who contribute a minimum of $700 will attend the 50th anniversary luncheon for advance gifts donors of the women's organization of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York at the Pierre Tuesday.

Last year Random House offered, with some trepidation, a $375 Christmas book "Alice in Wonderland" illustrated by Salvador Dali and easily sold the entire run of 2,500 copies. George Washington High School will be closed to students again on Monday, the Board of Education announced yesterday.
The Royal Vancouver Yacht Club of Canada and Club d'Hyeres of France have presented challenges for the America's Cup in 1973, if was announced yesterday by the New York Yacht Club.

The Equity Library Theater occasionally revives a big musical by cutting it down to size. SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 23 Followers of Dr. Salvador Allende today canceled plans to hold victory celebrations tomorrow following his expected election as President of Chile.

But everything seemed so much smoother this time. The principals, of course, have by now worked themselves into their roles, and the orchestra is completely relaxed and responsive to Julius Rudel's beat.

HANOI, North Vietnam, Oct. 23 (Agence France-Presse) A North Vietnamese commentator predicted today that President Nixon would "intensify and extend" the Vietnam war once next month's congressional elections in the United States were out of the way.

A manufacturer of technical equipment filed a suit in Federal Court here yesterday charging the nation's major automobile companies with a conspiracy to delay and monopolize air-pollution-control devices for motor vehicles.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 23 Troops of the Americal Division have violated a Pentagon order by continuing to use a chemical defoliant identified as a factor in animal birth defects, the United States command said today.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 23 (AP) Roberto Clemente of the Pittsburgh Pirates was cheered last night when he made his managerial debut in the Puerto Rican winter league, but eight innings later, after he made his first strategic move, the boos were louder than the cheers.

SAN JUAN, Tex. Oct. 23 (UPI) A pilot deliberately crashed his small plane into the Shrine of San Juan Roman Catholic Church at noon today, sending 130 children, women and priests fleeing from the burning ruins.

VUNGTAU, South Vietnam, Oct. 23 (AP) President Nguyen Van Thieu and South Vietnam's top military and political leaders mapped strategy today for a ceasefire or a prolonged Indochina war, Gathered for an extraordinary conference in this coastal resort city about 40 miles southeast of Saigon, the South Vietnamese leaders dis cussed what actions they would take if the Viet Cong accepted President Nixon's Oct.7 peace proposal.
SUMMIT, N.J., Oct. 23 Louis H.F. Mouquin, an insurance executive, died today in Overlook Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 141 Oak Ridge Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 The United States has agreed to provide Israel with about 180 modern tanks as part of almost $500-million in assistance designed to maintain the balance of power in the Middle East, Pentagon sources said today.

LONDON, Oct. 23 Meeting of the sixth form class in Current Affairs, Canonbtary, Comprehensive School, London.

MEDIA, Pa., Oct. 23 Judge George A. Welsh of the Federal Court of the Eastern District of Pennsylvania and a former Representative, died yesterday at his home here. His age was 92.

Alfred Andersch's "Efraim's Book" is a novel about nothing. The credit markets face another history-making week of financing activity as Federal and local governments and corporations continue to seek record amounts of funds.
The 1970 mid-term election has become a characteristic Nixon effort.
NOUAKCHOTT, Mauritania Oct. 16 Copper and iron are beginning to change this dusty wilderness, but the change is as slow as the camel caravans that roam its desert.

MERRICK, L.I., Oct. 25 Miss Susana Lannik, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William M. Lannick, was married here this noon to Mark Gorstein, son of Mrs. Vladimir Gorstein of New York and the late Mr. Gorstein.
As the 1970 tax year draws to a close, investors have some double-trouble planning. Is this the year to take capital gains or losses?

CRESTON, Iowa As Roger Blobaum sat hurriedly spooning down a bowl of chicken noodle soup one night recently in the Holiday Inn restaurant in Ottumwa, about 100 miles east of here in Iowa's sprawling Fourth Congressional District, a dusty dark blue 1967 Oldsmobile station wagon pulled into the parking lot outside.
Bus service for more than 29,000 school children, including 3,000 physically handicapped pupils, was to be interrupted this morning by a strike against the City Wide Transportation Company.
LUCERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 25 (AP)-- The male voters of the Swiss canton of Lucerne today voted 25,170 to 14,781 to grant women the right to vote and be elected to public office.

BARCELONA, Spain, Oct. 25 (Reuters) Manuel Santana of Spain scored today one of his finest triumphs since winning the 1966 Wimbledon title when he beat Rod Laver, the world's top-ranked player, and took Spain's first open tennis championship.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 25 Dr. Raymond G. Walters, president of the University of Cincinnati from 1932 to 1955, died today at Drake Memorial Hospital. Dr. Walters, who lived in suburban Clifton, was 85 years old.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., Oct. 25 Two neighbors in the elegant Greenfield Hills section here, who have been friends since boyhood, are locked in a close race for Connecticut's Fourth Congressional District seat being vacated by the Republican candidate for the Senate, Lowell P. Weicker Jr.

TEL AVIV, Oct. 25 An El Al Israel jet airliner flying Premier Golda Meir to the United States last week nearly collided with an Israel Air Force plane over Tel Aviv, it was said today by the civilian pilots.
The New Jersey Republican candidate for the United States Senate vowed yesterday, if elected, to try to see that his state received a fair share of Federal funds.
Arthur J. Goldberg accused Governor Rockefeller yesterday of resorting to "demagoguery and mud-slinging" in the gubernatorial election campaign.

Joseph C. Ingraham, a writer on automotive and traffic news for The New York Times, died Saturday night in University Hospital after a heart attack. He was 65 years old and lived at 303 West 66th Street.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 25 An all-white Baptist congregation, divided for months in a controversy over the membership application of a black woman and her daughter, split apart here today with a decision by the applicants' supporters to resign and form a new congregation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) About 2.5 million workers engaged in 5,035 strikes for a loss of 41.5 million man-days of production time so far in 1970, the Government said today. It was the highest work loss of any corresponding period in the last 10 years.
KANSAS CITY, Oct. 25 The Dallas Cowboys, all but interred by their fans after losing, 54-13, to Minnesota last Sunday, came back to life today and beat the champions, the Kansas City Chiefs, 27-16.

SEBRING, Fla., Oct. 25 (AP) Mark Donahue of Media, Pa., started on the pole, held the lead for 99 miles today and won the L. and M. Grand Prix Formula A continental championship sports car race. His average speed was 122.255 miles an hour.
LONDON, Oct. 25 The British Government has openly entered the battle to prevent the United States Congress from passing the protectionist trade bill before it.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 25--The Israeli Cabinet today branded the debate on the Middle East opening tomorrow in the United Nations General Assembly as a move by the Soviet Union and Egypt "to sabotage the possibility of holding peace talks."

CANAL WINCHESTER, Ohio, Oct. 25-- Miss Barbara Bonner, who is studying for a master's degree in art history at Queens College, was married at her parents' home here today to Jonathan Michael Marks, a lawyer with the New York firm of Townley, Updike, Carter and Rogers. The ceremony was performed by Lancaster Municipal Court Judge S. Farrell Jackson.
Two Brooklyn patrolmen were shot and critically wounded last night while responding to a report of a holdup at 1041 Winthrop Street, on the border of East Flatbush and Brownsville.
POPULATION About 540,000 largely middle and highincome, but some also in the lower ranges; primarily white Anglo-Saxon families with some of Italian and Eastern European heritage.

New orders for American machine tools rose 43.5 per cent in September from the August level, but there was little cheering among tool builders. As one industry spokesman remarked, "The August orders were at a disaster level. We rebounded in September to the recession level."
Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy indicated yesterday that he would increase the size of the police unit that deals with departmental discipline and investigates charges of corruption.

WEXFORD, Ireland, Oct. 25 Imagine, summoning up all your resources of fantasy, that President Nixon has uncovered a plot by members of his own Administration to smuggle guns to French-speaking elements in Canada. Criminal charges are brought against Secretary of the Treasury Kennedy and three others. After a long trial all the defendants are acquitted. Crowds carry Secretary Kennedy through the streets, demanding that he take over leadership of the Republican party.

Henryk Szeryng is an elegant violinist, and the members of I Solisti di Zagreb form a most polished chamber ensemble. When musicians of this caliber join forces, as they did Saturday night at Hunter College, the musical results are bound to be special.
LONDON, Oct. 25 Detective Superintendent George Smith, who broke up some of the biggest postwar Soviet spy operations in Britain, died yesterday in a Bath hospital. He was 65 years old.

HONG KONG, Oct. 25 Deputy Premier Li Hsien-nien of Communist China praised yesterday the refusal of President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia to meet with President Nixon in Washington last Monday, Hsinhua, the Chinese press agency, said today.

The Bank of Tokyo Trust Company announced today the start up of its electronic data processing and communication system which will ultimately link up and integrate its bank-... ing operations across the United States with the parent company, The Bank of Tokyo, Ltd. (Tokyo).
The appointment of seven vice presidents of the CibaGeigy Corporation, the newly merged chemical company, was announced over the weekend by Otto Strurzenegger, president and chief executive officer.
How one major multiagency advertiser is getting into the act was outlined in a speech by Robert A. Dobbin, director of advertising and marketing services of Best Foods.

In the 15 years since he made this American debut, Emil Gilels, the Soviet pianist, has covered a sizable cross-section of the repertory for his instrument, but at Philharmonic Hall on Saturday night he played his first all-Mozart recital here. The occasion was the opening of the 1970-71 Hurok International Series, and he made it a special one, indeed.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Oct. 25 After the University of Illinois football team had repeated its threat to boycott practice tomorrow, the Athletic Board today backed down and reinstated Jim Valek as coach for the four remaining games of the season.
MILWAUKEE, Oct. 25 (AP) Lew Alcindor scored 37 points and Bob Dandridge added 24 tonight as the Milwaukee Bucks downed the Seattle SuperSonics, 127-107, in a National Basketball Association game.

PARIS, Oct. 25 (UPI)--France, West Germany and the Netherlands have pledged to drop United States-made General Electric jet engines in favor of Rolls-Royce of England if the British rejoin the $500-million European airbus project, the weekly news magazine Express said today.
The reaction to Al Woodall's first start at quarterback for the Jets yesterday was optimistic, perhaps an attempt at confidence building.
American, British and Canadian scientists have collaborated in the discovery of a new means of radioactive disintegration proton decay.

Without Joe Namath, without Matt Snell, without even Emerson Boozer in the last quarter and with Al Woodall making his debut at quarterback the New York Jets lost to the Buffalo Bills at Shea Stadium vesterday, 10-6.
The city is urging elderly people who are eligible to file applications for exemption from the rent increases that went into effct last Aug. 1.

Often during the recent chess Olympiad in Siegen, West Germany, Grandmaster Pal Benko of New York scored brilliantly by an unexpected sacrifice in the middle game. In the Reti Opening, against Higashi of Japan, the American's winning maneuver was a two-part venture.
A "Northern strategy" against the Nixon Administration was outlined yesterday by the Rev. Joseph D. Duffey, the Democratic candidate for the seat now held by Senator Thomas J. Dodd of Connecticut.

The Maria Moors Cabot Prizes for inter-American journalism will be awarded Thursday at Columbia University to John M. Goshko of The Washington Post, John D. Harbron of The Toronto Telegram and Alberto Dines of The Jornal do Brazil of Rio de Janeiro.
WATERBURY, Conn., Oct. 25 Running for Congress from Connecticut's Fifth District is familiar stuff to the Democratic incumbent John S. Monagan, and James T. Patterson, his republican challenger.

HOUSTON, Oct. 25 At least one typhoid carrier and poor sanitation caused an epidemic of 56 cases of typhoid fever, including one death, among passengers and crew of the cruise ship Oronsay earlier this year, a Canadian health official reported here today.

Despite its status as musical standard bearer for our nation's capital, the National Symphony Orchestra of Washington has never been first in the hearts of orchestral music lovers, or near there: Now, with Antal Dorati in his first season as music director, the National Symphony is making serious efforts to rise in the world. That will take time, work and infusions of money, not to mention talent.
The miracle for dog fanciers happened on 34th Street yesterday when the Progressive Dog Club returned to Manhattan after an absence of more than two decades.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 25 The Khmer Soviet Friendship Hospital, not far from Premier Lon Nol's house, has become a principal center for the people wounded in the Cambodian war.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct. 25--An Iowa farm boy who earned a Bachelor of Science degree in college and worked as a chemical engineer until theology got the upper hand is the new president of the American Lutheran Church. He is the Rev. Dr. Kent Sigvart Knutson, the 46-year-old ...

VENTNOR, Isle of Wight, Oct. 25 (AP) Fire fighters today extinguished the flames that for 41 hours had ravaged the grounded tanker, Pacific Glory, but oil seepage raised new fears of pollution of beaches.

"Christmas business? A better question is will there be a Christmas season this year," snapped a top executive of one of the country's best-known department store chains. With a painful laugh he said, "Business is so different right now that it's hard to visualize that we will have a holiday season." He rang off with an admonition to hope for the best.
Max Reich, for 47 years a professor at the New York Law School, died Saturday evening in Brooklyn Jewish Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at 706 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn. He retired in 1968.

It took only a few measures for Guus Hoekman to proclaim his uncommonly expressive vocal gifts. The silver-haired Dutch bass was making his New York recital debut at Tully Hall on Saturday night, and the glowing initial impression was reinforced throughout his intriguingly unhackneyed program.

Although they are running under different party labels Governor Rockefeller and James L. Buckley are apparently viewed as running mates by a substantial proportion of New York voters, according to a statewide survey of voter attitudes.
Caution in consumer spending, more than any other single factor, is keeping the pace of general economic activity "relatively subdued," the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company said yesterday.

HOUSTON, Oct. 25 (UPI) Marilynn Smith had birdies on two of the last four holes for a 69 today and tied Sandra Haynie and Mrs. Judy Rankin for first place in the $17,500 Women's Charities open at 214.

Major structural changes in the securities industry are likely to occur as a result of the proposal by the Securities and Exchange Commission to abolish fixed commission rates on all transactions of $100,000 or more.

PORTLAND, Me., Oct. 24 As a token of appreciation from the Lewiston-Auburn Rotary Club, 82-year-old Harry W. Rowe the other day presented Senator Edmund S. Muskie with a pine bough to carry as the Senator set forth on his "task of making the nation smell better."
The new chairman of the city's watchdog Board of Correction said yesterday he would seek to "reduce the prison population quickly intelligently, not indiscriminately."

GREAT NECK, L.I, Oct. 25--Mrs. Betty Polisar Schwartz and Jack Reigot were married here this evening at the home of the bride's aunt, Mrs. Joshua Emmer. The ceremony was performed by Arthur Dobrin, leader of the Ethical Humanist Society in Garden City.

NAPA, Calif., Oct. 25-- Ken Still won a playoff for the $30,000 first prize in the $150,000 Kaiser Open golf tourney today by beating Lee Trevino and Bert Yancey with a birdie on the first extra hole.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 25--Highly placed sources said today that United States Special Forces troops leading clandestine operations in Laos had suffered casualties in recent months that never had been made public.

Many Americans, in and out of Congress, will be shocked to learn that the United States for the last ten years has been committed to oppose any threat to the territorial integrity of Ethiopia. This 1960 pledge by the Eisenhower Administration has been brought to light by a Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee investigating American overseas commitments.

Among intellectual snobs the Reader's Digest may be considered cornball but no magazine can match its 17.75-million domestic circulation. And few, can match its advertising sales force for aggressive ingenuity.

WATCHUNG, N.J. Plans for a one-day deer hunt on Dec. 19 in the Great Swamp Wildlife Refuge Wilderness have aroused the indignation of a small but vocal group of animal lovers who believe that the hunt is unnecessary and poorly conceived.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 25 Some 5,000 San Franciscans, their children and pets marched along the waterfront today to declare their dislike of what they think of as New York architecture.

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 25--Rick Barry was back on the sidelines tonight, but the New York Nets continued winning as they beat the Pittsburgh Condors, 115-98, in an American Basketball Association game at Island Garden.
A 17-member committee of public and private college and university officials was appointed yesterday to advise the Legislature on policy affecting higher education.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 President Nixon conferred at the White House today with six foreign heads of state and government then flew to his Camp David retreat in Maryland to rest overnight and prepare for another round of personal diplomacy here tomorrow.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Oct. 25 (AP) Gary Player of South Africa held off a last-round challenge by Australia's Bruce Devlin today to win his sixth Australian open golf championship.
Steve Sandler retained his United States one-wall handball title yesterday by topping Mike Dikman of the Elks Club of Queens, 21-9, 21-9, at the Brownsville Recreation Center in Brooklyn.
ATLANTA, Oct. 25 After an exile of 3 years, Muhammad Ali, sport's most controversial showman, will return to boxing tomorrow night against Jerry Quarry for the world's invisible heavyweight title.

Bill Nelsen, the quarterback who came to the Cleveland Browns from the Pittsburgh Steelers at the end of 1967 with two pain-worn knees and a reputation of erratic play, was at his best yesterday. Benched last week while his team lost to Detroit, Nelsen bounced back and picked apart the Dolphins to win, 28-0, in a National Football League American conference game at Miami.
MONTREAL, Oct. 25-- Jean Drapeau won a fourth term as mayor of Montreal by a landslide vote today.

LIMA, Peru, Oct. 24 The Anaconda Company, whose major mining operations are in leftist-moving Chile, is striving to activate its unworked properties in Peru by sharing its holdings with the military Government here and Japanese interests.
CAIRO, Oct. 25 The United Arab Republic was reported today to be ready to extend for two months the 90-day cease-fire along the Suez Canal.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 25 Dr. Kofi A. Busia, the Prime Minister of Ghana, has disclosed that his nation will seek a rescheduling of its massive foreign debts now totaling more than $800-million at an international meeting of its creditors next year.

If football is a microcosm of life, as some philosophers suggest, the country must be overshifting its defenses to the right, or blitzing administrators from the blind side. How else can one assess these unusual events in last week's college football program.

Outstanding bankers' acceptances fell in September for the first time in seven months, reflecting a large drop in bills created to finance third-country trade, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported over the weekend.

Returning to the ring after a three-and-a-half-year absence, Muhammad Ali stopped Jerry Quarry in their heavyweight bout in Atlanta last night. Quarry suffered a cut over his left eye and the referee, despite the Californian's protests, would not let him come out for the fourth round.
MOSCOW, Oct. 26 The Soviet Union protested to the United States and Turkey today over the incursion into Soviet airspace by an American Army plane that landed in Soviet Armenia last week.
"I don't know whether Goodell really thought about quitting," an important New York Republican said yesterday, "but I do know he had to do something desperate and dramatic and he did it rather well."
A juror at the trial of 13 Black Panthers here inadvertently locked a pair of handcuffs on his right wrist yesterday, causing adjournment a half hour early.
HIALEAH, Fla., Oct. 26-President Nixon will come to Florida tomorrow in an attempt to rescue two Republicans who are in trouble.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Oct. 26 (AP) About 1,400 fans were disappointed tonight when the closed-circuit telecast of the Muhammad Ali Jerry Quarry fight was "blacked out" at the Grenada Theater.

LONDON, Oct. 26 (Reuters) Gold prices hit new peaks for this year in the gold markets of London, Zurich and Beirut today with gains varying between 35 and 95 cents an ounce. There was a fairly heavy demand in all the markets although not all from the same buying source.
BERLIN, Oct. 26 The Big Four powers have agreed to resume on Nov. 4 their talks aimed at improving the situation in Berlin, an American spokesman announced today.
Charges against checking accounts in New York City banks declined in September by 2.1 per cent from the August level to $4.67-trillion, the Federal Reserve reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 The Federal Trade Commission, in what it called "a delicate experiment," has permitted a group of law students to intervene on behalf of consumers in a contested case.
TOKYO (Reuters) Japanese men still line up at the marriage bureaus but in many cases the women aren't there.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Oct. 26 Rain changed the name of the game here tonight as the Minnesota Vikings turned back the Los Angeles Rams, 13-3, before a wet crowd of 47,900 at Metropolitan Stadium.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 26 (AP) Arthur F. Wollenhaupt, former president and treasurer of the Poughkeepsie Newspapers, Inc., died yesterday at Vassar Hospital. He was 67 years old.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 26 (AP) The Army command in Saigon has recommended that an American general be stripped of the nation's third highest award for valor in combat because it was based on a fabricated citation.
HOT SPRINGS, Va. Oct. 26 The Association of National Advertisers got right down to business this morning as it began its three-day meeting by electing two former agency men to its top posts.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 A former Government specialist on Asia said today that allied intervention in Cambodia had made it "almost impossible" to negotiate a Vietnam settlement in Paris without enlarging the talks to deal with Cambodia and Laos as well.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct. 26 The fifth general convention of the American Lutheran Church began debate today on proposed major structural changes within the denomination, including use of the title "Bishop."

Daniel H. Lewis, chairman of the executive committee, vice chairman and corporate creative director of D'Arcy Advertising Company, is out.

Three weeks after the murder of one of the defendants in a Teamsters Union pension fund kickback case, a jury trial of 11 men accused of carrying out a bribery scheme through organized crime councils in New York, Detroit, and Pittsburgh began in Federal Court here yesterday.

Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy accepted the resignation of First Deputy Commissioner John F. Walsh yesterday and immediately appointed William H.T. Smith to the powerful job, whose prime responsibility is combating police corruption.
George Washington High School, which has been closed for more than a week because of student disorders, will be reopened this morning but only for seniors.
ATLANTA, Oct. 26 (UPI) Jerry Quarry sat in his dressing room with 11 stitches above his left eye and agreed that his fight with Muhammad Ali should have been stopped.
DARIEN, Conn., Oct. 26 John Clement Gledhill, a former New York insurance executive, died yesterday at his home on Contentment Island, off Darien in Long Island Sound. He was 92 years old.
Two lots of dynamite were found within an hour and a half yesterday in Brooklyn's Bushwick and Park Slope sections.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 A scientists' organization labeled today as "scare tactics" an extensive advertising campaign by the American Security Council asserting that the Soviet Union had taken the lead in strategic nuclear weaponry from the United States.

Alexander Schneider is, by ordinary standards, no conductor at all. He sat at a music stand facing a chamber orchestra in the New School Auditorium on Sunday night, occasionally lending a hand with his fiddle, leaping to his feet momentarily to punctuate a phrase by a sweep of his bow or otherwise indicating, in unorthodox ways that would get him thrown out of many a conducting class, how the music should go.

Trading was dull on the London Stock Exchange yesterday and prices were generally lower. Lagging sales were attributed to prospective buyers' preoccupation with what the Government will say about public expenditure in a report expected today.

A visiting European expert teamed with an old friend in the Swiss team championship of the Greater New York Bridge Association's Metropolitan Tournament at the New York Hilton Sunday, and proceeded to capture the title, heading a field of 92 teams.
MEMPHIS, Oct. 26 (AP) The Virginia Squires, led by George Carter's 26 points, won their sixth straight American Basketball Association game tonight, beating the Memphis Pros, 120-103.

RALEIGH, N.C., Oct. 26 Vice President Agnew, campaigning in the Carolinas, pledged today that the Nixon Administration would put a Southerner on the Supreme Court, stand with the South behind neighborhood schools and protect the region's textile industry.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 26 An unusual set of endorsements has helped Wilson C. Riles gain ground in his campaign to unseat Dr. Max Rafferty as State Superintendent of Public Instruction, but Mr. Riles is still far behind.

It is easy for the city's restive taxpayers to boil at the disclosure that nearly $500,000 in annual wage increases is being given to 300 professional employes in municipal agencies just when Mayor Lindsay has been warning that "payless paydays" may be needed to keep the city from bankruptcy. In truth, however, the two positions are much less contradictory than they seem.
BUFFALO, Oct. 26 (AP) State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said today that he had asked the courts to close the Mobil Oil refinery in Buffalo for polluting the Buffalo River.

Best Co., the Fifth-Avenue based chain of specialty stores that recently announced it would cease operations, expects its final closing date will be Monday, Nov. 16, Jack Schwadron, president, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 The United States surplus of exports over imports declined in September for the second consecutive month after a strong showing in the MayJuly period, the Commerce Department reported today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) President Nixon signed today a $1.7-billion military construction bill for the current fiscal year.
MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Oct. 26 Henry P. Wherry, a mining engineer, died today in a nursing home after a long illness. He was 90 years old and had lived in Middlebury since 1948.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 26 The father of four very athletic sons, Paul Anthony Samuelson finds himself rushing one of them with a concussion or lacerations to a hospital emergency room about three Saturdays a year.

The performance on Nov. 1 of the Jose Molinas Bailes Espanoles at Carnegie Hall will benefit the Girls and Boys Service League. The cast will attend a reception later at the Spanish Institute at 684 Park Avenue.

The Federal Aviation Administration proposed regulations yesterday designed to tightened Federal safety standards on aircraft used by colleges to carry athletic teams or other groups. The agency also moved to tighten Federal rules on certain other groups that operate planes, including real estate promoters who offer free trips to land developments.

DETROIT, Oct. 26 (AP) The Detroit Pistons established a club record for consecutive victories tonight when they trounced the Seattle SuperSonics, 142-111, for their eighth victory without a loss in the National Basketball Association season.

Abraham Verbell, a supervisory inspector with the Customs Service, died Saturday evening, apparently of a heart attack. He was 67 years old and lived at 67-71 Yellowstone Boulevard, Forest Hills, Queens.

BEDFORD, N.Y., Oct. 26-George Edward Faithfull of Mianus River Road, a New York patent lawyer long active in civic affairs here, died yesterday in Northern Westchester Hospital after a long illness. His age was 66.
ALBANY, Oct. 26 Arthur J. Goldberg opened the final week of his campaign for Governor today by charging that the South Mall state office building complex here was "a billiondollar blunder."

Ohio Wesleyan University has 80 athletes on its football roster. Last Friday, however, when the school began a twoweek election recess, Coach Jack Fouts had to trim 27 members temporarily from the team.

Noting a "resurgence of the kinds of complaints we haven't been getting in years," the incoming executive director of the New York chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union expressed alarm yesterday at a "growing trend of political purges of teachers."

WESTFIELD, N.J., Oct. 26 Harry J. Seelig of 728 West South Avenue, who retired in 1954 as payroll supervisor for the Home Insurance Company in New York, died today at Muhlenberg Hospital, Plainfield. His age was 81.
LONDON, Oct. 26 The financial future for British commercial aircraft and aircraft engines will be decisively influenced by Government decisions in the next few days.

HOUSTON, Oct. 26 (UPI) Marilynn Smith won a threeway playoff with Sandra Haynie and Mrs. Judy Rankin today with a birdie 3 on the first extra hole to capture the $17,500 Women's Charities open at the Inwood Forest Country Club.

The State Mediation Board has intervened in the threatened strike of Off Broadway actors and stage managers, which is scheduled for next Monday, when the current three-year production contract expires.

A Federai judge refused yesterday to block the elections next Tuesday in the 18th Congressional District, where Representative Adam Clayton Powell is contesting his narrow defeat by Charles B. Rangel in last June's Democratic primary.

The first National Conference on Citizens Rights in Broadcasting heard itself assailed yesterday by representatives of minorities, who said they had had enough of conferences and "intellectualizing" and that it was time for those anxious to democratize television to stop conferring and to begin acting.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 26 Five countries were elected today to two-year terms on the United Nations Security Council.

HOUSTON, Oct. 26 New York City women conceive more babies in the fall than at any other time of year, three Health Department officials reported here today in a statistical study that they said suggested the existence of a natural biological clock for human conception.
CLEVES, West Germany, Oct. 26 West Germany's first criminal trial involving charges of large, deliberate polluting of inland waterways opened here today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 What a vigorous political campaign is being waged by President Nixon and Vice President Spiro ("Jim") Agnew! Between them, they are everywhere, nailing down the winning position on every issue and having the last word on every network and front page, as well as the first word, the all-important middle word and all the words slightly to the right of middle.

The Western Union Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in revenues and net income for the first nine months of this year. Revenues rose to $299-million from $289million a year earlier. Net income was $17.5-million, or $1.71 a share, compared with $17.4-million, or $1.86 a share on fewer shares, in the nine months ended Sept. 30, 1969. There were 9,039,353 shares outstanding in the 1970 period and 8,258,978 a year earlier.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26-President Nixon ordered today that all Federal vehicles must be operated on low-lead or unleaded gasoline wherever practical, and he asked the Governors of all the states to use the same restriction with state-owned vehicles.

The 1970 Nobel Memorial Prize in economic science has been awarded to Prof. Paul A. Samuelson of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Although most widely known as the author of the world's best-selling economics textbook, as an economic adviser to President Kennedy and as a witty but rather off-handed magazine columnist, Professor Samuelson, in the judgment of many colleagues, is the world's greatest pure economic theorist.

Seven Republican Senators, part of a group of 20 who announced their support for Charles E. Goodell, fanned out across the state yesterday to praise their embattled colleague and try to blunt the attacks of Vice President Agnew.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 The White House announced today that President Nixon signed last night an act authorizing $463million in appropriations over three years to help states and cities plan and construct systems for solid waste disposal and recovery.
