The largest groups are Puerto Rican, Italian, Greek, black and Jewish.

CHICAGO A growing number of middle-and upper-income apartment dwellers across the country are following the lead of the poor in organizing to protest rising rents, shoddy maintenance and what they consider a legal imbalance in favor of landlords.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 28 (AP) Janis Joplin, the blues singer, died from an accidental overdose of heroin, the Los Angeles County coroner's office said today.
Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy told New York's top police officials yesterday to rid their commands of corruption or face demotion.

Ramon S. Velez, head of the major antipoverty program in the largely Puerto Rican area of the South Bronx, charged yesterday that he had been undergoing city and Federal investigations and "harassment" since he ran and lost in a Democratic Congressional primary, fight.
LONDON, Oct. 28 A new program of aid for poor families, somewhat resembling President Nixon's family-assistance plan, was announced today by Prime Minister Heath's Government.

The least you can say of the Brooklyn Academy of Music is that it is adventurous. Last night the Chelsea Theater Center of Brooklyn (New York's solitary professional dramatic theater outside of Manhattan) opened its sixth season with the New York premiere of Edward Bond's play "Saved."
TORONTO, Oct. 28 (Canadian Press) The Toronto-Dominian Bank announced today it would lower its prime interest rate on loans to 7 percent from 8 per cent effective Sunday.
When Richard Derecktor Schwartz was appointed to a teaching post at Northwestern University in 1961, a colleague named Harry V. Ball described him as "the best sociologist of law in the country."
The National Chorale and a group of about 300 schoolchildren gave a special concert for each other on a recent morning at Hunter College Assembly Hall.
DETROIT, Oct. 28 The General Motors Corporation, closed by a strike since Sept. 14, showed a net loss of about $77-million, or 28 cents a share, in the third quarter of 1970.
Two Soviet astronauts who hold the endurance record of 18 days in space said yesterday that they would welcome joint United States-Soviet flights, according to The Associated Press.

Officials of the First Spanish Methodist Church denied yesterday that they had been negotiating to sell the church building to the Young Lords, a militant group that has occupied the church for 11 days. The administrative board of the church said the property, at 1llth Street and Lexington Avenue, "is not for sale."

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 28 King Hussein of Jordan tonight appointed a new Cabinet under Premier Wasfi el-Tal with instructions to carry out recent agreements with Palestinian commandos and to seek closer relations with Jordan's Arab neighbors in order to strengthen the Arab "eastern front" against Israel. The Cabinet, the third an six weeks, replaces the Government of Premier Ahmed Toukan.

STOCKHOLM, Oct. 28 United States officials, seeking to strengthen their Government's shaky relations with Sweden, are convinced that the outpouring of anti-Americanism in recent years among students, radicals and politicians has steadily declined in the last few months.

The New York Times Company is acquiring a number of properties from Cowles Communications, Inc., it was announced yesterday by Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, president and publisher of The New York Times Company, and Gardner Cowles, chairman of the board of C.C.I.
The clerks of two Manhattan bookstores were found guilty yesterday of selling obscene material an issue of Zap comics. A third clerk was acquitted.

Metropolitan fanciers will have a chance to see dogsled racing. Starting on Jan. 3, six programs will be run on Sundays by the Garden State Siberian Husky Club over courses in Turkey Swamp Park, near Freehold, ...

Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that the state would give New York City $1-million for an emergency cleanup of its dirtiest areas. However, Henry L. Diamond, the state's Commissioner of Environmental Conservation, said the money would not be released until the city supplied a list of the blocks it intended to clean up.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) Congress's watchdog investigating agency contends that the builder of the Apollo Saturn 5 rocket booster increased potential earnings at least $695,000 by overstating costs by $2.7-million.

YONKERS, Oct. 28 Harry Minbar, a full brother to Meadow Elva, who at 4 was the world champion pacing mare, brought $40,000 today, a record price for a yearling at the Old Glory Sale at Yonkers Raceway.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 28 Two students who hijacked a small Soviet aircraft with four occupants yesterday and forced it to land in Turkey have requested political asylum and want to go to the United States, the Turkish state radio said today.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 28 (UPI) The co-pilot of a Caribbean Island Airways air taxi fell to his death today while apparently trying to close a door that had opened in flight, the Federal Aviation Administration reported.
The Communications Workers of America has urged the New York Telephone Company to establish day care centers at its locations.
PARIS, Oct. 28 A highranking delegation from East Germany appealed here today for the establishment of full diplomatic relations between its country and France.

Mayor Lindsay backed up his endorsement of Arthur J. Goldberg with shoe leather yesterday as he campaigned with the Democratic-Liberal candidate for Governor in the City Hall area and the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn.
Norman B. Uris has a rather simplistic way of dividing mankind into two great camps those who do and those who do not doodle.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 27-The new Lebanese Government has pressed Palestinian commandos not to fire rockets into Israel from Lebanese soil, highly placed Lebanese informants said today.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday (Reuters) South Vietnamese troops killed 44 guerrillas in a sharp clash near Seoul in Cambodia, a military spokesman said today.
LONDON, Oct. 28-The Government formally decided today to keep British forces in Southeast Asia-but at a level so low that it was promptly dismissed by critics as insignificant.

Despite reports of widespread rain in the central Midwest, soybean futures dropped sharply from seasonal highs under substantial profit taking yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. They rallied mildly near the end of trading and closed with prices irregular.

ROME, Oct 28-Giovacchino Forzano, a versatile man of letters who wrote librettos for Puccini operas and was co-author of plays with Benito Mussolini, died here today after a short illness. He was 86 years old.
MOSCOW, Oct. 28 Official propaganda floated like a bear and stung like a sledgehammer today as the Soviet public saw Muhammad Ali beat Jerry Quarry on a nationwide taped television broadcast.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 Representative Gerald R. Ford of Michigan, the House Republican leader, asked President Nixon today to order the Internal Revenue Service to resume granting tax-exempt status to organizations that file lawsuits against those who are allegedly damaging the environment.

DETROIT, Oct. 28 A deep concern over the economy appears to be replacing law and order as the chief issue with many workingmen in this year's elections. But labor leaders, while pleased with this trend, fear that it has come late and that widespread apathy among union members may sharply undercut the union vote.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28?A Federal judge issued a permanent injunction today barring official Government publication or distribution of a report by the House Internal Security Committee listing 65 persons as "radical" campus speakers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 The Treasury Department's Bureau of Customs will organize and train a permanent sky marshal force of at least 2,000 security officers to prevent hijacking of airliners, it was announced today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) The Federal Government incurred a $7.7-billion deficit for the first three months of the current fiscal year, the Treasury Department said today.

The 27th annual Greenwich Village Antiques Show Sale will be held from Nov. 12 to 15 at Greenwich House, a settlement at 27 Barrow Street. A preview cocktail party will open the show from 7 to 10 P.M. Nov. 11.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (UPI)-A move to admit women as members of the National Press Club failed today even though more than two-thirds of the members voting in a mail referendum favored it.
Theodore W. Kheel, the labor negotiator, has concluded as a result of recent talks with the various delegations in Paris that the Vietnam war will not be settled in Paris.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) Secretary of Transportation John A. Volpe granted New York and Connecticut an additional $11.6-million today to improve commuter operations of the Penn Central's New Haven Division.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Oct. 28 The engagement of Miss Jeanne Anne Doscher to Randy Brainerd Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Brainerd Fisk Smith of Deep River, Conn., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. John Henry Doscher.
LAWRENCE, Kan., Oct. 28 (UPI)-Elmer F. Beth, professor or journalism at the University of Kansas for 30 years, died today at the age of 67.
ATLANTA, Oct. 28 (UPI) The owners of a house used by a gang of thieves in the holdup of about 100 boxing fans Monday night denied today that they were involved in the robbery.
A brisk rally in the final minutes of trading yesterday led the popular averages out of minus territory into the land of small gains.

PALERMO, Sicily, Oct. 28 Four gunmen wearing white medical dress and gauze masks raided the city hospital here early this morning, ordered nurses to lie on the floor face down and killed a patient who was recovering from wounds suffered in a knifing last week.

You'll be there five hours or so after takeoff; with the time difference, two hours still lunchtime on the Coast, if it's a fairly early flight. Just 80 years ago this trip began in a handsome cab heading for a little two-story, red-brick Grand Central Station on 42d Street. An Englishman named W.G. Marshall made the trip, and left some notes.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 28 (AP) The pilot of a Trans World Airlines plane died in flight of an apparent heart attack today, but the Chicago-to-San Francisco flight landed safely in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, with 54 persons aboard, an airline spokesman here said.

PINEHURST, N.C., Oct. 28 (AP) Curtis Person of Memphis, Tenn., the defending champion, and David (Spec) Goldman of Dallas, medalist, were beaten today in the first round of match play in the North and South senior golf championship. Goldman lost to John Pottle of Linville, N.C., 2 and 1, while Person was ousted by Tom Draper of Troy, Mich., 3 and 2, at the Pinehurst Country Club. Other results:

CAIRO, Oct. 28 (AP)?Egyptian authorities eased their restrictions today on Dr. Timothy Leary, allowing him and his three traveling companions to visit Cairo briefly. But they said he would have to leave the county tomorrow.

The President's Commission on Financial Structure and Regulation held its third meeting here yesterday at the offices of the C.I.T. Financial Corporation and discussed the broad issue of the regulation of interest rates paid on deposits by banks and saving associations.

If enthusiasm were the prime factor in winning chess, Jude Acers of San Francisco, our faithful West Coast correspondent, would be champion of the world. Over-the-board, Acers is an adventurous tactician playing to win all the time. As an analyst, he is breezy, informative, objective and possessed of a pungent wit that he can turn on himself, and he is not afraid to comment on his losses as well as his victories.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 28 F. Clifton White, manager of the Senate campaign of James L. Buckley, refused to take comfort in any poll findings today, predicting election night would prove to be long but ultimately victorious.

Oleg G. Cherny, a financial consultant, who was recently appointed chief financial adviser to the New Communities Program of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, died Tuesday of a heart attack in his Washington apartment at the Broadmoor. He was 49 years old and also lived at 128 Corona Avenue, Pelham, N.Y.

The character of the newly created 21st Congressional District has attracted as much attention as the race for that seat. Both Herman Badillo, the Democratic-Liberal nominee, and George B. Smaragdas, the Conservative candidate, agree that no matter which of them wins, the job of representing this district will be difficult.

For the last six years Representative James H. Scheuer divided his time among his apartment in the Bronx, an office in Washington and his headquarters in the 21st Congressional District, in the westcentral section of the Bronx.

The president of the Uniformed Firefighters Association, Michael J. Maye, warned yesterday that the city's firemen might take strike action if they were unable to negotiate a satisfactory contract in current bargaining talks.
LONDON, Oct. 28 (UPI) Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko told British leaders today that "the time is not ripe" for an international peace conference on Vietnam, Government officials said.

BOSTON, Oct. 28 The New York Knicks put on their finest shooting and defensive effort of the season tonight in overwhelming the Boston Celtics, 126-89, for their third straight victory and second over the Celtics this season.
Emerson Boozer has joined Joe Namath and Matt Snell on the Jets' list of noncombatants for Sunday's game with the Giants at Shea Stadium.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 28 Two teen-age girls who wrote prize-winning essays about the United Nations met today with Secretary General Thant. A petition circulated by World Federalist Youth, signed by 30,000 young people in 36 countries, was presented to Mr. Thant at the meeting. The petition urged the United Nations to set up a permanent peacekeeping force.

A taxpayer's suit was begun in Brooklyn Supreme Court yesterday to prevent the busing of schoolchildren to a private hospital for routine medical examinations that will allegedly cost more than 10 times as much as examinations conducted in school.

New Hampshire's effort to introduce the coho salmon, a West Coast species, into its waters has been partially successful, but it is still too early to make a proper evaluation, according to Larry Stolte, the Fish and Game Department biologist in charge of the program.
The representative assembly of the Newspaper Guild of New York last night elected Thomas Lask, a book reviewer on the staff of The New York Times, as its president for 1970.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 28 (UPI) The undefeated Detroit Pistons streaked to their ninth victory tonight, putting down a Baltimore Bullet rally in the final two minutes and earning a 109-103 National Basketball Association triumph.

DETROIT, Oct. 28 (AP) A $45-million antitrust suit filed by the Checker Motors Corporation of Kalamazoo, Mich., against the Chrysler Corporation has been settled out of court, the two companies announced today.
Mrs. Elizabeth Dexter Simonds, wife of Herbert R. Simonds, a plastics engineer, died Sunday in Tucson, Ariz. She was 81 years old and formerly lived in Easton, Conn.

ATLANTA, Oct. 28 An Army Sergeant charged with murder at Mylai 4 has accused Gen. Creighton W. Abrams, the commander of United States Army troops in South Vietnam, of allowing prisoners to be beaten and tortured in his presence.

Carl Maria von Weber's "Euryanthe," one of the question-mark operas of the early romantic period, received one of its rare performances Tuesday night in Philharmonic Hall. Thomas Scherman was in charge of the concert version, with the Little Orchestra Society, a chorus and a cast consisting of Teresa Kubiak (Euryanthe), Frances Bible (Eglantine), William Lewis (Adolar), Mark Howard (Lysiart) and J.B. Davis (Louis VI).
LONDON, Oct. 28 (AP) Muhammad Ali was acclaimed in many parts of the world today for his victory over Jerry Quarry and many experts predicted he would regain the heavyweight championship.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 The Food and Drug Administration acted today to provide mothers with a better idea of what they are feeding their babies by ordering the makers of specialty baby foods to label the nutritional value of their products.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 28 Unemployment and underemployment affecting almost onethird of Chile's labor force will constitute one of the main problems facing Dr. Salvador Allende's leftist Government, according to a study made by Dr. Allende's economic planning team.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 28 Israel stressed before the United Nations today that Arab-Israeli peace talks could be resumed only if the conditions existing in the Suez Canal area at the start of the present 90-day cease-fire were restored.

POPULATION According to the 1960 census, there are 400,000 people in the district, Jews, Italians and Irish account for about half of the population, and blacks and Puerto Ricans make up the other half. The last two groups live in the southern end of the district in the Hunts Point section, one of the city's worst slums.

TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 29 Premier Eisaku Sato was reelected today to an unprecedented fourth term as president of the governing Liberal-Democratic party in a vote that assures his continuance as head of Japan's Government. If he serves out the two-year term, he will have been Premier for eight consecutive years, longer than any other occupant of the office.

PARIS, Oct. 28 The offshore mutual fund industry, managing $6-billion of other people's money, faces a major upheaval as national governments sharpen the knives of their regulatory authorities to prevent abusive practices.

PALISADES, N.Y. There is probably no section of the American population more dedicated to its native cookery than that of the Southwest. It is admirably varied, based largely on corn and beans and chilies that range from the mild to the piercingly hot, and it is derived rather loosely, Mexican purists say from the food of Mexico.
The Treasury Department is ready to apply on a nationwide basis special Customs cargo security measures that have been in effect at Kennedy International Airport since May.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 28 The Nassau County Drug Abuse and Addiction Commission announced today that it was applying for nearly $8-million in state funds to expand 53 community drug programs to reach every schoolchild in the county.
The Rangers continued to be faster, stronger and better than the opposition last night, and they wore down the Detroit Red Wings, 4-1, with three finalperiod goals.

The International Business Machines Corporation, the giant of the computer industry, made two nimble moves yesterday that it hopes will give it a dominant position in the lowpower, low-price spectrum of the data processing market.
FORT BRAGG, N.C., Oct. 28 (UPI) Capt. Jeffrey R. MacDonald was cleared today in the murders of his pregnant wife and two daughters.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 28 (AP) The National Collegiate governing council placed two universities on probation today, barring Kansas State and Tulsa from postseason football for three years. It also reprimanded Jacksonville.

HARRINGTON PARK, N.J., Oct. 28 Mr. and Mrs. Edward T. Baczewski have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Constance Marie Baczewski, to Alphonsus Gerard Collins, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Collins of the Bronx, New York.
George J. Hecht, the founder of Parents Magazine, will be honored by the Child Welfare League of America at a luncheon at noon tomorow at the Pierre Hotel, Fifth Avenue and 61st Street.
A 63-year-old widow who attends mass every morning was stabbed yesterday on a staircase in St. Jean Baptiste Church, Lexington Avenue at 76th Street.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 28 Lieut, William L. Calley Jr., accused of murdering at least 102 South Vietnamese civilians, conferred with Army officials here today amid the secrecy of a crucial military operation.

Although women students have had difficulty fitting into the general life at Princeton University, they have had a beneficial impact on the quality of education and on campus life, according to a report made public yesterday.

The president of the Investment Bankers Association of America urged last night that all segments of the securities industry unite to eliminate the growing fragmentation of the second market for securities, or the market that exists on regional stock exchanges.

Unishops, Inc., announced yesterday it had agreed in principle to acquire Goldfine's, Inc., operator of discount department stores in the Duluth, Minn,. area. The acquisition calls for Unishops to exchange its common stock in an initial amount to be determined by Goldfine's net worth on Dec. 31, 1970, and additional amounts of stock based on future earnings.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 28 After three chilly gray days, the Association of National Advertisers departed the gracious Homestead today leaving it in the hands of the American Urological Association.
"Kumt aroise un zugt sholom aleichem tzu eyer nexten Senator fun de stut fun New York," blared a loudspeaker atop a car in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn.

American railroads need $1.6-billion to $2-billion additional net income a year to bring them back to their 1950 financial condition, Paul W. Cherington, professor of transportation at Harvard University, said yesterday.
SANTA CRUZ, Calif., Oct. 28 (AP) John L. Frazier was indicted today for the murder of a wealthy eye surgeon, his wife, two sons and secretary.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Oct. 28 (AP) A 100-foot work boat sank in choppy seas 20 miles out in the Gulf of Mexico before dawn today, going down so quickly that the eight men on board were unable to scramble to the oil drilling platform where the boat was moored, the Coast Guard said.

LONGVIEW, Tex., Oct. 28 The Rev. Jess Moody was in fine oratorical fettle when he gave the invocation last night at the Nixon rally in West Palm Beach, Fla. What roiled the nation, he cried, was "not death throes but birth pangs and thank God our nation can still give birth. Help our President to be a good midwife!"
Bob Tucker, the Giants' rookie tight end, had a busy afternoon against the St. Louis Cardinals, but whether he'll be able to produce as well against the Jets on Sunday remains to be seen.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 Hartwig Steenken, a 29-year-old horse breeder, gave a sample of the style that has made him the riding champion of West Germany the last two years by taking first and second places in the jumping competition of the Washington International Horse Show tonight.
PARIS, Oct. 28 The French Government has decided to legislate age limits for business executives, a step unprecedented in a capitalist society.
The Lindsay administration announced yesterday that it was "closely examining" Controller Abraham D. Beame's role in the financial management of the city.

The final playoff match to determine the United States world championship representation in 1971 will be a New York vs. Los Angeles encounter. Five sessions of play begin here tomorrow afternoon at the New York Hilton.
MIAMI, Oct. 28 (UPI) The Miami Herald apologized today for a line from a movie review inadvertently added to the Tuesday television page listing of President Nixon's Miami Beach appearance.

The Surrogate's Court is a center of keen political interest because it dispenses most of the judicial patronage. The two Surrogates in Manhattan supervise the probate work in connection with nearly a billion dollars worth of estates each year. They appoint guardians and administrators who often reap lucrative fees.
Output per man-hour in the private economy increased substantially during the third quarter, President Nixon's chief economic adviser said here yesterday evening.
NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 28 Mr. and Mrs. George J. Dell have announced the engagement of Mr. Dell's daughter, Miss Elizabeth Mae Dell, to Arthur Rovins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Rovins of Westport.
NEWARK, Oct. 28 (UPI) The bars of New Jersey, open this Election Day for the first time in 51 years, will be on the ballot as much as any candidate, says the state's top liquor official.

Gerald Arpino's "Sea Shadow," one of those short, mysterious and often earnest ballets by Mr. Arpino that played around with fantasy and reality in the Joffrey Ballet's first few years, came back into the repertory last night at the City Center after a year's absence.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 28 Jack Nicklaus will be able to take the lead in tour earnings if he does as well as he usually does in the $100,000 Sahara invitation golf tournament, which begins tomorrow.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 28 Rose Bowl fever moved north this week to Stanford and Oregon as both Southern California and the University of California, Los Angeles, for the first time in a decade, have been virtually eliminated from the Pacific Eight Conference football title race.

TRENTON, Thursday, Oct. 29-Sporadic rock-throwing and window-breaking erupted in the predominantly black western area of this city last night on the third day of busing of 60 black and Puerto Rican students to largely white schools.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 28 Senator Harold E. Hughes flew to the California southland today on one of the lowest-key campaigns of the 1970 election for his dark-horse candidacy for President in 1972.
Two subway mishaps, one in the Bronx and the other in Manhattan, disrupted service just after the rush hour yesterday morning.

A group of principals and other educators in the city school system, among them Walter J. Degnan, the head of the Council of Supervisory Associations, has called for the re-election of Governor Rockefeller and the election of James L. Buckley, the Conservative candidate for the Senate.

An official United States Ski Team sweater, specially designed for members of the United States squad, will be presented to Mayor Lindsay at the fourth annual ski ball in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf Astoria Hotel tonight.
Anticipated buying support failed to develop on the London Stock Exchange yesterday following the British Government's announcement Tuesday that taxes, subsidies and public spending would be cut.

Most of the women who walk, timidly but hopefully, into the center's office on 57th Street are in the 50to-60 age bracket. They've been housewives for most of their lives. They're worried about money, they're bewildered, and they feel terribly lonely.

LONGVIEW, Tex., Oct. 28 President Nixon spent yet another long day's journey today in search of the two or three extra Senate seats that he believes are necessary to give him working control of Congress.

To the best of my knowledge, "Score" is the first nude sex play whose action takes place in Queens. I am not sure what to make of that fact, except perhaps the playwright-director, Jerry Douglas, hesitated to face a Manhattan audience with a Manhattan setting. He might be accused of lack of sophistication.
The jury hearing the trial of 13 Black Panthers here spent nearly an hour yesterday studying a little red-covered book containing the sayings of Mao Tse-tung.
MOSCOW, Oct. 28 Soviet and American officials agreed today to continue efforts leading to the development of a docking system that would enable their spacecraft to link up in space.

HOUSTON, Oct. 28 A medical evaluation program for automobile driver license applicants, combined with a more vigorous campaign to detect and penalize drunken drivers has reversed the steady rise of highway deaths in North Carolina, an epidemiologist in that state's health department reported here today.

Some musicians seem to thrive when the thickets of notes they have to negotiate become densest, and Blanca Uribe, the Colombian-born pianist, is apparently one of those. At the end of the recital she gave at Hunter College Playhouse on Tuesday night, the opening event in a Latin American Series being presented there this season, Miss Uribe plunged through VillaLobos's "Rudepoema" with a heartiness that was truly impressive.
CAIRO, Oct. 28 The new Government of President Anwar el-Sadat is giving urgent attention to a number of annoying problems on the home front.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 28 Vice President Agnew, discounting speculation that he would be dumped from the Republican ticket in 1972, gave his second demonstration in three days of his political value to the Nixon Administration in the South.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 28 The closing days of this election campaign in California are dominated by the maneuvering in the tight race between Senator George Murphy, Republican, and his Democratic challenger, Representative John V. Tunney of Riverside.
Governor Rockefeller has turned down urgent requests from his Republican running mate, Senator Charles E. Goodell, for last-minute campaign aid.

Sir Maurice Parsons, chairman of the Bank of London and South America, said yesterday that he saw new signs of hopefulness for private investment, particularly international banking, in Chile and Peru. The bank is a major trading bank in Latin America.
Emil Talamini, of 70 East 10th Street, a real estate broker and investor long active in the Greenwich Village area, died yesterday in Memorial Hospital after a long illness. He was 64 years old.

FORT HOOD, Tex., Oct. 28 A military spokesman said today that the court-martial of Staff Sgt. David Mitchell on a charge arising from the alleged massacre at Mylai 4 would probably not resume for another two weeks.

The latest statistics about the economy are scarcely reassuring. Los Angeles and four other major industrial centers have just been added to the list of labor markets with "substantial" unemployment. The Government's official list now puts just under one-quarter of all the country's principal labor markets in this category 38 out of a total of 150. Two years ago only six areas were in that plight.
WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 28 (AP) Quadruplet girls born eight weeks premature were reported in critical condition today at Memorial Hospital here.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 28 (UPI) A. Aubrey Bodine, photo director of The Baltimore Sunday Sun magazine, died at Johns Hopkins Hospital today at the age of 64.

MOSCOW, Oct. 28-The Soviet Government has turned down as unnecessary a United States request for a prompt second visit to one Turkish and three American. officers detained in Armenia since their United States Army plane violated Soviet airspace seven days ago.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 Economic indicators for September and October continued the recent string of relatively unfavorable news, Government reports showed today.

CAMBRIDGE, England, Oct. 27 The day appears to be rapidly approaching when it will be possible to remove egg cells from women unable to bear children, fertilize them in a laboratory with sperm from their husbands, culture them into many-celled embryos and reintroduce them into the womb. In recent weeks this process has been carried through here almost to the stage at which the embryo could be reimplanted in a prospective mother.
LONDON, Oct. 28 (AP) Thanks largely to Vice President Agnew, Europeans are gradually becoming aware that the United States is to hold midterm elections Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 The Vice President, of course, was only having more sport with the news industry when he proposed that panels of politicians examine news commentators on television so that the public might discover the philosophical convictions of those wordy wretches.

The City Council ended its public hearings on consultants' contracts yesterday with a demand for "major revisions" in the way the contracts with the city are awarded and supervised. "It is obvious to me that the present system cannot be permitted to continue," said Edward L. Sadowsky, Queens Democrat who is chairman of the Council's Committee on Charter and Governmental Operations.
A circle of leading Christian and Jewish scholars met at Seton Hall University this week in an attempt to pick up the interfaith dialogue debilitated by three years of crisis in the Middle East.
LONDON, Oct. 28 One of President Nixon's economic advisers indicated today that the Administration would adopt more expansionist policies soon if needed to move toward full employment by mid-1972.

Robert Short, the owner of the Washington Senators, said yesterday that Curt Flood "will be playing for us" in 1971. But he denied reports that he already had signed the controversial 32-year-old outfielder, who sued baseball this year for $1-million.
HILLSBOROUGH, Calif., Oct. 28 Miss Elizabeth Moore and George Ellis Summers of Locust Valley, L.I., plan to be married next spring.

THERAN, Iran, Oct. 28 (Reuters) The Shah of Iran and President Nikolai V. Podgorny of the Soviet Union today opened a 630-mile pipeline that will carry natural gas from the Iranian fields at Qum to the Soviet Union.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 28 Albatross, harness racing's best bargain-buy in recent years, is not expected to encounter difficulty in Saturday night's 11th annual Roosevelt Futurity for 2-year-old pacers at Roosevelt Raceway.
The American Stock Exchange continued to decline yesterday although a sharp rally in the last half-hour of trading erased some of the earlier losses.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28(AP) Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson recalled today her husband's prediction in the fall of 1968 that there might be "a great swing back toward authoritarianism and conservatism" in America in response to "the permissiveness, the lawlessness of the day." But, she said, he believed such a reaction would "set us back many decades," in the fight against ignorance, poverty and disease.
Bond prices rose fairly sharply yesterday and new corporate and tax-exempt issues carrying this week's higher yields attracted investors.

Morris High School in the Bronx was closed early after students ran through the corridors and cafeteria overturning chairs and tables yesterday. Later, after classes, they clashed with the police outside the building.

Leland Hayward, whose Broadway projects have collected two Pulitzer Prizes ("State of the Union" and "South Pacific"), one Drama Critics award ("South Pacific") and three Tonys ("Sound of Music," "South Pacific" and "Mister Roberts"), is planning his first Off Broadway venture.

VIENNA, W.Va., Oct. 28 (AP) Charges of "foot-dragging, pussy-footing and artful dodging" were lodged today against the Union Carbide Corporation by Representative Ken Hechler, Democrat of West Virgina.

A celebrity mother-anddaughter combination, which had an "unpleasant, sturm und drang" relationship when the daughter was a teen-ager, have teamed up to write a book designed to take the worries out of being a housewife.
Arthur J. Goldberg attacked Governor Rockefeller on a wide range of issues last night in their second confrontation of the gubernatorial campaign and their first televised debate.
Federal and local authorities yesterday began rounding up eight men who allegedly engineered a stock swindle that victimized brokerage houses and individuals across the country.
